♠ Dogs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Some of the sources mentioned horses, but not any other animals used in warfare
♠ Donkeys ♣ inferred absent ♥ Some of the sources mentioned horses, but not any other animals used in warfare
♠ Horses ♣ present ♥ "Yakut warriors ( säpi, säpi kisita ) were usually mounted horsemen ( minjär ), but there were also foot soldiers ( sat[unknown]ykisita ). Their weapons ( säp ) consisted of a light bent bow ( s[unknown]a ), a quiver ( käsäx, s[unknown]adax ), and arrows ( aya ) ."[253]
♠ Camels ♣ absent ♥ Some of the sources mentioned horses, but not any other animals used in warfare. Camels are extremely unlikely to have been in use
♠ Elephants ♣ absent ♥ Some of the sources mentioned horses, but not any other animals used in warfare. Elephants are extremely unlikely to have been in use
♠ Other ♣ ♥

Armor[edit]

♠ Wood, bark, etc ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with weapons and armor
♠ Leather, cloth ♣ present ♥ "Young people up to a certain age looked after the herds, drove them from one place to another, caught, saddled, and loaded horses. They were called uollar, which means fellows. Among them the older and more skillful ones were called batyr -- knight, khosun -- warrior, and bargan (byargyan') -- good shot, and roamed through the taiga not far from the settlements, hunting and fishing. Many of them had coats of mail (kuyakh) made from plates of iron and bone sewn over a leather caftan." [254]
♠ Shields ♣ present ♥ "Among them the older and more skillful ones were called batyr -- knight, khosun -- warrior, and bargan (byargyan') -- good shot, and roamed through the taiga not far from the settlements, hunting and fishing. Many of them had coats of mail (kuyakh) made from plates of iron and bone sewn over a leather caftan. In most cases these wanderers were mounted, but there were some who went on foot. Their weapons consisted of a light, bent, birch bow (okh), 5. a quiver (kikhek) filled with arrows (aya), a knife, and a war spear (batyya). Near the home they often used a light hunger's spear (batas), while many also used short swords (bolat) and small bone shields in the shape of a shovel, used for warding off arrows."[255]
♠ Helmets ♣ present ♥ "In the report of the soldier Semen Epishev (1652) to the Yakutsk voivode Dmitrii Frantsebekov it says, incidentally: we came by seam to the mouth of the Okhta River and at that time at the mouth there were many clans of foreigner Tungus, a thousand and more, and they shot at us; they had harnesses and weapons, and shot at us with arrows and cast spears, wearing caps and helmets of iron and of bone, and did not want to let us to the Okhta--they wanted to kill us." [256]
♠ Breastplates ♣ present ♥ "Young people up to a certain age looked after the herds, drove them from one place to another, caught, saddled, and loaded horses. They were called uollar, which means fellows. Among them the older and more skillful ones were called batyr -- knight, khosun -- warrior, and bargan (byargyan') -- good shot, and roamed through the taiga not far from the settlements, hunting and fishing. Many of them had coats of mail (kuyakh) made from plates of iron and bone sewn over a leather caftan." [257]
♠ Limb protection ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with weapons and armor
♠ Chainmail ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with weapons and armor
♠ Scaled armor ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with weapons and armor
♠ Laminar armor ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with weapons and armor
♠ Plate armor ♣ present ♥ This seems to fit the evidence most closely: "Young people up to a certain age looked after the herds, drove them from one place to another, caught, saddled, and loaded horses. They were called uollar, which means fellows. Among them the older and more skillful ones were called batyr -- knight, khosun -- warrior, and bargan (byargyan') -- good shot, and roamed through the taiga not far from the settlements, hunting and fishing. Many of them had coats of mail (kuyakh) made from plates of iron and bone sewn over a leather caftan." [258] "Warriors used armor which consisted of small iron plates fastened to a leather coat and was called kuyax . The Chukchee and Koryak iron armor described by Bogoras and myself was undoubtedly adopted from Yakut sources, perhaps through Tungus intermediaries." [259]

Naval technology[edit]

♠ Small vessels (canoes, etc) ♣ absent ♥ Given the importance of nomadism, it seems unlikely that naval technology was used in warfare.
♠ Merchant ships pressed into service ♣ absent ♥ Given the importance of nomadism, it seems unlikely that naval technology was used in warfare.
♠ Specialized military vessels ♣ absent ♥ Given the importance of nomadism, it seems unlikely that naval technology was used in warfare.

Fortifications[edit]

♠ Settlements in a defensive position ♣ absent ♥ Note: The sources suggest that many of these defensive structures may have ceased to be built after subjugation by the Russians in 1642. They were initially coded as inferred present. The data sheets for the Lena River valley were re-periodized after the initial coding of this section. The codes were changed accordingly, but remain in need of review, as indicated above.
♠ Wooden palisades ♣ absent ♥ Walls are mentioned (only) in the following source, but the building material used is not: "When speaking of structures, we should also mention the fact that in the old days the Yakuts knew how to make fortifications or ostrozhki, as they were called in the Russian texts of the 17th century. For example, in 1636-1637, during the campaign against the Kangalastsy, the Russian Cossacks found that “they had built strong forts with two walls covered with gravel, and surrounded by snow and water;” it was only after a two-day assault that the Cossacks managed to take one of these forts. In 1642 the Russians also took a Yakut fortress after great difficulty: “. . . the fort was made with two walls, the space between the walls was filled with earth, and there were log towers.” At a later stage these fortifications disappeared, and no one has described them since in detail. But even in the 19th century it was possible to find special tower-like barns here and there, which belonged to the Toyons." [260] We have assumed earth ramparts rather than wooden palisades in congruence with the evidence presented below.
♠ Earth ramparts ♣ present: 1632-1642 CE; absent: 1643-1900 CE ♥ "When speaking of structures, we should also mention the fact that in the old days the Yakuts knew how to make fortifications or ostrozhki, as they were called in the Russian texts of the 17th century. For example, in 1636-1637, during the campaign against the Kangalastsy, the Russian Cossacks found that “they had built strong forts with two walls covered with gravel, and surrounded by snow and water;” it was only after a two-day assault that the Cossacks managed to take one of these forts. In 1642 the Russians also took a Yakut fortress after great difficulty: “. . . the fort was made with two walls, the space between the walls was filled with earth, and there were log towers.” At a later stage these fortifications disappeared, and no one has described them since in detail. But even in the 19th century it was possible to find special tower-like barns here and there, which belonged to the Toyons." [261]
♠ Ditch ♣ absent ♥ Tokarev and Gurvich mention fortifications surrounded by water and snow, but no additional ditches dug out around the forts: "When speaking of structures, we should also mention the fact that in the old days the Yakuts knew how to make fortifications or ostrozhki, as they were called in the Russian texts of the 17th century. For example, in 1636-1637, during the campaign against the Kangalastsy, the Russian Cossacks found that “they had built strong forts with two walls covered with gravel, and surrounded by snow and water;” it was only after a two-day assault that the Cossacks managed to take one of these forts. In 1642 the Russians also took a Yakut fortress after great difficulty: “. . . the fort was made with two walls, the space between the walls was filled with earth, and there were log towers.” At a later stage these fortifications disappeared, and no one has described them since in detail. But even in the 19th century it was possible to find special tower-like barns here and there, which belonged to the Toyons." [262]
♠ Moat ♣ present: 1632-1642 CE; absent: 1643-1900 CE ♥ Tokarev and Gurvich mention fortifications surrounded by water and snow: "When speaking of structures, we should also mention the fact that in the old days the Yakuts knew how to make fortifications or ostrozhki, as they were called in the Russian texts of the 17th century. For example, in 1636-1637, during the campaign against the Kangalastsy, the Russian Cossacks found that “they had built strong forts with two walls covered with gravel, and surrounded by snow and water;” it was only after a two-day assault that the Cossacks managed to take one of these forts. In 1642 the Russians also took a Yakut fortress after great difficulty: “. . . the fort was made with two walls, the space between the walls was filled with earth, and there were log towers.” At a later stage these fortifications disappeared, and no one has described them since in detail. But even in the 19th century it was possible to find special tower-like barns here and there, which belonged to the Toyons." [263]
♠ Stone walls (non-mortared) ♣ present: 1632-1642 CE; absent: 1643-1900 CE ♥ Only gravel is mentioned: "When speaking of structures, we should also mention the fact that in the old days the Yakuts knew how to make fortifications or ostrozhki, as they were called in the Russian texts of the 17th century. For example, in 1636-1637, during the campaign against the Kangalastsy, the Russian Cossacks found that “they had built strong forts with two walls covered with gravel, and surrounded by snow and water;” it was only after a two-day assault that the Cossacks managed to take one of these forts. In 1642 the Russians also took a Yakut fortress after great difficulty: “. . . the fort was made with two walls, the space between the walls was filled with earth, and there were log towers.” At a later stage these fortifications disappeared, and no one has described them since in detail. But even in the 19th century it was possible to find special tower-like barns here and there, which belonged to the Toyons." [264] We have assumed that these gravel coverings can be considered non-mortared stone walls. This remains in need of confirmation.
♠ Stone walls (mortared) ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with warfare
♠ Fortified camps ♣ absent ♥ The description seems to suggest that Sakha fortification were permanent structures rather than being constructed on the move: "When speaking of structures, we should also mention the fact that in the old days the Yakuts knew how to make fortifications or ostrozhki, as they were called in the Russian texts of the 17th century. For example, in 1636-1637, during the campaign against the Kangalastsy, the Russian Cossacks found that “they had built strong forts with two walls covered with gravel, and surrounded by snow and water;” it was only after a two-day assault that the Cossacks managed to take one of these forts. In 1642 the Russians also took a Yakut fortress after great difficulty: “. . . the fort was made with two walls, the space between the walls was filled with earth, and there were log towers.” At a later stage these fortifications disappeared, and no one has described them since in detail. But even in the 19th century it was possible to find special tower-like barns here and there, which belonged to the Toyons." [265]
♠ Complex fortifications ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with warfare
♠ Long walls ♣ 0 ♥ km.
♠ Modern fortifications ♣ absent ♥ not mentioned in any of the sources that deal with warfare


Other technologies[edit]

Military Organization[edit]

♠ Standing armies ♣ absent ♥ Sakha warriors and spies fought for their clans and tribes, and were not professionals in the conventional sense of the term: 'Yakut warriors ( säpi, säpi kisita ) were usually mounted horsemen ( minjär ), but there were also foot soldiers ( sat[unknown]ykisita ). Their weapons ( säp ) consisted of a light bent bow ( s[unknown]a ), a quiver ( käsäx, s[unknown]adax ), and arrows ( aya ) .' [266] 'These warriors formed a chain of movable, vigilant pickets around the settlements. In case of war they formed the kernel of the fighting detachment -- sari Some of the bolder ones went to find their fortune, dzhol. They would go far into unknown territory, among foreigners, either by themselves or with companions. Such detachments would not take their cattle with them and often traveled on foot. They made their living exclusively by hunting, fishing, and looting. The Yakut kept these habits for a long time, until very recently. Khudiakov has a legend about Khaptagay-batyr and his son Khokhoe-batyr, and their three khosun: Sappy, Yngkabyl, and Batagyyan, who roamed about in the seventeen forties, during the time of Pavlutskii, in the north of the Yakutsk Oblast. In the Kolymsk Okrug (1882), I wrote down a legend about the two Yakut brothers who were the first to make their way into the kolymsk Krai. Their names have been forgotten. In the Namsk Ulus I was told a legend about the Vilyuysk Yakut Tangas-Boltongo who also wandered by himself somewhere in the little-known, remote regions of the Vilyuysk Okrug. He was called a bagatyr, just as the old epic heroes. Apparently he lived in the beginning of the present century; this is indicated by the name of a Yakut hunter of the Namsk Ulus, Betyunsk Nasleg, Chaky clan, whom he encountered: his name was Soldat. Soldiers appeared in the Yakutsk Oblast only in the last century, at the time of the Kamchatka campaigns of Pavlutskii. Then Middendorf mentions solitary Yakut hunters whom he encountered far from their native tribes in the mountains of the Amur Basin. Such bold fellows served their clans as a sort of voluntary spies, searching out new pastures suitable for settlement in case some sort of unpleasantness or inconvenience should arise in the homeland. They brought back word of new lands, of the peoples they had encountered, the details of the route, and the obstacles involved. Sometimes the clan would choose such people out of their own number and deliberately send them out on a searching party. The tales The Golden Eagle and the Teal, and The Flying Winged Creatures hint at this. These were chosen people and were also called bagatyr, baatyr, batyr, or batur; strictly speaking in the Yakut language this word means valorous, exceptionally manly, bold, strong, and clever. But these people did not have any special rights in the clan besides the usual rights gained through personal superiority.' [267] Military operations were lead by war-leaders, who formed a military aristocracy based on heredity and personal military success: 'Just as now, common matters were managed by the clan assembly. Matters of war and minor legal cases, which demanded quick settlement without any delays, were managed by a war leader -- toen -- acknowledged by the rest of the people. According to the Yakut this service was hereditary, on the strength of their belief that an eaglet is always an eagle; a young crow is always a crow. But this hereditary right was not strictly followed. Thus, the heir of the Borogon toen, Legey, was not his son, but a foreign adopted son who had been bought for money. Another saga relates, with full consciousness of the legality of such a matter, that the Tungus chose as their toen a Yakut, Khaptagay-batyr, because of his valor. The sago says: No Lamut (Tungus), no matter who, will kill you. Now you be our lord (toen). If a Lamut will not obey your word, let there be a sin upon him. The toen always had in addition the title of bagatyr (valorous) and in the popular conception his traits of character had to correspond with those demanded of a hero. But he would not wander by himself, nor look for adventures, but would always live where the clan was and only leave in time of war, at the head of the mounted and armed detachment.' [268] 'We can judge how large these unions sometimes were by the fact that in 1634 600 Yakut warriors under the leadership of prince Mymak took part in a battle on the right bank of the Lena, in which the army of ataman Galkin was crushed and all his horses were lost.' [269] 'At this period, however, the clan-tribal structure was already in a state of decomposition. The tribes and clans were headed by the military aristocracy-the toyons. These possessed large herds of cattle and employed the labor of slaves and dependent fellow clansmen on their farms; they were also the military leaders. Heading detachments of armed servants and junior fellow clansmen, the toyons raided each other’s territory, and frequently looted the farms of the free members of the community, seizing their cattle and destroying their economic independence. These toyon wars and raids were one of the factors which speeded up the decomposition of the clan commune. The ruined members of the commune were reduced to the status of “balyksyts” (poor people without cattle, or fishermen), or else became the indentured slaves of the toyons. Most of the slaves (kuluts or bokans) originated in this way.' [270] It is unclear from the sources reviewed so far whether Sakha warriors were also recruited by Cossack invaders.

♠ Uniformity of equipment ♣ absent ♥ See above.

♠ Total army ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Professional army ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Largest fielded army ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Maximum logistical lag ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Sources of recruits ♣ mass mobilization ♥ See above.

♠ Procurement of equipment and animals ♣ by soldiers ♥ See above.

General Characteristics of Warfare[edit]

Types of Warfare[edit]

♠ Inter-polity wars ♣ present: 1632-1642 CE; absent: 1643-1900 CE ♥ The stereotypes and legends described here seem to hint at a history of violent inter-tribal conflict: "The Yakut treat the Tungus haughtily, but give their warlike abilities their due: cunning like a Tungus, they say. A Tungus is quick; even in his sleep he can sense that an arrow is directed toward him, and slip away. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1882). We conquered the Tungus thanks to their stupidity.... We'd build wooden houses with apertures, and from there we'd smack them down (Kolymsk Ulus, 1882)." [271] "In another legend dating from about the same period they describe how a Yakut batyr killed Tungus khosun at a wedding and ran away. A Tungus warrior comes to his house to gain revenge, but he too is killed by the Yakut. Then, becoming frightened at the consequences, the murderer gathers his clan and persuades them to fall upon the tungus first, in order to protect themselves. The clan agrees and arms itself for the campaign, but to everyone's satisfaction the matter is settled peacefully, the feuding parties separate, and exchange presents. On the way back the Yakut meet some Russians and, bribed by them, jointly attack the Tungus again. (Namsk Ulus, 1891)." [272] The historical facts bear this out: ""By the fourteenth century, Yakut ancestors migrated north, perhaps in small refugee groups, with herds of horses and cattle. After arrival in the Lena valley, they fought and intermarried with the native Evenk and Yukagir nomads. Thus, both peaceful and belligerent relations with northern Siberians, Chinese, Mongols, and Turkic peoples preceded Russian hegemony." [273] But feuding and inter-tribal violence decreased after Russian occupation: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [274] The Sakha initially resisted Russian troops: "As we have seen, the Sakha people-called Yakuts by outsiders-dominated the crucial country of the middle Lena Valley, dotted with islands of fertile grassland, until the 1630s. Russian empire builders, spearheaded by Cossack bands, then pushed down the Lena and built three forts in the Yakut heartland, one of which would become the city of Yakutsk. As was true in the rest of Siberia, the Russians demanded yasak, or tribute in the form of fur, from the indigenes. The Yakut resisted, but they were divided into feuding clans and hampered by outmoded military technology. Resistance also provoked devastating Cossack raids on the scattered hamlets and homesteads of the vulnerably semi-sedentary Sakha. Although the Yakut were able to seriously besiege the Russian fort at Yakutsk on several occasions, they lost the war and subsequently submitted to Russian rule." [275] On the other hand, Sieroszewski reports looting even in the 18th century: "These warriors formed a chain of movable, vigilant pickets around the settlements. In case of war they formed the kernel of the fighting detachment -- sari Some of the bolder ones went to find their fortune, dzhol. They would go far into unknown territory, among foreigners, either by themselves or with companions. Such detachments would not take their cattle with them and often traveled on foot. They made their living exclusively by hunting, fishing, and looting. The Yakut kept these habits for a long time, until very recently. Khudiakov has a legend about Khaptagay-batyr and his son Khokhoe-batyr, and their three khosun: Sappy, Yngkabyl, and Batagyyan, who roamed about in the seventeen forties, during the time of Pavlutskii, in the north of the Yakutsk Oblast..." [276]

♠ Internal wars ♣ present ♥ These comments seem to suggest persistent feuding among the Sakha themselves: "As we have seen, the Sakha people-called Yakuts by outsiders-dominated the crucial country of the middle Lena Valley, dotted with islands of fertile grassland, until the 1630s. Russian empire builders, spearheaded by Cossack bands, then pushed down the Lena and built three forts in the Yakut heartland, one of which would become the city of Yakutsk. As was true in the rest of Siberia, the Russians demanded yasak, or tribute in the form of fur, from the indigenes. The Yakut resisted, but they were divided into feuding clans and hampered by outmoded military technology. Resistance also provoked devastating Cossack raids on the scattered hamlets and homesteads of the vulnerably semi-sedentary Sakha. Although the Yakut were able to seriously besiege the Russian fort at Yakutsk on several occasions, they lost the war and subsequently submitted to Russian rule." [277] "The Yakut were warlike and blood vengeance between clans occurred very often, but reconciliation was often sought through payment of a ransom or by giving a girl in marriage, the best way to end hostilities." [278] But feuding decreased after the Russian occupation. But there were several uprisings in the Russian colonial period: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [279] "Crushed by the omnipotence of the toyons, the masses of poor people in the ulus hardly dared to protest or fight for their rights. It was only now and then that the toyon oppression gave rise to outbursts of protest, but these were sporadic and promptly suppressed. This was the fate of the revolt of Vasiliy Manchara (1830-1850), hero of the Yakut legends." [280] "The Yakut masses led a hard life. They paid tribute in sable and fox furs, had to perform a number of other compulsory services and were exploited by the tsarist soldiery, Russian merchants and their own toyons. After several unsuccesful uprisings (1634, 1636-1637, 1639-1640, and 1642), and after the toyons had gone over to the side of the voyevods, the Yakut masses could only retaliate against the oppression by sporadic attempts at resistance and flight from their native ulusy to outlying parts." [281]

♠ Intra-elite conflicts ♣ present: 1632-1642 CE; absent: 1643-1900 CE ♥ Tokarev's and Gurvich's comments seem to suggest that the toyons figured prominently in inter-tribal feuding: "It is an extremely important fact that the establishment of Russian authority in Yakutiya put a stop to the intertribal warring and looting by the toyons, which up to that time had been a great hardship for the Yakut population." [282] But feuding decreased after the Russian occupation. "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [283] We have therefore assumed no violent conflict among the toyons after Russian occupation. We have adopted 1642 as a potential date of transition. This may have to be moved and is open to review.

♠ Popular uprisings ♣ present ♥ There were several uprisings in the Russian colonial period: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [284] "Crushed by the omnipotence of the toyons, the masses of poor people in the ulus hardly dared to protest or fight for their rights. It was only now and then that the toyon oppression gave rise to outbursts of protest, but these were sporadic and promptly suppressed. This was the fate of the revolt of Vasiliy Manchara (1830-1850), hero of the Yakut legends." [285] "The Yakut masses led a hard life. They paid tribute in sable and fox furs, had to perform a number of other compulsory services and were exploited by the tsarist soldiery, Russian merchants and their own toyons. After several unsuccesful uprisings (1634, 1636-1637, 1639-1640, and 1642), and after the toyons had gone over to the side of the voyevods, the Yakut masses could only retaliate against the oppression by sporadic attempts at resistance and flight from their native ulusy to outlying parts." [286]

♠ Military revolts ♣ absent ♥ No military revolts because there was no standing army

♠ Separatist rebellions ♣ absent ♥ No separatist rebellions either because there was no state to rebel against or secede from

Cultural distance[edit]

♠ Wars within same ethnic group ♣ present ♥ It is an extremely important fact that the establishment of Russian authority in Yakutiya put a stop to the intertribal warring and looting by the toyons, which up to that time had been a great hardship for the Yakut population [287]. There were several uprisings in the Russian colonial period: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [288] Some authors claim that some Yakut resistance was also directed against the toyons: "Crushed by the omnipotence of the toyons, the masses of poor people in the ulus hardly dared to protest or fight for their rights. It was only now and then that the toyon oppression gave rise to outbursts of protest, but these were sporadic and promptly suppressed. This was the fate of the revolt of Vasiliy Manchara (1830-1850), hero of the Yakut legends." [289] "The Yakut masses led a hard life. They paid tribute in sable and fox furs, had to perform a number of other compulsory services and were exploited by the tsarist soldiery, Russian merchants and their own toyons. After several unsuccesful uprisings (1634, 1636-1637, 1639-1640, and 1642), and after the toyons had gone over to the side of the voyevods, the Yakut masses could only retaliate against the oppression by sporadic attempts at resistance and flight from their native ulusy to outlying parts." [290] We have assumed this to be true of later uprisings as well. This remains in need of confirmation, as the evidence found so far is patchy.

♠ Wars involving groups with different dialects ♣ inferred present: 1632-1642 CE; absent: 1643-1900 CE ♥ As the Sakha initially fought both amongst themselves and with other tribes, it is likely that some fighting would have been against groups with different dialects, although there is no direct discussion of this in the sources. We have assumed that this, too, would have declined after the Russian occupation (see below). On the other hand, Sieroszewski reports looting even in the 18th century: "These warriors formed a chain of movable, vigilant pickets around the settlements. In case of war they formed the kernel of the fighting detachment -- sari Some of the bolder ones went to find their fortune, dzhol. They would go far into unknown territory, among foreigners, either by themselves or with companions. Such detachments would not take their cattle with them and often traveled on foot. They made their living exclusively by hunting, fishing, and looting. The Yakut kept these habits for a long time, until very recently. Khudiakov has a legend about Khaptagay-batyr and his son Khokhoe-batyr, and their three khosun: Sappy, Yngkabyl, and Batagyyan, who roamed about in the seventeen forties, during the time of Pavlutskii, in the north of the Yakutsk Oblast..." [291]

♠ Wars involving groups with different languages ♣ present: 1632-1642 CE; absent: 1643-1900 CE ♥ The stereotypes and legends described here seem to hint at a history of violent inter-tribal conflict: "The Yakut treat the Tungus haughtily, but give their warlike abilities their due: cunning like a Tungus, they say. A Tungus is quick; even in his sleep he can sense that an arrow is directed toward him, and slip away. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1882). We conquered the Tungus thanks to their stupidity.... We'd build wooden houses with apertures, and from there we'd smack them down (Kolymsk Ulus, 1882)." [292] "In another legend dating from about the same period they describe how a Yakut batyr killed Tungus khosun at a wedding and ran away. A Tungus warrior comes to his house to gain revenge, but he too is killed by the Yakut. Then, becoming frightened at the consequences, the murderer gathers his clan and persuades them to fall upon the tungus first, in order to protect themselves. The clan agrees and arms itself for the campaign, but to everyone's satisfaction the matter is settled peacefully, the feuding parties separate, and exchange presents. On the way back the Yakut meet some Russians and, bribed by them, jointly attack the Tungus again. (Namsk Ulus, 1891)." [293] The historical facts bear this out: ""By the fourteenth century, Yakut ancestors migrated north, perhaps in small refugee groups, with herds of horses and cattle. After arrival in the Lena valley, they fought and intermarried with the native Evenk and Yukagir nomads. Thus, both peaceful and belligerent relations with northern Siberians, Chinese, Mongols, and Turkic peoples preceded Russian hegemony." [294] But feuding and inter-tribal violence decreased after Russian occupation: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [295] We have assumed 1642 as a date of transition; this is open to review.

♠ Wars involving groups with different language families ♣ present ♥ There were several uprisings in the Russian colonial period: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [296] "Crushed by the omnipotence of the toyons, the masses of poor people in the ulus hardly dared to protest or fight for their rights. It was only now and then that the toyon oppression gave rise to outbursts of protest, but these were sporadic and promptly suppressed. This was the fate of the revolt of Vasiliy Manchara (1830-1850), hero of the Yakut legends." [297] "The Yakut masses led a hard life. They paid tribute in sable and fox furs, had to perform a number of other compulsory services and were exploited by the tsarist soldiery, Russian merchants and their own toyons. After several unsuccesful uprisings (1634, 1636-1637, 1639-1640, and 1642), and after the toyons had gone over to the side of the voyevods, the Yakut masses could only retaliate against the oppression by sporadic attempts at resistance and flight from their native ulusy to outlying parts." [298] Also, Sieroszewski reports looting even in the 18th century: "These warriors formed a chain of movable, vigilant pickets around the settlements. In case of war they formed the kernel of the fighting detachment -- sari Some of the bolder ones went to find their fortune, dzhol. They would go far into unknown territory, among foreigners, either by themselves or with companions. Such detachments would not take their cattle with them and often traveled on foot. They made their living exclusively by hunting, fishing, and looting. The Yakut kept these habits for a long time, until very recently. Khudiakov has a legend about Khaptagay-batyr and his son Khokhoe-batyr, and their three khosun: Sappy, Yngkabyl, and Batagyyan, who roamed about in the seventeen forties, during the time of Pavlutskii, in the north of the Yakutsk Oblast..." [299]

♠ Wars between groups from different archaeological cultures ♣ present ♥ conflict between imperial Russia and Siberians, who were clearly culturally distinct

♠ Wars between different religious sects ♣ absent ♥adherents of a world religion (Russian Orthodox Christianity) against animists, not a conflict between adherents of different world religions or between adherents of different sects of the same religion

♠ Wars between different world religions ♣ absent ♥ adherents of a world religion (Russian Orthodox Christianity) against animists, not a conflict between adherents of different world religions or between adherents of different sects of the same religion

♠ Wars of world religion against tribal religion ♣ present ♥ There were several uprisings in the Russian colonial period: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [300] "Crushed by the omnipotence of the toyons, the masses of poor people in the ulus hardly dared to protest or fight for their rights. It was only now and then that the toyon oppression gave rise to outbursts of protest, but these were sporadic and promptly suppressed. This was the fate of the revolt of Vasiliy Manchara (1830-1850), hero of the Yakut legends." [301] "The Yakut masses led a hard life. They paid tribute in sable and fox furs, had to perform a number of other compulsory services and were exploited by the tsarist soldiery, Russian merchants and their own toyons. After several unsuccesful uprisings (1634, 1636-1637, 1639-1640, and 1642), and after the toyons had gone over to the side of the voyevods, the Yakut masses could only retaliate against the oppression by sporadic attempts at resistance and flight from their native ulusy to outlying parts." [302] We feel justified in selecting this code as the pace of Christianization was slow among Sakha.

♠ Wars on Urbanism-Literacy frontier ♣ present ♥ There were several uprisings in the Russian colonial period: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [303] "Crushed by the omnipotence of the toyons, the masses of poor people in the ulus hardly dared to protest or fight for their rights. It was only now and then that the toyon oppression gave rise to outbursts of protest, but these were sporadic and promptly suppressed. This was the fate of the revolt of Vasiliy Manchara (1830-1850), hero of the Yakut legends." [304] "The Yakut masses led a hard life. They paid tribute in sable and fox furs, had to perform a number of other compulsory services and were exploited by the tsarist soldiery, Russian merchants and their own toyons. After several unsuccesful uprisings (1634, 1636-1637, 1639-1640, and 1642), and after the toyons had gone over to the side of the voyevods, the Yakut masses could only retaliate against the oppression by sporadic attempts at resistance and flight from their native ulusy to outlying parts." [305]

♠ Wars on steppe frontier ♣ present ♥ The Sakha initially resisted Russian troops: "As we have seen, the Sakha people-called Yakuts by outsiders-dominated the crucial country of the middle Lena Valley, dotted with islands of fertile grassland, until the 1630s. Russian empire builders, spearheaded by Cossack bands, then pushed down the Lena and built three forts in the Yakut heartland, one of which would become the city of Yakutsk. As was true in the rest of Siberia, the Russians demanded yasak, or tribute in the form of fur, from the indigenes. The Yakut resisted, but they were divided into feuding clans and hampered by outmoded military technology. Resistance also provoked devastating Cossack raids on the scattered hamlets and homesteads of the vulnerably semi-sedentary Sakha. Although the Yakut were able to seriously besiege the Russian fort at Yakutsk on several occasions, they lost the war and subsequently submitted to Russian rule." [306] There were several uprisings in the Russian colonial period: "Yakut leaders cooperated with Russian commanders and governors, becoming active in trade, fur-tax collection, transport, and the postal system. Fighting among Yakut communities decreased, although horse rustling and occasional anti-Russian violence continued. For example, a Yakut Robin Hood named Manchari led a band that stole from the rich (usually Russians) to give to the poor (usually Yakut) in the nineteenth century." [307] "Crushed by the omnipotence of the toyons, the masses of poor people in the ulus hardly dared to protest or fight for their rights. It was only now and then that the toyon oppression gave rise to outbursts of protest, but these were sporadic and promptly suppressed. This was the fate of the revolt of Vasiliy Manchara (1830-1850), hero of the Yakut legends." [308] "The Yakut masses led a hard life. They paid tribute in sable and fox furs, had to perform a number of other compulsory services and were exploited by the tsarist soldiery, Russian merchants and their own toyons. After several unsuccesful uprisings (1634, 1636-1637, 1639-1640, and 1642), and after the toyons had gone over to the side of the voyevods, the Yakut masses could only retaliate against the oppression by sporadic attempts at resistance and flight from their native ulusy to outlying parts." [309] Given how the Yakut were initially pastoralists, the 'steppe frontier' seems to apply here. We have coded the variable under the assumption that this applies to later rebellions as well, given the slow pace of sedentization and the slow spread of cereal agriculture in Yakutsia.

♠ Wars on agricultural frontier ♣ absent ♥ conflict between a society with intensive agriculture and a group of societies that were semi-nomadic pastoralists, not hunter-gatherers

Intensity of warfare[edit]

♠ Annexation ♣ suspected unknown ♥

Sieroszewski's informants named livestock rather than land as a reason for conflict: "It was more often that we tried to take cattle away from each other... We didn't care about land... there was a lot of that... (Namsk Ulus, 1890)... It wasn't that we fought over land so much; it was over cattle... (Bayagantaysk Ulus, 1887)."[310] As indicated below, victorious toyons seized cattle rather than land, allowing them to accumulate wealth and gain influence. "It wasn't that we fought over land so much" - so they may have occasionally fought over land?

Russian troops subjugated the Sakha, incorporating Yakutsia into the Russian Empire: "As we have seen, the Sakha people-called Yakuts by outsiders-dominated the crucial country of the middle Lena Valley, dotted with islands of fertile grassland, until the 1630s. Russian empire builders, spearheaded by Cossack bands, then pushed down the Lena and built three forts in the Yakut heartland, one of which would become the city of Yakutsk. As was true in the rest of Siberia, the Russians demanded yasak, or tribute in the form of fur, from the indigenes. The Yakut resisted, but they were divided into feuding clans and hampered by outmoded military technology. Resistance also provoked devastating Cossack raids on the scattered hamlets and homesteads of the vulnerably semi-sedentary Sakha. Although the Yakut were able to seriously besiege the Russian fort at Yakutsk on several occasions, they lost the war and subsequently submitted to Russian rule." [311] We are coding what the Sakha did not what Russia did so this data does not count.

♠ Looting ♣ present ♥

Looting campaigns were a common feature of Sakha warfare and economy: "These warriors formed a chain of movable, vigilant pickets around the settlements. In case of war they formed the kernel of the fighting detachment -- sari Some of the bolder ones went to find their fortune, dzhol. They would go far into unknown territory, among foreigners, either by themselves or with companions. Such detachments would not take their cattle with them and often traveled on foot. They made their living exclusively by hunting, fishing, and looting. The Yakut kept these habits for a long time, until very recently. Khudiakov has a legend about Khaptagay-batyr and his son Khokhoe-batyr, and their three khosun: Sappy, Yngkabyl, and Batagyyan, who roamed about in the seventeen forties, during the time of Pavlutskii, in the north of the Yakutsk Oblast..." [312]

♠ Sack ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Rape ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Deportation ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Expulsion ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Enslavement ♣ present ♥

Prisoners of war were frequently enslaved: "Kinship and politics were mixed in the hierarchical council system that guided AQA-USA, AIMAK, and DZHON. Yakut explanations of DZHON in the nineteenth century included concepts like "people," "community," or "tribe," territorially defined. Councils were composed of ranked circles of elders, usually men, whose leaders, TOYONS, were called nobles by Russians. A lineage head was BIS-USA-TOYON; respected warriors and hunters were BATYR. Lineage councils decided major economic issues, interfamily disputes, and questions of blood revenge for violence committed against the group. AIMAK and DZHON councils were infrequent, dealing with issues of security, revenge, alliance, and, before Russian control, war. Through war, slaves were captured for service in the wealthiest TOYON households." [313]

"One way or another, among the Yakut hexogamy was accompanied by war and slavery. It is a very usual thing for Yakut legends to mention slaves given to a conqueror together with a daughter." [314] We need to confirm when the practice was discontinued.

♠ Imprisonment ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Destruction ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Torture ♣ inferred present ♥

No indication that this was a widespread or systematic practice: "For a murder we took vengeance on the children of the murderers and on the children of these children, up to the ninth generation... When we would catch them we did not kill them right away, but would torture them with terrible tortures... (Namsk Ulus, 1890).[315]"

♠ Mutilation ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Targeted massacre ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

"For a murder we took vengeance on the children of the murderers and on the children of these children, up to the ninth generation... When we would catch them we did not kill them right away, but would torture them with terrible tortures... (Namsk Ulus, 1890).[316] Up to the ninth generation.

♠ General massacre ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Extermination ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Ethnocide ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

"For a murder we took vengeance on the children of the murderers and on the children of these children, up to the ninth generation... When we would catch them we did not kill them right away, but would torture them with terrible tortures... (Namsk Ulus, 1890).[317] Up to the ninth generation.


Archaeological proxies:

♠ Skeletal evidence of violence ♣ inferred present ♥

"During later times, Yakuts suffered terrible from their contacts with transported Russian criminals. It seems likely that the social disruption and Western patterns of violence introduced by these people accounts for many Yakuts cranial injuries."[318]

"It is possible that some of the Yakuts nasal fractures are sports injuries. Czaplicka (1916) describes a popular Yakuts game called maasyuk that in many respects is similar to soccer. The ball is made of raindeer skin and is kicked and butted about with the head and 'propelled by almost any means short of manslaughter' (Czaplicka 1916:117-118). Fouling is not penalized and if a kick is impossible, the ball may be picked up and thrown. In view of the clinical evidence that nasal fractures are a common result of collisions between soccer players (Frenguelli et al. 1991), this type of sports injury may well account for some of the nasal fractures, especially among Yakuts men."[319]

♠ Mass burials ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Settlement destruction ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Pictorial evidence of warfare ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

List of Wars[edit]

Ritual variables[edit]

A collective ritual is a ritual in which two or more people participate. With the official cult we refer to the set of collective ritual practices that are most closely associated with legitimation of the power structure (including elites, if any).

♠ RA ♣ Daniel Mullins; Eva Brandl; Enrico Cioni ♥ DM coded largest ritual. EC copy-and-pasted rituals coded for RuYakuE by EB onto this page.

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

Largest scale collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Ayy ysyaxa ♥ "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn. The steward addresses a prayer to the “creators,” begging for blessings,-increase of horses and cattle, a good harvest of hay, good health for the people and animals, and an abundance of food. Then he takes the kumiss-festival ladle , and makes a libation, in the direction of the dawn, to the benevolent deities . Then, while making a libation to the ground, he addresses the local deity, “the owner of the place” (än doidu iccitä), asking him not to harm the inhabitants of the spot and the members of the clan. After that, the steward, with the help of the sacrificial ladle, proceeds to divine. He throws the ladle towards the sky: and if it falls with the front part upwards, it portends the granting by the deities of future abundance; and all the people utter the joyful cry Uru! Then the boys and girls give the goblets with the sacrificial kumiss, according to the directions of the steward, to the elder and honored members of the clan, both male and female. These, after placing themselves,-the men on the right and the women on the left of the altar,-drink off the kumiss from the goblets, and pass them on to the less important and the younger people." [320][321]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs ' seasonally (less often than monthly but more often than annually)'[322]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Thomas Cressy: Changed all frequency codes to seasonally after discussion with RA
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[323]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Thomas Cressy: Changed all frequency codes to seasonally after discussion with RA
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[324]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Thomas Cressy: Changed all frequency codes to seasonally after discussion with RA
♠ Duration ♣ 9 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual database, this ritual is coded as '6 to 12 hours'[325]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 3600 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database, 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are 'present'[326]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Given a clan size of roughly 4000 people, I estimate that roughly 3600 people participate.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ elites ♥ shamans; male elders. The only two figures mentioned by the original source [327] are a shaman and a clan elder, who appears to be exclusively male.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ The following suggests that there were no specific restrictions: "During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited" [328]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ The following suggests that there were no specific restrictions: "During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited" [329]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[330]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ inferred absent ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[331]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ fear ♣ inferred absent ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[332]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ humiliation ♣ inferred absent ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[333]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ disgust ♣ inferred absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[334]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ inferred absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [335]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ pain ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'[336]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 1 (Low).
♠ mutilation ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'[337]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ risk of death ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the original source [338], as well as the ritual's general dearth of dysphoric elements, including ones that might lead to infection or excessive blood loss: for example, 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'[339]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred present ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'present'[340]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred present ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'present'[341]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [342]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ sex ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [343]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ dancing ♣ inferred present ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'present'[344]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. "Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests." [345]
♠ synchronous movement ♣ inferred absent ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as 'absent'[346]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ singing ♣ inferred present ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as 'absent', but songs are mentioned in the ritual description: "Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests." [347]
♠ entertainment ♣ inferred present ♥ "Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests." [348]
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred present ♥ "Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded." [349]
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Narrative or story recounted' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database'[350]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. There is no mention of oath taking in the original source [351], though it's worth noting that "Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded."
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ inferred present ♥ "Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded." [352]
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ inferred present ♥ "Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded." [353]
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ inferred present ♥ "Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded." [354]
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned in original source [355], and the Ritual Database does not provide information regarding orthopraxy checks.
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Distribution of ritual exegesis' is coded in the Ritual Database as 'Known by all competent participants' and the 'Dominant mode of acquisition of exegesis' is ' Learnt through verbal egalitaritarian transmission'
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ No formal currency is present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ inferred present ♥ A food offering is made. 'Other offering' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'present'[356]. One has to be a rich man to host one of these rituals: "During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained." [357] It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ There is no mention of direct health costs associated with this ritual in the original source [358].
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [359]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ (i.e. an individual who is not considered part of the group performing the ritual) 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [360]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ (i.e. an individual who is considered part of the group performing the ritual) 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [361]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ (e.g. sacrificing the first-born son) 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [362]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
♠ other ♣ inferred absent ♥ List the other(s) No other costs are described.

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Weddings ♥ Weddings were subject to a high degree of ritualization, resembling peacemaking procedures between two families: 'Traditionally, for wealthy Yakut, marriage could be polygamous. More common, however, was monogamy, with occasional remarriage after the death of a spouse. Arranged marriages were sometimes politically motivated. Patrilineage exogamy was reckoned strictly; those one could marry were called SYGAN. Until the 1920s many marriage arrangements were complicated and protracted, involving financial, emotional, and symbolic resources of the bride's and groom's extended families. This included the matchmaking ritual; several formal payments of animals, furs, and meat to the bride's family; informal gifts; and extensive dowries. Some families permitted poor grooms to work in their households as a replacement for the bride-price. Occasionally bride-capture occurred (it may have been more common in pre-Russian times). Wedding ceremonies and their attendant feasts, prayers, and dancing, were held first at the household of the bride's parents, then at that of the groom's. The couple usually lived or settled in a nearby yurt.' [363]//Kharuzin also describes the wedding proceedings: 'On the day of the wedding the choom of the father of the bride and that of the father of the bridegroom were set up side by side. Depending on the degree of their prosperity the owner of each of the chooms slaughtered between one and five deer and treated the assembled guests. In addition, the bridegroom slaughtered one more deer and sent its meat to the father of the bride. Aided by his friends the bridegroom would next catch the deer for the black kalym. At the same time, near the choom of the bride, other young men caught deer that were to be handed over as dowry. Out on the street, meanwhile, the bride would dance in the company of her girl friends and of other young men. Having caught the deer for the black kalym, the young men tied them up to the back of the narta of the match-maker who, with the deer behind him, rode in front of the bridegroom.//'Upon approaching the choom of the bride the matchmaker and the bridegroom rode around her choom in the direction of the movement of the sun. The matchmaker would then enter the choom alone and announce: The son-in-law has arrived. At the same time the people present would let the deer in a special enclosure built by stretching lassoes between trees and by setting up of overturned nartas . A great number of guests would arrive together with the bridegroom. Out on the street the matchmaker would lead the bridegroom to the father of the bride. The bridegroom would pull behind him a vazhenka ( nyal'dzhin ) tied to a leather strap. Upon approaching his future father-in-law he would hand the animal over to him. The bridegroom together with the guests would then remain outside while in the choom preparations were made for a feast and a wedding bed was set up for the newlyweds. The making of the bed was entrusted to one of the relatives of the bride.//'While the guests stood outside and waited for the beginning of the feast, the matchmaker would make numerous sorties from the choom of the bride and in a light-hearted way inform them of what was going on inside the choom. At the same time the father of the bride would received the deer of the black kalym. In the east tundra all the brought deer were accepted without any argument; in the Noril'-skiy rayon, however, the father of the bride would frequently pronounce some animals unacceptable and would send them back expecting other animals in their stead. In the case of a demanding father the business of receiving the deer would occasionally extend into the late evening.//'If the father of the bride was a snob he would make the guests freeze outside for a long time. When, at long last, the feast and the bed were ready and the deer of the black kalym all checked, the match-maker would lead the bridegroom into the choom and would make him pray in front of the ikons. The bride stationed herself by the side of the bridegroom and prayed together with him. After the prayers were ended the matchmaker would say to the bridegroom: Bow to the big father-in-law and ask for his blessing. The bride and the bridegroom would then make a low bow before the parents and came up to receive their blessing as well as the blessing of the relatives older than the bride. All of them blessed the young people, gave them their hands to kiss, and proffered their best wishes. The matchmaker would at this point, give ten rubles to the father of the bride, and to all her relatives pieces of cloth and kerchiefs. In Noril'sk in the place of money the matchmaker gave the bride's father a fox skin, and to her mother a polar fox skin or a fur coat. These presents were called yungyu --prayer or request. After these presents had been made all the relatives of the bride got up and shook the bridegroom's hand. There were no handshakes between these relatives and the members of the bridegroom's entourage.//'After the blessing ceremony was over the bride and the bridegroom were placed behind the bed curtain. Only then would the guests be let in in a strictly observed order. The guests would be brought in from outside by the relatives, who would lead them by the hand--the adult relatives accompanying the adult guests, and children-relatives--other children. The guests would be taken to places that were asssigned to them. The closest relatives and the most honored guests as well as foreigners (Yakut, Russians, Tungus) would be let in first. To avoid mistakes the relatives of the bride asked their friends as to who should come in and in what order. Before the guests were let in two people would be selected from among those who were known for their talents as improvisers. The two chosen men were to play the role of people who predict the future ( yr kerderer dzhon ). One of these men was selected by the relatives of the bridegroom, the other----by the relatives of the bride. The presence of these men was not an essential part of the wedding ceremony.//'When all the honored guests were seated the bride's father would ask them: Guests! What do you have to say? The matchmaker would answer: We have a word to say. Then a representative of the bridegroom would get us and colorfully and ornately would describe the future life of the young people and the peace and harmony of their household. He would also describe the number of the children they were going to have, how rich they were going to be, etc. He would end his speech by saying: My words ended, now is your turn. Thereupon a similar speech would be made by a representative of the bride. The guests predicted a happier life for the bridegroom or the bride, depending on which side gave the better speech. After this a woman relative of the bride poured out tea and took charge of the serving of the food. After the first meal, i.e. after drinking the tea, and before the opening of the table ( ostuolu asyar inniger ), i.e. the serving of the meal, all the guests would go out on the street and dance until the second meal was served. The ceremony of distributing the kalym ( sulu tuttarar ) would be taking place at the same time.//'The wedding bed was transported to the choom of the bridegroom before the arrival of the bride herself. In front of the procession rode the matchmaker; he was followed by the bridegroom, behind whom was the bride, and behind the latter the deer loaded with the bride's dowry. The bride put on two coats made out of cloth ( sontap ) and a Siberian fur-coat ( dokha ), embroidered with patterns ( ardaydakh sangyyakh ). In the Noril'skiy rayon the size of the dowry was decided upon in the course of the negotiations conducted by the matchmaker; in other places the custom was different and the size of the dowry depended on that of the kalym. If the kalym consisted of sixty deer, the number of deer given with the dowry would be forty-five. A rich dowry consisted of sixty or seventy selected deer of various ages, among them no harness or old deer. Nor more than two or three deer could be included in a rich dowry. In addition to the deer a rich dowry would consist of seven and the poor one of five nartas, harnessed to the best deer (a pair of deer harnessed to each narta of the rich dowry, and a single deer harnessed to each narta of the poor one). In addition to the nartas a dowry included a narta choom, to which were harnessed four deer.//'When the bride's train approached the choom of the bridegroom, the matchmaker would go to the parents of the bridegroom and announced to them the arrival of the bride. The newlyweds would then travel three times around the choom in the direction of the movement of the sun. In the Noril'skiy rayon the bride rode around the choom by herself; after she had entered the choom the deer were led around the choom by some one else. This ceremony was called the entrance of the hearth ( sarany bullarar ). The bride was led into the choom of the bridegroom by a respected old woman who could not be her relative. The bride and the bridegroom prayed together before the ikon, and then, with a deep bow to the bridegroom's father and mother, asked for their blessing and came up to kiss their hands. The parents of the bridegroom then blessed the newlyweds and wished them a happy life. At this point the bride would give the bridegroom's parents presents of money or of valuable skins; these presents had to be much more valuable that those given by the bridegroom to the parents of the bride, for the father of the bride would want to put up a front before the bridegroom's father. In the bridegroom's choom the guests were again treated to a feast, which was served to them in two shifts. In the ancient times a shaman would always be invited to a wedding. Before the beginning of the feast he would stand dressed not in his ceremonial but in his ordinary garments, and leaning upon a deer staff of the bride called upon beneficent gods and spirits to be kind to the newlywed, and for himself wished them a happy and prosperous life. After this address by the shaman the first group of honored guests sat down to the feast.'//'The bridegroom's father would next come out to glance at the deer that were brought as a dowry, and offered the people who helped him in the equipping of the kalym to chose the animals they wanted.//'After the end of the festivities the father would inspect the dowry in the light of the day (this custom was not practised by the Noril'skiye Dolgani): he would go out of the choom, open up the trunks and examine their contents. If it turned out that the amount of the dowry was not equivalent to the amount of the kalym, the stinginess of the bride's parents would be disapprovingly commented on by all those present. As a rule, the father of the bride tried to include in the dowry as many valuable things as he could, for fear that otherwise he might disgrace himself. The inspection described above ended the ceremonies of the Dolgani wedding. The assembled guests would spend the day in eating, in games and in dancing, and would depart in the late evening. The father and the mother of the bride stayed with the bridegroom for a period of three days. Before their departure the father of the bridegroom would present the parents of the bride with one deer (ogo kereryu) which was to be looked upon by them as their daughter. The animal thus given as a present was highly valued. On the morning of the third day the young wife poured out tea. During the tea drinking her father would publicly instruct her as follows: From this time on you must obey your husband. Your mother-in-law now stands in the place of your own mother. Your father-in-law in the place of your father. Respect and obey them and do not quarrel with them.' [364]//Elders played a prominent role alongside parents and shamans: 'The oldest kinsman in the clan, or the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa , is always heaped with honors, if he is both rich and has never been put on trial. To him pertains the jurisdiction in trifling quarrels between kinsfolk. The following ceremonies serve to recall the religious functions that he (Ysekh) formerly exercised: a. At the time of the spring festival, which bears a strictly clan character, they bring to him, first of all, a large wooden vessel ( Choron ) containing kumiss; he pronounces a prayer of thanks to the gods and then pours the kumiss upon the fire. b. At the time of the arrival of the betrothed at the bridegroom’s yurt, they take from the sleigh of the betrothed, and place upon a table in front of the fire place the boiled head of a horse, whose eyes are covered with butter, to whose ears are attached intestines filled with horse’s blood, and a wooden cup filled with butter. After this the betrothed enters the yurt, and stands, having first untied her girdle, on the right side of the komelok [RCH: i. e., the fireplace] where she is met by the oldest kinsman, whose place is sometimes taken nowadays by the most honored guest, who, kneeling, throws into the fire 41 pieces of meat, blood and butter, and blesses the bride. For the completion of this ceremony, whose obvious object is to unite the bride with the bridegroom’s home, the oldest kinsman secures for his use the head, blood and butter brought into the yurt, and in addition the sum of one ruble.' [365]//NOTE: Weddings and nuptials were not coded in the Ritual Database. The below codes accordingly reflect the gathered eHRAF materials only.
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ monthly ♥ The shaman would perform marriages more frequently than the average participant or audience member. The code given is an approximation only and is open to review.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once in a lifetime ♥ We have considered bridge and groom to be participants in this case. We have assumed that most marriages were monogamous: 'Traditionally, for wealthy Yakut, marriage could be polygamous. More common, however, was monogamy, with occasional remarriage after the death of a spouse.' [366].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ seasonally ♥ We have considered the extended kin of bride and groom to be audience members in this case. We are unsure how many weddings a community member would attend as an audience member. The code given is an approximation only and is open to review.
♠ Duration ♣ 6 ♥ hours. Based on the source's description [367], the wedding ceremony itself appears to have been confined to one day, although the parents would remain in the dwelling of the groom's family for a few days. We have given a rough estimate only, as no precise duration is mentioned in the material gathered so far; this is open to review.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ [50-100] ♥ in absolute numbers Weddings were attended by the extended kin groups of bride and groom [368]. Toyons may have celebrated more lavish and thus larger weddings than the general population. We have assumed around 50-100 participants. This number may be in need of review and need correction. The ethnography does not clearly state how many guests a wedding would receive on average.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ substantial minority ♥ male shamans. 'In the ancient times a shaman would always be invited to a wedding. Before the beginning of the feast he would stand dressed not in his ceremonial but in his ordinary garments, and leaning upon a deer staff of the bride called upon beneficent gods and spirits to be kind to the newlywed, and for himself wished them a happy and prosperous life. After this address by the shaman the first group of honored guests sat down to the feast.' [369] NOTE: There were both male and female shamans, but the material gathered on weddings specifically only mentions male shamans. More information on the specific tasks of and potential differences between male and female shamans is needed. Thomas Cressy: Coded as substantial minority, as it seems only the male shamans could be the specialists.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ Weddings were attended by the extended kin groups of bride and groom [370]. Weddings of this kind were not generally exclusive to 'ruling classes', although toyons may have celebrated more lavish ones.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ Weddings were attended by the extended kin groups of bride and groom [371]. Weddings of this kind were not generally exclusive to 'ruling classes', although toyons may have celebrated more lavish ones.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that a very detailed description of a typical late nineteenth-century ceremony [372] does not include references to this practice.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that a very detailed description of a typical late nineteenth-century ceremony [373] does not include references to this practice.
