But no less interest attaches to certain juridical customs, communicated by the compiler, which have been worked out by the Yakuts under the obvious influence of the Russians; the structure of Yakut life is changing its aspect; the new conditions of life which are coming to birth demand new norms for their satisfaction. The latter are sometimes borrowed from Russian neighbors, come into contradiction with the bases of the ancient life and undergo certain changes under the influence of the archaic views on legal relations.' [530] But Sakha trials were based on prior agreements between the contending parties rather than codified law: 'Agreements and contracts, both written and oral, are taken as a basis for all trials and settlements; therefore, if there is no quarrel about the contents of an agreement, the decision is quick, but if anyone refuses to abide by an agreement, and it was oral, his opponent may prove it with witnesses, and, if there are no witnesses, the quarrel is decided by an oath.' [531] '“As a nation they are unsocial, litigious, and vindictive. An injury received by one of them is very rarely forgotten, and, if he cannot revenge it himself, he will leave the feud to his son. Their passion for litigation is excessive: they will frequently undertake difficult and expensive journeys, in a cause where perhaps the matter in dispute is not of the value of a rouble. Their unsocial dispo-sition, which leads them to prefer settling by single families at a distance from each other, is strikingly contrasted with the cheerful and ready hospitality which they show to strangers. They very seldom settle in communities, and it is only along the route from Jakuzk to the Aldan, where the country is more populous, that such settlements are now and then to be met with; but beyond the Werchojansk chain, the solitary jurti are often hundreds of wersts apart, so that the nearest neighbours may not see each other for years. Such distances are far greater than can be required on account of pasture, and are rather to be ascribed to the disposition which leads them to seek solitude, and to avoid all social intercourse.”' [532] Clan elders fulfilled judicial, but also ceremonial and other duties: 'The oldest kinsman in the clan, or the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa , is always heaped with honors, if he is both rich and has never been put on trial. To him pertains the jurisdiction in trifling quarrels between kinsfolk. The following ceremonies serve to recall the religious functions that he (Ysekh) formerly exercised a. At the time of the spring festival, which bears a strictly clan character, they bring to him, first of all, a large wooden vessel ( Choron ) containing kumiss; he pronounces a prayer of thanks to the gods and then pours the kumiss upon the fire. b. At the time of the arrival of the betrothed at the bridegroom’s yurt, they take from the sleigh of the betrothed, and place upon a table in front of the fire place the boiled head of a horse, whose eyes are covered with butter, to whose ears are attached intestines filled with horse’s blood, and a wooden cup filled with butter. After this the betrothed enters the yurt, and stands, having first untied her girdle, on the right side of the komelok [RCH: i. e., the fireplace] where she is met by the oldest kinsman, whose place is sometimes taken nowadays by the most honored guest, who, kneeling, throws into the fire pieces of meat, blood and butter, and blesses the bride. For the completion of this ceremony, whose obvious object is to unite the bride with the bridegroom’s home, the oldest kinsman secures for his use the head, blood and butter brought into the yurt, and in addition the sum of one ruble.' [533] Clans handled offences and litigation in assemblies of elders: 'I shall end this survey of Yakut clan institutions and their self-government by a note about Yakut legal procedure. Strictly speaking the Yakut court is the assembly: the clan, nasleg, or ulus assembly, depending on the circumstances. These courts are under each other's jurisdiction as courts of appeal. The Yakut enjoy waging law suits against each other and witnessing court proceedings. More important matters are always handed over to the assembly. At the assembly the wealthy people usually put in their comments, which areheard attentively, and although the final judgement is pronounced by the chairman of the assembly, he usually simply transmits a condensed form of the general opinion. The ligitants stand before the presiding clansmen with their heads bare, and, frequently nodding their heads and, while making the most important points, making deep bows from the waist, each in turn expound their case. Witnesses are called forth and interrogated on the spot, while unruly witnesses are brought by policemen. The judges always have to sit. In some localities it is customary for the judges to wear caps on their head.' [534] Sakha assemblies relied on witnesses and oaths: '4. When a complaint is brought, the defendant is summoned and if he admits the claim against him to be just, a decision is made, and if not, witnesses are summoned by the nasleg corporals, who are paid by the petitioner for the service. At the end of the case, the petitioner gets this payment back, along with other losses, from the defendant if the latter is convicted. If he is not convicted and the petition proves unjust, these losses are imposed on the petitioner as a penalty. 5. Converted witnesses are questioned under an oath made before an image of God. After they have kissed the image, they briefly declare that they will tell the genuine truth about what is asked them, and, if not, that they will incur the wrath of God and be deprived of His blessings, etc. Priests are not required to make this oath. 6. Unconverted witnesses are administered an oath in which they bow to a fire and swear that they will be deprived of God's blessings, etc., if they give false testimony. 7. Claims and disputes to which there are no witnesses are decided by an oath administered in the manner described above. If both the plaintiff and the defendant wish to take it, the oath is usually given to the defendant. 8. Important and complex claims, such as those concerning big thefts, disputed places, etc., are settled on the basis of instructions given on June 30, 1728 by the ambassador plenipotentiary to China, Count Ragunzinskiy, to the frontier guards Firsov and Mikhalev,; the clan-chiefs of the nasleg in which the affair took place invite the clan-chiefs of the neighboring naslegs, six men in all, whose unanimous decision ends the case; there is no appeal. Although this is called an intermediary trial, the name is wrong, since the plaintiffs do not take part in inviting the clan-chiefs of the neighboring naslegs.' [535] Sauer describes the oaths of unconverted witnesses: 'A magician [RCH: i.e., the shaman] places his tambour and dress before the fire, the embers of which are burning. The accused stands before it, facing the sun, and says: ‘May I lose during my life all that man holds dear and desirable [...]' The magician throws butter on the hot embers; the man accused must then step over the tambour and dress, advance to the fire, and swallow some of the exhaling smoke from the butter; then, looking to the sun, say, ‘If I have sworn false, deprive me‘of the light and heat.’ Some of the tribes close the ceremony by making the accused bite the head of a bear; because they allow this beast to have more than human wisdom, and suppose that some bear will kill the aggressor.”' [536] Criminal cases were transferred to courts applying Russian law only after 1889: 'Nevertheless until very r ecently and even criminal cases such as beatings, personal injury, and thefts, even for a considerable amount, as long as a house was not broken into, were judged by the clan administration. Only from the year 1889, when an order came out to proceed against the trible authorities if they did not communicate such matters, have thefts begun to be referred to the Russian courts and judged according to Russian laws. For theft the Yakut usually punished wealthy people by a fine which was two or three times the value of the stolen article, depending on the circumstances. For beatings and personal injuries they sentenced the guilty party to support the injured party during his disablement or to pay him a lump sum. Now the guilty are put in prison, and to the great horror of their neighbors they usually leave out and out scoundrels. Such crimes as the violation of women, the breaking of agreements, fraud, and forgery were apparently unknown to the Yakut and went unpunished. But the violation of the wedding agreement was provided for by the kalym. At the present time most of the cases and statements of claim which come before the clan administrations concern the violation of boundary lines and various disputed lands.' [537] Clerical courts occasionally prosecuted polygamy prior to that date: 'Such polygamy, which is tolerated for the above reasons, and which has existed since ancient times and does not do any harm, had not become bad in the judgement of the Yakut, and no regulations for the abolition of this custom have been set up by the Yakut. However, since the Yakut adopted the Christian faith, and as they have become enlightened by strict surveillance and sometimes by indulgent reprimands from the eparchial priests, it has been gradually dying out, but nevertheless denunciations on this subject are made concerning people who have lawfully wedded wives but keep the others, and people who had several wives before conversion and married one of them in church without leaving the others, who were left at home with their children; in the case of such a denunciation the local authorities, on the grounds of the repugnance of the Christian religion for this custom, pressed formal charges, and the guilty parties were handed over to the clerical court as fornicators, and the cases were decided according to general state laws, which constituted and still constitute and extreme burden for the Yakut.' [538] Sieroszewski's material on punishment seems to refer to Yakut assemblies rather than Russian courts: 'In 1867, according to official data, 1870 cases were judged in the upravas in the vicinity of Yakutsk: out of the total, 1855 concerned land disputes; in the Vilyuysk Okrug, out of 3786 cases, more than half had to do with land. Besides levying fines the Yakut also punish a guilty party by reprimanding him publicly, before the assembly, by sending him on some job, or putting him into solitary confinement. The latter is apparently a Russian innovation. Punishment with birch-rods was quite unknown to the Yakut in the past. Even now they have recourse to this very rarely and with great distaste. In the north they did not even know what this was like, and once, in the Kolymsk Ulus, when the assembly did not known what to do with one of its disobedient members and decided, on the advice of some Yakut who had come from the south, to flog him, they turned to me with questions: where should we beat him?, and do we have to lay him down and undress him or is that not permitted? (Kolymsk Ulus, Undzha, 1883). Usually the influence of the commune is quite sufficient to exert necessary compulsion. In the south, where the ties of the commune have weakened, we find disobedient people whose cattle are taken away as a punishment, or who are forced to obey. Many decisions of the clan assemblies astonished me by their strangeness, but once I looked closer into their life and made thorough inquiries into their motives I always found at the bottom a deep respect for the individual and a striving toward equality. Naturally I say nothing about those decisions which are demonstrably incorrect, and not in accord with custom and the conscience of the people, but which they have been forced to make because of the economic pressure of unscrupulous rich people or because of administrative arbitrariness.' [539] Accordingly, Sakha systems of dispute resolution co-existed with the institutions of the expanding Russian state.

♠ Courts are supported by the state ♣ present ♥ See above.

♠ Criminal Prosecution ♣ absent: 1632-1889 CE; present: 1889-1900 CE ♥ See above.

Accessibility of the Legal System

♠ ruling elite ♣ inferred present ♥ We have assumed that the legal system was accessible to the general population (see above).
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ general population ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ inferred present ♥

Accessibility of Trials

♠ ruling elite ♣ inferred present ♥ We have assumed that the legal system was accessible to the general population (see above).
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ general population ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ inferred present ♥

Accessibility of Courts

♠ Courts in polity capital ♣ present ♥ It appears that courts were only present in larger towns.
♠ Courts in regional capitals ♣ present ♥
♠ Courts in provincial towns ♣ absent ♥

♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in criminal cases ♣ ♥ We have found no reliable data on this.

♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in civil cases ♣ ♥ We have found no reliable data on this.

Informal Justice[edit]

♠ Non-state judiciary ♣ present ♥ During the Russian period, some Russian legal concepts were adopted by the Sakha: 'N. P. Pripuzov gathered his material among the Yakuts living in the Yakutsk district, i. e., in the midst of that part of the Yakut tribe among whom we may rightly expect to encounter some traces of the action of Russian customary and legislative norms upon the customary law of the Yakuts. All the more interest attaches to the norms of the Yakut customary law noted by the compiler, which, despite the long association of the Yakuts with the Russians, have survived as a valuable vestige of the ancient familial-clan foundations. But no less interest attaches to certain juridical customs, communicated by the compiler, which have been worked out by the Yakuts under the obvious influence of the Russians; the structure of Yakut life is changing its aspect; the new conditions of life which are coming to birth demand new norms for their satisfaction. The latter are sometimes borrowed from Russian neighbors, come into contradiction with the bases of the ancient life and undergo certain changes under the influence of the archaic views on legal relations.' [540] But Sakha trials were based on prior agreements between the contending parties rather than codified law: 'Agreements and contracts, both written and oral, are taken as a basis for all trials and settlements; therefore, if there is no quarrel about the contents of an agreement, the decision is quick, but if anyone refuses to abide by an agreement, and it was oral, his opponent may prove it with witnesses, and, if there are no witnesses, the quarrel is decided by an oath.' [541] '“As a nation they are unsocial, litigious, and vindictive. An injury received by one of them is very rarely forgotten, and, if he cannot revenge it himself, he will leave the feud to his son. Their passion for litigation is excessive: they will frequently undertake difficult and expensive journeys, in a cause where perhaps the matter in dispute is not of the value of a rouble. Their unsocial dispo-sition, which leads them to prefer settling by single families at a distance from each other, is strikingly contrasted with the cheerful and ready hospitality which they show to strangers. They very seldom settle in communities, and it is only along the route from Jakuzk to the Aldan, where the country is more populous, that such settlements are now and then to be met with; but beyond the Werchojansk chain, the solitary jurti are often hundreds of wersts apart, so that the nearest neighbours may not see each other for years. Such distances are far greater than can be required on account of pasture, and are rather to be ascribed to the disposition which leads them to seek solitude, and to avoid all social intercourse.”' [542] Clan elders fulfilled judicial, but also ceremonial and other duties: 'The oldest kinsman in the clan, or the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa , is always heaped with honors, if he is both rich and has never been put on trial. To him pertains the jurisdiction in trifling quarrels between kinsfolk. The following ceremonies serve to recall the religious functions that he (Ysekh) formerly exercised a. At the time of the spring festival, which bears a strictly clan character, they bring to him, first of all, a large wooden vessel ( Choron ) containing kumiss; he pronounces a prayer of thanks to the gods and then pours the kumiss upon the fire. b. At the time of the arrival of the betrothed at the bridegroom’s yurt, they take from the sleigh of the betrothed, and place upon a table in front of the fire place the boiled head of a horse, whose eyes are covered with butter, to whose ears are attached intestines filled with horse’s blood, and a wooden cup filled with butter. After this the betrothed enters the yurt, and stands, having first untied her girdle, on the right side of the komelok [RCH: i. e., the fireplace] where she is met by the oldest kinsman, whose place is sometimes taken nowadays by the most honored guest, who, kneeling, throws into the fire pieces of meat, blood and butter, and blesses the bride. For the completion of this ceremony, whose obvious object is to unite the bride with the bridegroom’s home, the oldest kinsman secures for his use the head, blood and butter brought into the yurt, and in addition the sum of one ruble.' [543] Clans handled offences and litigation in assemblies of elders: 'I shall end this survey of Yakut clan institutions and their self-government by a note about Yakut legal procedure. Strictly speaking the Yakut court is the assembly: the clan, nasleg, or ulus assembly, depending on the circumstances. These courts are under each other's jurisdiction as courts of appeal. The Yakut enjoy waging law suits against each other and witnessing court proceedings. More important matters are always handed over to the assembly. At the assembly the wealthy people usually put in their comments, which areheard attentively, and although the final judgement is pronounced by the chairman of the assembly, he usually simply transmits a condensed form of the general opinion. The ligitants stand before the presiding clansmen with their heads bare, and, frequently nodding their heads and, while making the most important points, making deep bows from the waist, each in turn expound their case. Witnesses are called forth and interrogated on the spot, while unruly witnesses are brought by policemen. The judges always have to sit. In some localities it is customary for the judges to wear caps on their head.' [544] Sakha assemblies relied on witnesses and oaths: '4. When a complaint is brought, the defendant is summoned and if he admits the claim against him to be just, a decision is made, and if not, witnesses are summoned by the nasleg corporals, who are paid by the petitioner for the service. At the end of the case, the petitioner gets this payment back, along with other losses, from the defendant if the latter is convicted. If he is not convicted and the petition proves unjust, these losses are imposed on the petitioner as a penalty. 5. Converted witnesses are questioned under an oath made before an image of God. After they have kissed the image, they briefly declare that they will tell the genuine truth about what is asked them, and, if not, that they will incur the wrath of God and be deprived of His blessings, etc. Priests are not required to make this oath. 6. Unconverted witnesses are administered an oath in which they bow to a fire and swear that they will be deprived of God's blessings, etc., if they give false testimony. 7. Claims and disputes to which there are no witnesses are decided by an oath administered in the manner described above. If both the plaintiff and the defendant wish to take it, the oath is usually given to the defendant. 8. Important and complex claims, such as those concerning big thefts, disputed places, etc., are settled on the basis of instructions given on June 30, 1728 by the ambassador plenipotentiary to China, Count Ragunzinskiy, to the frontier guards Firsov and Mikhalev,; the clan-chiefs of the nasleg in which the affair took place invite the clan-chiefs of the neighboring naslegs, six men in all, whose unanimous decision ends the case; there is no appeal. Although this is called an intermediary trial, the name is wrong, since the plaintiffs do not take part in inviting the clan-chiefs of the neighboring naslegs.' [545] Sauer describes the oaths of unconverted witnesses: 'A magician [RCH: i.e., the shaman] places his tambour and dress before the fire, the embers of which are burning. The accused stands before it, facing the sun, and says: ‘May I lose during my life all that man holds dear and desirable [...]' The magician throws butter on the hot embers; the man accused must then step over the tambour and dress, advance to the fire, and swallow some of the exhaling smoke from the butter; then, looking to the sun, say, ‘If I have sworn false, deprive me‘of the light and heat.’ Some of the tribes close the ceremony by making the accused bite the head of a bear; because they allow this beast to have more than human wisdom, and suppose that some bear will kill the aggressor.”' [546] Criminal cases were transferred to courts applying Russian law only after 1889: 'Nevertheless until very r ecently and even criminal cases such as beatings, personal injury, and thefts, even for a considerable amount, as long as a house was not broken into, were judged by the clan administration. Only from the year 1889, when an order came out to proceed against the trible authorities if they did not communicate such matters, have thefts begun to be referred to the Russian courts and judged according to Russian laws. For theft the Yakut usually punished wealthy people by a fine which was two or three times the value of the stolen article, depending on the circumstances. For beatings and personal injuries they sentenced the guilty party to support the injured party during his disablement or to pay him a lump sum. Now the guilty are put in prison, and to the great horror of their neighbors they usually leave out and out scoundrels. Such crimes as the violation of women, the breaking of agreements, fraud, and forgery were apparently unknown to the Yakut and went unpunished. But the violation of the wedding agreement was provided for by the kalym. At the present time most of the cases and statements of claim which come before the clan administrations concern the violation of boundary lines and various disputed lands.' [547] Clerical courts occasionally prosecuted polygamy prior to that date: 'Such polygamy, which is tolerated for the above reasons, and which has existed since ancient times and does not do any harm, had not become bad in the judgement of the Yakut, and no regulations for the abolition of this custom have been set up by the Yakut. However, since the Yakut adopted the Christian faith, and as they have become enlightened by strict surveillance and sometimes by indulgent reprimands from the eparchial priests, it has been gradually dying out, but nevertheless denunciations on this subject are made concerning people who have lawfully wedded wives but keep the others, and people who had several wives before conversion and married one of them in church without leaving the others, who were left at home with their children; in the case of such a denunciation the local authorities, on the grounds of the repugnance of the Christian religion for this custom, pressed formal charges, and the guilty parties were handed over to the clerical court as fornicators, and the cases were decided according to general state laws, which constituted and still constitute and extreme burden for the Yakut.' [548] Sieroszewski's material on punishment seems to refer to Yakut assemblies rather than Russian courts: 'In 1867, according to official data, 1870 cases were judged in the upravas in the vicinity of Yakutsk: out of the total, 1855 concerned land disputes; in the Vilyuysk Okrug, out of 3786 cases, more than half had to do with land. Besides levying fines the Yakut also punish a guilty party by reprimanding him publicly, before the assembly, by sending him on some job, or putting him into solitary confinement. The latter is apparently a Russian innovation. Punishment with birch-rods was quite unknown to the Yakut in the past. Even now they have recourse to this very rarely and with great distaste. In the north they did not even know what this was like, and once, in the Kolymsk Ulus, when the assembly did not known what to do with one of its disobedient members and decided, on the advice of some Yakut who had come from the south, to flog him, they turned to me with questions: where should we beat him?, and do we have to lay him down and undress him or is that not permitted? (Kolymsk Ulus, Undzha, 1883). Usually the influence of the commune is quite sufficient to exert necessary compulsion. In the south, where the ties of the commune have weakened, we find disobedient people whose cattle are taken away as a punishment, or who are forced to obey. Many decisions of the clan assemblies astonished me by their strangeness, but once I looked closer into their life and made thorough inquiries into their motives I always found at the bottom a deep respect for the individual and a striving toward equality. Naturally I say nothing about those decisions which are demonstrably incorrect, and not in accord with custom and the conscience of the people, but which they have been forced to make because of the economic pressure of unscrupulous rich people or because of administrative arbitrariness.' [549] Accordingly, Sakha systems of dispute resolution co-existed with the institutions of the expanding Russian state.

♠ Religious judiciary ♣ absent ♥ UPDATE: Maybe change to present: some references mention courts held by the Orthodox clergy.

Property Rights[edit]

♠ Private property (land) ♣ present ♥ As the Sakha were traditionally pastoralists, the below sections mostly refer to livestock rather than land per se. Sakha society was organized in patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [550] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [551] Land and livestock were controlled by patrilineages: 'By customary law, land, cattle, and horses, although used by households, were controlled by the patriline. Animal or land sale and inheritance was approved by elders. But by the twentieth century, smaller families were keeping resources, in part because of the decline of large horse droves. Men owned most of the wealth, and passed it to sons, especially elder sons, although the youngest son often inherited the family yurt. Mothers could pass on dowries to daughters, unless the dowry was forfeited by bad behavior. In theory, dowries included land, as well as goods, jewelry, and animals, although in practice elders rarely gave land to another lineage. Soviet law limited inheritance to goods and nonstate housing could be bequeathed at individual discretion. Most apartments and summer houses were kept in families.' [552] Accordingly, women's property and inheritance rights were limited, although their legal status improved in the Russian period: 'The property rights of women are extremely limited; however, even in this direction certain changes are taking place under the influence of the gradual recognition of woman’s capacity. These innovations, however, are apparently only beginning to penetrate the consciousness of the Yakuts, and have not yet succeeded in conclusively changing the archaic views, denying property rights to women.' [553] 'In relations to her own family group the woman is completely without rights: she must marry into a strange clan, and it is understandable that her kinsmen look upon her as a severed member.' [554] 'Each clan or familial unit, under the influence of the impulse of self-preservation in the struggle for existence, strives insofar as possible to insure its economic existence through the accumulation of wealth. Naturally, it jealously guards its property against transfer into the hands of members of a strange clan; it is here that we must seek the reason for the fact that women have no rights in relation to the property belonging to their kin group. Among the Yakuts, the latter, as is the case everywhere with peoples on a low level of economic development, permits a girl to accumulate property by her personal labor: the product of her personal exertions, whether sewing or other handicraft, becomes part of her possessions, but among the Yakuts, as is the case everywhere, the girl secures the right of ownership of the products of her labor only in the degree that she performs this labor during her hours of leisure and rest, after having performed the household duties which fall to her share. The same rule, it appears, applies 44 to married women. Woman, as a member of her kin group prior to marriage, and subsequently in the capacity of a worker for her husband and his group, has only a portion of the time for her own use, and the group concedes to her as personal property only what she can produce after satisfying the needs of her father’s or her husband’s family.' [555] 'The absence of property rights on the part of women in relation to their kin group in graphically expressed in the exclusion of women from inheritance. If the economic and administrative principle lying at the foundation of the family constructed on a blood basis makes quite natural the rule of Yakut customary law, that sisters cannot inherit from brothers, that upon the death of a brother his cultivated land passes to another brother, although the latter might already have a farmstead, then in the exclusion of women from inheritance from the parents, where only daughters survived, we must see a direct consequence of the clan structure, in which the kinsmen vigilantly watch to see that the clan property does not pass to a strange clan, which inevitably happens in the case of the marriage of a girl-legatee.' [556] 'M. Pripuzov informs us that upon the death of a person survived only by daughters, the legatees are in the first place his brothers, i. e., the uncles on the paternal side. Further, if the father of the deceased is alive, then by the general rule of Yakut customary law in the district investigated, which makes the parents the legatees of their children deceased without issue, he secures a larger share of the inheritance than the other relations. Where death takes place without male issue, the situation is the same as if there were no issue at all. Finally, the remaining relations come in for their share of the inheritance. A part of the property is set aside for the support and subsistence of the daughters, the remainder is divided between the relations with the closer relations securing a larger part (the father gets more than the rest), while the more distant relatives get a lesser share. A married daughter, like the unmarried daughters, is excluded form sharing in the paternal inheritance: in any case, she cannot inherit her father’s cultivated land, and if there are no direct heirs, the farm passes to the closest relations.' [557] 'The brothers, excluding their sisters from inheritance of the paternal property, are nevertheless obliged to support their unmarried sisters, to concern themselves with giving them in marriage, and to provide them with dowries from the general property. Mr. Priklonski, however, (Tri goda v[unknown] IAkutskoi oblasti [three years in the Yakutsk territory]. Zhiva[unknown]ia Starina, 1890, pt. 3, p. 80). notes that the share of the daughters in the division of property upon the death of the father is equal to that of the brothers; this share goes to the brothers, for the support of the sisters.' [558] 'That in effect it is the economic principle, in union with the blood principle, and not the fact of the grant of a dowry to a girl entering into marriage, that lies at the basis of the exclusion of women from the paternal inheritance, is demonstrated by the fact that the dowry itself does not in any way correspond to the shares which fall to the lot of the sons upon the death of the father. Mr. Pripuzov unfortunately communicates only extremely fragmentary and incomplete information concerning the size of the dowry, concerning the objects which go to make it up, and concerning the relation of the personal property of the girl, accumulated by her own labor, to the dowry given by her parents at the time of marriage.' [559] While elders needed to approve of inheritance and transfers, fathers generally passed on livestock to their sons. We have considered this to be a form of private property.

♠ Usufruct ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of usufruct arrangements.
♠ Exclusivity ♣ present ♥ Differential investment in sons and daughters was guided by the desire to exclude other clans from the property held by the patrilineage (see above).
♠ Partibility ♣ present ♥ Fathers preferentially passed on property to eldest sons, but younger sons also inherited wealth (see above).
♠ Lease ♣ present ♥ Debt obligations were covered by 'interest' payments. Livestock was used as security: 'Debt obligations are protected by the security or deposit of cattle. The lender obtains in the manner of a reward either a present of two percent of the sum of the debt. A debt incurred under the influence of deceit or in an intoxicated condition is not considered valid. Even if the eldest in the family incurred it, the family can demand the nullification of the obligation. Card debts are also considered invalid, no matter whether the loser was drunk or sober at the time of playing. A defaulting debtor is condemned by the elders not only to pay the debt, but also to pay the interest on the debt which has accumulated between the term of payment and the time of judicial proceedings, as well as the expenses borne by the creditor in entering the action. In trifling cases the elders are content 64 to satisfy the debt by taking from the defaulting debtor his excess clothing.' [560] Wealthy househelds used to lend livestock to poor ones for upkeep, and failure to comply with agreed upon arrangements was punished: 'Up to the present time there has existed the custom of rich men lending reindeer “gratis” to poor men, which cannot help leading to cases of open or hidden exploitation. Usually in the autumn the nearby poor men descend on a rich person and take reindeer from him for their needs for a month, for two months, or until spring, depending on the understanding; and if the borrowed reindeer is killed by a wolf or dies of a disease, the poor man does not have to make good the loss, but merely brings the hide from the reindeer’s leg to the owner. An especially favorable environment for exploitation is formed when reindeer are lent to a poor man to import government loads: in this case the rich man gives the poor man several extra reindeer in order that the poor man may import the alloted load on them, and for this labor the latter is not repaid in any way, but the money for transporting the goods goes to the owner of the reindeer. The advantage of such an arrangement becomes clear when one realizes that under this system the rich man does not have to hire draymen at his own expense.' [561] '1. Among the financial obligations of the Yakut, the most important and necessary, both for the rich and poor, is the maintenance of animals, because it gives the former a chance to increase their herds, and the latter a means of subsistence and of paying taxes and duties. This the rich, including Russians of various ranks, give a certain number of animals to poor Yakut and to Yakut of moderate means: from ten to 40 head to one family for one year, from May to May of the following year, for a payment which is fixed and agreed upon [Page 26] mutually; for instance, a person who takes 20 head of cattle is paid 20 rubles in cash for feeding this number of cattle, four milch cows, figuring their milk at 10 to 15 rubles, which is not counted in the amount for maintaining the cattle, one bull for harnessing, figuring the “body” for him at three to five rubles; for this amount, and sometimes more, the keeper, called the cattleman, must pasture the animals in the summer and the winter give them hay which he has prepared on his lands, so as to return them stout and healthy in the spring. The milk from the dun-colored cows, excluding those given him to feed, he must deliver to the owner in October in the form of butter and sour milk; he must guard the animals 238 from death or loss; and, in case he does lose any, or they are stolen or die for any reason, he must pay for them in kind or in money, except in case of infection or natural disease, or in case the thief makes the payment.' [562] '2. If the keeper uses an animal for his own needs, willfully and without the consent of the owner, he pays for it in kind, and is beaten with rods for his willfulness.' [563] '3. If he keeps an animal himself and says that it has been lost or stolen, or if he deliberately kills it, which frequently happens, as he may want to eat its meat, and says that it has died in some way, and his lie is discovered, he is beaten with rods and must pay as a thief.' [564] We have considered this to be a form of lease.
♠ Lease Rights ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Transfer of property ♣ present ♥ Property was held and passed on within patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [565] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [566] 'By customary law, land, cattle, and horses, although used by households, were controlled by the patriline. Animal or land sale and inheritance was approved by elders. But by the twentieth century, smaller families were keeping resources, in part because of the decline of large horse droves. Men owned most of the wealth, and passed it to sons, especially elder sons, although the youngest son often inherited the family yurt. Mothers could pass on dowries to daughters, unless the dowry was forfeited by bad behavior. In theory, dowries included land, as well as goods, jewelry, and animals, although in practice elders rarely gave land to another lineage. Soviet law limited inheritance to goods and nonstate housing could be bequeathed at individual discretion. Most apartments and summer houses were kept in families.' [567] Accordingly, the property and inheritance rights were generally concentrated in men: 'The property rights of women are extremely limited; however, even in this direction certain changes are taking place under the influence of the gradual recognition of woman’s capacity. These innovations, however, are apparently only beginning to penetrate the consciousness of the Yakuts, and have not yet succeeded in conclusively changing the archaic views, denying property rights to women.' [568] 'In relations to her own family group the woman is completely without rights: she must marry into a strange clan, and it is understandable that her kinsmen look upon her as a severed member.' [569] 'Each clan or familial unit, under the influence of the impulse of self-preservation in the struggle for existence, strives insofar as possible to insure its economic existence through the accumulation of wealth. Naturally, it jealously guards its property against transfer into the hands of members of a strange clan; it is here that we must seek the reason for the fact that women have no rights in relation to the property belonging to their kin group. Among the Yakuts, the latter, as is the case everywhere with peoples on a low level of economic development, permits a girl to accumulate property by her personal labor: the product of her personal exertions, whether sewing or other handicraft, becomes part of her possessions, but among the Yakuts, as is the case everywhere, the girl secures the right of ownership of the products of her labor only in the degree that she performs this labor during her hours of leisure and rest, after having performed the household duties which fall to her share. The same rule, it appears, applies 44 to married women. Woman, as a member of her kin group prior to marriage, and subsequently in the capacity of a worker for her husband and his group, has only a portion of the time for her own use, and the group concedes to her as personal property only what she can produce after satisfying the needs of her father’s or her husband’s family.' [570] 'The absence of property rights on the part of women in relation to their kin group in graphically expressed in the exclusion of women from inheritance. If the economic and administrative principle lying at the foundation of the family constructed on a blood basis makes quite natural the rule of Yakut customary law, that sisters cannot inherit from brothers, that upon the death of a brother his cultivated land passes to another brother, although the latter might already have a farmstead, then in the exclusion of women from inheritance from the parents, where only daughters survived, we must see a direct consequence of the clan structure, in which the kinsmen vigilantly watch to see that the clan property does not pass to a strange clan, which inevitably happens in the case of the marriage of a girl-legatee.' [571] 'M. Pripuzov informs us that upon the death of a person survived only by daughters, the legatees are in the first place his brothers, i. e., the uncles on the paternal side. Further, if the father of the deceased is alive, then by the general rule of Yakut customary law in the district investigated, which makes the parents the legatees of their children deceased without issue, he secures a larger share of the inheritance than the other relations. Where death takes place without male issue, the situation is the same as if there were no issue at all. Finally, the remaining relations come in for their share of the inheritance. A part of the property is set aside for the support and subsistence of the daughters, the remainder is divided between the relations with the closer relations securing a larger part (the father gets more than the rest), while the more distant relatives get a lesser share. A married daughter, like the unmarried daughters, is excluded form sharing in the paternal inheritance: in any case, she cannot inherit her father’s cultivated land, and if there are no direct heirs, the farm passes to the closest relations.' [572] 'The brothers, excluding their sisters from inheritance of the paternal property, are nevertheless obliged to support their unmarried sisters, to concern themselves with giving them in marriage, and to provide them with dowries from the general property. Mr. Priklonski, however, (Tri goda v[unknown] IAkutskoi oblasti [three years in the Yakutsk territory]. Zhiva[unknown]ia Starina, 1890, pt. 3, p. 80). notes that the share of the daughters in the division of property upon the death of the father is equal to that of the brothers; this share goes to the brothers, for the support of the sisters.' [573] 'That in effect it is the economic principle, in union with the blood principle, and not the fact of the grant of a dowry to a girl entering into marriage, that lies at the basis of the exclusion of women from the paternal inheritance, is demonstrated by the fact that the dowry itself does not in any way correspond to the shares which fall to the lot of the sons upon the death of the father. Mr. Pripuzov unfortunately communicates only extremely fragmentary and incomplete information concerning the size of the dowry, concerning the objects which go to make it up, and concerning the relation of the personal property of the girl, accumulated by her own labor, to the dowry given by her parents at the time of marriage.' [574]
♠ Use of property ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of this (see above).
♠ Property market ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of this (see above).

♠ Other property ownership ♣ present ♥ Brides brought dowry into the marriage: 'The deer with the exception of those received by the wife as a present from her relatives ( nyadzhyma ), or from the guests ( yallaty taba ), or those harnessed to her narta or to the nartas loaded [Page 41] with her things (plates, garments and small objects used in domestic life), were regarded as the property of the husband. Excepted were also the deer which the children received as a present from their relatives. The contents of the sleighs given in dowry, including plates, animal skins, and money were regarded as the property of the wife. This property could be used by the woman at her own discretion. Some husbands tried to hinder such independent use of her property by the wife, but such conduct was regarded as a violation of the local law. The woman had also the right to spend at her own discretion the money received by her from the sale of the property that belonged to her. The Dolgani believed that the deer included in the dowry brought in luck, and in some families no such deer would be sold in the course of three years. Various members of the family--the wife, the sons, and the daughters could own their own pasti traps. This ownership was, however, but a fiction, since all the polar foxes caught in the traps were regarded as the property of the father. The fiction of ownership is to be explained by the following belief: when for a long time no animals would be caught in the pasti, the father of the family, who was their real owner, thought that the cause of this poor hunting was the departure of his luck, but that the animals may still be caught by the luck possessed by some of the other members of the family. Acting on this belief the father would then make a nominal distribution of his pasti among the members of his family. When a daughter got married such pastis, which were only her nominal property, were retained by the father.' [575] 'When the widow married a fellow clansman the property of her dead husband remained with her. On the other hand, if she married into an alien clan, she would be left with a small share, while the rest of the dead husband's property would be retained by the latter's clan. This arrangement was based on the view that a tranfer of property to an alien clan should not be permitted ( bay omukka barara tyukteri ).' [576] As mentioned above, pastoralists herded and owned livestock, including cattle, horses and reindeer: 'The reindeer, which is an object of private property, is marked by each owner with a particular sign called the belie. The most reliable markings are considered to be figures made by making cuts in the ears of the animal, without making any distinction between the right and left ear; these ear cuts have different appellations depending on their form [Fig. 17]. Independently of the markings on the ears, the natives cut signs with a knife in the form of different combinations of lines in the hair on the sides of the reindeer [Fig. 18]. They do this in the month of the spring sunrise, after the polar night--the time of severe cold--has passed, in order that the reindeer may not get frostbitten in the places where the hair has been cut off. The signs of ownership are the same both for bucks and for mares. Cult signs, as among the Tavgi, are not found among the Dolgan. When the children of a family grow up and are given part of the reindeer herd for their own, the old markings are left on the grown reindeer, and the new markings are put only on the offspring. The youngest son, who is the last in line to receive the family wealth, receives his father’s markings by inheritance. The markings of the husband are put on reindeer which are received as part of a dowry. When an owner buys another reindeer he cuts his own markings into its ears, and one may often see reindeer with several markings in their ears. It must be added that when an owner has a large herd not all the reindeer are marked with the signs of ownership. The Dolgan have an amazing ability [Facing 198: Figure 16 on an unpaginated insert] 199 to recognize their own reindeer even after several years have passed, and even when the reindeer were only calves when last seen. Rich reindeer breeders often have more reindeer in their herds than they can count, but if they see one of their own reindeer in someone else’s herd they recognize it at once, even if it has no markings; at the same time they are unable to say which [Page 19] reindeer are missing in their own herds. We tried to find out how this was done, but even the Dolgan themselves could not explain it, but only said that it was so simple because the eye “gets used to” one’s own reindeer. [Fig. 17] If a strange reindeer attaches himself to a herd the owner of the herd passes the word along and supports the reindeer until its owner is found.' [577] However, their treatment as private property may be of recent origin: 'It must be concluded that the custom of regarding reindeer as private property did not arise so long ago--perhaps even after the Russians came--which can be seen from the following: 1) in summer the reindeer owned by a rich man are treated as a food supply for the whole nomadic group in case of insufficiency of wild animals and birds; in such cases the reindeer are killed without any compensation for the owner; 2) the fact that it is only within the last few decades that the reindeer has become an object of merchandise. These questions are considered in greater detail in our work on the Dolgan clan, and for this reason we shall not dwell on them here.' [578] Men and women also owned household goods (see above).

Inheritance System

♠ partible inheritance ♣ present ♥ Livestock was preferentially passed on from fathers to eldest sons, but younger sons also inherited wealth, for example in the form of yurts (see below).
♠ patrilineal inheritance ♣ present ♥ Sakha society was organized in patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [579] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [580] Property was passed on within patrilineages: 'By customary law, land, cattle, and horses, although used by households, were controlled by the patriline. Animal or land sale and inheritance was approved by elders. But by the twentieth century, smaller families were keeping resources, in part because of the decline of large horse droves. Men owned most of the wealth, and passed it to sons, especially elder sons, although the youngest son often inherited the family yurt. Mothers could pass on dowries to daughters, unless the dowry was forfeited by bad behavior. In theory, dowries included land, as well as goods, jewelry, and animals, although in practice elders rarely gave land to another lineage. Soviet law limited inheritance to goods and nonstate housing could be bequeathed at individual discretion. Most apartments and summer houses were kept in families.' [581] Accordingly, the property and inheritance rights of women were limited, although their legal status improved during the Russian period: 'The property rights of women are extremely limited; however, even in this direction certain changes are taking place under the influence of the gradual recognition of woman’s capacity. These innovations, however, are apparently only beginning to penetrate the consciousness of the Yakuts, and have not yet succeeded in conclusively changing the archaic views, denying property rights to women.' [582] 'In relations to her own family group the woman is completely without rights: she must marry into a strange clan, and it is understandable that her kinsmen look upon her as a severed member.' [583] 'Each clan or familial unit, under the influence of the impulse of self-preservation in the struggle for existence, strives insofar as possible to insure its economic existence through the accumulation of wealth. Naturally, it jealously guards its property against transfer into the hands of members of a strange clan; it is here that we must seek the reason for the fact that women have no rights in relation to the property belonging to their kin group. Among the Yakuts, the latter, as is the case everywhere with peoples on a low level of economic development, permits a girl to accumulate property by her personal labor: the product of her personal exertions, whether sewing or other handicraft, becomes part of her possessions, but among the Yakuts, as is the case everywhere, the girl secures the right of ownership of the products of her labor only in the degree that she performs this labor during her hours of leisure and rest, after having performed the household duties which fall to her share. The same rule, it appears, applies 44 to married women. Woman, as a member of her kin group prior to marriage, and subsequently in the capacity of a worker for her husband and his group, has only a portion of the time for her own use, and the group concedes to her as personal property only what she can produce after satisfying the needs of her father’s or her husband’s family.' [584] 'The absence of property rights on the part of women in relation to their kin group in graphically expressed in the exclusion of women from inheritance. If the economic and administrative principle lying at the foundation of the family constructed on a blood basis makes quite natural the rule of Yakut customary law, that sisters cannot inherit from brothers, that upon the death of a brother his cultivated land passes to another brother, although the latter might already have a farmstead, then in the exclusion of women from inheritance from the parents, where only daughters survived, we must see a direct consequence of the clan structure, in which the kinsmen vigilantly watch to see that the clan property does not pass to a strange clan, which inevitably happens in the case of the marriage of a girl-legatee.' [585] 'M. Pripuzov informs us that upon the death of a person survived only by daughters, the legatees are in the first place his brothers, i. e., the uncles on the paternal side. Further, if the father of the deceased is alive, then by the general rule of Yakut customary law in the district investigated, which makes the parents the legatees of their children deceased without issue, he secures a larger share of the inheritance than the other relations. Where death takes place without male issue, the situation is the same as if there were no issue at all. Finally, the remaining relations come in for their share of the inheritance. A part of the property is set aside for the support and subsistence of the daughters, the remainder is divided between the relations with the closer relations securing a larger part (the father gets more than the rest), while the more distant relatives get a lesser share. A married daughter, like the unmarried daughters, is excluded form sharing in the paternal inheritance: in any case, she cannot inherit her father’s cultivated land, and if there are no direct heirs, the farm passes to the closest relations.' [586] 'The brothers, excluding their sisters from inheritance of the paternal property, are nevertheless obliged to support their unmarried sisters, to concern themselves with giving them in marriage, and to provide them with dowries from the general property. Mr. Priklonski, however, (Tri goda v[unknown] IAkutskoi oblasti [three years in the Yakutsk territory]. Zhiva[unknown]ia Starina, 1890, pt. 3, p. 80). notes that the share of the daughters in the division of property upon the death of the father is equal to that of the brothers; this share goes to the brothers, for the support of the sisters.' [587] 'That in effect it is the economic principle, in union with the blood principle, and not the fact of the grant of a dowry to a girl entering into marriage, that lies at the basis of the exclusion of women from the paternal inheritance, is demonstrated by the fact that the dowry itself does not in any way correspond to the shares which fall to the lot of the sons upon the death of the father. Mr. Pripuzov unfortunately communicates only extremely fragmentary and incomplete information concerning the size of the dowry, concerning the objects which go to make it up, and concerning the relation of the personal property of the girl, accumulated by her own labor, to the dowry given by her parents at the time of marriage.' [588]
♠ matrilineal inheritance ♣ present ♥ Mothers could pass on dowry to daughters, but property rights of women were generally limited (see above).
♠ primogeniture inheritance by only males ♣ absent ♥ Livestock was preferentially passed on from fathers to eldest sons, but younger sons also inherited wealth, for example in the form of yurts (see above).
♠ primogeniture inheritance by males and females ♣ absent ♥
♠ other inheritance practices ♣ absent ♥
♠ Trusts ♣ absent ♥ We are unsure whether clans could be considered trusts. We have assumed this not to be the case for the time being.
♠ State expropriation ♣ absent ♥ It appears that explicit state expropriation only started in the Soviet period (see above). This remains in need of confirmation. More material is needed.
♠ Non-state expropriation ♣ absent ♥

Equity[edit]

Sex Class and Race[edit]

♠ Monogamy ♣ present ♥ Sakha society was organized in patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [589] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [590] eHRAF provides a general description of the marriage system. While polygyny was practiced, monogamy was more common: 'Traditionally, for wealthy Yakut, marriage could be polygamous. More common, however, was monogamy, with occasional remarriage after the death of a spouse. Arranged marriages were sometimes politically motivated. Patrilineage exogamy was reckoned strictly; those one could marry were called SYGAN. Until the 1920s many marriage arrangements were complicated and protracted, involving financial, emotional, and symbolic resources of the bride's and groom's extended families. This included the matchmaking ritual; several formal payments of animals, furs, and meat to the bride's family; informal gifts; and extensive dowries. Some families permitted poor grooms to work in their households as a replacement for the bride-price. Occasionally bride-capture occurred (it may have been more common in pre-Russian times). Wedding ceremonies and their attendant feasts, prayers, and dancing, were held first at the household of the bride's parents, then at that of the groom's. The couple usually lived or settled in a nearby yurt. Since the 1970s interest in limited aspects of ritual and gift exchange has revived, although few couples are paired through matchmakers. In the 1980s one young man was chagrined to find that a woman he had fallen in love with on a train was a distant cousin, a forbidden marriage partner according to kin rules still observed.' [591] 'Polygamy has existed since ancient times among many of the Yakut; however, a man never had more than five wives at a time. The reasons for this are as follows: 1) the Yakut promise their children in marriage at an early age, and the children, by the time they are of age, have ceased to love one another, and therefore the husband takes a second wife; 2) if a man lives with his wife for several years without having any children, he takes a second and a third merely in order to have children; 3) the rich Yakut had many wives to supervise their houses and cattle, which they usually had in many places, for the wives ran their estates more diligently than outside hired men; thus the farm is improved and the estate is guarded; 4) if they leave their wives, even those whom they have married in church, because of some bad behavior or because they are permanently delirious, or rendered completely incapable of taking care of house and cattle as a result of some disease which deprived them of sight, speech, arms, and legs, since the Yakut leave the whole house and cattle-raising to the wife's care, they take other wives and leave the former one's in their houses; 5) various other circumstances induce the Yakut to practise polygamy; the principle reason is the desire to have good supervision of the households and an increase of the cattle; 6) having had several 221 wives before conversion, and having married one in church after conversion but without abandoning the others, the Yakut will keep them in his [Page 15] houses with their children, and some without children because they are sterile. Such polygamy, which is tolerated for the above reasons, and which has existed since ancient times and does not do any harm, had not become bad in the judgement of the Yakut, and no regulations for the abolition of this custom have been set up by the Yakut. However, since the Yakut adopted the Christian faith, and as they have become enlightened by strict surveillance and sometimes by indulgent reprimands from the eparchial priests, it has been gradually dying out, but nevertheless denunciations on this subject are made concerning people who have lawfully wedded wives but keep the others, and people who had several wives before conversion and married one of them in church without leaving the others, who were left at home with their children; in the case of such a denunciation the local authorities, on the grounds of the repugnance of the Christian religion for this custom, pressed formal charges, and the guilty parties were handed over to the clerical court as fornicators, and the cases were decided according to general state laws, which constituted and still constitute and extreme burden for the Yakut.' [592] Exogamy was the norm, and the sources mention bride-price and dowry arrangements: 'To the end of the eighteenth century, there remained in vogue among the Yakut the custom of concession of wives. Formerly the bridegroom lived permanently in the house of his father-in-law, but in more recent times he lived there only for a definite period.' [593] 'The kalym, or bride-price, replaced the system of marriage by capture. The origin of the kalym may be seen in the simulated enmity of the mother-in-law and the son-in-law.' [594] 'A matriarchal system presupposes looseness of sex relations. The chastity of girls in rich families is not a question of morality but of kalym . The kalym for a widow or a girl who has had children is low. In the case of a widow, the belief in the right of the deceased husband may limit the number of wooers. A girl with a child, however, is sometimes preferred as a guaranty against barrenness which the Yakut dislike. In Yakut tales, the guest does not ask, “Where shall I sleep?”, but, “Where do you put your guests?” and then they are shown to the beds of the girls. This is a form of hospitable hetaerism.' [595] 'The Yakut look for brides for their sons not only outside of their clans ( us, nasleg ), but outside of the ulus, or union of clans. A girl, say the Yakut, is really a lot of aliens. This saying is reminiscent of the old time marriage by capture. Marriage is now also exogamic, but kalym (brideprice) is given in money, cattle, and other goods. Practically, the kalym may be regarded as an exchange of presents. What the parents of the bride receive from the parents of the bridegroom is almost equivalent to what they give her when she leaves their house. Often the bride carries with her cattle and goods of a greater value than her parents received that she may not be reproached by the bridegroom’s relatives for bringing only a small dowry with her. The young bride remains under the protection of her clan and family. Many common law customs regulate disagreements and dissensions: If a young woman leaves her husband because she dislikes him, her dowry remains with him; but, if she accuses him of cruelties, relatives on both sides decide the matter. The Yakut do not like to appeal to the Russian courts.' [596] 'The Yakut were warlike and blood vengeance between clans occurred very often, but reconciliation was often sought through payment of a ransom or by giving a girl in marriage, the best way to end hostilities. It was more difficult to compound assassinations within the clan. To kill the murderer would deprive the clan of another member and the punishment had to take the form of ransom, service, or public disapproval.' [597] Sieroszewski describes these payments: 'If we analyse the component parts of the kalym and their names and designations we see that this expense is always the essential part of the payment for a bride. The amount of the kalym aries greatly, between several rubles and several hundred rubles. Sometimes it is even as much as one and one-half or two thousand rubles. Usually the amount is somewhere around the mean between these figures - that is, one hundred rubles. Most families would not have the means to pay so large an amount were it not for the fact that most of it is returned in the form of a dowry.' [598] 'According to custom only the kurum, hat is, the part that goes for hospitality, and other minor additions for the same purpose, [Page 857] are paid by the bridegroom without return. The payment given to the bride's parents, sulu, and the presents given to the relatives and match-makers, tyunngyur-khodogoy kesite, is afterwards given back in the form of a dowry, enne, and presents, 546 torkyut. Since the bridegroom usually assumes his conjungal rights immediately after the festivities, if he dies the kurum is never given back, but only half of the sulu, if this has been paid. The amounts of various parts of the kalym are strictly 547 determined by the agreement, [Page 858 is blank] [Page 859] kil'tegan. It also varies greatly in different localities, and depends on the force of the ancient customs, and the prosperity and way of life of the inhabitants. Even in the same locality it differs for each wedded couple, depending on the affluence of their parents, their stinginess or generosity and their attachment to their children.' [599] 'The Yakut maintain that in older days the kalym was bigger, and I have noticed that it is infact larger in less cultured localities, where the ancient customs are still strong. Thus the amount of cattle exchanged and killed at weddings in the Kolymsk and Verkhoyansk uluses or in remote uluses of the Yakutsk Okrug is a considerably greater part of the total property of those who are getting married that in more cultured localities, near a city or in the south, despite the fact that there is more cattle in the south. In the latter uluses we notice a tendency to convert the larger part of the kalym into money, and to replace the meat offered as hospitality with flour, butter, and vodka, for which no norms and rules have been worked out. This allows this part of the expense to be decreased unnoticably. Nowhere, however, has the kalym disappeared, and poor people will often slaughter their only cow or mare for a wedding, as the bridegroom's present, so that the parents only had to give around ten rubles in money as payment for the bride, sulu. In the meantime, it is their duty to dress the bride and give her at least a few household utensils. To be sure, there are people who give their daughter very little or nothing at all even though they have received a considerable kalym.' [600] 'However, such cases are rare. They are either a result of the sudden impoverishment of a heretofore rich family or a consequence of a bridegroom's particular passion for a girl, which her parents notice and which they never miss a chance to profit by.' [601] 'Popular opinion condemns such behavior. Nevertheless I have seen very respected and even loving fathers who sucked all they could get from their sons-in-law when they visited their brides, still living 548 at home. Parents never give their daughters to their husbands immediately after the wedding. This is the custom, and parents also give as an excuse either that they must prepare the dowry, or that their daughter is unaccustomed to marriage, or that she is too young, and so forth; this is true even if they have been married and the kalym has been paid, or the agreement has been made to pay it immediately. In the old days this state sometimes lasted for four or five years, and still earlier the Yakut had the custom to marry their children when they were very young. During this time the bridegroom visits his bride at his leisure and must bring her a present each time he does so - a thigh piece or two of meat, a fox, or some other present, as payment for being allowed to exercise his conjungal rights. More than once I have heard fathers order this thing or that - sometimes a great deal. The son-in-law obediently heard him out, but grumbled once out of sight and carried out only part of the promise. Often all this is a burdensome addition to the conditions agreed upon when the match was arranged.' [602] 'When that time comes, and the bride brings less to the house than was expected, the bridegroom's relatives greet her very coldly. If the dowry is less than the amount agreed upon lawsuits and hostility [Page 861] begin. Often a complete break in relations takes place, if the marriage had not been sanctified in church. In the latter case the young bride is forced to remain in her bridegroom's home, but must suffer all sorts of nagging and persecution on the part of the family which absolutely poison her existence. I know of several cases when this persecution drove young women to flight or suicide. This is why Yakut who love their daughters try to give them as large a dowry as possible, so that her husband, father-in-law, and mother-in-law would respect her. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883; Namsk Ulus, 1891). It is also easy to understand why parents try in every way possible to make their daughters' dowries appear larger than they actually are, just as the bridegroom's family tries to exaggerate the size of the kalym they have paid.' [603] Samokvasov also provides a summary: 'When the Yakut marry, they give an agreed number of living and slaughtered cattle, and sometimes money, in installments, which is called kalym, for the wife. To compensate this loss, the bride's parents or her relatives who have arranged the match, give as a 222 dowry cattle, clothing, and sometimes money, for half of the whole agreed kalym. The wife cannot bring a dowry worth less than half the kalym, and to bring more, sometimes exceeding the whole kalym (which very rarely happens) is a matter for the discretion of her parents. Besides this, the bridegroom gives cattle to the bride's relatives at the wedding--or money, or animal skins. For these gifts, his wife, for a certain time, when she visits those relatives with presents for them, receives gifts herself, no less than ten head of cattle from each, or three times the value of the original gifts and the presents which she took with her. The excess of these gifts over the original gifts and presents is included in the compensation for the kalym. Therefore, in case of a rupture of the marriage, the wife or her relatives return the kalym to the husband, minus the dowry and the excess of the gifts; from which it follows that the Yakut wife possesses no property, unless she brought a dowry larger than the kalym, and unless she receives an award from her relatives or others after her marriage. Suits concerning kalyms have various causes, of which [Page 16] the main ones are the following: 1) Having lives several years with her husband, a wife suddenly leaves him on the grounds that he does not have any natural capacity for carnal relations; sometimes this is just, and, in that case, she is judged innocent; however, the kalym is returned, minus offspring and milk, but not until she marries another husband; but if her claim proves to be false, this proves her guilt and the fact that she left her husband because of lack of affectionate disposition to him; therefore, if she does not agree to stay with her husband, she herself, or her relatives pay back the kalym at the time of the divorce, with offspring and milk. 2) At the instigation of other, women marry them, and 223 in such a case, the instigators pay the kalym and all damages and are beaten with rods. 3)A husband abandons his wife: a)because of her dissolute behavior and poor running of the house; b) because of dislike for her, and as very frequently happens, dissoluteness of his own and love for another woman; in cases of this sort, the husband loses the right to demand the kalym. 4) Having taken each other during childhood by the will of the parents, and having no mutual affection, a couple divorce, and the wife's father or the relatives who married her off return half the kalym at the time of the divorce and the other half when she marries another man. 5) If a husband leaves his wife without any compelling reasons, not only does he not get the kalym back but he has to return the clothing and other objects of the dowry; the same right is enjoyed by the wife who leaves her husband because of cruel and mean treatment of her. 6) If a wife leaves her husband without any compelling reasons, her parents or the relatives who married her off must return the whole kalym, with the right of giving her in marriage for a kalym a second time. 7) If a wife's husband dies, the husband's parents do not have the right to give her in marriage again, but she herself, if she does not wish to stay in her husband's house, is free to marry without a kalym. 8) If a bride dies after being promised in marriage but still living at her father's house, and if there she had no sexual relations with the bridegroom, the whole kalym is returned immediately after her death, minus offspring and milk; but if she dies after having had sexual relations, a half-kalym is returned, without offspring or milk; when a widow marries a second time, similarly, the payment is made to the husband's relatives, if he dies after the promising of the bride but before she is taken into the house. 9) After a bride is promised to a bridegroom, after part or sometimes 224 all of the [Page 17] agreed kalym is paid, without any sins on the part of either bride or bridegroom, if the relatives are dissatisfied or if other potential mates are preferred or for various other reasons, and the bride or bridegroom refuses to marry, the bridegroom (if he is the one who refuses) is deprived of all the kalym which he has paid, and the bride (if she refuses) pays the bridegroom the whole kalym which he paid, plus offspring, milk, and other damages, even if she had sexual relations with him. 10) If the bridegroom of a promised bride proves unable to pay all or part of the kalym, then, if there were no carnal relations between the contracting parties, the bride and her relatives are free to refuse to proceed, and they return what he has paid; if there was sexual intercourse, the marriage is cancelled, but the kalym is paid, like an ordinary debt, through earnings, etc. 11) If the husband, after having the bride promised to him and having sexual intercourse with her, leaves her for three years without lawful reasons and does not take her, such a woman is free to marry another without giving back the kalym to the first one. 12) At the time of the wedding both the bride and the groom eat cattle, which is taken into account in case of a divorce, and this loss is paid by the one who is guilty in the divorce case.' [604] Endogamy was more common among rich families in the North: 'We have previously mentioned the exogamic character of the Yakut marriages, but some other tendencies have been observed in the northern districts of Yakut Province. The few rich families endeavor to keep their horses, cattle, and grazing places within a certain group of families through marriage of close relatives, insofar as this is permitted by the Russian church. By special permission of a bishop, even cousins are permitted to marry. In one case, known to the author, a man lived with his niece, a marital relation forbidden by the Church, though his neighbors avoided mentioning this irregularity to strangers.' [605] Wives/widows generally held fewer rights than men, but their legal status was improved during the Russian period: 'The absence of any rights on the part of woman, among the Yakuts of the district studied by M. Pripuzov, is most marked. . . in the field of property relations. Her personal position is at the present time considerably better protected than in earlier times. In this respect one notes in the life of the Yakuts a definite, although naturally a very relative progress. In effect, even at present, the husband considers himself within his rights to beat up his wife if she neglects her household duties, if she is a spendthrift, or if she is unfaithful to him.
