However, the unequal distribution of the livestock was by no means anything new for the Yakuts. But the question of land was different. The system which had grown up in the domain of land tenure was of comparatively recent origin. Since the arrival of the Russians in Yakutiya, the process of decomposition of the ancient communal-clan system of using the meadowland had been stepped up. The toyons were vigorously seeking to acquire the common lands. The development of private land ownership by the toyons continued to the 1760’s, when certain measures introduced by the Russian administration gave it a new direction. In 1765, Yakuts were forbidden to buy or sell land, and in the next few years, through the activity of the Yakut Tribute Commission, the distribution of land in accordance with the so-called “sable” and “fox” taxes or parts of them was introduced among the Yakuts. Later on, in about 1820, this distribution of land assumed the form of the so-called “class system” of land usage, which legalized the extremely unequal distribution of the land, though, on the surface, it seemed to be something like common land usage. This “class system,” which was later modified, had assumed the following form by the beginning of the 20th century.' [686] 'The unit of measurement of land among the Yakuts was the “rick” ([unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown]), a plot of land from which one hayrick could be mown (the size of the rick ranged from 10 to 30 cartloads, sometimes as many as 40 or 60). These allotments made up plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) which were extremely varied in size, depending on the “class,” and there were three or four “classes.” One first-class plot ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ) was equal to two secondclass plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] [unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) and three or four third-class plots (kenniki or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ). The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called[unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] -[unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). [Page 272] Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [687] 'In the second half of the 19th century the custom of equalizing of the land each year in accordance with the yield of grass came into use. The harvest was evaluated by elected “deputies,” and those whose harvest was poorer than it should have been in view of the plot had the right to an extra quota of hay, and vice versa. This was called bebierke (from the Russian word poverka [adjustment]). But in actual fact this custom did not reduce inequality, for the “deputies” always acted in favor of the more influential (toyon) section of the population, to which they themselves very often belonged.' [688] Tokarev describes the system of labour and cattle hire as a form of institutionalized exploitation: 'Generally speaking, the toyons possessed a large proportion of the available land, and the best part, to boot. For example, in 1908 two-thirds of all the land in the First Ospetskiy Nasleg in the Dyupsyunskiy Ulus belonged to five toyon households. In the Suntarskiy Ulus the toyons, who made up only 7% of the total population, possessed approximately half the land. By 1917, 55% of all the usable land was possessed by the rich people. By owning land and livestock the toyons were in a position to exploit the needy masses of the population. The forms that the exploitation took were greatly varied; they included elements characteristic of capitalist relations and the older patriarchal-feudal forms, as well as hidden survivals of slavery. For example, it was the practice to hire laborers—khamnachyts—usually for a definite period, particularly for haymaking; they were hired to carry firewood, build yurts and so on. They were paid either in money or in kind; and the method used was usually the typical Yakut system of payment (remuneration in advance), which was called “to take a contract” from the toyon for this or that work. This system of contracting was very advantageous to the richer people, since they then had complete power over the laborers. In return for a paltry sum received in advance, the poor person was sometimes in the toyon’s clutches for a long time to come.' [689] 'The system of contracting was also applied in other cases; advances were paid by the toyons for the supply of a whole variety of products, ranging from butter and hay right down to wild duck eggs. This system was a form of extremely cruel exploitation. One observer (V. F. Troshchanskiy, an exiled member of Narodnaya Volya wrote outright that the “welfare of the population will not be improved as long as this system exists in its present form.”' [690] 'Another very common form of exploitation was the handing over of the milch cattle to the poor people by the toyons for their use and for feeding, the so-called system of khahaas. At an earlier stage (at the beginning of the 19th century) the livestock was taken over, usually for a year, from spring to spring, but at the end of the 19th century it was more common to take over the cattle for only the summer (the distribution of livestock for feeding during the winter—uostur—was a separate process). In return for use of the cow, the poor peasant had to pay the toyon, as was the custom, 30 pounds of melted butter and 12-15 poods of tar (frozen sour milk) in the autumn; sometimes this was replaced or supplemented by compulsory service for the benefit [Page 273] of the toyon. This custom was a very typical and often extremely cruel form of exploitation. The winter upkeep of the livestock was a still more burdensome, enslaving agreement; in return for a head of cattle, the toyon usually paid 1 ruble, 50 kopeks or 2 rubles for the whole winter, whereas in actual fact the upkeep cost at least 5 rubles, and so it was only the poor peasants driven by need who entered into such agreements.' [691] 'A still more typical custom, the origin of which in ancient times was connected with mutual assistance between clan members, but which later became in fact one of the forms of exploitation, was kumalaanism. A kumalaan was a poor peasant, a disabled person, an orphan or sometimes all the members of an impoverished family, who were assigned by the whole community to live for a certain time with a rich man or wealthy kinsman who would maintain them. Officially, the adoption of a kumalaan was regarded as an act of charity, and a way of helping a kinsman in need. But in actual fact the custom concealed the cruelest exploitation of unpaid labor. In many cases it was a disguised form of slavery and lasted a long time.' [692] Toyons legitimated their superior position by presenting themselves as patriarchal benefactors: 'Apart from these individual customs, the Yakut society admittedly retained the characteristic, half-conscious patriarchal ideology, which was clearly not a reflection of their true relationships, although it served the interests of the toyons, who knew how to make use of it. The toyons liked to style themselves the forefathers, heads and sponsors of their clans; they skillfully fomented various interclan quarrels (usually [Page 276] over land), thereby sustaining the fiction of community of clan interests. A poor kinsman used to call a toyon who had robbed him of his possessions aga (father), and was expected to look upon him as his “benefactor.”' [693] Toyons also derived their names from deities: 'In the cult of both the benevolent and malevolent deities, a part was played at one stage by the military aristocracy—the toyons; they were usually the organizers. In their legendary genealogies the toyons often derived their names from the great and powerful deities.' [694] Most people were poor and of lower status: 'In pre-Revolutionary Yakutiya the poor and middle peasant families totaled more than 80 percent of all households. One-seventh of all the households were entirely without sowings, and many were only able to sow a few hundredths of a hectare each. Most of the households (97 percent) had to do without factory-made agricultural implements. Stockbreeding produced extremely poor results. The owners of large areas of land and abundant livestock i.e.,—the kulaks and toyons, grew rich, but not so much by raising the level of land cultivation and animal husbandry as by exploiting the poor and middle peasants.' [695] Coercion and exploitation exercisted by toyons continued into the early Soviet period: 'During the first two years of the Soviet regime the situation hardly changed for the better. There was redistribution of the land in 1923-24, but the reform only partly cut down the amount of land used by the toyons and virtually made no difference to the burdensome state of the poor people. For example, the nonrepartitional land expropriated by the toyons on the basis of their “clearing right” was left in their possession. It was only the second land reform of 1929 that put an end to toyon coercion and created a situation in which the agriculture of Yakutiya could be improved. About 150,000 hectares of the best land, formerly owned by the toyons and kulaks, then passed into the hands of the working peasantry.' [696] We are unsure whether this counts as a 'caste' system of sorts.

♠ social mobility ♣ absent ♥ Sakha society was organized in patrilineal clans, not social classes: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [697] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [698] 'By customary law, land, cattle, and horses, although used by households, were controlled by the patriline. Animal or land sale and inheritance was approved by elders. But by the twentieth century, smaller families were keeping resources, in part because of the decline of large horse droves. Men owned most of the wealth, and passed it to sons, especially elder sons, although the youngest son often inherited the family yurt. Mothers could pass on dowries to daughters, unless the dowry was forfeited by bad behavior. In theory, dowries included land, as well as goods, jewelry, and animals, although in practice elders rarely gave land to another lineage. Soviet law limited inheritance to goods and nonstate housing could be bequeathed at individual discretion. Most apartments and summer houses were kept in families.' [699] However, wealth stratification was present and Russian imperial authorities co-opted native toyons: 'Precise historical accounts of the Yakuts only date from the time of their first contact with the Russians, that is to say, 1620, and annexation to the Russian State. At that time the Yakuts were not a single political unit, but were divided into a number of independent tribes. Tribal relations were already decomposing, however, and there was a fairly clearly marked class stratification. The tsarist voyevods and soldiery took advantage of the intertribal strife to break the resistance of some of the Yakut population; they also took advantage of the class differences within it by pursuing a policy of systematic support of the ruling aristocratic clique, the princelings (toyons), whom they turned into their own agents for purposes of governing the Yakut district. From that moment on, the class differences among the Yakuts began to become more clearly marked.' [700] 'Such, in general terms, was the social structure of the Yakuts by the time the Russians arrived. Tsarist policy between the 17th and 19th centuries speeded up the development of social relations, so that Yakut society just before the October Revolution had already changed very much from what it had been three centuries ago. Nevertheless, many phenomena proved extremely stable and retained their archaic nature until recent times. Just before the Revolution the division of the Yakuts into strata according to the property they possessed was extremely marked. Most of the population did not even have enough cattle for the hunger norm (this norm, when the grade of the livestock was low, was considered to be two head of livestock per person), whereas in the few toyon households there were several dozen head of livestock per person. However, the unequal distribution of the livestock was by no means anything new for the Yakuts. But the question of land was different. The system which had grown up in the domain of land tenure was of comparatively recent origin. Since the arrival of the Russians in Yakutiya, the process of decomposition of the ancient communal-clan system of using the meadowland had been stepped up. The toyons were vigorously seeking to acquire the common lands. The development of private land ownership by the toyons continued to the 1760’s, when certain measures introduced by the Russian administration gave it a new direction. In 1765, Yakuts were forbidden to buy or sell land, and in the next few years, through the activity of the Yakut Tribute Commission, the distribution of land in accordance with the so-called “sable” and “fox” taxes or parts of them was introduced among the Yakuts. Later on, in about 1820, this distribution of land assumed the form of the so-called “class system” of land usage, which legalized the extremely unequal distribution of the land, though, on the surface, it seemed to be something like common land usage. This “class system,” which was later modified, had assumed the following form by the beginning of the 20th century.' [701] 'The unit of measurement of land among the Yakuts was the “rick” ([unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown]), a plot of land from which one hayrick could be mown (the size of the rick ranged from 10 to 30 cartloads, sometimes as many as 40 or 60). These allotments made up plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) which were extremely varied in size, depending on the “class,” and there were three or four “classes.” One first-class plot ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ) was equal to two secondclass plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] [unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) and three or four third-class plots (kenniki or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ). The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called[unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] -[unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). [Page 272] Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [702] 'In the second half of the 19th century the custom of equalizing of the land each year in accordance with the yield of grass came into use. The harvest was evaluated by elected “deputies,” and those whose harvest was poorer than it should have been in view of the plot had the right to an extra quota of hay, and vice versa. This was called bebierke (from the Russian word poverka [adjustment]). But in actual fact this custom did not reduce inequality, for the “deputies” always acted in favor of the more influential (toyon) section of the population, to which they themselves very often belonged.' [703] Tokarev describes the system of labour and cattle hire as a form of institutionalized exploitation: 'Generally speaking, the toyons possessed a large proportion of the available land, and the best part, to boot. For example, in 1908 two-thirds of all the land in the First Ospetskiy Nasleg in the Dyupsyunskiy Ulus belonged to five toyon households. In the Suntarskiy Ulus the toyons, who made up only 7% of the total population, possessed approximately half the land. By 1917, 55% of all the usable land was possessed by the rich people. By owning land and livestock the toyons were in a position to exploit the needy masses of the population. The forms that the exploitation took were greatly varied; they included elements characteristic of capitalist relations and the older patriarchal-feudal forms, as well as hidden survivals of slavery. For example, it was the practice to hire laborers—khamnachyts—usually for a definite period, particularly for haymaking; they were hired to carry firewood, build yurts and so on. They were paid either in money or in kind; and the method used was usually the typical Yakut system of payment (remuneration in advance), which was called “to take a contract” from the toyon for this or that work. This system of contracting was very advantageous to the richer people, since they then had complete power over the laborers. In return for a paltry sum received in advance, the poor person was sometimes in the toyon’s clutches for a long time to come.' [704] 'The system of contracting was also applied in other cases; advances were paid by the toyons for the supply of a whole variety of products, ranging from butter and hay right down to wild duck eggs. This system was a form of extremely cruel exploitation. One observer (V. F. Troshchanskiy, an exiled member of Narodnaya Volya wrote outright that the “welfare of the population will not be improved as long as this system exists in its present form.”' [705] 'Another very common form of exploitation was the handing over of the milch cattle to the poor people by the toyons for their use and for feeding, the so-called system of khahaas. At an earlier stage (at the beginning of the 19th century) the livestock was taken over, usually for a year, from spring to spring, but at the end of the 19th century it was more common to take over the cattle for only the summer (the distribution of livestock for feeding during the winter—uostur—was a separate process). In return for use of the cow, the poor peasant had to pay the toyon, as was the custom, 30 pounds of melted butter and 12-15 poods of tar (frozen sour milk) in the autumn; sometimes this was replaced or supplemented by compulsory service for the benefit [Page 273] of the toyon. This custom was a very typical and often extremely cruel form of exploitation. The winter upkeep of the livestock was a still more burdensome, enslaving agreement; in return for a head of cattle, the toyon usually paid 1 ruble, 50 kopeks or 2 rubles for the whole winter, whereas in actual fact the upkeep cost at least 5 rubles, and so it was only the poor peasants driven by need who entered into such agreements.' [706] 'A still more typical custom, the origin of which in ancient times was connected with mutual assistance between clan members, but which later became in fact one of the forms of exploitation, was kumalaanism. A kumalaan was a poor peasant, a disabled person, an orphan or sometimes all the members of an impoverished family, who were assigned by the whole community to live for a certain time with a rich man or wealthy kinsman who would maintain them. Officially, the adoption of a kumalaan was regarded as an act of charity, and a way of helping a kinsman in need. But in actual fact the custom concealed the cruelest exploitation of unpaid labor. In many cases it was a disguised form of slavery and lasted a long time.' [707] Toyons legitimated their superior position by presenting themselves as patriarchal benefactors: 'Apart from these individual customs, the Yakut society admittedly retained the characteristic, half-conscious patriarchal ideology, which was clearly not a reflection of their true relationships, although it served the interests of the toyons, who knew how to make use of it. The toyons liked to style themselves the forefathers, heads and sponsors of their clans; they skillfully fomented various interclan quarrels (usually [Page 276] over land), thereby sustaining the fiction of community of clan interests. A poor kinsman used to call a toyon who had robbed him of his possessions aga (father), and was expected to look upon him as his “benefactor.”' [708] Toyons also derived their names from deities: 'In the cult of both the benevolent and malevolent deities, a part was played at one stage by the military aristocracy—the toyons; they were usually the organizers. In their legendary genealogies the toyons often derived their names from the great and powerful deities.' [709] Most people were poor and of lower status: 'In pre-Revolutionary Yakutiya the poor and middle peasant families totaled more than 80 percent of all households. One-seventh of all the households were entirely without sowings, and many were only able to sow a few hundredths of a hectare each. Most of the households (97 percent) had to do without factory-made agricultural implements. Stockbreeding produced extremely poor results. The owners of large areas of land and abundant livestock i.e.,—the kulaks and toyons, grew rich, but not so much by raising the level of land cultivation and animal husbandry as by exploiting the poor and middle peasants.' [710] Coercion and exploitation exercisted by toyons continued into the early Soviet period: 'During the first two years of the Soviet regime the situation hardly changed for the better. There was redistribution of the land in 1923-24, but the reform only partly cut down the amount of land used by the toyons and virtually made no difference to the burdensome state of the poor people. For example, the nonrepartitional land expropriated by the toyons on the basis of their “clearing right” was left in their possession. It was only the second land reform of 1929 that put an end to toyon coercion and created a situation in which the agriculture of Yakutiya could be improved. About 150,000 hectares of the best land, formerly owned by the toyons and kulaks, then passed into the hands of the working peasantry.' [711] It appears that social mobility was absent.

♠ recruitment of chief executive ♣ equal ♥ eHRAF provides a summary of the political history in the region: 'Yakut oral histories begin well before first contact with Russians in the seventeenth century. For example, OLONKHO (epics) date at least to the tenth century, a period of interethnic mixing, tensions, and upheaval that may have been a formative period in defining Yakut tribal affiliations. Ethnographic and archaeological data suggest that the ancestors of the Yakut, identified in some theories with the Kuriakon people, lived in an area near Lake Baikal and may have been part of the Uighur state bordering China. By the fourteenth century, Yakut ancestors migrated north, perhaps in small refugee groups, with herds of horses and cattle. After arrival in the Lena valley, they fought and intermarried with the native Evenk and Yukagir nomads. Thus, both peaceful and belligerent relations with northern Siberians, Chinese, Mongols, and Turkic peoples preceded Russian hegemony. When the first parties of Cossacks arrived at the Lena River in the 1620s, Yakut received them with hospitality and wariness.' [712] Sakha society was organized in patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [713] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [714] 'Kinship and politics were mixed in the hierarchical council system that guided AQA-USA, AIMAK, and DZHON. Yakut explanations of DZHON in the nineteenth century included concepts like "people," "community," or "tribe," territorially defined. Councils were composed of ranked circles of elders, usually men, whose leaders, TOYONS, were called nobles by Russians. A lineage head was BIS-USA-TOYON; respected warriors and hunters were BATYR. Lineage councils decided major economic issues, interfamily disputes, and questions of blood revenge for violence committed against the group. AIMAK and DZHON councils were infrequent, dealing with issues of security, revenge, alliance, and, before Russian control, war. Through war, slaves were captured for service in the wealthiest TOYON households. Kin-based councils were rare by the nineteenth century and had little influence on twentieth-century politics. Yet in the Soviet period Yakut remain aware of regional and kin ties and help kin obtain jobs and political positions. In this period the Yakut elite, some of whom are Communist party members, revived certain traditions, participating in wedding ceremonies and annual festivals once associated with council meetings. To avoid doing so would be impolitic. Yakut have demanded greater economic and political autonomy from Moscow and some Yakut politicians, including the elected president, are reformers implementing the new republic constitution. A major ecological movement and democratically elected councils are trying to redress local grievances.' [715] It appears there was little mobility between toyons and other strata of Sakha society (see above). We have treated them as a form of 'nobility' here, although this is debatable.
♠ extreme status elevation ♣ absent ♥
♠ extreme status diminution ♣ absent ♥

♠ occupational mobility ♣ absent ♥ Pastoralism has a long history in the region: 'In prehistoric times, beginning with the northern retreat of the glaciers, many southern peoples who had to adjust themselves to the severe conditions of life in the northern forests or the polar tundra, occupied Siberia. Some of the newcomers, like the Tungus, lost many of their former culture traits, and became reindeer breeders or hunters, while others, like the Yakut, were able in the far north to retain their cattle-breeding culture of the Central Asiatic steppes. But this northward [Page 61] migration was involuntary; the southerners were forced out from their former habitat by the competition of alien tribes. Naturally, in the course of their wandering, they left some traces which have been disclosed by the work of archaeologists. Skeletal finds also have shown that northern Siberia was primarily inhabited by a long-headed people of the Nordic type who had come from the west, and who were assimilated or else annihilated by Mongoloid newcomers from the south. Many of these questions still await solution through the work of archaeologists.' [716] 'We have some knowledge of prehistoric Yakut monuments through the recent work of Russian archaeologists, chiefly Petri, whose excavations in the region of Lake Baikal revealed many remains of a horse and cattle breeding tribe, in all probability, the prehistoric Yakut.' [717] 'The identifications by the chief zoologist of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Bialanitski-Birula, of animal bones found at the Murino sites and the caves of Orkhon show that these are chiefly the remains of domesticated animals-of oxen, rams, goats, and horses. Remains of wild animals, the products of hunting, are very scarce, proving that the people were cattle breeders. Besides, no traces of agriculture were found to the north of Lake Baikal, presenting negative evidence that the prehistoric inhabitants were herders. Further, Bialanitski-Birula pointed out that the ox of these people, like that of the Yakut, was a cross-breed of the yak. Among the iron arrows were found many with bifurcated heads, a characteristic of Yakut arrows. The iron knives and scissors found have the same distinguishing marks as Yakut knives, as will be shown in the discussion of their iron industry. The horseshoe found in the excavations is exactly like the Yakut horseshoe; it is narrow, with holes for nails and one calk in the middle. The Siberian natives, even in stony mountainous places, seldom shoe their horses. The iron bits of an ancient bridle consisted of two unequal parts, without appendages in the corners. This may be explained by the manner in which the rider held the reins on the left side of the horse as do the present Yakut. Modern Yakut bits consist of two equal parts, a form which may be regarded as having been adopted from the Russians, from whom the Yakut learned to harness horses to sledges and carts, for which long reins are necessary. Formerly, the Yakut used the horse only as a riding and pack animal. Appurtenances of horse harness show that the people bred horses. An iron sickle for hay making was found by Petri. It is quite different from the Russian form and resembles the present Yakut sickle. [Page 62] An iron hook for digging edible roots and plants and iron fish hooks were also found.' [718] 'It is indubitable that the training of the deer was at one time the occupation of the natives throughout the country. Even in those areas of the Yakut region where there are no deer at present, deer bones are found in the ground intermingled with human ones and with metallic items of deer harness. Many localities have preserved legends about the one-time existence of the domestic deer among the inhabitants. I can point, as an example, to the valley of the Borgonski settlement, which until the coming of the Yakuts was the scene of nomadic travels of the Tungus Miore with his numerous herds; also--to the valley of the Suntarski lake, which supposedly derived its name from the Tungus Suntar. The Tungus did not know any other cattle, except the deer...The deer are the Tungus cattle! unanimously assert the legends. They also assert, that the Yakuts imitated the Tungus in their use of the deer.' [719] 'The capacity to bear bad weather, cold, and hunger, to eat little and literally everything and anything that grows, to be satisfied with little in time of need, and afterwards to fatten up on the good feed and to live on the reserves of the fat and the meat stored up--this capacity is remarkably developed in the [Page 313] Yakut cattle. A great deal of energy is thus spent to survive. From the point of view of productivity this capacity for survival has no significance except, perhaps, a negative one. On the other hand this quality of survival makes the Yakut cattle invaluable in pioneering. Only because of it were the Yakuts able to penetrate with their cattle so far to the north. At present the Yakuts are the northernmost cattle breeders not only in Asia, but on the whole globe. Their northernmost cattle breeding sett lements known to me are on the Amoloi river at 70° N.L. and the northernmost one visited by me (in 1882) was on The Yana River at 69° where the Kungyas River enters it. On the Kolyma, the Alazei, and the Indigirka, the breeding of horned cattle does not, at present, reach such proportions, and stops about two degrees 152 south of the above mentioned point. In ancient times, cattle breeding reached the Arctic but was practised--of course--only in the river valleys. Fossils of horned cattle are found in Ustyansk, and legends about it are preserved in Nizhne-Kolymsk and on the Allaikha (the lower course of the Indigir-' [720] 'All those who have tried to connect the horses of the Yakut with those of southern or western Siberia in external appearance have most often pointed to the breed of horses of the Kirghiz. So far there have been no scientific investigations based on any numerous and exact measurements. The only data worthy of attention on this subject are those found in Cherskii. On the basis of a study of the skull of a contemporary Yakut horse, brought by Doctor Bunge from the Adycha River (Berkhoyansk Okrug), Cherskii was able to establish a distinct type of Yakut horse, differing from other Siberian horses and coming closest to the tarpans of southern Russia and the western Siberian subfossilis horse. I. Cherskii classifies the Yakut horse in the eastern group, with the breed of dwarfs (the length of the skull at the base is 472 millimeters) and with medium browed horses (the width of the forehead is 235.2 millimeters). The post-tertiary fossil horse whose remains are found in great number at the Yakutsk Oblast, bears a certain relation, in the shape of the skull and of the bones, to present Siberian breeds and, by the way, to the Yakut horse. This is the opinion of the same Doctor Cherskii. This relationship expresses itself in the moderate width of the forehead, the inclined position of the bones above the eyebrows, the narrow width of the offshoots of the bones in the forehead to the skull, the concavity of the profile, and the singular dental systemThe size of the fossil [Page 343] Yakut horses makes one class them with the tall breeds (around Lake Lyakhov) and the very tall breeks (Yana River).' [721] 'The finding of the fully preserved corpse of a white horse in the frozen soil of the lower Yana, as reported by Bunge , strengthens this interest, as it seems to indicate the possibility of coming to a definitive solution of this problem. The answer to both these questions is directly bound with the time of the northern migration of the Yakut and with the location of their original homeland. Here I will only note that white is still the predominant color among Yakut horses, and that [Page 344] the interbreeding of domestic with wild animals is considered by them to be advantageous for the improvement of the breed. Such interbreeding in the case of domesticated deer, as I mentioned above, is practiced even now by the Yakut and Tungus of the far north.' [722] 'We must analyze some discrepancies in the account of the finds representing supposedly old Yakut culture. The excavations were made in old earth huts and caves. Thus this horse and cattle-breeding tribe must have been nomadic, yet, at the same time, must have had permanent dwellings. This may be explained by their double occupation. Iron [Page 63] mining, smelting, forging, and smithing required a sedentary life. While some families of a clan, or even some members of a family, were engaged in the iron industry, their relatives nomadized with their herds. Caves may have served as temporary shelters during the winter when the wet walls became frozen and a fire was used as protection from the cold.' [723] The Sakha were initially nomadic pastoralists: 'Traditional pastoralism in central Yakutia required homestead self-reliance, with intense dependence on calves and foals in a harsh climate. Stables, corrals, and haying developed in conjunction with hardy breeds of cattle and short, fat, furry horses. Richer families owned hundreds of horses and cattle; poorer ones raised a few cattle or herded for others. A huge variety of dairy products, including fermented mare's milk, (Russian: KUMYS), was the staple food, with meat for special occasions. The diet was augmented by hunting (bears, elk, squirrels, hare, ferrets, fowl), fishing (salmon, carp, MUSKSUN, MUNDU), and, under Russian influence, agriculture (cereals). Wealthy Yakut hunted on horseback using dogs. The poorest Yakut, those without cattle, relied on fishing with horsehair nets and, in the north, herded reindeer like their Evenk and Yukagir neighbors.' [724] Most implements were made in the home: 'Before iron was imported, ironworkers used ore from local marshes. Similarly, ceramics from local clay preceded Russian pottery. Most homemade crafts were for household use: decorated birch-bark containers, leather bags, dairy-processing equipment, horsehair blankets, fur clothing, benches, hitching posts, and elaborately carved wooden containers (including CHORONS for KUMYS).' [725] 'Although occupations within a household were divided by gender and status, the atmosphere was usually one of productive group activity. All participated in hay making, cattle herding, and milking, but, in general, horses were more a male preserve and cattle a female responsibility. Women tended children and fires, prepared food, carried water, and made clothing and pottery. Men handled more strenuous firewood preparation, house building, sled making, hunting, fishing, and mowing. Ivory carving and wood- and metalworking were male tasks.' [726] Sieroszewski reports some trades, such as carpentry and blacksmithing, for the south: 'In the north, where most of the household utensils are mad at home, all are prepared with the aid of only these clumsy implements. In the south, where trades are kept separate to a greater degree, a carpenter owns, besides these, a wide and a narrow saw, planes, a brace and bit, chisels, and sometimes even a rasp. But everywhere the axe is most important. The Yakut handle the axe in a masterly fashion and are excellent carpenters. The majority of the churches in the Yakutsk Okrug and almost all the house s in the town of Yakutsk have been built by Yakut carpenters. In their carpentry work they use the same methods, the same compass for cutting, the same pitch rope, plumb, triangle, and ruler as do the Russians. The head of the carpenters artel, the elder carpenter, is called the regulator, after the Russian fashion. But their chief instruments, the axes and knives, have retained their ancient shape.They weigh from two to no more than four pounds, and cost from fifty kopecks to one ruble. The Yakut cut with them smoothly, cleanly, and quickly; they are ready to fashion even small pieces with an axe.' [727] 'As with other Siberian peoples, Yakut shamans (OIUN if male, UDAGAN if female) combine medical and spiritual practice. [...] In the nineteenth century a few Yakut leaders financed the building of Russian Orthodox churches, and many Yakut declared themselves Christian, but this did not mean that they saw Christianity and shamanism as mutually exclusive. The Yakut also believed in the spiritual power of blacksmiths.' [728] But most Sakha continued to rely on household-level subsistence production after the introduction of cereal agriculture: 'In pre-Revolutionary Yakutiya the poor and middle peasant families totaled more than 80 percent of all households. One-seventh of all the households were entirely without sowings, and many were only able to sow a few hundredths of a hectare each. Most of the households (97 percent) had to do without factory-made agricultural implements. Stockbreeding produced extremely poor results. The owners of large areas of land and abundant livestock i.e.,-the kulaks and toyons, grew rich, but not so much by raising the level of land cultivation and animal husbandry as by exploiting the poor and middle peasants.' [729] Temporary wage labour was slightly more common in areas close to Russian settlements: 'The Yakut are unwilling to hire themselves out on a daily basis, although the daily rate of pay is always higher than the monthly or yearly rates. Among themselves they hardly ever do this. This has begun to come into custom only in the vicinity of cities, and only very lately. The Skoptsy were particularly responsible for spreading this custom. The Skopsty usually pay their workers in flours, baked bread, potatoes, brick tea, and sugar; only rarely in money and in cotton goods.' [730] As most people were engaged in subsistence pastoralism or small-scale cultivation, we have decided against coding for the presence of 'occupational mobility' and complexity. This is debatable and open to review.

Slavery[edit]

♠ Proportion of population enslaved ♣ ♥ Prisoners of war were traditionally kept as slaves by toyons: 'Kinship and politics were mixed in the hierarchical council system that guided AQA-USA, AIMAK, and DZHON. Yakut explanations of DZHON in the nineteenth century included concepts like "people," "community," or "tribe," territorially defined. Councils were composed of ranked circles of elders, usually men, whose leaders, TOYONS, were called nobles by Russians. A lineage head was BIS-USA-TOYON; respected warriors and hunters were BATYR. Lineage councils decided major economic issues, interfamily disputes, and questions of blood revenge for violence committed against the group. AIMAK and DZHON councils were infrequent, dealing with issues of security, revenge, alliance, and, before Russian control, war. Through war, slaves were captured for service in the wealthiest TOYON households. Kin-based councils were rare by the nineteenth century and had little influence on twentieth-century politics. Yet in the Soviet period Yakut remain aware of regional and kin ties and help kin obtain jobs and political positions. In this period the Yakut elite, some of whom are Communist party members, revived certain traditions, participating in wedding ceremonies and annual festivals once associated with council meetings. To avoid doing so would be impolitic. Yakut have demanded greater economic and political autonomy from Moscow and some Yakut politicians, including the elected president, are reformers implementing the new republic constitution. A major ecological movement and democratically elected councils are trying to redress local grievances.' [731] Dependents were considered part of the patriarchal household: 'At the head of the family was the aga, meaning primarily “elder in age” and then “father.” All the people of the household were regarded as and called by him “my children,” “my sons or my daughters.” Among these were included not only his own children, but also all relatives by blood and marriage, by adoption, by purchase (slaves), and any other dependents, as war captives. The aga continued to rule as long as he preserved his physical and mental abilities. According to a Yakut tradition, aged parents and also sick and crippled people, unable to work, were doomed to die and were even buried alive after three days of abundant entertainment.' [732] Slaves were occasionally included in dowry payments: 'Afterwards enne kulut were slaves included in a bride's dowry. If they were women they became the concubines of the master. (Namsk Ulus, 1891).' [733] 'One way or another, among the Yakut hexogamy was accompanied by war 560 and slavery. It is a very usual thing for Yakut legends to mention slaves given to a conqueror together with a daughter.' [734] Slavery and serfdom continued into the Russian period and it is unclear when precisely the practice was abandoned: 'It is understandable that here as everywhere else the conquerors first of all tried to make use of the clan leaders to facilitate the gathering of yassak and pacification. They named them princelings [Page 782] and wealthy people of the ulus and made them responsible for arrears and disorders, took hostages, and translators from them, and forced them to pay contributions. Afterwards, when the government became convinced that the Cossack carnival was threatening the interest of the government, was impoverishing the population to the bone, and by its unbearable taxation and cruelties was forcing the population to scatter, inciting it into rebellion and disobedience, it tried to give those same princelings and wealthy people of the ulus control over their rapacious servants. They were entrused to be present as witnesses at the gathering of yassak, at inquiries, and all other matters arising between the soldiers and officials who had come and the local population. Later they were charge to stamp with their own stamps the furs given as yassak, so that the soldiers would not exchange them on the way. of the whole clan. They were not slow to take advantage of this.All this raised them to an unparalleled height in 495 the eyes of the population; when afterwards it was acknowledged that it would be better to divide the yassak by clans and uluses and, without inquiring into the distribution and means of exaction, to [Page 783] demand it in full from the clan leaders, the princelings, turned completely into land officials. They began to be encouraged and rewarded for their service by signs of excellence: medals, cutlasses, and caftans, and by a decree of the Senate, on February 1, 1740 and May 17, 1764, they were even assigned a constant recompense, depending on the amount of yassak brought in. A salary to the yassak princelings and those elected as yassak officials: for every 1000 rubles of yassak brought into the treasury, a salary of 20 rubles to each as a gift, and if the amount is smaller or greater than 1000 rubles, to take this into calculation. Encouraged and supported from outside, the princelings little by little freed themselves from the clan traditions and began to oppress the people no less than the Cossacks. Being perfectly acquanited with the conditions of life they were able to enter into agreements with the voivodes and clerks, keeping the whole matter concealed, and under protection conduct themselves in their lands in their lands as if they owned them: they seized land, levy taxes without any control, introduce serfdom, and even buy and sell people. It is a dark memory and bad habits that the princes of that time have left behind them. There was only one way in which the people benefited by the fact that they replaced the Russian officials: they became accustomed to battle for their own interest under new conditions. The princes were their own people, the aura of a conqueror did not surround them, they had nowhere to go with their plundered riches, and even formerly the people had been forced to keep them in check, in their capacity as heads of the clan.' [735] It is unclear how many people were enslaved or enserfed.

♠ Proportion of population enserfed ♣ ♥ See above.

Types

♠ Chattel slavery ♣ inferred present ♥ See above.
♠ Elite slavery ♣ absent ♥
♠ Bonded serfdom ♣ inferred present ♥ See above.
♠ Corvée labor to a landowner ♣ inferred present ♥ There may have been an equivalent to this concerning livestock herding performed by poor households for wealthy ones (see also property variables). More material is needed.
♠ Corvée labor to the state ♣ absent ♥

Restraints

♠ Owners can execute slaves ♣ inferred present ♥ We have assumed this to be the case, but more material is needed.
♠ Owners can impose corporal punishment on slaves ♣ inferred present ♥ We have assumed this to be the case, but more material is needed.
♠ Corporal punishment by the state ♣ absent ♥

Human sacrifice

♠ Prisoners ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of human sacrifice (see also below).
♠ Low social class ♣ absent ♥
♠ Elites ♣ absent ♥
♠ Retainers ♣ absent ♥
♠ Outsiders ♣ absent ♥

Religion and Normative Ideology[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥ The name of the research assistant or associate who coded the data. If more than one RA made a substantial contribution, list all.

♠ Expert ♣ ♥ The name of the historical or archaeological expert who supervised coding and checked/improved/approved the result. If more than one expert was involved, list all.

♠ Name of Official Cult ♣ Sakha Religion ♥

♠ alternate Names of Official Cult ♣ ♥

♠ Name of other significant religious or ideological systems ♣ Christianity ♥

♠ Description of the Normative Ideology ♣ ♥ eHRAF provides the following summary: 'Yakut religion derives from Turkic, Mongolic, Tungusic, and Russian ideas. Labels like "animist," "shamanist," or "Russian Orthodox" do not suffice. Ideas of sin are syncretised with concepts of contamination and taboo. Saints and bears are seen as shamanic spirit helpers. Christ is identified with the Yakut Bright Creator Elder God, Aiyy-toyon. A pantheon of gods, believed to live in nine hierarchical eastern heavens, was only one aspect of a complex traditional cosmology that still has meaning for some Yakut. Another crucial dimension was the spirit-soul (ICHCHI) of living beings, rocks, trees, natural forces, and objects crafted by humans. Most honored was the hearth spirit (YOT ICHCHITE), still fed morsels of food and drink by pious Yakut. Giant trees (AL LUKH MAS), deep in the forest, were especially sacred: their ICHCHI are still given small offerings of coins, scarves, and ribbons. Belief in ICHCHI is related to ancient ideas of harmony and equilibrium with nature, and to shamanism. Yakut shamanism is a Turkic, Mongolic, and Tungusic blend of belief in the supernatural, with emphasis on the ability of "white," or benign, shamans to intercede, through prayers and séances, with eastern spirits for the sake of humans. "Black" shamans, communing with evil spirits, could both benefit and harm humans.' [736] 'As with other Siberian peoples, Yakut shamans (OIUN if male, UDAGAN if female) combine medical and spiritual practice. Despite centuries of Russian Orthodox and Soviet discrediting of shamans as greedy charlatans, some Yakut maintain belief in shamans and supernatural powers. Others, struggling to recover spirituality after rejecting Marxist-Leninist materialism, accept aspects of shamanic philosophy. Still others, influenced by Soviet education and science, reject all religion as superstition. In the nineteenth century a few Yakut leaders financed the building of Russian Orthodox churches, and many Yakut declared themselves Christian, but this did not mean that they saw Christianity and shamanism as mutually exclusive. The Yakut also believed in the spiritual power of blacksmiths. By the 1980s shamans in Yakutia were rare and more likely to be Evenk than Yakut. Yet rituals once associated with spirit belief were being revived by urban as well as rural Yakut.' [737] 'The most important ceremony, associated with a founding Yakut ancestor named Ellei, is the annual summer YHYAK festival, a celebration of seasonal change, of KUMYS (fermented mare's milk), and of kin solidarity. Once a religious celebration led by a shaman, the ceremony has been adapted since World War I into a secular commemoration of Yakut traditions. Practiced in villages and towns, it features opening prayers (ALGYS) and libations of KUMYS to the earth. Although some Yakut debate its "authenticity," the festival still includes feasting, horse racing, wrestling, and all-night line dancing to improvised chants. It lasts three joyous days in Suntar, where it is especially famed. Wedding rituals, pared down from previous eras, center around memorial hitching posts (SERQE), carved for the occasion, with couples honored by prayers, special food, and dancing. New rituals marking wedding anniversaries and graduations at all educational levels include the placement of SERQE, on which names of those honored are carved. But traditional rituals of birth, supplicating the goddess of fertility, Aiyycyt, have become less popular, with some Yakut women even mocking the restrictions that were once associated with beliefs about female impurity. Russian Orthodox holidays are rarely celebrated.' [738] Gogolev describes Sakha shamanism: 'Pre-Christian beliefs comprise the dominant component of the traditional worldview of the Yakuts. “Traditional” because the foundation for such a worldview by these people was developed during an era when mythological-epic thinking dominated among a people of a preclass society (L’vova et al., p. 6). “World-view” is interpreted here to mean “the spiritual assimilation of the universe . . . from the pint of view of the interrelation of such fundamental elements of the universe as nature and humanity” (Chanyshev, p. 38).' [739] 'Yakut traditional beliefs and shamanism have been studied in considerable detail.’ Despite this, the genesis of black and white shamanism has not received an appropriate explanation, although the history of research into this matter has begun.' [740] 'The first information concerning the existence of black and white shamans among Yakuts was reported by participants of the Second Kamchatka Expedition. I. Gmelin and G. Miller described the “summer” shaman, who directed the performance of the ritual holidayyhyakh. Ia. I. Lindenau gave another name for the Yakut white shaman-tnnnrrr oiiiunn, the “heavenly shaman” or the “shaman of the sky” (Lindenau, p. 39). But a more thorough description of the white shaman was given by one of the first Yakut ethnographers, N. S. Gorokhov. “For the dealings of earthly humans with Iuriung Aiyy foion there exist ‘ai oiuna,’ ” he wrote, “-the ai shamans, who can never do any evil to anyone. . . . The ai oiuna do not have any shamanic costume. . . , not even a shamanic drum; they only give benedictions and beg for the mercy of Iuriung Aiyy toion. The ai oiuna always pray only to Iuriung Aiyy toion, and only in one case, when attempting to cure infertility, do they pray to Magan Sylgylakh or to some other dweller of the heavens, in order to petition for a son. The ai oiuna do not perform sacrifices-that is, they do not slaughter livestock as sacrifices, and may only consecrate one animal or another to a heavenly dweller, and then they do not do any work with this animal and, if possible, safeguard it and care for it” (Gorokhov, p. 56).' [741] 'N. S. Gorokhov was born and lived in the north of Yakutia, in Verkhoiansk, where white shamans, the “aiyy shamans,” could still be found until the 1870s. “These were,” as he notes, “truly wonderful people, gentle to the point of delicacy, unconditionally honest, and genuinely kind. Looking at them, it would be difficult to doubt the sincerity of their faith in their vocation. . . .” ' [742] 'Gorokhov explained the division of shamanism into black and white by the Yakuts’ division of the visible and invisible world into two parts: into aiyy-the divine, light, clean, and good-and abahy-the diabolical, evil, and unclean. Humanity, livestock, and useful animals and plants comprised aijy. Everything harmful and foul-that is, everything that causes harm to humanity-was the invention of abahy.' [743] 'Certain prerevolutionary researchers, uncovering features of dualism in Yakut beliefs, explained them by pointing out that numerous ethnic groups had participated in the ethnogenesis of the Yakuts, and that a unification of the various mythological and religious systems had taken place during their merging into one people (Kharuzina, pp. 171-72).' [744] 'In the opinion of V. F. Troshchanskii, the division of shamanism is the result of the evolutionary development of primal [pervobytnaia] religion. One evolutionary direction is associated with the continued development of black shamanism. This finds its highest expression in the formalization of the “religion of the devotees of Shiva.” Yakut beliefs were correlated to a “black faith” derived from the beliefs of the “Turkic and Mongol peoples” (Troshchanskii, pp. 156-58). In contrast, W. I. Jochelson (pp. 197-205) found themes of dualism in the custom of celebrating two holidays during the year-in early summer, an yhyakh was organized as a holiday of fertility, while in the autumn, an yhyakh took place in honor of destructive forces and evil spirits and deities-“the dwellers of the west.” Therefore, “the dualistic ideas and poetic folklore of Western Asia are characteristic. . . ” of Yakut spiritual culture.' [745] 'In Soviet times, a number of researchers have regarded the pre-Christian religion of the Yakuts as consisting of two components. P. A. Oiunskii separated shamanism from the ancient religious cults of Yakut ancestors. A similar opinion was expressed by the well-known expert on Yakut ethnography, M. M. No~ov.~ G. V. Ksenofontov associated the airy cult with a “higher,” predominant component of the religion, which was publicly recognized and openly practiced. Demonology, alternatively, comprised the “lower” tier-the unofficial popular religion of the masses. He explained the disappearance of white shamans, who served the higher tier of Yakut religion: “with the acceptance of Christianity, Yakut leaders [toions] were obliged to liquidate their ancient official cult.” Yet black shamans, as the practitioners of the popular demonology, did not yield easily to public control, and therefore were able to remain alongside Christianity.' [746] 'S. A. Tokarev described white shamanism in different waysfor instance, as involving the priests of particular deities of light. “The very concept of benevolent, luminous deities,” he wrote, “as distinct from evil spirits, arises relatively late, as the result of more complex conditions of social life” (Tokarev, pp. 171-72).' [747] 'In the opinion of N. A. Alekseev, white shamans were the priests of tribal uiyy deities. In his work, he gave a fuller description of this cult in its entirety. In contrast to black shamans, white shamans prayed to their deities during their rituals, similarly to the priests of any polytheistic religions; they did not “voyage” or “fly” to them, they did not fall into ecstasy, nor did they have helper-spirits. They had to observe ritual purity (including avoiding the dead, not associating with black shamans, and so on) (Alekseev, 1975, pp. 77-102).' [748] 'Research in the area of the historical lexicon of the Yakut language has led to the conclusion that the terminology of black shamanism is of Mongol-Buryat origin (including the names of the parts of the shamanic drum, the cloak, and shamanic rituals), while terminology associated with the uiyy cult and its priests has a Turkic origin as its basis (Antonov, p. 145). According to Ksenofontov, the attitude of the livestock-herding peoples of the Lena toward shamans was hostile; shamans were considered to be servants of a foul profession alien to their own age-old traditions.' [749] 'According to modern evolutionary thought on the subject, shamanism is understood to be a particular form of religion widespread among peoples of classless societies-particularly at the stage of their decline-and is then retained as a vestige at higher stages of social development. In a narrower sense, shamanism usually refers to the religion of the peoples of Northern Asia. The typical course of action in shamanism is the seance [kumlunie], the purpose of which, more often than not, is to heal the sick. As perceived in folk conceptions, shamans make inquiries of spirits with the assistance of their personal helper-spirits. A good shaman would need to possess many extraordinary qualities. “He is not conceited,” notes V. L. Seroshevskii, “ . . . not greedy, not overly demanding. Neither excessive arrogance nor pride are discernible in his dealings with people; more likely, a tangible feeling of internal strength is revealed, before which those surrounding him involuntarily bow, and which generates trust in and obedience to him” (Seroshevskii, p. 631).' [750] 'The ethnographic record of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries has provided a wealth of material on shamanism among the peoples of Siberia, Kazakhstan, and Central Asia, the American Indians and Eskimos, and many of the peoples of Southeast Asia. The majority of these peoples lived under the conditions of an appropriative [pr-isvnivni~tshchee] economy, nomadic livestock-breeding, and slash-and-burn agriculture. All of this seems to demonstrate that shamanism indeed represents a specific early stage in the development of religion. Figuratively speaking, shamanism is the focused nucleus of the religious beliefs of an early society during the era of its decline, being fundamentally the ideology of an appropriative economy. In those regions of the world where a transition took place from Stone-Age society directly to a producer economy, religious conceptions changed accordingly, and the foundations of the agricultural polytheistic religions were laid. But in societies that never made a transition to developed agriculture (among advanced fishing, hunting, gathering, and, to some extent, livestock-breeding societies), shamanism remains the principal form of religious belief, attaining more refined forms of development. Therefore, in the forest-and-steppe regions, the dense taiga of the north, and the tropical jungles-that is, in those places where gathering and fishing, hunting, and undevcloped forms of producer economy dominate-there have remained the conditions for the existence of shamanism.' [751] 'The Eurasian steppes, due to their geographic situation, have occupied a “buffer zone” position. In the east, the steppes divided the relevant portion of the continent into a northern part, where primarily the appropriative economy developed, and a southern one, which had producer forms of economy. The steppes themselves occupied the central area. It is possible that on the strength of the mediating position of the steppe nomads, their religious formulations were characterized by syncretic features-the intertwining of shamanic and priesthood concepts, with a clear dominance of the former. Not only that, but in the early state formations that were situated in the semisteppe regions of the Far East and Central Asia during the tenth through thirteenth centuries-those of the Jurchens, Kidans, and Tanguts-shamanism was elevated to the status of a state religion (Vorob’ev, pp. 48-49). Shamanism existed right up until the twentieth century in such an expressly agricultural East Asian country as Korea (Ionova). This is connected with the idea that Altaic-speaking elements, such as the ManchuroTungus, played an active part in the origin of the Koreans.' [752] 'The perpetuation of shamanism among the peoples of Kazakhstan and Central Asia was closely connected with the ancient beliefs and rituals of local Iranian-speaking peoples. This view held by researchers is confirmed in part by the phenomenon that vestiges of the ancient Prashaman complex of Iranian-speaking ethnoses are distinctly manifested in the fervor of the Central Asian and Iranian dervishes, which consists of the recitation of verses, the attainment of a trance state, the utilization of zoomorphic helper-spirits, and the use of a shamanic drum and beater (Kuz’mina, p. 171).' [753] 'The origin of the shamanism of the Turkic-speaking Yakuts from outside of the ethnic group seems to be confirmed not only linguistically, but also by folkloric data. According to legends, the Yakuts are descended from two progenitorsOmogoi and Ellei. From Omogoi came the residents of the Namsk and Baiagantai regions [ulus], who in ancient times did not have the right to organize an yhyakh festival. The origins of the principal central-Yakut ulus are associated with Ellei, the cultural hero, the first organizer and priest of the yhyclkh, and the founder of the niyy cult. These people, the “Tribe of Ellei,” most likely belonged to the Turkic-speaking ancestors of the Yakuts. The etymology of the word “Ellei”-which in the opinion of 0. Botling, is derived from the Uighur 3115 meaning “to give birth to a clan”-likewise supports this. Horse-breeding dominanted their economy, which is also corroborated by linguistic materials: all Yakut words for equine livestock, for their stages of growth, and for meat and milk products obtained from equine livestock, as well as all terms associated with the exploitation of the horse, are Turkic (Antonov, pp. 25-34). In their beliefs, a prominent place was occupied by theyhyakh, the cult holiday of equine livestock fertility. The principal themes of Yakut mythology, in which worldviews derived from the ancient nomadic Iranian-speaking tribes of Middle and Central Asia are evident alongside those of Turkic peoples, are associated with this complex.' [754] 'The bulk of Yakut livestock-breeding terms are of Mongol derivation, associated with the “People of Omogoi” in their origin. The terminology of a “hunter-artisan cult” likewise belongs among the words of Mongol derivation (Antonov, pp. 36-37, 145). This complex consists of shamanism and the entire demonological aspect of the Yakut religious system. The “livestock-breeding accoutrements” of these two outlooks have found reflection in proverbs and sayings.' [755] 'On the cliff drawings on the Middle Lena, dated as being prior to the arrival of Yakut ancestors, figures of shamans with drums and rattles have been uncovered, as well as a depiction of a person with arms raised upward as if in prayer, above whom were carved three circles-symbols of three suns or of a three-dimensional conception of the Universe. A. P. Okladnikov considered this priest figure to be a depiction of a Yakut white shaman (Okladnikov, pp. 375-76).' [756] 'It is not enough to explain the nature of the dualism in Yakut traditional beliefs merely through ethnic considerations, given the fact that dualism to one extent or another actually appears in many religions. The division of shamanism was likewise inherent in the beliefs of the Mongol-speaking peoples, with which we have attempted to associate the origin of Yakut black shamanism. The Mongol white shamans dressed all in white, rode on white horses, and participated in running the country. But starting at the end of the thirteenth century, they began to be supplanted by the clergy of the “yellow religion.”e The black shamans, on the other hand, continued to exist alongside the yellow-robed lamas, M. N. Khangalov (p. 89) associates the appearance of white shamanism among the Buryats with the time their ancestors underwent a transition from hunting to mass livestock-breeding and the noyon class first appeared.' [757] 'Until the middle of the nineteenth century, the Yakuts continued to conduct two large yhyakhs during the year-in spring and in autumn. The first, directed by white shamans, was dedicated to the aiyy deities, which represented the eastern, “benevolent” direction of light, whence the sun rises. Originally, Tangara-the sky god, the father of the gods, typologically comparable to the Rigvedic D’iaus, and to the Latin concept of “god” (D’iaus-Deos-Theo)-was supposed to occupy the dominant position among the aiyy deities. Later, this image was embodied in the central figure of the Yakut pantheon, Iuriung Aiyy toion, the “White Creator God,” the god of light, the personified image of the Sun, with the functions of sovereign of the Universe. Then came the other aiyy deities. A particularly important place was occupied by Aal Uot ichchite, the spirit of sacred fire-both of the sacrificial flame and of the domestic hearth. Like the Arian Agni, Aal Uot ichchite was considered to be the protector of the family and the giver of good fortune and healthy offspring. If the goddess Ieiiekhsit was regarded as the messenger of Iuriung Aiyy toion, then the spirit of fire fulfilled the function of intermediary between earth and heaven, between humanity and the gods.' [758] 'The second, autumnal yhyakh was dedicated to the terrible, destructive forces of nature, the deities and demonic spirits of the cult of abahy-“the dwellers of the west.” It took place at night and was led by nine black male and female shamans. Blood sacrifices of livestock and horses took place in honor of the chief deities of Yakut demonology Uluu toion and Arsan Duolai. This entire complex with its multitude of shamanic rituals, in the center of which stood a shamanic seance, may be called the cult of abahy. At the same time, it should be explained that the word abahy refers to all manner of evil origins, everything malevolent, hostile, and contrary to the interests of humanity or customs. In the epics [olonkho], abnhy was a nonspecific word for evil beings and monsters, including members of alien tribes, speakers of foreign tongues, and persons with different moral values and customs or completely foreign religions (Ksenofontov, 1977, p. 236). The etymology of abahy is not completely clear. E. K. Pekarskii derived it from aba, ap, meaning “sorcery.” In the dictionary of M. Kashgarskii, which was compiled at the beginning of the twentieth century, this word is found in the form abachi, meaning “scarecrow” (Kashgarskii, p. 10). It can speculatively be connected with the term albasti, which refers to an evil demon associated with waterrelated disasters among Turkic peoples. According to the most widespread version, the image of albasty is associated with Iranian mythology.' [759] 'In this manner, the juxtaposition of two groups of mythological symbols-those of good and of evil, typologically common to many religions-became the foundation of the dualism in Yakut religious beliefs. An analogy is found in the Altaic dualistic myth, according to which Ul’gen proclaims that the people created by his brother Erlik are black and go to the west, while the white people created by him personally must go to the east.' [760] 'It is possible that at one time the Yakut white shaman, the a&y oiuuna, had a special name, which the word toion-used in historical times with the meaning “master, sovereign, ruler, prince, military leader, tsar, lord, owner”-migh t have turned into. Pekarskii derived it from the ancient Turkic toiyn- “a monk, a Buddhist priest” (Pekarskii, col. 2706). Indeed, in the Kashgarskii dictionary, this word is given with the meaning “an ecclesiastical order of a non-muslim religion.” Khan Dzhubeini, who lived in the thirteenth century, uses the term tuin in the meaning “Manichaean priest.” The editors of an ancient Turkic dictionary derive tojun = tojoin from the ancient Chinese daozhen, literally “a person on the path” (Drevnetiitrkskii sfovar’, 1977, p. 572).' [761] 'Evidently Prof. N. K. Antonov is correct in regarding this term as an ancient Turkic word, comparable to the Mongol toin-“a monk of noble [origin]” (Antonov, p. 110). As a hypothetical exercise, it can be supposed that the word toion, etymologically speaking, once represented a compound word, consisting of two words-foiuk and oiiun, where toiuk is “a shamanic hymn, song, or incantation” (Pekarskii, col. 2710), and tuoi is “to sing, to praise.” The ancient Turkic (Uighur) oiiun-“a game” and Uighur oina-“to play, to engage in a seance”-are like the Yakut onn’oo-“play” [imperative]. Thus, toi + oiiun is “one who sings = one who plays” in the sense of “entering into play with god.” Toion may have originally referred to a tribal priest or to a nobleman leader who had been charged with priestly functions. It should also be noted that the names of all of the Yakut gods contain the obligatory appendage “toion.” And it is not for nothing that L. G. Levental’, one of the leading researchers of the Yakut foionate, gave it the following definition: “A military aristocracy, cruel and proud, which traces its origins to the members of the Yakut Olympus, and to illustrious shamans and shamanesses” (Levental’ et al., p. 241).' [762]

Deification of Rulers[edit]

♠ Rulers are legitimated by gods ♣ absent ♥ Toyons legitimated their superior position by presenting themselves as patriarchal benefactors: 'Apart from these individual customs, the Yakut society admittedly retained the characteristic, half-conscious patriarchal ideology, which was clearly not a reflection of their true relationships, although it served the interests of the toyons, who knew how to make use of it. The toyons liked to style themselves the forefathers, heads and sponsors of their clans; they skillfully fomented various interclan quarrels (usually [Page 276] over land), thereby sustaining the fiction of community of clan interests. A poor kinsman used to call a toyon who had robbed him of his possessions aga (father), and was expected to look upon him as his “benefactor.”' [763] Toyons also derived their names from deities: 'In the cult of both the benevolent and malevolent deities, a part was played at one stage by the military aristocracy—the toyons; they were usually the organizers. In their legendary genealogies the toyons often derived their names from the great and powerful deities.' [764] However, we are unsure whether this extended to a form of 'divine' legitimation. We have assumed this was not the case.

♠ Rulers control supernatural energy ♣ absent ♥

♠ Rulers are descendants of gods ♣ absent ♥

♠ Rulers become gods after death ♣ absent ♥

♠ Automatic deification ♣ absent ♥

♠ Rulers are gods ♣ absent ♥

Normative Ideological Aspects of Equity and Prosociality[edit]

♠ Ideological reinforcement of equality ♣ suspected unknown ♥ The sources report a high degree of cross-cultural and cross-'ethnic' hybridization: 'In the north, beyond the inner mountain range, closer to the sea, where the Yakut population penetrates along the valleys of rivers and brooks far into the mountain country, the influence of Tungus and Yukaghir (Mongol-Manchurian) blood is less strongly felt. The Dolgan, whose way of live is similar to that of the Tungus and who dress in the same way, are taken for Tungus by many, although they speak the Yakut language and their traditions clearly point to a mixed half-Yakut origin. The Yukaghir who at one time inhabited thickly the lower reaches 240 [Page 449] of the Yana, Indigirka, and Kolyma Rivers have disappeared, swallowed up by the Yakut. The same thing has happened to many Tungus clans. In the Kolymsk Ulus I came across many households, known to be Tungus, who lived in the Yakut manner and who had intermarried and become related to the Yakut. In the northern parts of the Dyupsyunsk and Bayagantaysk uluses adjoining the southern spurs of the Verkhoyansk Mountains, where Tungus still lead nomadic lives, numerous Tungus families appear in years of famine; they hire themselves out to the Yakut as workmen, or live at the expense of the ulus. Such families often remain permanently among the Yakut. In cases of their parent's death, orphaned children are willingly adopted by well-to-do Yakut. The same thing happens in other places where Tungus and Yakut live side by side. Many Tungus in the Vilyuysk Okrug have become Yakutized, and some of them even have numerous herds of horned cattle... Most of them speak the Yakut language, and few of them know their nat ive tongue..., Maak remarks on this subject. Each year, in winter, in the Olekminsk Okrug, Tungus come into the Yakut settlements and live there side by side with the Yakut, in the same yurts, during the coldest months.' [765] 'They come at the beginning of Advent and leave at the end of maslyanka (the week before Lent). They bring their hosts presents: furs, nuts, and squirrel and bear meat. They buy horse meat, khayak and flour from the Yakut: they like these things very much. Then life is gay. Every day there is singing and dancing. The Tungus like [Page 450] merriment, the grown-ups as well as the little children; they talk to the Yakut with songs. After the dancing various things happen..., a Yakut woman who had lived in the Olekminsk Okrug for a long time told me (Namsk Ulus, 1887).' [766] 'The Tungus of the Maya River (a tributary of the Aldan), as can be seen from the travel notes of General Svetlitskii, have also become partly Yakutized and even engage in cattle raising and agriculture. ' [767] We are unsure whether ethnic stratification (apart from stratification between 'natives' and Russians) was present. More material is needed before a coding decision can be taken.

♠ Ideological thought equates rulers and commoners ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates elites and commoners ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates all ethnicities ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Sakha society was organized in patrilineal clans, not social classes: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [768] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [769] 'By customary law, land, cattle, and horses, although used by households, were controlled by the patriline. Animal or land sale and inheritance was approved by elders. But by the twentieth century, smaller families were keeping resources, in part because of the decline of large horse droves. Men owned most of the wealth, and passed it to sons, especially elder sons, although the youngest son often inherited the family yurt. Mothers could pass on dowries to daughters, unless the dowry was forfeited by bad behavior. In theory, dowries included land, as well as goods, jewelry, and animals, although in practice elders rarely gave land to another lineage.
