Soviet law limited inheritance to goods and nonstate housing could be bequeathed at individual discretion. Most apartments and summer houses were kept in families.' [770] However, wealth stratification was present and Russian imperial authorities co-opted native toyons: 'Precise historical accounts of the Yakuts only date from the time of their first contact with the Russians, that is to say, 1620, and annexation to the Russian State. At that time the Yakuts were not a single political unit, but were divided into a number of independent tribes. Tribal relations were already decomposing, however, and there was a fairly clearly marked class stratification. The tsarist voyevods and soldiery took advantage of the intertribal strife to break the resistance of some of the Yakut population; they also took advantage of the class differences within it by pursuing a policy of systematic support of the ruling aristocratic clique, the princelings (toyons), whom they turned into their own agents for purposes of governing the Yakut district. From that moment on, the class differences among the Yakuts began to become more clearly marked.' [771] 'Such, in general terms, was the social structure of the Yakuts by the time the Russians arrived. Tsarist policy between the 17th and 19th centuries speeded up the development of social relations, so that Yakut society just before the October Revolution had already changed very much from what it had been three centuries ago. Nevertheless, many phenomena proved extremely stable and retained their archaic nature until recent times. Just before the Revolution the division of the Yakuts into strata according to the property they possessed was extremely marked. Most of the population did not even have enough cattle for the hunger norm (this norm, when the grade of the livestock was low, was considered to be two head of livestock per person), whereas in the few toyon households there were several dozen head of livestock per person. However, the unequal distribution of the livestock was by no means anything new for the Yakuts. But the question of land was different. The system which had grown up in the domain of land tenure was of comparatively recent origin. Since the arrival of the Russians in Yakutiya, the process of decomposition of the ancient communal-clan system of using the meadowland had been stepped up. The toyons were vigorously seeking to acquire the common lands. The development of private land ownership by the toyons continued to the 1760’s, when certain measures introduced by the Russian administration gave it a new direction. In 1765, Yakuts were forbidden to buy or sell land, and in the next few years, through the activity of the Yakut Tribute Commission, the distribution of land in accordance with the so-called “sable” and “fox” taxes or parts of them was introduced among the Yakuts. Later on, in about 1820, this distribution of land assumed the form of the so-called “class system” of land usage, which legalized the extremely unequal distribution of the land, though, on the surface, it seemed to be something like common land usage. This “class system,” which was later modified, had assumed the following form by the beginning of the 20th century.' [772] 'The unit of measurement of land among the Yakuts was the “rick” ([unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown]), a plot of land from which one hayrick could be mown (the size of the rick ranged from 10 to 30 cartloads, sometimes as many as 40 or 60). These allotments made up plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) which were extremely varied in size, depending on the “class,” and there were three or four “classes.” One first-class plot ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ) was equal to two secondclass plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] [unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) and three or four third-class plots (kenniki or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ). The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called[unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] -[unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). [Page 272] Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [773] 'In the second half of the 19th century the custom of equalizing of the land each year in accordance with the yield of grass came into use. The harvest was evaluated by elected “deputies,” and those whose harvest was poorer than it should have been in view of the plot had the right to an extra quota of hay, and vice versa. This was called bebierke (from the Russian word poverka [adjustment]). But in actual fact this custom did not reduce inequality, for the “deputies” always acted in favor of the more influential (toyon) section of the population, to which they themselves very often belonged.' [774] Tokarev describes the system of labour and cattle hire as a form of institutionalized exploitation: 'Generally speaking, the toyons possessed a large proportion of the available land, and the best part, to boot. For example, in 1908 two-thirds of all the land in the First Ospetskiy Nasleg in the Dyupsyunskiy Ulus belonged to five toyon households. In the Suntarskiy Ulus the toyons, who made up only 7% of the total population, possessed approximately half the land. By 1917, 55% of all the usable land was possessed by the rich people. By owning land and livestock the toyons were in a position to exploit the needy masses of the population. The forms that the exploitation took were greatly varied; they included elements characteristic of capitalist relations and the older patriarchal-feudal forms, as well as hidden survivals of slavery. For example, it was the practice to hire laborers—khamnachyts—usually for a definite period, particularly for haymaking; they were hired to carry firewood, build yurts and so on. They were paid either in money or in kind; and the method used was usually the typical Yakut system of payment (remuneration in advance), which was called “to take a contract” from the toyon for this or that work. This system of contracting was very advantageous to the richer people, since they then had complete power over the laborers. In return for a paltry sum received in advance, the poor person was sometimes in the toyon’s clutches for a long time to come.' [775] 'The system of contracting was also applied in other cases; advances were paid by the toyons for the supply of a whole variety of products, ranging from butter and hay right down to wild duck eggs. This system was a form of extremely cruel exploitation. One observer (V. F. Troshchanskiy, an exiled member of Narodnaya Volya wrote outright that the “welfare of the population will not be improved as long as this system exists in its present form.”' [776] 'Another very common form of exploitation was the handing over of the milch cattle to the poor people by the toyons for their use and for feeding, the so-called system of khahaas. At an earlier stage (at the beginning of the 19th century) the livestock was taken over, usually for a year, from spring to spring, but at the end of the 19th century it was more common to take over the cattle for only the summer (the distribution of livestock for feeding during the winter—uostur—was a separate process). In return for use of the cow, the poor peasant had to pay the toyon, as was the custom, 30 pounds of melted butter and 12-15 poods of tar (frozen sour milk) in the autumn; sometimes this was replaced or supplemented by compulsory service for the benefit [Page 273] of the toyon. This custom was a very typical and often extremely cruel form of exploitation. The winter upkeep of the livestock was a still more burdensome, enslaving agreement; in return for a head of cattle, the toyon usually paid 1 ruble, 50 kopeks or 2 rubles for the whole winter, whereas in actual fact the upkeep cost at least 5 rubles, and so it was only the poor peasants driven by need who entered into such agreements.' [777] 'A still more typical custom, the origin of which in ancient times was connected with mutual assistance between clan members, but which later became in fact one of the forms of exploitation, was kumalaanism. A kumalaan was a poor peasant, a disabled person, an orphan or sometimes all the members of an impoverished family, who were assigned by the whole community to live for a certain time with a rich man or wealthy kinsman who would maintain them. Officially, the adoption of a kumalaan was regarded as an act of charity, and a way of helping a kinsman in need. But in actual fact the custom concealed the cruelest exploitation of unpaid labor. In many cases it was a disguised form of slavery and lasted a long time.' [778] Toyons legitimated their superior position by presenting themselves as patriarchal benefactors: 'Apart from these individual customs, the Yakut society admittedly retained the characteristic, half-conscious patriarchal ideology, which was clearly not a reflection of their true relationships, although it served the interests of the toyons, who knew how to make use of it. The toyons liked to style themselves the forefathers, heads and sponsors of their clans; they skillfully fomented various interclan quarrels (usually [Page 276] over land), thereby sustaining the fiction of community of clan interests. A poor kinsman used to call a toyon who had robbed him of his possessions aga (father), and was expected to look upon him as his “benefactor.”' [779] Toyons also derived their names from deities: 'In the cult of both the benevolent and malevolent deities, a part was played at one stage by the military aristocracy—the toyons; they were usually the organizers. In their legendary genealogies the toyons often derived their names from the great and powerful deities.' [780] Most people were poor and of lower status: 'In pre-Revolutionary Yakutiya the poor and middle peasant families totaled more than 80 percent of all households. One-seventh of all the households were entirely without sowings, and many were only able to sow a few hundredths of a hectare each. Most of the households (97 percent) had to do without factory-made agricultural implements. Stockbreeding produced extremely poor results. The owners of large areas of land and abundant livestock i.e.,—the kulaks and toyons, grew rich, but not so much by raising the level of land cultivation and animal husbandry as by exploiting the poor and middle peasants.' [781] Coercion and exploitation exercisted by toyons continued into the early Soviet period: 'During the first two years of the Soviet regime the situation hardly changed for the better. There was redistribution of the land in 1923-24, but the reform only partly cut down the amount of land used by the toyons and virtually made no difference to the burdensome state of the poor people. For example, the nonrepartitional land expropriated by the toyons on the basis of their “clearing right” was left in their possession. It was only the second land reform of 1929 that put an end to toyon coercion and created a situation in which the agriculture of Yakutiya could be improved. About 150,000 hectares of the best land, formerly owned by the toyons and kulaks, then passed into the hands of the working peasantry.' [782]
♠ Ideological thought equates men and women ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates people of all locations ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes rulers and commoners ♣ present ♥
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes elites and commoners ♣ present ♥ Sakha society was organized in patrilineal clans, not social classes: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [783] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [784] 'By customary law, land, cattle, and horses, although used by households, were controlled by the patriline. Animal or land sale and inheritance was approved by elders. But by the twentieth century, smaller families were keeping resources, in part because of the decline of large horse droves. Men owned most of the wealth, and passed it to sons, especially elder sons, although the youngest son often inherited the family yurt. Mothers could pass on dowries to daughters, unless the dowry was forfeited by bad behavior. In theory, dowries included land, as well as goods, jewelry, and animals, although in practice elders rarely gave land to another lineage. Soviet law limited inheritance to goods and nonstate housing could be bequeathed at individual discretion. Most apartments and summer houses were kept in families.' [785] However, wealth stratification was present and Russian imperial authorities co-opted native toyons: 'Precise historical accounts of the Yakuts only date from the time of their first contact with the Russians, that is to say, 1620, and annexation to the Russian State. At that time the Yakuts were not a single political unit, but were divided into a number of independent tribes. Tribal relations were already decomposing, however, and there was a fairly clearly marked class stratification. The tsarist voyevods and soldiery took advantage of the intertribal strife to break the resistance of some of the Yakut population; they also took advantage of the class differences within it by pursuing a policy of systematic support of the ruling aristocratic clique, the princelings (toyons), whom they turned into their own agents for purposes of governing the Yakut district. From that moment on, the class differences among the Yakuts began to become more clearly marked.' [786] 'Such, in general terms, was the social structure of the Yakuts by the time the Russians arrived. Tsarist policy between the 17th and 19th centuries speeded up the development of social relations, so that Yakut society just before the October Revolution had already changed very much from what it had been three centuries ago. Nevertheless, many phenomena proved extremely stable and retained their archaic nature until recent times. Just before the Revolution the division of the Yakuts into strata according to the property they possessed was extremely marked. Most of the population did not even have enough cattle for the hunger norm (this norm, when the grade of the livestock was low, was considered to be two head of livestock per person), whereas in the few toyon households there were several dozen head of livestock per person. However, the unequal distribution of the livestock was by no means anything new for the Yakuts. But the question of land was different. The system which had grown up in the domain of land tenure was of comparatively recent origin. Since the arrival of the Russians in Yakutiya, the process of decomposition of the ancient communal-clan system of using the meadowland had been stepped up. The toyons were vigorously seeking to acquire the common lands. The development of private land ownership by the toyons continued to the 1760’s, when certain measures introduced by the Russian administration gave it a new direction. In 1765, Yakuts were forbidden to buy or sell land, and in the next few years, through the activity of the Yakut Tribute Commission, the distribution of land in accordance with the so-called “sable” and “fox” taxes or parts of them was introduced among the Yakuts. Later on, in about 1820, this distribution of land assumed the form of the so-called “class system” of land usage, which legalized the extremely unequal distribution of the land, though, on the surface, it seemed to be something like common land usage. This “class system,” which was later modified, had assumed the following form by the beginning of the 20th century.' [787] 'The unit of measurement of land among the Yakuts was the “rick” ([unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown]), a plot of land from which one hayrick could be mown (the size of the rick ranged from 10 to 30 cartloads, sometimes as many as 40 or 60). These allotments made up plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) which were extremely varied in size, depending on the “class,” and there were three or four “classes.” One first-class plot ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ) was equal to two secondclass plots ([unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] [unknown][unknown][unknown]γ[unknown][unknown]) and three or four third-class plots (kenniki or [unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] ). The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called[unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown][unknown] -[unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). [Page 272] Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [788] 'In the second half of the 19th century the custom of equalizing of the land each year in accordance with the yield of grass came into use. The harvest was evaluated by elected “deputies,” and those whose harvest was poorer than it should have been in view of the plot had the right to an extra quota of hay, and vice versa. This was called bebierke (from the Russian word poverka [adjustment]). But in actual fact this custom did not reduce inequality, for the “deputies” always acted in favor of the more influential (toyon) section of the population, to which they themselves very often belonged.' [789] Tokarev describes the system of labour and cattle hire as a form of institutionalized exploitation: 'Generally speaking, the toyons possessed a large proportion of the available land, and the best part, to boot. For example, in 1908 two-thirds of all the land in the First Ospetskiy Nasleg in the Dyupsyunskiy Ulus belonged to five toyon households. In the Suntarskiy Ulus the toyons, who made up only 7% of the total population, possessed approximately half the land. By 1917, 55% of all the usable land was possessed by the rich people. By owning land and livestock the toyons were in a position to exploit the needy masses of the population. The forms that the exploitation took were greatly varied; they included elements characteristic of capitalist relations and the older patriarchal-feudal forms, as well as hidden survivals of slavery. For example, it was the practice to hire laborers—khamnachyts—usually for a definite period, particularly for haymaking; they were hired to carry firewood, build yurts and so on. They were paid either in money or in kind; and the method used was usually the typical Yakut system of payment (remuneration in advance), which was called “to take a contract” from the toyon for this or that work. This system of contracting was very advantageous to the richer people, since they then had complete power over the laborers. In return for a paltry sum received in advance, the poor person was sometimes in the toyon’s clutches for a long time to come.' [790] 'The system of contracting was also applied in other cases; advances were paid by the toyons for the supply of a whole variety of products, ranging from butter and hay right down to wild duck eggs. This system was a form of extremely cruel exploitation. One observer (V. F. Troshchanskiy, an exiled member of Narodnaya Volya wrote outright that the “welfare of the population will not be improved as long as this system exists in its present form.”' [791] 'Another very common form of exploitation was the handing over of the milch cattle to the poor people by the toyons for their use and for feeding, the so-called system of khahaas. At an earlier stage (at the beginning of the 19th century) the livestock was taken over, usually for a year, from spring to spring, but at the end of the 19th century it was more common to take over the cattle for only the summer (the distribution of livestock for feeding during the winter—uostur—was a separate process). In return for use of the cow, the poor peasant had to pay the toyon, as was the custom, 30 pounds of melted butter and 12-15 poods of tar (frozen sour milk) in the autumn; sometimes this was replaced or supplemented by compulsory service for the benefit [Page 273] of the toyon. This custom was a very typical and often extremely cruel form of exploitation. The winter upkeep of the livestock was a still more burdensome, enslaving agreement; in return for a head of cattle, the toyon usually paid 1 ruble, 50 kopeks or 2 rubles for the whole winter, whereas in actual fact the upkeep cost at least 5 rubles, and so it was only the poor peasants driven by need who entered into such agreements.' [792] 'A still more typical custom, the origin of which in ancient times was connected with mutual assistance between clan members, but which later became in fact one of the forms of exploitation, was kumalaanism. A kumalaan was a poor peasant, a disabled person, an orphan or sometimes all the members of an impoverished family, who were assigned by the whole community to live for a certain time with a rich man or wealthy kinsman who would maintain them. Officially, the adoption of a kumalaan was regarded as an act of charity, and a way of helping a kinsman in need. But in actual fact the custom concealed the cruelest exploitation of unpaid labor. In many cases it was a disguised form of slavery and lasted a long time.' [793] Toyons legitimated their superior position by presenting themselves as patriarchal benefactors: 'Apart from these individual customs, the Yakut society admittedly retained the characteristic, half-conscious patriarchal ideology, which was clearly not a reflection of their true relationships, although it served the interests of the toyons, who knew how to make use of it. The toyons liked to style themselves the forefathers, heads and sponsors of their clans; they skillfully fomented various interclan quarrels (usually [Page 276] over land), thereby sustaining the fiction of community of clan interests. A poor kinsman used to call a toyon who had robbed him of his possessions aga (father), and was expected to look upon him as his “benefactor.”' [794] Toyons also derived their names from deities: 'In the cult of both the benevolent and malevolent deities, a part was played at one stage by the military aristocracy—the toyons; they were usually the organizers. In their legendary genealogies the toyons often derived their names from the great and powerful deities.' [795] Most people were poor and of lower status: 'In pre-Revolutionary Yakutiya the poor and middle peasant families totaled more than 80 percent of all households. One-seventh of all the households were entirely without sowings, and many were only able to sow a few hundredths of a hectare each. Most of the households (97 percent) had to do without factory-made agricultural implements. Stockbreeding produced extremely poor results. The owners of large areas of land and abundant livestock i.e.,—the kulaks and toyons, grew rich, but not so much by raising the level of land cultivation and animal husbandry as by exploiting the poor and middle peasants.' [796] Coercion and exploitation exercisted by toyons continued into the early Soviet period: 'During the first two years of the Soviet regime the situation hardly changed for the better. There was redistribution of the land in 1923-24, but the reform only partly cut down the amount of land used by the toyons and virtually made no difference to the burdensome state of the poor people. For example, the nonrepartitional land expropriated by the toyons on the basis of their “clearing right” was left in their possession. It was only the second land reform of 1929 that put an end to toyon coercion and created a situation in which the agriculture of Yakutiya could be improved. About 150,000 hectares of the best land, formerly owned by the toyons and kulaks, then passed into the hands of the working peasantry.' [797]
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes all ethnicities ♣ suspected unknown ♥ The sources report a high degree of cross-cultural and cross-'ethnic' hybridization: 'In the north, beyond the inner mountain range, closer to the sea, where the Yakut population penetrates along the valleys of rivers and brooks far into the mountain country, the influence of Tungus and Yukaghir (Mongol-Manchurian) blood is less strongly felt. The Dolgan, whose way of live is similar to that of the Tungus and who dress in the same way, are taken for Tungus by many, although they speak the Yakut language and their traditions clearly point to a mixed half-Yakut origin. The Yukaghir who at one time inhabited thickly the lower reaches 240 [Page 449] of the Yana, Indigirka, and Kolyma Rivers have disappeared, swallowed up by the Yakut. The same thing has happened to many Tungus clans. In the Kolymsk Ulus I came across many households, known to be Tungus, who lived in the Yakut manner and who had intermarried and become related to the Yakut. In the northern parts of the Dyupsyunsk and Bayagantaysk uluses adjoining the southern spurs of the Verkhoyansk Mountains, where Tungus still lead nomadic lives, numerous Tungus families appear in years of famine; they hire themselves out to the Yakut as workmen, or live at the expense of the ulus. Such families often remain permanently among the Yakut. In cases of their parent's death, orphaned children are willingly adopted by well-to-do Yakut. The same thing happens in other places where Tungus and Yakut live side by side. Many Tungus in the Vilyuysk Okrug have become Yakutized, and some of them even have numerous herds of horned cattle... Most of them speak the Yakut language, and few of them know their nat ive tongue..., Maak remarks on this subject. Each year, in winter, in the Olekminsk Okrug, Tungus come into the Yakut settlements and live there side by side with the Yakut, in the same yurts, during the coldest months.' [798] 'They come at the beginning of Advent and leave at the end of maslyanka (the week before Lent). They bring their hosts presents: furs, nuts, and squirrel and bear meat. They buy horse meat, khayak and flour from the Yakut: they like these things very much. Then life is gay. Every day there is singing and dancing. The Tungus like [Page 450] merriment, the grown-ups as well as the little children; they talk to the Yakut with songs. After the dancing various things happen..., a Yakut woman who had lived in the Olekminsk Okrug for a long time told me (Namsk Ulus, 1887).' [799] 'The Tungus of the Maya River (a tributary of the Aldan), as can be seen from the travel notes of General Svetlitskii, have also become partly Yakutized and even engage in cattle raising and agriculture. ' [800] We are unsure whether ethnic stratification (apart from stratification between 'natives' and Russians) was present. More material is needed before a coding decision can be taken.
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes men and women ♣ present ♥ Labour was divided along gender lines, but cooperation within the household was common: 'Although occupations within a household were divided by gender and status, the atmosphere was usually one of productive group activity. All participated in hay making, cattle herding, and milking, but, in general, horses were more a male preserve and cattle a female responsibility. Women tended children and fires, prepared food, carried water, and made clothing and pottery. Men handled more strenuous firewood preparation, house building, sled making, hunting, fishing, and mowing. Ivory carving and wood- and metalworking were male tasks.' [801] Generally, women were less valued than men: 'Despite the fact that with respect to marriage the sons still are in a position of dependence upon the parents, their situation is considerably freer than that of the girls. A widowed daughter, returning to the parental home, again falls under the authority of the father; she is as devoid of rights as her young unmarried sister. The more independent position of the son is explained chiefly by the fact that the family and the clan prize children of the male sex more highly than those of the female sex: the birth of a boy is greeted by the Yakut with greater joy than the birth of a girl. Yakuts who do not have sons are scorned by their neighbors: they call them khatirik-uoma, i.e. “fire from bark (?).” The small esteem in which girl children are held by the Yakuts is indicated by the rule, whereby 54 a widow who marries for a second time must leave her sons by the first marriage with the family of her husband; but the daughters, as an unnecessary element in the family group, she can take with her to her new family. This rule is obviously of comparativelyrecent origin: it could arise only after the widow became free in general to marry outside of the confines of her husband’s group, and after the kalym had begun to lose its significance of a purchase price for the bride, and had begun to return to the family of the bridegroom in the form of a dowry. Gaining nothing by giving a daughter in marriage, the Yakut familial-household group naturally regards daughters as a completely superfluous element in the family, and sets no value on them.' [802] Mothers influenced marriage arrangements of their children, but fathers retained superior authority over sons and especially daughters: 'The Yakut is not in the full possession of his rights until he is married. The unmarried son cannot even ask for a share of the family goods without a particularly valid reason, even if he does not live with his father, for instance, when there is an older son in the family. Only after marriage does the grown-up Yakut step forth as an independent personality. In the question of marriage the authority of the father over the person of his son finds graphic expression. It is true that, in the words of Mr. Pripuzov, in the selection of a bride for the son, or of a bridegroom for the daughter, the consent of the mother carries more weight than that of the father. In this privilege of the women before the man, which, incidentally, is guaranteed by nothing more than moral principles, is contained the only advantage of the wife and mother. But the authority of the father expresses itself above all in the right to give in marriage his under-age son or daughter. The information communicated, for example, by Mr. Shchukin (Zh. M. V. D. [RCH: I have been unable to determine what these initials stand for] 1854, VII, p. 26), that the Yakut himself selects his bride and announces his choice to his parents, is confirmed neither by Mr. Pripuzov nor by other investigators. On the contrary, marriages, or at least betrothals, of under-age children, appear to be very widespread, even at the present time among the Yakuts. “As formerly, so now,” writes Mr. Pripuzov, “the Yakuts marry off young children, for which purpose the parents come to an agreement, determining the bride price, and the children have a church marriage upon coming of age.” 52 On the basis of other sources there is even reason to consider the betrothal of young children almost general among the Yakuts: this is done with the object of easing the payment of the bride price, payment of which, in installments, is begun by the parents of the bridegroom immediately after the conclusion of the agreement. “With the payment of the first installments of the bride price, the child-bridegroom acquires, so to speak conjugal rights with respect to his bride, who herself is still but a child. He is often a guest at the home of his future wife, sleeps with her and, having grown up, becomes her factual husband.” (Vsesoiuznoe Geograficheskoe Obshchestvo, Vostochno-Sibirskii Otdel, Izv[unknown]iesti[unknown]ia, XXVI, No. 4-5, p. 214).' [803] Wives/husbands generally held fewer rights than men, but their legal status improved during the Russian period: 'The absence of any rights on the part of woman, among the Yakuts of the district studied by M. Pripuzov, is most marked. . . in the field of property relations. Her personal position is at the present time considerably better protected than in earlier times. In this respect one notes in the life of the Yakuts a definite, although naturally a very relative progress. In effect, even at present, the husband considers himself within his rights to beat up his wife if she neglects her household duties, if she is a spendthrift, or if she is unfaithful to him. The Yakut further has the right to put his wife out to hire as a workwoman, and to use the money earned by her. But he does not have the right to kill her; he cannot sell her, or lend her to someone else.' [804] 'Instances of the cession of wives to other men, as is known, were encountered among the Yakuts up to the end of the 18th century, while the existence of the custom of lending one’s wife to a guest is substantiated by traditions (Vseso[unknown]iuzone Geograficheskoe ob[unknown]shchestvo, Vostochno-Sibirskii Otdel, Izviest[unknown]iia, XXVI, No. 4-5, pp. 218-19). As concerns instances of putting our wives to work, Prince Kostrov (Ocherk iuridicheskoe byta IAkutov [Juridical Customs of the Yakut]. p. 283) communicates the rather interesting fact that this practice has as its object to effect a separation from the wife: after a church wedding the Yakut rarely leaves his wife, but since such marriages are often consummated against the will of the parties involved, the husband sometimes abandons his wife, who customarily finds herself a lover, to whom she goes to live. In order to avoid prosecution by the authorities, writes Prince Kostrov, the husband and the lover make an oral and sometimes even written agreement to the effect that the former is hiring his wife out to the latter in the capacity of a servant with her consent and for the upkeep of the household.' [805] 'If the husband beat his wife without good reason, from the point of view of the Yakuts, she has the right to complain to the clan government or to apply for protection to the Natives’ Court. The husband is not oblidged to maintain fidelity; he can abandon his wife, live in another place, cohabit with another woman. The wife, on the contrary; must preserve fidelity, although occasional relations with other men, if they take place with the consent of the husband, are regarded by the Yakuts with complete indifference. 43 Although at the present time the personal position of the wife in relation to her husband has changed for the better, in comparison with the past, to her lot, nevertheless, continues to fall the most arduous domestic labor. Except where the family is rich, or the wife is richer than the husband, the duties of the woman include more than the care of the household: the care of the cattle, the making of cheese and butter, the painting of the yurt, and often even the mowing of hay, cutting of wood, etc., if the husband cannot manage the other jobs by himself.' [806] But property rights of women remained limited and their support systems were generally weaker: 'The property rights of women are extremely limited; however, even in this direction certain changes are taking place under the influence of the gradual recognition of woman’s capacity. These innovations, however, are apparently only beginning to penetrate the consciousness of the Yakuts, and have not yet succeeded in conclusively changing the archaic views, denying property rights to women.' [807] 'In relations to her own family group the woman is completely without rights: she must marry into a strange clan, and it is understandable that her kinsmen look upon her as a severed member.' [808] This was largely due to the practice of patrilineal transmission: 'Each clan or familial unit, under the influence of the impulse of self-preservation in the struggle for existence, strives insofar as possible to insure its economic existence through the accumulation of wealth. Naturally, it jealously guards its property against transfer into the hands of members of a strange clan; it is here that we must seek the reason for the fact that women have no rights in relation to the property belonging to their kin group. Among the Yakuts, the latter, as is the case everywhere with peoples on a low level of economic development, permits a girl to accumulate property by her personal labor: the product of her personal exertions, whether sewing or other handicraft, becomes part of her possessions, but among the Yakuts, as is the case everywhere, the girl secures the right of ownership of the products of her labor only in the degree that she performs this labor during her hours of leisure and rest, after having performed the household duties which fall to her share. The same rule, it appears, applies 44 to married women. Woman, as a member of her kin group prior to marriage, and subsequently in the capacity of a worker for her husband and his group, has only a portion of the time for her own use, and the group concedes to her as personal property only what she can produce after satisfying the needs of her father’s or her husband’s family.' [809] 'The absence of property rights on the part of women in relation to their kin group in graphically expressed in the exclusion of women from inheritance. If the economic and administrative principle lying at the foundation of the family constructed on a blood basis makes quite natural the rule of Yakut customary law, that sisters cannot inherit from brothers, that upon the death of a brother his cultivated land passes to another brother, although the latter might already have a farmstead, then in the exclusion of women from inheritance from the parents, where only daughters survived, we must see a direct consequence of the clan structure, in which the kinsmen vigilantly watch to see that the clan property does not pass to a strange clan, which inevitably happens in the case of the marriage of a girl-legatee.' [810] 'M. Pripuzov informs us that upon the death of a person survived only by daughters, the legatees are in the first place his brothers, i. e., the uncles on the paternal side. Further, if the father of the deceased is alive, then by the general rule of Yakut customary law in the district investigated, which makes the parents the legatees of their children deceased without issue, he secures a larger share of the inheritance than the other relations. Where death takes place without male issue, the situation is the same as if there were no issue at all. Finally, the remaining relations come in for their share of the inheritance. A part of the property is set aside for the support and subsistence of the daughters, the remainder is divided between the relations with the closer relations securing a larger part (the father gets more than the rest), while the more distant relatives get a lesser share. A married daughter, like the unmarried daughters, is excluded form sharing in the paternal inheritance: in any case, she cannot inherit her father’s cultivated land, and if there are no direct heirs, the farm passes to the closest relations.' [811] 'The brothers, excluding their sisters from inheritance of the paternal property, are nevertheless obliged to support their unmarried sisters, to concern themselves with giving them in marriage, and to provide them with dowries from the general property. Mr. Priklonski, however, (Tri goda v[unknown] IAkutskoi oblasti [three years in the Yakutsk territory]. Zhiva[unknown]ia Starina, 1890, pt. 3, p. 80). notes that the share of the daughters in the division of property upon the death of the father is equal to that of the brothers; this share goes to the brothers, for the support of the sisters.' [812] 'That in effect it is the economic principle, in union with the blood principle, and not the fact of the grant of a dowry to a girl entering into marriage, that lies at the basis of the exclusion of women from the paternal inheritance, is demonstrated by the fact that the dowry itself does not in any way correspond to the shares which fall to the lot of the sons upon the death of the father. Mr. Pripuzov unfortunately communicates only extremely fragmentary and incomplete information concerning the size of the dowry, concerning the objects which go to make it up, and concerning the relation of the personal property of the girl, accumulated by her own labor, to the dowry given by her parents at the time of marriage.' [813] 'Neither Mr. Pripuzov, nor, as far as we know, any other investigators of the customary law of the Yakuts, have given us a clear answer to the question as to the relationship in which the personally earned property of the girl stands to her dowry. Is this personal property.. 47 ..combined with the dowry given by the parents, or does it form a separate type of female personal ownership among the Yakuts? We do not know. As concerns the dowry given by the parents at the time of the daughter’s marriage, the absence of rights on the part of the woman in the agnatic group of her husband, as well as the very origin of the dowry in the returned part of the kalym, render completely natural the rule of Yakut customary law, whereby the woman is not the owner of her dowry. The latter, writes Mr. Pripuzov, “is completely at the disposal of the husband.” The husband is the owner of his wife’s dowry; he answers to no one for his squandering of it. A logical consequence of this order of things are the following rules, noted by Mr. Pripuzov, in the Yakutsk district: 1. In the case of the death of the wife the dowry is not returned, but passes to the husband and his children. 2. In the case of the death of the husband, if the couple had no children of the male sex, the wife can take her dowry and return to her parents. But she can only have the dowry back under the condtition that her husband made a disposition in that sense before his death: in its absence, the dowry, as a part of the familial-clan property, passes to the closest relatives of the deceased, and the wife has no right to claim it back from the heirs.' [814] Some rights of women, especially widows, were introduced during the Russian period: 'The right of the widow in the event of a childless marriage to return to her own family, the right of the husband to arrange before his death for the return of the dowry to his widow--all these rules, it appears, rose under the influence of the progressive softening of views on the personal and property incapacity of women. At an earlier time she was completely the property of her husband’s group. Actually, we have no definite information concerning the existence of the levirate among the Yakuts at a former time; but the rules forbidding women to show themselves before the father-in-law and brothers-in-law, and vice versa, obviously bearing the character of so-called “sexual precaution” are traces of a one-time polyandry; finally, the absence among the Yakuts of any proper term for “widow,” etc. (Sieroszewski, 569), compel us to assume that at a more remote time 48 the widow was considered the personal property of the family of the husband and probably passed to them as a piece of property. ' [815] 'At the present time a widow can remain with her children after the death of her husband. The liberating tendency in favor of women in the development of customary law in the Yakutsk district is reflected in the fact that if a widow has young children of the male sex, she becomes the complete mistress of her husband’s property; she freely disposes of it until the children reach their majority. More archaic views on woman’s rights, however, are reflected in the fact that when the children reach their majority they have the right to proceed to the division of their grandfather’s and father’s property without seeking the consent of their mother. To her is assigned some indefinite part of the property, but always smaller than the share of each of the sons. The right of wives to one-fourth part of their husband’s property, which is attested to in the Sbornik obychnago prava Sibiriskikh inord[unknown]tsev [Compilation of the Customary Law of the Siberian Natives] p. 234. probably was the result of the influence of the Russians, and apparantly found very little reflection in life. The Yakuts of the Yakutsk district, at least, do not know this rule, if we are to judge by the information imparted to us by Mr. Pripuzov. The Yakut clan, permitting a certain economic independence to a widow with young children of the male sex, who are independent members of the clan unit, completely sets aside the widow, if her late husband left only children of the female sex. In such an eventuality, the situation, as we noted above, is held to be the same as if the man had died without issue: a certain part of the property is assigned to the widow with daughters, all the rest goes to the relatives of the deceased. Incidentally, a more humane attitude toward women sometimes induces these relatives to permit the widow and her daughters to live on the farmstead of her deceased husband, depriving her, however, of the right to dispose of the farm. In the event of the death of the widow, 49 (or if she should marry a second time) the farm passes to the relatives of the deceased husband.' [816] 'The following rules, conceding certain rights to women, must be considered the result of the new views: 1. The wife has the right to complain against her husband if the latter, by his improvidence, is ruining the household; 2. The wife is conceded the right to contract debts; the wife is not responsible for the debts contracted by her husband for his own personal needs, and conversely the husband is not responsible for the personal debts of his wife. An exception is made when the couple offer surety for each other. These rules stand in such contradiciton to the personal and property incapacity of women that there can be no doubt of their later origin.' [817] But women remained in an inferior legal position: 'The facts adduced here testify that despite certain improvements in the attitude toward the personal and property rights of women, the position of the latter is still far from enviable: clan and household bases principally regulate the structure of Yakut life.' [818] 'One cannot yet speak of the independence or equal rights of women among the Yakuts: even the rule making the parents the legatees of their children who died without issue, changes its aspect, if the deceased is survived only by a mother; while the father inherits all or the greater part of the property, the rights of the mother or widow to the property of children dead without issue are only equal to the rights of the other heirs.' [819]
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes people from different locations ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Ideological reinforcement of inequality ♣ present ♥ See examples above.

♠ Ideological reinforcement of monogamy ♣ present ♥ Sakha society was organized in patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [820] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [821] eHRAF provides a general description of the marriage system. While polygyny was practiced, monogamy was more common: 'Traditionally, for wealthy Yakut, marriage could be polygamous. More common, however, was monogamy, with occasional remarriage after the death of a spouse. Arranged marriages were sometimes politically motivated. Patrilineage exogamy was reckoned strictly; those one could marry were called SYGAN. Until the 1920s many marriage arrangements were complicated and protracted, involving financial, emotional, and symbolic resources of the bride's and groom's extended families. This included the matchmaking ritual; several formal payments of animals, furs, and meat to the bride's family; informal gifts; and extensive dowries. Some families permitted poor grooms to work in their households as a replacement for the bride-price. Occasionally bride-capture occurred (it may have been more common in pre-Russian times). Wedding ceremonies and their attendant feasts, prayers, and dancing, were held first at the household of the bride's parents, then at that of the groom's. The couple usually lived or settled in a nearby yurt. Since the 1970s interest in limited aspects of ritual and gift exchange has revived, although few couples are paired through matchmakers. In the 1980s one young man was chagrined to find that a woman he had fallen in love with on a train was a distant cousin, a forbidden marriage partner according to kin rules still observed.' [822] 'Polygamy has existed since ancient times among many of the Yakut; however, a man never had more than five wives at a time. The reasons for this are as follows: 1) the Yakut promise their children in marriage at an early age, and the children, by the time they are of age, have ceased to love one another, and therefore the husband takes a second wife; 2) if a man lives with his wife for several years without having any children, he takes a second and a third merely in order to have children; 3) the rich Yakut had many wives to supervise their houses and cattle, which they usually had in many places, for the wives ran their estates more diligently than outside hired men; thus the farm is improved and the estate is guarded; 4) if they leave their wives, even those whom they have married in church, because of some bad behavior or because they are permanently delirious, or rendered completely incapable of taking care of house and cattle as a result of some disease which deprived them of sight, speech, arms, and legs, since the Yakut leave the whole house and cattle-raising to the wife's care, they take other wives and leave the former one's in their houses; 5) various other circumstances induce the Yakut to practise polygamy; the principle reason is the desire to have good supervision of the households and an increase of the cattle; 6) having had several 221 wives before conversion, and having married one in church after conversion but without abandoning the others, the Yakut will keep them in his [Page 15] houses with their children, and some without children because they are sterile. Such polygamy, which is tolerated for the above reasons, and which has existed since ancient times and does not do any harm, had not become bad in the judgement of the Yakut, and no regulations for the abolition of this custom have been set up by the Yakut. However, since the Yakut adopted the Christian faith, and as they have become enlightened by strict surveillance and sometimes by indulgent reprimands from the eparchial priests, it has been gradually dying out, but nevertheless denunciations on this subject are made concerning people who have lawfully wedded wives but keep the others, and people who had several wives before conversion and married one of them in church without leaving the others, who were left at home with their children; in the case of such a denunciation the local authorities, on the grounds of the repugnance of the Christian religion for this custom, pressed formal charges, and the guilty parties were handed over to the clerical court as fornicators, and the cases were decided according to general state laws, which constituted and still constitute and extreme burden for the Yakut.' [823] Exogamy was the norm, and the sources mention bride-price and dowry arrangements: 'To the end of the eighteenth century, there remained in vogue among the Yakut the custom of concession of wives. Formerly the bridegroom lived permanently in the house of his father-in-law, but in more recent times he lived there only for a definite period.' [824] 'The kalym, or bride-price, replaced the system of marriage by capture. The origin of the kalym may be seen in the simulated enmity of the mother-in-law and the son-in-law.' [825] 'A matriarchal system presupposes looseness of sex relations. The chastity of girls in rich families is not a question of morality but of kalym . The kalym for a widow or a girl who has had children is low. In the case of a widow, the belief in the right of the deceased husband may limit the number of wooers. A girl with a child, however, is sometimes preferred as a guaranty against barrenness which the Yakut dislike. In Yakut tales, the guest does not ask, “Where shall I sleep?”, but, “Where do you put your guests?” and then they are shown to the beds of the girls. This is a form of hospitable hetaerism.' [826] 'The Yakut look for brides for their sons not only outside of their clans ( us, nasleg ), but outside of the ulus, or union of clans. A girl, say the Yakut, is really a lot of aliens. This saying is reminiscent of the old time marriage by capture. Marriage is now also exogamic, but kalym (brideprice) is given in money, cattle, and other goods. Practically, the kalym may be regarded as an exchange of presents. What the parents of the bride receive from the parents of the bridegroom is almost equivalent to what they give her when she leaves their house. Often the bride carries with her cattle and goods of a greater value than her parents received that she may not be reproached by the bridegroom’s relatives for bringing only a small dowry with her. The young bride remains under the protection of her clan and family. Many common law customs regulate disagreements and dissensions: If a young woman leaves her husband because she dislikes him, her dowry remains with him; but, if she accuses him of cruelties, relatives on both sides decide the matter. The Yakut do not like to appeal to the Russian courts.' [827] 'The Yakut were warlike and blood vengeance between clans occurred very often, but reconciliation was often sought through payment of a ransom or by giving a girl in marriage, the best way to end hostilities. It was more difficult to compound assassinations within the clan. To kill the murderer would deprive the clan of another member and the punishment had to take the form of ransom, service, or public disapproval.' [828] Sieroszewski describes these payments: 'If we analyse the component parts of the kalym and their names and designations we see that this expense is always the essential part of the payment for a bride. The amount of the kalym aries greatly, between several rubles and several hundred rubles. Sometimes it is even as much as one and one-half or two thousand rubles. Usually the amount is somewhere around the mean between these figures - that is, one hundred rubles. Most families would not have the means to pay so large an amount were it not for the fact that most of it is returned in the form of a dowry.' [829] 'According to custom only the kurum, hat is, the part that goes for hospitality, and other minor additions for the same purpose, [Page 857] are paid by the bridegroom without return. The payment given to the bride's parents, sulu, and the presents given to the relatives and match-makers, tyunngyur-khodogoy kesite, is afterwards given back in the form of a dowry, enne, and presents, 546 torkyut. Since the bridegroom usually assumes his conjungal rights immediately after the festivities, if he dies the kurum is never given back, but only half of the sulu, if this has been paid. The amounts of various parts of the kalym are strictly 547 determined by the agreement, [Page 858 is blank] [Page 859] kil'tegan. It also varies greatly in different localities, and depends on the force of the ancient customs, and the prosperity and way of life of the inhabitants. Even in the same locality it differs for each wedded couple, depending on the affluence of their parents, their stinginess or generosity and their attachment to their children.' [830] 'The Yakut maintain that in older days the kalym was bigger, and I have noticed that it is infact larger in less cultured localities, where the ancient customs are still strong. Thus the amount of cattle exchanged and killed at weddings in the Kolymsk and Verkhoyansk uluses or in remote uluses of the Yakutsk Okrug is a considerably greater part of the total property of those who are getting married that in more cultured localities, near a city or in the south, despite the fact that there is more cattle in the south. In the latter uluses we notice a tendency to convert the larger part of the kalym into money, and to replace the meat offered as hospitality with flour, butter, and vodka, for which no norms and rules have been worked out. This allows this part of the expense to be decreased unnoticably. Nowhere, however, has the kalym disappeared, and poor people will often slaughter their only cow or mare for a wedding, as the bridegroom's present, so that the parents only had to give around ten rubles in money as payment for the bride, sulu. In the meantime, it is their duty to dress the bride and give her at least a few household utensils. To be sure, there are people who give their daughter very little or nothing at all even though they have received a considerable kalym.' [831] 'However, such cases are rare. They are either a result of the sudden impoverishment of a heretofore rich family or a consequence of a bridegroom's particular passion for a girl, which her parents notice and which they never miss a chance to profit by.' [832] 'Popular opinion condemns such behavior. Nevertheless I have seen very respected and even loving fathers who sucked all they could get from their sons-in-law when they visited their brides, still living 548 at home. Parents never give their daughters to their husbands immediately after the wedding. This is the custom, and parents also give as an excuse either that they must prepare the dowry, or that their daughter is unaccustomed to marriage, or that she is too young, and so forth; this is true even if they have been married and the kalym has been paid, or the agreement has been made to pay it immediately. In the old days this state sometimes lasted for four or five years, and still earlier the Yakut had the custom to marry their children when they were very young. During this time the bridegroom visits his bride at his leisure and must bring her a present each time he does so - a thigh piece or two of meat, a fox, or some other present, as payment for being allowed to exercise his conjungal rights. More than once I have heard fathers order this thing or that - sometimes a great deal. The son-in-law obediently heard him out, but grumbled once out of sight and carried out only part of the promise. Often all this is a burdensome addition to the conditions agreed upon when the match was arranged.' [833] 'When that time comes, and the bride brings less to the house than was expected, the bridegroom's relatives greet her very coldly. If the dowry is less than the amount agreed upon lawsuits and hostility [Page 861] begin. Often a complete break in relations takes place, if the marriage had not been sanctified in church. In the latter case the young bride is forced to remain in her bridegroom's home, but must suffer all sorts of nagging and persecution on the part of the family which absolutely poison her existence. I know of several cases when this persecution drove young women to flight or suicide. This is why Yakut who love their daughters try to give them as large a dowry as possible, so that her husband, father-in-law, and mother-in-law would respect her. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883; Namsk Ulus, 1891). It is also easy to understand why parents try in every way possible to make their daughters' dowries appear larger than they actually are, just as the bridegroom's family tries to exaggerate the size of the kalym they have paid.' [834] Samokvasov also provides a summary: 'When the Yakut marry, they give an agreed number of living and slaughtered cattle, and sometimes money, in installments, which is called kalym, for the wife. To compensate this loss, the bride's parents or her relatives who have arranged the match, give as a 222 dowry cattle, clothing, and sometimes money, for half of the whole agreed kalym. The wife cannot bring a dowry worth less than half the kalym, and to bring more, sometimes exceeding the whole kalym (which very rarely happens) is a matter for the discretion of her parents. Besides this, the bridegroom gives cattle to the bride's relatives at the wedding--or money, or animal skins. For these gifts, his wife, for a certain time, when she visits those relatives with presents for them, receives gifts herself, no less than ten head of cattle from each, or three times the value of the original gifts and the presents which she took with her. The excess of these gifts over the original gifts and presents is included in the compensation for the kalym. Therefore, in case of a rupture of the marriage, the wife or her relatives return the kalym to the husband, minus the dowry and the excess of the gifts; from which it follows that the Yakut wife possesses no property, unless she brought a dowry larger than the kalym, and unless she receives an award from her relatives or others after her marriage. Suits concerning kalyms have various causes, of which [Page 16] the main ones are the following: 1) Having lives several years with her husband, a wife suddenly leaves him on the grounds that he does not have any natural capacity for carnal relations; sometimes this is just, and, in that case, she is judged innocent; however, the kalym is returned, minus offspring and milk, but not until she marries another husband; but if her claim proves to be false, this proves her guilt and the fact that she left her husband because of lack of affectionate disposition to him; therefore, if she does not agree to stay with her husband, she herself, or her relatives pay back the kalym at the time of the divorce, with offspring and milk. 2) At the instigation of other, women marry them, and 223 in such a case, the instigators pay the kalym and all damages and are beaten with rods. 3)A husband abandons his wife: a)because of her dissolute behavior and poor running of the house; b) because of dislike for her, and as very frequently happens, dissoluteness of his own and love for another woman; in cases of this sort, the husband loses the right to demand the kalym. 4) Having taken each other during childhood by the will of the parents, and having no mutual affection, a couple divorce, and the wife's father or the relatives who married her off return half the kalym at the time of the divorce and the other half when she marries another man. 5) If a husband leaves his wife without any compelling reasons, not only does he not get the kalym back but he has to return the clothing and other objects of the dowry; the same right is enjoyed by the wife who leaves her husband because of cruel and mean treatment of her. 6) If a wife leaves her husband without any compelling reasons, her parents or the relatives who married her off must return the whole kalym, with the right of giving her in marriage for a kalym a second time. 7) If a wife's husband dies, the husband's parents do not have the right to give her in marriage again, but she herself, if she does not wish to stay in her husband's house, is free to marry without a kalym. 8) If a bride dies after being promised in marriage but still living at her father's house, and if there she had no sexual relations with the bridegroom, the whole kalym is returned immediately after her death, minus offspring and milk; but if she dies after having had sexual relations, a half-kalym is returned, without offspring or milk; when a widow marries a second time, similarly, the payment is made to the husband's relatives, if he dies after the promising of the bride but before she is taken into the house. 9) After a bride is promised to a bridegroom, after part or sometimes 224 all of the [Page 17] agreed kalym is paid, without any sins on the part of either bride or bridegroom, if the relatives are dissatisfied or if other potential mates are preferred or for various other reasons, and the bride or bridegroom refuses to marry, the bridegroom (if he is the one who refuses) is deprived of all the kalym which he has paid, and the bride (if she refuses) pays the bridegroom the whole kalym which he paid, plus offspring, milk, and other damages, even if she had sexual relations with him. 10) If the bridegroom of a promised bride proves unable to pay all or part of the kalym, then, if there were no carnal relations between the contracting parties, the bride and her relatives are free to refuse to proceed, and they return what he has paid; if there was sexual intercourse, the marriage is cancelled, but the kalym is paid, like an ordinary debt, through earnings, etc. 11) If the husband, after having the bride promised to him and having sexual intercourse with her, leaves her for three years without lawful reasons and does not take her, such a woman is free to marry another without giving back the kalym to the first one. 12) At the time of the wedding both the bride and the groom eat cattle, which is taken into account in case of a divorce, and this loss is paid by the one who is guilty in the divorce case.' [835] Endogamy was more common among rich families in the North: 'We have previously mentioned the exogamic character of the Yakut marriages, but some other tendencies have been observed in the northern districts of Yakut Province. The few rich families endeavor to keep their horses, cattle, and grazing places within a certain group of families through marriage of close relatives, insofar as this is permitted by the Russian church. By special permission of a bishop, even cousins are permitted to marry. In one case, known to the author, a man lived with his niece, a marital relation forbidden by the Church, though his neighbors avoided mentioning this irregularity to strangers.' [836] Wives/widows generally held fewer rights than men, but their legal status was improved during the Russian period: 'The absence of any rights on the part of woman, among the Yakuts of the district studied by M. Pripuzov, is most marked. . . in the field of property relations. Her personal position is at the present time considerably better protected than in earlier times. In this respect one notes in the life of the Yakuts a definite, although naturally a very relative progress. In effect, even at present, the husband considers himself within his rights to beat up his wife if she neglects her household duties, if she is a spendthrift, or if she is unfaithful to him. The Yakut further has the right to put his wife out to hire as a workwoman, and to use the money earned by her. But he does not have the right to kill her; he cannot sell her, or lend her to someone else.' [837] 'The right of the widow in the event of a childless marriage to return to her own family, the right of the husband to arrange before his death for the return of the dowry to his widow--all these rules, it appears, rose under the influence of the progressive softening of views on the personal and property incapacity of women. At an earlier time she was completely the property of her husband’s group. Actually, we have no definite information concerning the existence of the levirate among the Yakuts at a former time; but the rules forbidding women to show themselves before the father-in-law and brothers-in-law, and vice versa, obviously bearing the character of so-called “sexual precaution” are traces of a one-time polyandry; finally, the absence among the Yakuts of any proper term for “widow,” etc. (Sieroszewski, 569), compel us to assume that at a more remote time 48 the widow was considered the personal property of the family of the husband and probably passed to them as a piece of property. ' [838] 'Despite the fact that with respect to marriage the sons still are in a position of dependence upon the parents, their situation is considerably freer than that of the girls. A widowed daughter, returning to the parental home, again falls under the authority of the father; she is as devoid of rights as her young unmarried sister. The more independent position of the son is explained chiefly by the fact that the family and the clan prize children of the male sex more highly than those of the female sex: the birth of a boy is greeted by the Yakut with greater joy than the birth of a girl. Yakuts who do not have sons are scorned by their neighbors: they call them khatirik-uoma, i.e. “fire from bark (?).” The small esteem in which girl children are held by the Yakuts is indicated by the rule, whereby 54 a widow who marries for a second time must leave her sons by the first marriage with the family of her husband; but the daughters, as an unnecessary element in the family group, she can take with her to her new family. This rule is obviously of comparativelyrecent origin: it could arise only after the widow became free in general to marry outside of the confines of her husband’s group, and after the kalym had begun to lose its significance of a purchase price for the bride, and had begun to return to the family of the bridegroom in the form of a dowry. Gaining nothing by giving a daughter in marriage, the Yakut familial-household group naturally regards daughters as a completely superfluous element in the family, and sets no value on them.' [839] Divorce was practiced in the form of 'ceding' the wife to a lover: 'Instances of the cession of wives to other men, as is known, were encountered among the Yakuts up to the end of the 18th century, while the existence of the custom of lending one’s wife to a guest is substantiated by traditions (Vseso[unknown]iuzone Geograficheskoe ob[unknown]shchestvo, Vostochno-Sibirskii Otdel, Izviest[unknown]iia, XXVI, No. 4-5, pp. 218-19). As concerns instances of putting our wives to work, Prince Kostrov (Ocherk iuridicheskoe byta IAkutov [Juridical Customs of the Yakut]. p. 283) communicates the rather interesting fact that this practice has as its object to effect a separation from the wife: after a church wedding the Yakut rarely leaves his wife, but since such marriages are often consummated against the will of the parties involved, the husband sometimes abandons his wife, who customarily finds herself a lover, to whom she goes to live. In order to avoid prosecution by the authorities, writes Prince Kostrov, the husband and the lover make an oral and sometimes even written agreement to the effect that the former is hiring his wife out to the latter in the capacity of a servant with her consent and for the upkeep of the household.' [840] ***UPDATE: maybe change to absent as one paragraph states tat polygyny continued to be practiced in the colonial period.

♠ Ideology reinforces prosociality ♣ present ♥

♠ charity ♣ absent ♥ Cooperative herding was practiced in the summer: 'In summer the herds of several owners unite to form one big herd which is often quite large in size. In the first place, such large herds formed from smaller ones result in economizing of the working forces, since a considerably smaller number of people is required to look after these large herds 185 [Figure 1] than is needed for the separate smaller herds which united to form the larger one; in the second place, when dark clouds, gnats, and gadflies pass over the tundra, the large herd does not disperse like the small herds do; the reindeer bunch up and keep revolving constantly, since each one of the circling group tries to squeeze into the center in order to protect his sides from the bites of the gnats. When they drive the reindeer to the camp, the latter do this “circle dance” of theirs around the chooms, which threatens to knock them down. In the case of animals with such habits very few persons are required to pasture a large herd, since the only work they have to do amounts to driving the strays back into the herd.' [841] 'Another advantage of having the large herds in summer is the fact that there is a sufficiently large number of workers for the times when it is necessary to guard the herd day and night--at the time when the grass grows in spring, and during the mushroom period in the summer; the sufficiently large number of people makes it possible for them to take regular shifts at the pasture, which almost never has the effect of withdrawing the working forces in the economy.' [842] Mutual aid between families was practiced in pitching hay: 'Ordinarily they try to place grass which has been mowed early into large ricks, for this reason also, that these ricks will have to stand the whole summer, since the Yakut throw the hay into haystacks only after they have finished all the mowing, in the last days of August or even the early part of September. It sometimes happens that downpours, which come down for whole weeks at a time in the end of July and in August, penetrate right through the small ricks, and the hay in them rots, burns, and blackens. Even in large ricks a thick crust of rotten hay always forms, and the bottom of the rick, if it has been lying on the ground, and not on a peg, rots a great deal. Only the middle of the rick remains green. This admixture of black, rotten hay is quite considerable, in view of the small size of the ricks, and given even the finest Yakut hay, which has been gathered at the proper time and has been carefully dried, a greyish color. [Page 499] Such greyish-green hay is preferred by the Yakut and is called Yakut, to distinguish it from bright green hay gathered by Russian methods, i.e. first dried out in the open air right where it has been mowed for twenty-four hours, then tedded and turned over, and heaped together on the third day, in good weather, then placed in large ricks weighing four or five poods, and finally raked into haystacks as soon as possible, as soon as the weather and the assignment of labor permits. This method of work is recommended by government ukases, whose printed blanks I saw in native upravas; it is well known to the non-Russians, particularly those who live near Russian villages and cities. The introduction of these improvements is hindered by the parallelism of household arrangements throughout the whole region which is to a considerable degree necessary, for example, the custom of opening or closing the meadows to the cattle at certain definite times, the certain sequence in which arable land is mowed, and also the necessity of pitching hay everywhere at the same time. Far from all Yakut families have the strength to pitch all the hay from their spacious farmsteads in one or two days all by themselves and quickly. On the other hand it is dangerous to continue this work very long, in view of the changeability of the weather in the second half of the local summer. They are forced to pitch hay in company with 280 other families. This makes each individual homestead owner dependent on the general progress of the labor. In families which can get along without outside help, they always try to pitch part of the hay as early as possible, in the middle of the summer. The Yakut yearning to mow as much hay as possible forces them just as naturally to treasure every day of good weather in the first half of the summer, when the grasses have not yet hardened and dried up. When the grass is already moved and put into ricks, then it is another matter. It is then that all kinds of mutual help - keme and gulyay Begin, and families join together in small [Page 500] cartels for pitching the hay. They bring the hay to the [unknown] in sleds on wh ich they pla ce not more than four or five ricks which are tightened by belts placed slantwise. At the [unknown]they overturn the sleds. In this way, enormous heaps of hay arise around the from here they systematically pile the hay into haystacks with pitchforks. Among the various kinds of pitchforks, atyrdzhakh, there is one enormous one, reaching a length of two sagenes. The Yakut are not familiar with the application of beams and with lifting up the hay in whole cart-loads. Their haystacks are small; year after year they place them in the same places, on the very highest points of the meadows where they will not be swamped with floods and the water from snows in spring. They always put the worst grasses as a foundation for the [unknown] : they will dampen and blacken in any case.
