They put the best grass in the middle of the stacks, and the more moist grass at the edges. Workers, usually women or youths, trample hard on the edges and kill the grass. Every man who raises and piles the hay with a pitchfork needs one youth on the haystack and one or two youths with the bulls in the sled, and two rakers. Such a number of Yakut workers are able to pitch from twenty-five to thirty loads of hay (cubic sagenes) in one day, i.e. to transfer from one place to another, carry away, and lift to a certain height from five to six hundred Yakut ricks each weighing one pood. The haystacks are round or rectangular in shape; the latte r shape is preferred, particularly for damp hay which has been wettened by rain.' [843] Social life was characterized by a lot of ad hoc mutualism: 'Among the Yakut there are only temporary co-operative unions [Page 680] in use. These are very popular. Two fisherman who come together a t the same fishing place will immediately organize a company. They will fish together and divide the catch equally. Several wood-choppers who chop wood in the same vicinity will also enter into a company, because this is more fun. Mowers often join together into small brigades consisting of five or six men and will mow the meadows of each member in turn (Namsk Ulus, 1889). A peasant woman will help her neighbor rake, in return for the same service, and it has practically become a custom to pitch hay by combining the joint strength of two or three households and doing each household's work in turn. Besides this, neighbors constantly exchange a great number of small services which demand a special skill; the number of these is beyond calculation. Cutting and sewing a dress, gluing together a broken dish, catching and restraining a raging stallion, squaring a door, finding a lost piece of livestock, and so forth -- a whole mass of services, whose total far exceeds those which are paid for by agreement, are exchanged without causing any particular misunderstanding. It is also remarkable that all these unions have clearly expressed within them the foundations of artels: equal distribution of labor and equal partnership is called kompaniya, as in Russian, although the Yakut have their own word: kytyk - kytykas, 428 which expresses this conception quite well. They also use the Russian word gulyay for the support of beggars; in the Yakut language this word is komo. The word is used by prosperous people who can afford to extend certain hospitality, or by the needy paupers themselves. The latter bow from the waist to their neighbors, give them some [Page 681] small present: a brick of tea, one ruble in money, and if the reasons presented by the petitioner were sufficiently valid, then the one supplicated will carry out the work without repayment, at his own expense: he will build a house, mow the meadow, chop and deliver kindling wood. For rich Yakut, princes, and all personages who are influential in their neighborhood, this custom of aid is exceedingly profitable. It is impossible to refuse them, while the hospitality they extent is always calculated so that it costs them less than it would to hire a laborer. The day for gulyay begins at sunrise and ends at sunset. During the working day the laborers are only fed once and given tea once; the main hospitality is extended after the work is done. Sometimes the owner brings his helpers a glass of vodka apiece; this is considered a great honor. The food given consists of kumiss or tea, milk, butter, flour, and meat. Usually they slaughter a piece of livestock and cook part of it, while the rest is given out raw as a present. Besides mowing hay, aid is given in the form of building houses, harrowing, carrying hay, and in general all kinds of work where collected efforts are useful and applicable. Only paupers and homeowners of average means are invited for aid; rich people consider it shameful for them to take part in this.' [844] But this does not seem to constitute charity.
♠ production of public goods ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We are unsure which norms or institutions would qualify was public goods in a pastoralist society.
♠ communal dining ♣ present ♥ Feasting was practiced at festivals and weddings. Jochelson describes Kumiss festivals: "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn. The steward addresses a prayer to the “creators,” begging for blessings,-increase of horses and cattle, a good harvest of hay, good health for the people and animals, and an abundance of food. Then he takes the kumiss-festival ladle , and makes a libation, in the direction of the dawn, to the benevolent deities . Then, while making a libation to the ground, he addresses the local deity, “the owner of the place” (än doidu iccitä), asking him not to harm the inhabitants of the spot and the members of the clan. After that, the steward, with the help of the sacrificial ladle, proceeds to divine. He throws the ladle towards the sky: and if it falls with the front part upwards, it portends the granting by the deities of future abundance; and all the people utter the joyful cry Uru! Then the boys and girls give the goblets with the sacrificial kumiss, according to the directions of the steward, to the elder and honored members of the clan, both male and female. These, after placing themselves,-the men on the right and the women on the left of the altar,-drink off the kumiss from the goblets, and pass them on to the less important and the younger people." [845][846] Weddings were subject to a high degree of ritualization, resembling peacemaking procedures between two families: 'Traditionally, for wealthy Yakut, marriage could be polygamous. More common, however, was monogamy, with occasional remarriage after the death of a spouse. Arranged marriages were sometimes politically motivated. Patrilineage exogamy was reckoned strictly; those one could marry were called SYGAN. Until the 1920s many marriage arrangements were complicated and protracted, involving financial, emotional, and symbolic resources of the bride's and groom's extended families. This included the matchmaking ritual; several formal payments of animals, furs, and meat to the bride's family; informal gifts; and extensive dowries. Some families permitted poor grooms to work in their households as a replacement for the bride-price. Occasionally bride-capture occurred (it may have been more common in pre-Russian times). Wedding ceremonies and their attendant feasts, prayers, and dancing, were held first at the household of the bride's parents, then at that of the groom's. The couple usually lived or settled in a nearby yurt.' [847]//Kharuzin also describes the wedding proceedings: 'On the day of the wedding the choom of the father of the bride and that of the father of the bridegroom were set up side by side. Depending on the degree of their prosperity the owner of each of the chooms slaughtered between one and five deer and treated the assembled guests. In addition, the bridegroom slaughtered one more deer and sent its meat to the father of the bride. Aided by his friends the bridegroom would next catch the deer for the black kalym. At the same time, near the choom of the bride, other young men caught deer that were to be handed over as dowry. Out on the street, in the meanwhile, the bride would dance in the company of her girl friends and of other young men. Having caught the deer for the black kalym, the young men tied them up to the back of the narta of the match-maker who, with the deer behind him, rode in front of the bridegroom.//'Upon approaching the choom of the bride the matchmaker and the bridegroom rode around her choom in the direction of the movement of the sun. The matchmaker would then enter the choom alone and announce: The son-in-law has arrived. At the same time the people present would let the deer in a special enclosure built by stretching lassoes between trees and by setting up of overturned nartas . A great number of guests would arrive together with the bridegroom. Out on the street the matchmaker would lead the bridegroom to the father of the bride. The bridegroom would pull behind him a vazhenka ( nyal'dzhin ) tied to a leather strap. Upon approaching his future father-in-law he would hand the animal over to him. The bridegroom together with the guests would then remain outside while in the choom preparations were made for a feast and a wedding bed was set up for the newlyweds. The making of the bed was entrusted to one of the relatives of the bride.//'While the guests stood outside and waited for the beginning of the feast, the matchmaker would make numerous sorties from the choom of the bride and in a light-hearted way inform them of what was going on inside the choom. At the same time the father of the bride would received the deer of the black kalym. In the east tundra all the brought deer were accepted without any argument; in the Noril'-skiy rayon, however, the father of the bride would frequently pronounce some animals unacceptable and would send them back expecting other animals in their stead. In the case of a demanding father the business of receiving the deer would occasionally extend into the late evening.//'If the father of the bride was a snob he wold make the guests freeze outside for a long time. When, at long last, the feast and the bed were ready and the deer of the black kalym all checked, the match-maker would lead the bridegroom into the choom and would make him pray in front of the ikons. The bride stationed herself by the side of the bridegroom and prayed together with him. After the prayers were ended the matchmaker would say to the bridegroom: Bow to the big father-in-law and ask for his blessing. The bride and the bridegroom would then make a low bow before the parents and came up to receive their blessing as well as the blessing of the relatives older than the bride. All of them blessed the young people, gave them their hands to kiss, and proffered their best wishes. The matchmaker would at this point, give ten rubles to the father of the bride, and to all her relatives pieces of cloth and kerchiefs. In Noril'sk in the place of money the matchmaker gave the bride's father a fox skin, and to her mother a polar fox skin or a fur coat. These presents were called yungyu --prayer or request. After these presents had been made all the relatives of the bride got up and shook the bridegroom's hand. There were no handshakes between these relatives and the members of the bridegroom's entourage.//'After the blessing ceremony was over the bride and the bridegroom were placed behind the bed curtain. Only then would the guests be let in in a strictly observed order. The guests would be brought in from outside by the relatives, who would lead them by the hand--the adult relatives accompanying the adult guests, and children-relatives--other children. The guests would be taken to places that were asssigned to them. The closest relatives and the most honored guests as well as foreigners (Yakut, Russians, Tungus) would be let in first. To avoid mistakes the relatives of the bride asked their friends as to who should come in and in what order. Before the guests were let in two people would be selected from among those who were known for their talents as improvisers. The two chosen men were to play the role of people who predict the future ( yr kerderer dzhon ). One of these men was selected by the relatives of the bridegroom, the other----by the relatives of the bride. The presence of these men was not an essential part of the wedding ceremony.//'When all the honored guests were seated the bride's father would ask them: Guests! What do you have to say? The matchmaker would answer: We have a word to say. Then a representative of the bridegroom would get us and colorfully and ornately would describe the future life of the young people and the peace and harmony of their household. He would also describe the number of the children they were going to have, how rich they were going to be, etc. He would end his speech by saying: My words ended, now is your turn. Thereupon a similar speech would be make by a representative of the bride. The guests predicted a happier life for the bridegroom or the bride, depending on which side gave the better speech. After this a woman relative of the bride poured out tea and took charge of the serving of the food. After the first meal, i.e. after drinking the tea, and before the opening of the table ( ostuolu asyar inniger ), i.e. the serving of the meal, all the guests would go out on the street and dance until the second meal was served. The ceremony of distributing the kalym ( sulu tuttarar ) would be taking place at the same time.//'The wedding bed was transported to the choom of the bridegroom before the arrival of the bride herself. In front of the procession rode the matchmaker; he was followed by the bridegroom, behind whom was the bride, and behind the latter the deer loaded with the bride's dowry. The bride put on two coats made out of cloth ( sontap ) and a Siberian fur-coat ( dokha ), embroidered with patterns ( ardaydakh sangyyakh ). In the Noril'skiy rayon the size of the dowry was decided upon in the course of the negotiations conducted by the matchmaker; in other places the custom was different and the size of the dowry depended on that of the kalym. If the kalym consisted of sixty deer, the number of deer given with the dowry would be forty-five. A rich dowry consisted of sixty or seventy selected deer of various ages, among them no harness or old deer. Nor more than two or three deer could be included in a rich dowry. In addition to the deer a rich dowry would consist of seven and the poor one of five nartas, harnessed to the best deer (a pair of deer harnessed to each narta of the rich dowry, and a single deer harnessed to each narta of the poor one). In addition to the nartas a dowry included a narta choom, to which were harnessed four deer.//'When the bride's train approached the choom of the bridegroom, the matchmaker would go to the parents of the bridegroom and announced to them the arrival of the bride. The newlyweds would then travel three times around the choom in the direction of the movement of the sun. In the Noril'skiy rayon the bride rode around the choom by herself; after she had entered the choom the deer were led around the choom by some one else. This ceremony was called the entrance of the hearth ( sarany bullarar ). The bride was led into the choom of the bridegroom by a respected old woman who could not be her relative. The bride and the bridegroom prayed together before the ikon, and then, with a deep bow to the bridegroom's father and mother, asked for their blessing and came up to kiss their hands. The parents of the bridegroom then blessed the newlyweds and wished them a happy life. At this point the bride would give the bridegroom's parents presents of money or of valuable skins; these presents had to be much more valuable that those given by the bridegroom to the parents of the bride, for the father of the bride would want to put up a front before the bridegroom's father. In the bridegroom's choom the guests were again treated to a feast, which was served to them in two shifts. In the ancient times a shaman would always be invited to a wedding. Before the beginning of the feast he would stand dressed not in his ceremonial but in his ordinary garments, and leaning upon a deer staff of the bride called upon beneficent gods and spirits to be kind to the newlywed, and for himself wished them a happy and prosperous life. After this address by the shaman the first group of honored guests sat down to the feast.'//'The bridegroom's father would next come out to glance at the deer that were brought as a dowry, and offered the people who helped him in the equipping of the kalym to chose the animals they wanted.//'After the end of the festivities the father would inspect the dowry in the light of the day (this custom was not practised by the Noril'skiye Dolgani): he would go out of the choom, open up the trunks and examine their contents. If it turned out that the amount of the dowry was not equivalent to the amount of the kalym, the stinginess of the bride's parents would be disapprovingly commented on by all those present. As a rule, the father of the bride tried to include in the dowry as many valuable things as he could, for fear that otherwise he might disgrace himself. The inspection described above ended the ceremonies of the Dolgani wedding. The assembled guests would spend the day in eating, in games and in dancing, and would depart in the late evening. The father and the mother of the bride stayed with the bridegroom for a period of three days. Before their departure the father of the bridegroom would present the parents of the bride with one deer (ogo kereryu) which was to be looked upon by them as their daughter. The animal thus given as a present was highly valued. On the morning of the third day the young wife poured out tea. During the tea drinking her father would publicly instruct her as follows: From this time on you must obey your husband. Your mother-in-law now stands in the place of your own mother. Your father-in-law in the place of your father. Respect and obey them and do not quarrel with them.' [848]//Elders played a prominent role alongside parents and shamans: 'The oldest kinsman in the clan, or the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa , is always heaped with honors, if he is both rich and has never been put on trial. To him pertains the jurisdiction in trifling quarrels between kinsfolk. The following ceremonies serve to recall the religious functions that he (Ysekh) formerly exercised a. At the time of the spring festival, which bears a strictly clan character, they bring to him, first of all, a large wooden vessel ( Choron ) containing kumiss; he pronounces a prayer of thanks to the gods and then pours the kumiss upon the fire. b. At the time of the arrival of the betrothed at the bridegroom’s yurt, they take from the sleigh of the betrothed, and place upon a table in front of the fire place the boiled head of a horse, whose eyes are covered with butter, to whose ears are attached intestines filled with horse’s blood, and a wooden cup filled with butter. After this the betrothed enters the yurt, and stands, having first untied her girdle, on the right side of the komelok [RCH: i. e., the fireplace] where she is met by the oldest kinsman, whose place is sometimes taken nowadays by the most honored guest, who, kneeling, throws into the fire 41 pieces of meat, blood and butter, and blesses the bride. For the completion of this ceremony, whose obvious object is to unite the bride with the bridegroom’s home, the oldest kinsman secures for his use the head, blood and butter brought into the yurt, and in addition the sum of one ruble.' [849]//
♠ morality ♣ suspected unknown ♥

Normative Ideological Aspects of Slavery[edit]

♠ Ideology forbids slavery for co-ethnics ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Ideology forbids slavery for co-religionists ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Ideology forbids slavery universally ♣ absent ♥ Prisoners of war were traditionally kept as slaves by toyons: 'Kinship and politics were mixed in the hierarchical council system that guided AQA-USA, AIMAK, and DZHON. Yakut explanations of DZHON in the nineteenth century included concepts like "people," "community," or "tribe," territorially defined. Councils were composed of ranked circles of elders, usually men, whose leaders, TOYONS, were called nobles by Russians. A lineage head was BIS-USA-TOYON; respected warriors and hunters were BATYR. Lineage councils decided major economic issues, interfamily disputes, and questions of blood revenge for violence committed against the group. AIMAK and DZHON councils were infrequent, dealing with issues of security, revenge, alliance, and, before Russian control, war. Through war, slaves were captured for service in the wealthiest TOYON households. Kin-based councils were rare by the nineteenth century and had little influence on twentieth-century politics. Yet in the Soviet period Yakut remain aware of regional and kin ties and help kin obtain jobs and political positions. In this period the Yakut elite, some of whom are Communist party members, revived certain traditions, participating in wedding ceremonies and annual festivals once associated with council meetings. To avoid doing so would be impolitic. Yakut have demanded greater economic and political autonomy from Moscow and some Yakut politicians, including the elected president, are reformers implementing the new republic constitution. A major ecological movement and democratically elected councils are trying to redress local grievances.' [850] Dependents were considered part of the patriarchal household: 'At the head of the family was the aga, meaning primarily “elder in age” and then “father.” All the people of the household were regarded as and called by him “my children,” “my sons or my daughters.” Among these were included not only his own children, but also all relatives by blood and marriage, by adoption, by purchase (slaves), and any other dependents, as war captives. The aga continued to rule as long as he preserved his physical and mental abilities. According to a Yakut tradition, aged parents and also sick and crippled people, unable to work, were doomed to die and were even buried alive after three days of abundant entertainment.' [851] Slaves were occasionally included in dowry payments: 'Afterwards enne kulut were slaves included in a bride's dowry. If they were women they became the concubines of the master. (Namsk Ulus, 1891).' [852] 'One way or another, among the Yakut hexogamy was accompanied by war 560 and slavery. It is a very usual thing for Yakut legends to mention slaves given to a conqueror together with a daughter.' [853] Slavery and serfdom continued into the Russian period and it is unclear when precisely the practice was abandoned: 'It is understandable that here as everywhere else the conquerors first of all tried to make use of the clan leaders to facilitate the gathering of yassak and pacification. They named them princelings [Page 782] and wealthy people of the ulus and made them responsible for arrears and disorders, took hostages, and translators from them, and forced them to pay contributions. Afterwards, when the government became convinced that the Cossack carnival was threatening the interest of the government, was impoverishing the population to the bone, and by its unbearable taxation and cruelties was forcing the population to scatter, inciting it into rebellion and disobedience, it tried to give those same princelings and wealthy people of the ulus control over their rapacious servants. They were entrused to be present as witnesses at the gathering of yassak, at inquiries, and all other matters arising between the soldiers and officials who had come and the local population. Later they were charge to stamp with their own stamps the furs given as yassak, so that the soldiers would not exchange them on the way. of the whole clan. They were not slow to take advantage of this. All this raised them to an unparalleled height in 495 the eyes of the population; when afterwards it was acknowledged that it would be better to divide the yassak by clans and uluses and, without inquiring into the distribution and means of exaction, to [Page 783] demand it in full from the clan leaders, the princelings, turned completely into land officials. They began to be encouraged and rewarded for their service by signs of excellence: medals, cutlasses, and caftans, and by a decree of the Senate, on February 1, 1740 and May 17, 1764, they were even assigned a constant recompense, depending on the amount of yassak brought in. A salary to the yassak princelings and those elected as yassak officials: for every 1000 rubles of yassak brought into the treasury, a salary of 20 rubles to each as a gift, and if the amount is smaller or greater than 1000 rubles, to take this into calculation. Encouraged and supported from outside, the princelings little by little freed themselves from the clan traditions and began to oppress the people no less than the Cossacks. Being perfectly acquanited with the conditions of life they were able to enter into agreements with the voivodes and clerks, keeping the whole matter concealed, and under protection conduct themselves in their lands in their lands as if they owned them: they seized land, levy taxes without any control, introduce serfdom, and even buy and sell people. It is a dark memory and bad habits that the princes of that time have left behind them. There was only one way in which the people benefited by the fact that they replaced the Russian officials: they became accustomed to battle for their own interest under new conditions. The princes were their own people, the aura of a conqueror did not surround them, they had nowhere to go with their plundered riches, and even formerly the people had been forced to keep them in check, in their capacity as heads of the clan.' [854] It is unclear how many people were enslaved or enserfed.

Normative Ideological Aspects of Human Sacrifice[edit]

♠ Human sacrifice ♣ [0-1] ♥ Only animal sacrifices are mentioned in descriptions of Sakha religion. 'Nevertheless, the outward conditions of life have hardly changed after the Russian conquest. There is always the same uncertainty of existence; the unsatisfactory conditions for men as well as for animals continue to exist. The sacrificial priests still everywhere and always hold position and duties of priests, physicians, and fortune-tellers (prophets).' [855] There where black and white shamans: 'Supernatural power was attributed to blacksmiths, since their art was considered a divine gift. The old Sakha religion had many supernatural spirits, good and evil. Black shamans dealt with evil spirits and could be benevolent or harmful; white shamans were concerned with spiritual intercession for human beings. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [856] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. To all of these evil spirits, in addition to the libations of kumiss made to the benevolent deities, blood sacrifices of cattle and horses are also made. This ceremony, according to Trostchansky, is superintended by nine male and nine female shamans.' [857] "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [858][859] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [860]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [861] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [862].

♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Only animal sacrifices are mentioned in descriptions of Sakha religion. 'Nevertheless, the outward conditions of life have hardly changed after the Russian conquest. There is always the same uncertainty of existence; the unsatisfactory conditions for men as well as for animals continue to exist. The sacrificial priests still everywhere and always hold position and duties of priests, physicians, and fortune-tellers (prophets).' [863] There where black and white shamans: 'Supernatural power was attributed to blacksmiths, since their art was considered a divine gift. The old Sakha religion had many supernatural spirits, good and evil. Black shamans dealt with evil spirits and could be benevolent or harmful; white shamans were concerned with spiritual intercession for human beings. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [864] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. To all of these evil spirits, in addition to the libations of kumiss made to the benevolent deities, blood sacrifices of cattle and horses are also made. This ceremony, according to Trostchansky, is superintended by nine male and nine female shamans.' [865] "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [866][867] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [868]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [869] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [870].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Only animal sacrifices are mentioned in descriptions of Sakha religion. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [872] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [874][875] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [876]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [877] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [878].

[886].

[894].

Black shamans dealt with evil spirits and could be benevolent or harmful; white shamans were concerned with spiritual intercession for human beings. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [896] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. To all of these evil spirits, in addition to the libations of kumiss made to the benevolent deities, blood sacrifices of cattle and horses are also made. This ceremony, according to Trostchansky, is superintended by nine male and nine female shamans.' [897] "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [898][899] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [900]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [901] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [902].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ Only animal sacrifices are mentioned in descriptions of Sakha religion. 'Nevertheless, the outward conditions of life have hardly changed after the Russian conquest. There is always the same uncertainty of existence; the unsatisfactory conditions for men as well as for animals continue to exist. The sacrificial priests still everywhere and always hold position and duties of priests, physicians, and fortune-tellers (prophets).' [903] There where black and white shamans: 'Supernatural power was attributed to blacksmiths, since their art was considered a divine gift. The old Sakha religion had many supernatural spirits, good and evil. Black shamans dealt with evil spirits and could be benevolent or harmful; white shamans were concerned with spiritual intercession for human beings. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [904] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. To all of these evil spirits, in addition to the libations of kumiss made to the benevolent deities, blood sacrifices of cattle and horses are also made. This ceremony, according to Trostchansky, is superintended by nine male and nine female shamans.' [905] "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [906][907] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [908]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [909] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [910].
♠ human sacrifice of other ♣ ♥
♠ Maximum known number of victims in a HS event ♣ 0 ♥ Only animal sacrifices are mentioned in descriptions of Sakha religion. 'Nevertheless, the outward conditions of life have hardly changed after the Russian conquest. There is always the same uncertainty of existence; the unsatisfactory conditions for men as well as for animals continue to exist. The sacrificial priests still everywhere and always hold position and duties of priests, physicians, and fortune-tellers (prophets).' [911] There where black and white shamans: 'Supernatural power was attributed to blacksmiths, since their art was considered a divine gift. The old Sakha religion had many supernatural spirits, good and evil. Black shamans dealt with evil spirits and could be benevolent or harmful; white shamans were concerned with spiritual intercession for human beings. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [912] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. To all of these evil spirits, in addition to the libations of kumiss made to the benevolent deities, blood sacrifices of cattle and horses are also made. This ceremony, according to Trostchansky, is superintended by nine male and nine female shamans.' [913] "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [914][915] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [916]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [917] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [918].
♠ Capital Punishment for Religious Offenses ♣ ♥
♠ Capital Punishment for Witchcraft ♣ ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ suspected unknown ♥ HS are seemingly absent, but whether this is due to religious interdiction or whether they were simply absent from the ritual repertoire is unclear. Only animal sacrifices are mentioned in descriptions of Sakha religion. 'Nevertheless, the outward conditions of life have hardly changed after the Russian conquest. There is always the same uncertainty of existence; the unsatisfactory conditions for men as well as for animals continue to exist. The sacrificial priests still everywhere and always hold position and duties of priests, physicians, and fortune-tellers (prophets).' [919] There where black and white shamans: 'Supernatural power was attributed to blacksmiths, since their art was considered a divine gift. The old Sakha religion had many supernatural spirits, good and evil. Black shamans dealt with evil spirits and could be benevolent or harmful; white shamans were concerned with spiritual intercession for human beings. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [920] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. To all of these evil spirits, in addition to the libations of kumiss made to the benevolent deities, blood sacrifices of cattle and horses are also made. This ceremony, according to Trostchansky, is superintended by nine male and nine female shamans.' [921] "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [922][923] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [924]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [925] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [926].
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ suspected unknown ♥ HS are seemingly absent, but whether this is due to religious interdiction or whether they were simply absent from the ritual repertoire is unclear. Only animal sacrifices are mentioned in descriptions of Sakha religion. 'Nevertheless, the outward conditions of life have hardly changed after the Russian conquest. There is always the same uncertainty of existence; the unsatisfactory conditions for men as well as for animals continue to exist. The sacrificial priests still everywhere and always hold position and duties of priests, physicians, and fortune-tellers (prophets).' [927] There where black and white shamans: 'Supernatural power was attributed to blacksmiths, since their art was considered a divine gift. The old Sakha religion had many supernatural spirits, good and evil. Black shamans dealt with evil spirits and could be benevolent or harmful; white shamans were concerned with spiritual intercession for human beings. Two major religious festivals were celebrated with ritual use of koumiss (fermented mare’s milk), one in spring for good spirits and one in fall accompanied by blood sacrifices of livestock for evil spirits.' [928] 'The first night of the festival is in honor of Big-Lord ( Ulu-Toyon ) and the evil spirits of the upper world subordinate to him. The second night is in honor of Axsan Duolai and his subordinates, the evil spirits of the lower world. To all of these evil spirits, in addition to the libations of kumiss made to the benevolent deities, blood sacrifices of cattle and horses are also made. This ceremony, according to Trostchansky, is superintended by nine male and nine female shamans.' [929] "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn." [930][931] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [932]. It is worth noting that this is based on data collected in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. 'On the third day after the birth of the child the sent deer would be slaughtered in the presence of assembled guests and a feast would be held on the same day the mother got up from her couch, and a ceremony of purification would take place to honor the occasion.' [933] Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embraces him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon.' [934].

Moralizing Supernatural Powers[edit]

♠ Moral concern is primary ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is certain ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing norms are broad ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is targeted ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement of rulers ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by elites ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by commoners ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in afterlife ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in this life ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is agentic ♣ {absent;present} ♥

These data were reviewed by expert advisors and consultants. For a detailed description of these data, refer to the relevant Analytic Narratives, reference tables, and acknowledgements page. [935] [936] [937]

Normative Ideological precepts concerning morality/supernatural beings[edit]

Supernatural beings (e.g., gods, spirits, ancestors)

♠ Number of officially sanctioned supernatural beings ♣ polytheistic ♥ 'Saints and bears are seen as shamanic spirit helpers. Christ is identified with the Yakut Bright Creator Elder God, Aiyy-toyon. A pantheon of gods, believed to live in nine hierarchical eastern heavens, was only one aspect of a complex traditional cosmology that still has meaning for some Yakut. Another crucial dimension was the spirit-soul (ICHCHI) of living beings, rocks, trees, natural forces, and objects crafted by humans. Most honored was the hearth spirit (YOT ICHCHITE), still fed morsels of food and drink by pious Yakut. Giant trees (AL LUKH MAS), deep in the forest, were especially sacred: their ICHCHI are still given small offerings of coins, scarves, and ribbons. Belief in ICHCHI is related to ancient ideas of harmony and equilibrium with nature, and to shamanism. Yakut shamanism is a Turkic, Mongolic, and Tungusic blend of belief in the supernatural, with emphasis on the ability of "white," or benign, shamans to intercede, through prayers and séances, with eastern spirits for the sake of humans. "Black" shamans, communing with evil spirits, could both benefit and harm humans.'[938]
♠ Omnipresent supernatural beings ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Omniscient supernatural beings ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Omnipotent supernatural beings ♣ inferred present ♥ We define omnipotent supernatural beings as "all-powerful supernatural beings who can intervene in human affairs at will to punish/reward". On the one hand, the Sakha "lack[ed] any idea of retaliation as we understand it"[939]. On the other hand, spirits did intervene in human affairs to punish childlessness and impurity.
♠ High Gods (creator gods) ♣ active ♥ Sakha spirits and deities appear qualify as high gods, in that they have created and rule over reality. 'Originally, Tangara-the sky god, the father of the gods, typologically comparable to the Rigvedic D’iaus, and to the Latin concept of “god” (D’iaus-Deos-Theo)-was supposed to occupy the dominant position among the aiyy deities. Later, this image was embodied in the central figure of the Yakut pantheon, Iuriung Aiyy toion, the “White Creator God,” the god of light, the personified image of the Sun, with the functions of sovereign of the Universe. Then came the other aiyy deities. A particularly important place was occupied by Aal Uot ichchite, the spirit of sacred fire-both of the sacrificial flame and of the domestic hearth. Like the Arian Agni, Aal Uot ichchite was considered to be the protector of the family and the giver of good fortune and healthy offspring. If the goddess Ieiiekhsit was regarded as the messenger of Iuriung Aiyy toion, then the spirit of fire fulfilled the function of intermediary between earth and heaven, between humanity and the gods.' [940] However, it appears they were not moralizing. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[941] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[942] 'The Yakut Satan, that allara abasy ogonior (the old man-spirit of the underworld) who is sometimes also called Satan, is a quite different conception, although recently he took has begun to take on some of the attributes of his Biblical equivalent. For example, he is called the king of the evil spirits, abasy yrakhta, although he is by no means considered to be the most powerful among the fetishes and spirits embodying the evil and harmful forces of nature. It is noteworthy that the Yakut world conception does not bear any mystical facets; they are aware of harmful, helpful, and indifferent phenomena, but no sinful phenomena. The concept of grace, as a result of the victory by the spirit over the body, mortification of the flesh, chastity, humility, and other ascetic ideals, is completely foreign to them. They have the word aji - sin, but the meaning of this word is quite different. I myself have not been able to establish completely just what concepts this word includes, but most probably it is the idea of suffering. In the past they said arakh; this is the same as aji. (Namsk Ulus, 1889). The concepts of faith as virtue and doubt as sin are both equally incomprehensible to them.'[943] 'I shall close this brief sketch of Yakut beliefs with a description of a cult which differs from all the gloomy beliefs I have heretofore described by its light and joyous character. The basis of this cult consists in the worship of fertility, abundance, wealth, and in general everything which aids in the maintenance and rebirth of life. All the gods, guardians, and bestowers of these blessings live in the east. Their priests are called the white or light shamans (yuryung ai oyuna) they were once called summer shamans (saingy), because the feasts (ysyakh) in honor of these divinities are usually held in the summer.' [944]

Supernatural Enforcement of Morality

♠ supernatural enforcement against harm ♣ inferred absent ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[945] and purity[946]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[947] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[948]
♠ supernatural enforcement of fairness ♣ inferred absent ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[949] and purity[950]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[951] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[952]
♠ supernatural enforcement of human reciprocity ♣ inferred absent ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[953] and purity[954]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[955] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[956]
♠ supernatural enforcement of property rights ♣ inferred absent ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[957] and purity[958]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[959] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[960]
♠ supernatural enforcement of kinship obligations ♣ inferred present ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[961] and purity[962]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[963] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[964] However, fecundity was valued and received supernatural enforcement: 'Until the most recent times the Dolgani regarded it as sinful (an'i) for the men to remain bachelors and for the women to remain unmarried. After their death the souls of these people were to become heretics (sic) (dzheretinnik), who would frighten the living, for they would remain by their graves and would not depart for the land of the dead. However, if without getting married a girl gave birth to children, her soul was not turned into a heretic. At the same time it was considered a sin for a widower to marry again. A married couple would rarely break up, for fear of committing a sin thereby. In selecting his first wife a man was believed to be following a course predetermined for him by a beneficent god: the particular woman he selected was believed to have been born specially for him and had been fated to be his wife. If upon the death of his wife the widower remarried it was believed that the ayy (a beneficent god) would stop treating him with good will (aytytyn eyetya aragar). It was thought that the ayy did not select ten wives for a man, but only one. As a result, the second marriage was believed to be entered into without the approval of the ayy, but of the man's own free will. When a man who had been married to two women died, it was believed that he would unite with his first wife, while his second wife would reside separately with her maternal relatives. If upon the death of his second wife a man would marry for the third time, it was believed that such conduct was inspired by the evil spirit--abasy, and was very sinful. After his [Page 23] death such man, as well as his wives, would to into the region inhabited by the abasy.'[965]
♠ supernatural enforcement of in-group loyalty ♣ inferred absent ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[966] and purity[967]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[968] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[969]
♠ supernatural enforcement of respect ♣ inferred absent ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[970] and purity[971]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[972] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[973]
♠ supernatural enforcement of bravery ♣ inferred absent ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[974] and purity[975]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it.
