The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[976] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[977]
♠ supernatural enforcement of purity ♣ inferred present ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[978] and purity[979]. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[980] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[981] However, contact with pregnant women, who were considered to be impure, : 'Custom forbids women, particularly when they are pregnant, to eat certain dishes, and to touch certain objects. They are considered to be unclean. They may spoil a hunter's rifle for him or bring bad fortune to a fisherman. (Verkhoyansk Ulus, 1882).'[982]
♠ general supernatural enforcement of morality ♣ inferred present ♥ It appears the Sakha spirits and deities did not enforce most forms of morality, with the apparent exception of some kinship obligations[983] and purity[984].
♠ other supernatural enforcement of piety ♣ inferred present ♥ 'When a man, willingly or unwillingly, had offended some spirit, violated his rights, or did not fulfill his obligations, he was liable to be punished in some way: by illness, epizooty, or some other calamity. The Yakut is a hunter and fishermen. The abasy-siäce (i.e., abasy, the eater) also procures food for himself, and this food may be the man and his cattle. The Ajy and Icci may or may not give the man something. They are quite indifferent to him.'[985] 'Although parents are responsible for a child while it is growing, it may itself be punished for disrespect towards the spirits. When he has reached maturity, marries, and establishes his own household, he selects a place to build a house, but it has its owner-spirit from whom it is necessary to obtain permission to proceed. When the house, stall, and shelter for cattle are ready, each of these buildings, as well as the new fireplace, has its own “owners” with whom it is important to enter into good relations. To procure food and clothing for the family it is necessary to hunt in the woods and to fish in the lakes, but forests and waters have their own owners, without whose permission one cannot use the utilities they supervise. That the family may have adequate provision, the cattle must propagate, and for this, corresponding spirits must be propitiated. For the cattle, one needs to store hay, but grass grows in places belonging to particular owners. While traveling, a man passes the possessions of different owners, who must be conciliated with gifts or appropriate prayers. Thus, we see a well organized system in the relations of man to the circle of spirits.'[986]
♠ other supernatural enforcement ♣ ♥

Human Enforcement of Morality

♠ care/harm ♣ absent ♥ According to Sieroszewski, strength was valued above care-giving obligations: 'I received such answers to my plainly put questions as to the leadership of the family from everyone, in all the corners of the Yakutsk Oblast, but at the present time they express no more than a certain ideal to long for, a morality like the Christian love thy neighbor as thyself. In actual practice the Yakut family is quite a different thing, and only the subordination of women is strictly drawn. The subordination of the younger to the elder is in its turn subject to a still more general rule: the subordination of the weaker to the stronger, and of the poor to the rich. It is true that I have heard of many cases where the father, eldest brother, or uncle forced younger members of the household to marry, gave them to outsiders to work under very harsh conditions and kept all they pay themselves. I know of a case where the father took possession of the son's belongings, took away his axe and boat, sold the hay which his son had mowed all by himself, and the son only bewailed his fate and could not do anyt hing. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883). I know of a case where the parents sold their eight year old daughter to an official who was passing through. (Borogon Ulus, 1884). Many times I have heard and seen the older members of a family cruelly beat their relatives, [Page 806] particularly wives and children, but I know of an equal number of cases where the opposite has taken place. I know of cases where the younger brothers played a more important role in the family than the elder brothers; where sons beat their aged parents until they went into tears; where a wife, unconstrained by the presence of outsiders, treated her sick, feeble husband very rudely, and even beat him and openly kept a lover in the house. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883), Namsk Ulus 511 1888). I have also heard of a daughter, realizing that she was the only worker in the house, paid absolutely no attention to her parents, did what she wished, refused a profitable marriage, and went around with boys in front of everyone's eyes. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883). I know of a case where the old people did not dare to sell a funt of butter, or a load of hay, and did not dare buy anything for themselves without the permission of their grown-up son.' [987] 'None of these things were considered to be anything unusual and called forth no more censure on the part of the commune, than the cruel or unfair treatment of children would. There can not even be any question of any kind of strict patriarchial relations, or of some kind of deeply inborn or inbred feeling of respect to elders among the Yakut. Not only don't they feed, respect, and obey old people, but they often even curse them and beat them. With my own eyes I've seen more than once how Yakut beat their parents... Rich people and poor people do this, thin people, respected people; they beat their fathers and beat their mothers... a young fellow of the Betyun'sk Nasleg told me (Namsk Ulus, 1892).' [988] 'In conversation they are not loath ot ridicule old people: You foolish old man, blind, doing everything the opposite way, turning backwards... a Yakut proverb says. (Namsk Ulus, 1892).' [989] 'It sometimes happened that they would simply be driven out and forced to become beggards, to wander between the yurts. This is not always a consequence of poverty. In 1882 in Verkhoyansk an old beggar woman froze to death in the field in winter; she was the mother of the wife of one of the local rich Yakut. The clan could not 512 force the son-in-law to feed the old woman, since she was considered as belonging to another clan, and he did not want to take care of her of his own free will.' [990]
♠ fairness/cheating ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no material on fairness/cheating norms.
♠ in-group loyalty ♣ present ♥ The in-group coincided with the kin group. Sakha society was organized in patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [991] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [992] Kharuzin describes the kinship and clan system: 'The clan system of the Yakuts of the Yakutsk district finds its expression in the following principal features: . . . Each clan, or subdivision of a clan, taking its descent from one progenitor, possesses a definite territory, the rights to which derive from occupation and remoteness. From generation to generation, the kinsmen use the same sections of land or fishing sites which they possessed in the olden time. In its agrarian aspect the clan thus represents an isolated group, although at present, in the majority of cases, the community of neighbors has taken the place of the clan.' [993] 'The oldest kinsman in the clan, or the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa , is always heaped with honors, if he is both rich and has never been put on trial. To him pertains the jurisdiction in trifling quarrels between kinsfolk. The following ceremonies serve to recall the religious functions that he (Ysekh) formerly exercised a. At the time of the spring festival, which bears a strictly clan character, they bring to him, first of all, a large wooden vessel ( Choron ) containing kumiss; he pronounces a prayer of thanks to the gods and then pours the kumiss upon the fire. b. At the time of the arrival of the betrothed at the bridegroom’s yurt, they take from the sleigh of the betrothed, and place upon a table in front of the fire place the boiled head of a horse, whose eyes are covered with butter, to whose ears are attached intestines filled with horse’s blood, and a wooden cup filled with butter. After this the betrothed enters the yurt, and stands, having first untied her girdle, on the right side of the komelok [RCH: i. e., the fireplace] where she is met by the oldest kinsman, whose place is sometimes taken nowadays by the most honored guest, who, kneeling, throws into the fire 41 pieces of meat, blood and butter, and blesses the bride. For the completion of this ceremony, whose obvious object is to unite the bride with the bridegroom’s home, the oldest kinsman secures for his use the head, blood and butter brought into the yurt, and in addition the sum of one ruble.' [994] 'The solidarity of the kinsmen further expresses itself in the extensive mutual aid. “When disaster strikes,” writes M. Pripuzov, “each clan assists its indigent kinfolk, either through an assessment on the tax-paying individuals, or through the contributions of the separate families.” The support of the kutalani , i. e., of the persons unable to provide a subsistence for themselves (aged cripples, orphans, having neither father nor mother, etc.) constitutes an obligation of the clan or the separate families which compose it. The closest kinsmen are the customary guardians of the incapacitated members of the tribe: the mentally diseased, deaf and dumb, blind, etc.' [995] 'The exclusiveness of the clan structure finds expression among the Yakuts of the Yakutsk district in the fact that entrance into the clan for an outsider is almost impossible. Cases of adoption of strangers into the family are in fact encountered among the Yakuts, but only girls are accepted from a strange clan. The adoption of children of the male sex is practiced between close relations or in the most extreme case within the confines of the clan. The adopted child takes the name of the adoptive father, is considered a close relation of the members of the family of the latter, in consequence of which marriage between them and the adopted child is forbidden.' [996] 'Artificial kinship, in addition to cases of adoption, is also established through foster kinship [BK: in Russian, molochnim rodstvom , literally, “by milk kinship,” presumably referring to cases in which adoption is based on suckling of child by woman of the adoptive family]; it is considered as significant as blood kinship. As concerns the swearing of brothership, the almost universal mode of establishing artifical kinship, M. Pripuzov confirms the conclusion, to which M. Sieroszewski apparently also arrives, that at the present time it has fallen into desuetude among the Yakuts. Its existence at a former time, however, is to a certain degree proved by the traditions of the Yakuts.' [997] Clan structures became less important as the Russian period progressed, but did not disappear entirely: 'The old Yakut clan was governed by family representatives or a family council in which women very often played a conspicuous rôle. After the Russian conquest of Yakut Province, clan ties became less important and the family head more despotic.' [998] 'At the present time the so-called “great” families are but very rarely encountered among the Yakuts; sons usually separate (split off) after marriage and upon coming of age. Despite the fact that the type of the individual, i. e., “small” family, thus appears characteristic for the contemporary familial-household structure of the Yakuts of the Yakutsk district, the clan structure must by no means be counted in the number of completely vanished phenomena. In addition to the known division of the Yakuts into [unknown]ul[unknown]usi and naslegi , a division which one of the best investigators of Yakut life, M. Sieroszewski, does not recognize as indigenous to the Yakuts, the native population of the Yakutsk district, as in other localities of the region, continues to retain the ancient division into clans-- aga-usa (the paternal clan), resolving itself into 4-8 [unknown]iya-[unknown]usa . This latter term M. Pripuzov translates by the word “tribe”; M. Sieroszewski, who, as far as we know, was the first to turn his attention to the [unknown]iya-[unknown]usa , has observed that [unknown]iya-[unknown]usa ( [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa ) has the exact meaning of “maternal clan,” has described the significance that the latter has in the contemporary clan division of the Yakuts, and has set forth a hypothesis concerning the origin of the “maternal clan” among the Yakuts. [Page 38-39] At the present time, relationship within the limits of the iye-usa is traced through the male line, and M. Sieroszewski makes the extremely likely guess that the division of the paternal clan into several maternal clans is a natural consequence of the polygamy that was once practiced among the Yakuts. Monogamous marriage took a firm hold among the Yakuts only at the beginning of the 19th century. The aga-[unknown]usa included all the descendants taking their descent from one father, while each [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa included only the issue of one of his wives. The supposition of M. Sieroszewski has a great deal of verisimilitude. 39 In reality, however, where polygamy leads to the above-mentioned division of the paternal clan into several maternal clans, it only plays the role of a factor supporting in life the reckoning of relationship through the female line, and not the reason which gave rise to it: only upon the basis of an already existing custom of reckoning relationship through the wife’s line can the maternal clan arise, either as an independent organization, or as a sub-grouping of the paternal clan. Consequently, how ever the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa may have arisen among the Yakuts, its existence must be in fact regarded as a proof that there once existed among the Yakuts the custom of determining relationship through the wife’s line, the recollection of an epoch when the bonds uniting child and father were not yet taken into account. The fact cited by M. Sieroszewski, that according to tradition many paternal clans ( aga-[unknown]usa ) and even entire naslegi , took their designation from women, strengthens this supposition. The chief significance in the contemporary structure of the Yakuts, however, attaches to the aga-[unknown]usa , the paternal clan.' [999] The father's clan was structurally more important than the mother's clan: 'Following this presentation of the complete list of Yakut terms of relationship, two points remain to be cleared up: first, the function of the Yakut Je-usa (mother’s clan) as opposed to the Aga-usa (father’s clan or gens); and second, the inference to be drawn from Yakut classificatory and descriptive terms of relationship.' [1,000] 'The Yakut mother’s clan is not connected with a family organization in which the women have the chief place in the government, or with the mythical race of women of Asia Minor called Amazons. The Yakut man is the real ruler and head of certain social groups. The origin of the term, Je-usa, may be explained, as Sieroszevski assumed, by the former existence of polygamy among the Yakut. The children of each wife—and there is no question that the children knew their own mothers—formed a Je-usa, but all these groups of mothers with their children were considered to be divisions of the Aga-usa, or the father’s gens.' [1,001] 'In connection with the statement that the Yakut mother’s clan is an integral part of the father’s clan, we should like to present some data bearing on earlier matriarchal relations. The Yakut regard themselves [Page 132] as the offspring of the mythical Omogoi-bai, in spite of the fact that they originate from his daughter, who married a Tatar or a Buryat.' [1,002] Exogamy was the norm: '. . . In general, kinship ties play a very important role among the Yakuts in the question of wedlock. Up to the present the clan constitutes an exogamic group. While paying little attention to relationship [RCH: i. e., geneological relationship] as an obstacle to marriage, the Yakuts 40 , according to M. Pripuzov, not only consider kinship [RCH: i. e., patrilineal kinship] up to five removes an obstacle to marriage, but in general do not take wives from their own clan. Formerly, rich Yakuts even sought, insofar as possible, to secure wives for their sons from other naslegi . Inasmuch, on the other hand, as kinship through the female line is not taken into account in the making of marriages, data communicated by Prince Kostrov demonstrate that not only father and son or two brothers can marry their own sisters-german [RCH: presumably cousins who are not members of the patrilineal kin group] but an uncle can take to wife his own niece (the daughter of his sister). Inasmuch as such marriages are not permitted by the local priesthood, the Yakuts have resort to the following friction: the betrothed hires his fiancée, in the capacity of a servant, and lives with her sometimes throughout his whole life as if she were his wife. The recollection that all kinsfolk bear the same clan surname has led to the prohibition of marriages between individuals of the same name, if they live in the same locality.' [1,003] 'The Yakut look for brides for their sons not only outside of their clans ( us, nasleg ), but outside of the ulus, or union of clans. A girl, say the Yakut, is really a lot of aliens. This saying is reminiscent of the old time marriage by capture. Marriage is now also exogamic, but kalym (brideprice) is given in money, cattle, and other goods. Practically, the kalym may be regarded as an exchange of presents. What the parents of the bride receive from the parents of the bridegroom is almost equivalent to what they give her when she leaves their house. Often the bride carries with her cattle and goods of a greater value than her parents received that she may not be reproached by the bridegroom’s relatives for bringing only a small dowry with her. The young bride remains under the protection of her clan and family. Many common law customs regulate disagreements and dissensions: If a young woman leaves her husband because she dislikes him, her dowry remains with him; but, if she accuses him of cruelties, relatives on both sides decide the matter. The Yakut do not like to appeal to the Russian courts.' [1,004] 'We have previously mentioned the exogamic character of the Yakut marriages, but some other tendencies have been observed in the northern districts of Yakut Province. The few rich families endeavor to keep their horses, cattle, and grazing places within a certain group of families through marriage of close relatives, insofar as this is permitted by the Russian church. By special permission of a bishop, even cousins are permitted to marry. In one case, known to the author, a man lived with his niece, a marital relation forbidden by the Church, though his neighbors avoided mentioning this irregularity to strangers.' [1,005]
♠ purity ♣ present ♥ Concepts of contamination were prominent and spirits punished violations of taboo: 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.' [1,006] 'When a man, willingly or unwillingly, had offended some spirit, violated his rights, or did not fulfill his obligations, he was liable to be punished in some way: by illness, epizooty, or some other calamity. The Yakut is a hunter and fishermen. The abasy-siäce (i.e., abasy, the eater) also procures food for himself, and this food may be the man and his cattle. The Ajy and Icci may or may not give the man something. They are quite indifferent to him.' [1,007] 'Although parents are responsible for a child while it is growing, it may itself be punished for disrespect towards the spirits. When he has reached maturity, marries, and establishes his own household, he selects a place to build a house, but it has its owner-spirit from whom it is necessary to obtain permission to proceed. When the house, stall, and shelter for cattle are ready, each of these buildings, as well as the new fireplace, has its own “owners” with whom it is important to enter into good relations. To procure food and clothing for the family it is necessary to hunt in the woods and to fish in the lakes, but forests and waters have their own owners, without whose permission one cannot use the utilities they supervise. That the family may have adequate provision, the cattle must propagate, and for this, corresponding spirits must be propitiated. For the cattle, one needs to store hay, but grass grows in places belonging to particular owners. While traveling, a man passes the possessions of different owners, who must be conciliated with gifts or appropriate prayers. Thus, we see a well organized system in the relations of man to the circle of spirits.' [1,008] Pregnancy and birth were considered impure: 'The choom of the woman who gave birth to a child was regarded as impure. Only three people were allowed to reside in it: the mother herself, a midwife, and a third woman who kept up the fire in the fire place, prepared food, and washed the dishes; all this had to be done by the third woman, for the midwife, like the mother, was considered impure and was not supposed to touch the fire until the navel cord fell off the child's belly. Women who brought foodstuffs, or came to ask about the health of the mother, were not allowed to enter the choom and conversed and handed over what they brought through the open door.' [1,009] 'We Yakut were fastidious towards women (byrdyr) in the past; we considered them to be unclean (byrdakhta). (Namsk Ulus, 1891).' [1,010] 'Custom forbids women, particularly when they are pregnant, to eat certain dishes, and to touch certain objects. They are considered to be unclean. They may spoil a hunter's rifle for him or bring bad fortune to a fisherman. (Verkhoyansk Ulus, 1882). All this, constantly repeated, forces the women themselves from youngest years to become accustomed to the consciousness of their inconsequence and lack of rights, and makes them meek and modest. Yakut women in general are considerably more submissive and obedient than our women.' [1,011] However, fecundity was still valued: 'Until the most recent times the Dolgani regarded it as sinful (an'i) for the men to remain bachelors and for the women to remain unmarried. After their death the souls of these people were to become heretics (sic) (dzheretinnik), who would frighten the living, for they would remain by their graves and would not depart for the land of the dead. However, if without getting married a girl gave birth to children, her soul was not turned into a heretic. At the same time it was considered a sin for a widower to marry again. A married couple would rarely break up, for fear of committing a sin thereby. In selecting his first wife a man was believed to be following a course predetermined for him by a beneficent god: the particular woman he selected was believed to have been born specially for him and had been fated to be his wife. If upon the death of his wife the widower remarried it was believed that the ayy (a beneficent god) would stop treating him with good will (aytytyn eyetya aragar). It was thought that the ayy did not select ten wives for a man, but only one. As a result, the second marriage was believed to be entered into without the approval of the ayy, but of the man's own free will. When a man who had been married to two women died, it was believed that he would unite with his first wife, while his second wife would reside separately with her maternal relatives. If upon the death of his second wife a man would marry for the third time, it was believed that such conduct was inspired by the evil spirit--abasy, and was very sinful. After his [Page 23] death such man, as well as his wives, would to into the region inhabited by the abasy.' [1,012]
♠ respect for authority ♣ present ♥ According to Sieroszewski, strength and the ability to enforce one's will were valued: 'I received such answers to my plainly put questions as to the leadership of the family from everyone, in all the corners of the Yakutsk Oblast, but at the present time they express no more than a certain ideal to long for, a morality like the Christian love thy neighbor as thyself. In actual practice the Yakut family is quite a different thing, and only the subordination of women is strictly drawn. The subordination of the younger to the elder is in its turn subject to a still more general rule: the subordination of the weaker to the stronger, and of the poor to the rich. It is true that I have heard of many cases where the father, eldest brother, or uncle forced younger members of the household to marry, gave them to outsiders to work under very harsh conditions and kept all they pay themselves. I know of a case where the father took possession of the son's belongings, took away his axe and boat, sold the hay which his son had mowed all by himself, and the son only bewailed his fate and could not do anyt hing. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883). I know of a case where the parents sold their eight year old daughter to an official who was passing through. (Borogon Ulus, 1884). Many times I have heard and seen the older members of a family cruelly beat their relatives, [Page 806] particularly wives and children, but I know of an equal number of cases where the opposite has taken place. I know of cases where the younger brothers played a more important role in the family than the elder brothers; where sons beat their aged parents until they went into tears; where a wife, unconstrained by the presence of outsiders, treated her sick, feeble husband very rudely, and even beat him and openly kept a lover in the house. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883), Namsk Ulus 511 1888). I have also heard of a daughter, realizing that she was the only worker in the house, paid absolutely no attention to her parents, did what she wished, refused a profitable marriage, and went around with boys in front of everyone's eyes. (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883). I know of a case where the old people did not dare to sell a funt of butter, or a load of hay, and did not dare buy anything for themselves without the permission of their grown-up son.' [1,013] 'None of these things were considered to be anything unusual and called forth no more censure on the part of the commune, than the cruel or unfair treatment of children would. There can not even be any question of any kind of strict patriarchial relations, or of some kind of deeply inborn or inbred feeling of respect to elders among the Yakut. Not only don't they feed, respect, and obey old people, but they often even curse them and beat them. With my own eyes I've seen more than once how Yakut beat their parents... Rich people and poor people do this, thin people, respected people; they beat their fathers and beat their mothers... a young fellow of the Betyun'sk Nasleg told me (Namsk Ulus, 1892).' [1,014] 'In conversation they are not loath ot ridicule old people: You foolish old man, blind, doing everything the opposite way, turning backwards... a Yakut proverb says. (Namsk Ulus, 1892).' [1,015] 'It sometimes happened that they would simply be driven out and forced to become beggards, to wander between the yurts. This is not always a consequence of poverty. In 1882 in Verkhoyansk an old beggar woman froze to death in the field in winter; she was the mother of the wife of one of the local rich Yakut. The clan could not 512 force the son-in-law to feed the old woman, since she was considered as belonging to another clan, and he did not want to take care of her of his own free will.' [1,016] We have provisionally coded this as a form of 'respect for authority', but this is debatable and open to review. However, this concept may have legitimated toyon rule. More material is needed.
♠ kinship ♣ present ♥ Sakha society was organized in patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [1,017] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [1,018] Kharuzin describes the kinship and clan system: 'The clan system of the Yakuts of the Yakutsk district finds its expression in the following principal features: . . . Each clan, or subdivision of a clan, taking its descent from one progenitor, possesses a definite territory, the rights to which derive from occupation and remoteness. From generation to generation, the kinsmen use the same sections of land or fishing sites which they possessed in the olden time. In its agrarian aspect the clan thus represents an isolated group, although at present, in the majority of cases, the community of neighbors has taken the place of the clan.' [1,019] 'The oldest kinsman in the clan, or the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa , is always heaped with honors, if he is both rich and has never been put on trial. To him pertains the jurisdiction in trifling quarrels between kinsfolk. The following ceremonies serve to recall the religious functions that he (Ysekh) formerly exercised a. At the time of the spring festival, which bears a strictly clan character, they bring to him, first of all, a large wooden vessel ( Choron ) containing kumiss; he pronounces a prayer of thanks to the gods and then pours the kumiss upon the fire. b. At the time of the arrival of the betrothed at the bridegroom’s yurt, they take from the sleigh of the betrothed, and place upon a table in front of the fire place the boiled head of a horse, whose eyes are covered with butter, to whose ears are attached intestines filled with horse’s blood, and a wooden cup filled with butter. After this the betrothed enters the yurt, and stands, having first untied her girdle, on the right side of the komelok [RCH: i. e., the fireplace] where she is met by the oldest kinsman, whose place is sometimes taken nowadays by the most honored guest, who, kneeling, throws into the fire 41 pieces of meat, blood and butter, and blesses the bride. For the completion of this ceremony, whose obvious object is to unite the bride with the bridegroom’s home, the oldest kinsman secures for his use the head, blood and butter brought into the yurt, and in addition the sum of one ruble.' [1,020] 'The solidarity of the kinsmen further expresses itself in the extensive mutual aid. “When disaster strikes,” writes M. Pripuzov, “each clan assists its indigent kinfolk, either through an assessment on the tax-paying individuals, or through the contributions of the separate families.” The support of the kutalani , i. e., of the persons unable to provide a subsistence for themselves (aged cripples, orphans, having neither father nor mother, etc.) constitutes an obligation of the clan or the separate families which compose it. The closest kinsmen are the customary guardians of the incapacitated members of the tribe: the mentally diseased, deaf and dumb, blind, etc.' [1,021] 'The exclusiveness of the clan structure finds expression among the Yakuts of the Yakutsk district in the fact that entrance into the clan for an outsider is almost impossible. Cases of adoption of strangers into the family are in fact encountered among the Yakuts, but only girls are accepted from a strange clan. The adoption of children of the male sex is practiced between close relations or in the most extreme case within the confines of the clan. The adopted child takes the name of the adoptive father, is considered a close relation of the members of the family of the latter, in consequence of which marriage between them and the adopted child is forbidden.' [1,022] 'Artificial kinship, in addition to cases of adoption, is also established through foster kinship [BK: in Russian, molochnim rodstvom , literally, “by milk kinship,” presumably referring to cases in which adoption is based on suckling of child by woman of the adoptive family]; it is considered as significant as blood kinship. As concerns the swearing of brothership, the almost universal mode of establishing artifical kinship, M. Pripuzov confirms the conclusion, to which M. Sieroszewski apparently also arrives, that at the present time it has fallen into desuetude among the Yakuts. Its existence at a former time, however, is to a certain degree proved by the traditions of the Yakuts.' [1,023] Clan structures became less important as the Russian period progressed, but did not disappear entirely: 'The old Yakut clan was governed by family representatives or a family council in which women very often played a conspicuous rôle. After the Russian conquest of Yakut Province, clan ties became less important and the family head more despotic.' [1,024] 'At the present time the so-called “great” families are but very rarely encountered among the Yakuts; sons usually separate (split off) after marriage and upon coming of age. Despite the fact that the type of the individual, i. e., “small” family, thus appears characteristic for the comtemporary familial-household structure of the Yakuts of the Yakutsk district, the clan structure must by no means be counted in the number of completely vanished phenomena. In addition to the known division of the Yakuts into [unknown]ul[unknown]usi and naslegi , a division which one of the best investigators of Yakut life, M. Sieroszewski, does not recognize as indigenous to the Yakuts, the native population of the Yakutsk district, as in other localities of the region, continues to retain the ancient division into clans-- aga-usa (the paternal clan), resolving itself into 4-8 [unknown]iya-[unknown]usa . This latter term M. Pripuzov translates by the word “tribe”; M. Sieroszewski, who, as far as we know, was the first to turn his attention to the [unknown]iya-[unknown]usa , has observed that [unknown]iya-[unknown]usa ( [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa ) has the exact meaning of “maternal clan,” has described the significance that the latter has in the contemporary clan division of the Yakuts, and has set forth a hypothesis concerning the origin of the “maternal clan” among the Yakuts. [Page 38-39] At the present time, relationship within the limits of the iye-usa is traced through the male line, and M. Sieroszewski makes the extremely likely guess that the division of the paternal clan into several maternal clans is a natural consequence of the polygamy that was once practiced among the Yakuts. Monogamous marriage took a firm hold among the Yakuts only at the beginning of the 19th century. The aga-[unknown]usa included all the descendants taking their descent from one father, while each [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa included only the issue of one of his wives. The supposition of M. Sieroszewski has a great deal of verisimilitude. 39 In reality, however, where polygamy leads to the above-mentioned division of the paternal clan into several maternal clans, it only plays the role of a factor supporting in life the reckoning of relationship through the female line, and not the reason which gave rise to it: only upon the basis of an already existing custom of reckoning relationship through the wife’s line can the maternal clan arise, either as an independent organization, or as a sub-grouping of the paternal clan. Consequently, how ever the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa may have arisen among the Yakuts, its existence must be in fact regarded as a proof that there once existed among the Yakuts the custom of determining relationship through the wife’s line, the recollection of an epoch when the bonds uniting child and father were not yet taken into account. The fact cited by M. Sieroszewski, that according to tradition many paternal clans ( aga-[unknown]usa ) and even entire naslegi , took their designation from women, strengthens this supposition. The chief significance in the contemporary structure of the Yakuts, however, attaches to the aga-[unknown]usa , the paternal clan.' [1,025] The father's clan was structurally more important than the mother's clan: 'Following this presentation of the complete list of Yakut terms of relationship, two points remain to be cleared up: first, the function of the Yakut Je-usa (mother’s clan) as opposed to the Aga-usa (father’s clan or gens); and second, the inference to be drawn from Yakut classificatory and descriptive terms of relationship.' [1,026] 'The Yakut mother’s clan is not connected with a family organization in which the women have the chief place in the government, or with the mythical race of women of Asia Minor called Amazons. The Yakut man is the real ruler and head of certain social groups. The origin of the term, Je-usa, may be explained, as Sieroszevski assumed, by the former existence of polygamy among the Yakut. The children of each wife—and there is no question that the children knew their own mothers—formed a Je-usa, but all these groups of mothers with their children were considered to be divisions of the Aga-usa, or the father’s gens.' [1,027] 'In connection with the statement that the Yakut mother’s clan is an integral part of the father’s clan, we should like to present some data bearing on earlier matriarchal relations. The Yakut regard themselves [Page 132] as the offspring of the mythical Omogoi-bai, in spite of the fact that they originate from his daughter, who married a Tatar or a Buryat.' [1,028] Exogamy was the norm: '. . . In general, kinship ties play a very important role among the Yakuts in the question of wedlock. Up to the present the clan constitutes an exogamic group. While paying little attention to relationship [RCH: i. e., geneological relationship] as an obstacle to marriage, the Yakuts 40 , according to M. Pripuzov, not only consider kinship [RCH: i. e., patrilineal kinship] up to five removes an obstacle to marriage, but in general do not take wives from their own clan. Formerly, rich Yakuts even sought, insofar as possible, to secure wives for their sons from other naslegi . Inasmuch, on the other hand, as kinship through the female line is not taken into account in the making of marriages, data communicated by Prince Kostrov demonstrate that not only father and son or two brothers can marry their own sisters-german [RCH: presumably cousins who are not members of the patrilineal kin group] but an uncle can take to wife his own niece (the daughter of his sister). Inasmuch as such marriages are not permitted by the local priesthood, the Yakuts have resort to the following friction: the betrothed hires his fiancée, in the capacity of a servant, and lives with her sometimes throughout his whole life as if she were his wife. The recollection that all kinsfolk bear the same clan surname has led to the prohibition of marriages between individuals of the same name, if they live in the same locality.' [1,029] 'The Yakut look for brides for their sons not only outside of their clans ( us, nasleg ), but outside of the ulus, or union of clans. A girl, say the Yakut, is really a lot of aliens. This saying is reminiscent of the old time marriage by capture. Marriage is now also exogamic, but kalym (brideprice) is given in money, cattle, and other goods. Practically, the kalym may be regarded as an exchange of presents. What the parents of the bride receive from the parents of the bridegroom is almost equivalent to what they give her when she leaves their house. Often the bride carries with her cattle and goods of a greater value than her parents received that she may not be reproached by the bridegroom’s relatives for bringing only a small dowry with her. The young bride remains under the protection of her clan and family. Many common law customs regulate disagreements and dissensions: If a young woman leaves her husband because she dislikes him, her dowry remains with him; but, if she accuses him of cruelties, relatives on both sides decide the matter. The Yakut do not like to appeal to the Russian courts.' [1,030] 'We have previously mentioned the exogamic character of the Yakut marriages, but some other tendencies have been observed in the northern districts of Yakut Province. The few rich families endeavor to keep their horses, cattle, and grazing places within a certain group of families through marriage of close relatives, insofar as this is permitted by the Russian church. By special permission of a bishop, even cousins are permitted to marry. In one case, known to the author, a man lived with his niece, a marital relation forbidden by the Church, though his neighbors avoided mentioning this irregularity to strangers.' [1,031]
♠ bravery ♣ present ♥ This short passage by Jochelson seems to imply that bravery was valued: 'The brave, fearless, heroic, courageous, daring, strong, gallant one; a title particle to the names of heroes in folklore. See bärgän, böhö, böhös .' [1,032] More material is needed.
♠ respect for property ♣ present ♥ Property was held and transmitted within patrilineages: 'Key kin relations are based on a patrilineage (AQA-USA) that traces membership back nine generations. Within this, children born to a specific mother are distinguished as a group (YE-USA), and may form the basis for different households (KORGON). Historically, more distant kin were recognized on two levels, the AIMAK (or territorial NASLEG), with one to thirty lineages, and the DZHON (or territorial ULUS), composed of several AIMAK. These larger units were united by alliances, including for common defense, alliances, and by economic relations; these links were renewed at councils and festivals.' [1,033] 'Kin terms reflect gender and age distinctions, and distinguish senior from junior paternal lines. Any relation, affinal or consanguineal, is called URU, which is the word for wedding.' [1,034] 'By customary law, land, cattle, and horses, although used by households, were controlled by the patriline. Animal or land sale and inheritance was approved by elders. But by the twentieth century, smaller families were keeping resources, in part because of the decline of large horse droves. Men owned most of the wealth, and passed it to sons, especially elder sons, although the youngest son often inherited the family yurt. Mothers could pass on dowries to daughters, unless the dowry was forfeited by bad behavior. In theory, dowries included land, as well as goods, jewelry, and animals, although in practice elders rarely gave land to another lineage. Soviet law limited inheritance to goods and nonstate housing could be bequeathed at individual discretion. Most apartments and summer houses were kept in families.' [1,035] Clans excluded women from inheritance in order to protect the property of hte patrilineage: 'The property rights of women are extremely limited; however, even in this direction certain changes are taking place under the influence of the gradual recognition of woman’s capacity. These innovations, however, are apparently only beginning to penetrate the consciousness of the Yakuts, and have not yet succeeded in conclusively changing the archaic views, denying property rights to women.' [1,036] 'In relations to her own family group the woman is completely without rights: she must marry into a strange clan, and it is understandable that her kinsmen look upon her as a severed member.' [1,037] 'Each clan or familial unit, under the influence of the impulse of self-preservation in the struggle for existence, strives insofar as possible to insure its economic existence through the accumulation of wealth. Naturally, it jealously guards its property against transfer into the hands of members of a strange clan; it is here that we must seek the reason for the fact that women have no rights in relation to the property belonging to their kin group. Among the Yakuts, the latter, as is the case everywhere with peoples on a low level of economic development, permits a girl to accumulate property by her personal labor: the product of her personal exertions, whether sewing or other handicraft, becomes part of her possessions, but among the Yakuts, as is the case everywhere, the girl secures the right of ownership of the products of her labor only in the degree that she performs this labor during her hours of leisure and rest, after having performed the household duties which fall to her share. The same rule, it appears, applies 44 to married women. Woman, as a member of her kin group prior to marriage, and subsequently in the capacity of a worker for her husband and his group, has only a portion of the time for her own use, and the group concedes to her as personal property only what she can produce after satisfying the needs of her father’s or her husband’s family.' [1,038] 'The absence of property rights on the part of women in relation to their kin group in graphically expressed in the exclusion of women from inheritance. If the economic and administrative principle lying at the foundation of the family constructed on a blood basis makes quite natural the rule of Yakut customary law, that sisters cannot inherit from brothers, that upon the death of a brother his cultivated land passes to another brother, although the latter might already have a farmstead, then in the exclusion of women from inheritance from the parents, where only daughters survived, we must see a direct consequence of the clan structure, in which the kinsmen vigilantly watch to see that the clan property does not pass to a strange clan, which inevitably happens in the case of the marriage of a girl-legatee.' [1,039] 'M. Pripuzov informs us that upon the death of a person survived only by daughters, the legatees are in the first place his brothers, i. e., the uncles on the paternal side. Further, if the father of the deceased is alive, then by the general rule of Yakut customary law in the district investigated, which makes the parents the legatees of their children deceased without issue, he secures a larger share of the inheritance than the other relations. Where death takes place without male issue, the situation is the same as if there were no issue at all. Finally, the remaining relations come in for their share of the inheritance. A part of the property is set aside for the support and subsistence of the daughters, the remainder is divided between the relations with the closer relations securing a larger part (the father gets more than the rest), while the more distant relatives get a lesser share. A married daughter, like the unmarried daughters, is excluded form sharing in the paternal inheritance: in any case, she cannot inherit her father’s cultivated land, and if there are no direct heirs, the farm passes to the closest relations.' [1,040] 'The brothers, excluding their sisters from inheritance of the paternal property, are nevertheless obliged to support their unmarried sisters, to concern themselves with giving them in marriage, and to provide them with dowries from the general property. Mr. Priklonski, however, (Tri goda v[unknown] IAkutskoi oblasti [three years in the Yakutsk territory]. Zhiva[unknown]ia Starina, 1890, pt. 3, p. 80). notes that the share of the daughters in the division of property upon the death of the father is equal to that of the brothers; this share goes to the brothers, for the support of the sisters.' [1,041] 'That in effect it is the economic principle, in union with the blood principle, and not the fact of the grant of a dowry to a girl entering into marriage, that lies at the basis of the exclusion of women from the paternal inheritance, is demonstrated by the fact that the dowry itself does not in any way correspond to the shares which fall to the lot of the sons upon the death of the father. Mr. Pripuzov unfortunately communicates only extremely fragmentary and incomplete information concerning the size of the dowry, concerning the objects which go to make it up, and concerning the relation of the personal property of the girl, accumulated by her own labor, to the dowry given by her parents at the time of marriage.' [1,042] Non-fulfillment of material obligations and theft were punished: '1. Among the financial obligations of the Yakut, the most important and necessary, both for the rich and poor, is the maintenance of animals, because it gives the former a chance to increase their herds, and the latter a means of subsistence and of paying taxes and duties. This the rich, including Russians of various ranks, give a certain number of animals to poor Yakut and to Yakut of moderate means: from ten to 40 head to one family for one year, from May to May of the following year, for a payment which is fixed and agreed upon [Page 26] mutually; for instance, a person who takes 20 head of cattle is paid 20 rubles in cash for feeding this number of cattle, four milch cows, figuring their milk at 10 to 15 rubles, which is not counted in the amount for maintaining the cattle, one bull for harnessing, figuring the “body” for him at three to five rubles; for this amount, and sometimes more, the keeper, called the cattleman, must pasture the animals in the summer and the winter give them hay which he has prepared on his lands, so as to return them stout and healthy in the spring. The milk from the dun-colored cows, excluding those given him to feed, he must deliver to the owner in October in the form of butter and sour milk; he must guard the animals 238 from death or loss; and, in case he does lose any, or they are stolen or die for any reason, he must pay for them in kind or in money, except in case of infection or natural disease, or in case the thief makes the payment.' [1,043] '2. If the keeper uses an animal for his own needs, willfully and without the consent of the owner, he pays for it in kind, and is beaten with rods for his willfulness.' [1,044] '3. If he keeps an animal himself and says that it has been lost or stolen, or if he deliberately kills it, which frequently happens, as he may want to eat its meat, and says that it has died in some way, and his lie is discovered, he is beaten with rods and must pay as a thief.' [1,045] '3. If anyone says that a certain animal came and joined his herd, and afterwards that animal is missing and he does not report its loss, he pays 230 for it in full, if there is no suspicion of him; if there is, he is judged a thief.' [1,046]

♠ Moralistic punishment by human religious agents ♣ absent ♥ absent/present/unknown. eHRAF provides the following summary: 'Yakut religion derives from Turkic, Mongolic, Tungusic, and Russian ideas. Labels like "animist," "shamanist," or "Russian Orthodox" do not suffice. Ideas of sin are syncretised with concepts of contamination and taboo. Saints and bears are seen as shamanic spirit helpers. Christ is identified with the Yakut Bright Creator Elder God, Aiyy-toyon. A pantheon of gods, believed to live in nine hierarchical eastern heavens, was only one aspect of a complex traditional cosmology that still has meaning for some Yakut. Another crucial dimension was the spirit-soul (ICHCHI) of living beings, rocks, trees, natural forces, and objects crafted by humans. Most honored was the hearth spirit (YOT ICHCHITE), still fed morsels of food and drink by pious Yakut. Giant trees (AL LUKH MAS), deep in the forest, were especially sacred: their ICHCHI are still given small offerings of coins, scarves, and ribbons. Belief in ICHCHI is related to ancient ideas of harmony and equilibrium with nature, and to shamanism. Yakut shamanism is a Turkic, Mongolic, and Tungusic blend of belief in the supernatural, with emphasis on the ability of "white," or benign, shamans to intercede, through prayers and séances, with eastern spirits for the sake of humans. "Black" shamans, communing with evil spirits, could both benefit and harm humans.' [1,047] 'As with other Siberian peoples, Yakut shamans (OIUN if male, UDAGAN if female) combine medical and spiritual practice. Despite centuries of Russian Orthodox and Soviet discrediting of shamans as greedy charlatans, some Yakut maintain belief in shamans and supernatural powers. Others, struggling to recover spirituality after rejecting Marxist-Leninist materialism, accept aspects of shamanic philosophy. Still others, influenced by Soviet education and science, reject all religion as superstition. In the nineteenth century a few Yakut leaders financed the building of Russian Orthodox churches, and many Yakut declared themselves Christian, but this did not mean that they saw Christianity and shamanism as mutually exclusive. The Yakut also believed in the spiritual power of blacksmiths. By the 1980s shamans in Yakutia were rare and more likely to be Evenk than Yakut. Yet rituals once associated with spirit belief were being revived by urban as well as rural Yakut.' [1,048] 'The most important ceremony, associated with a founding Yakut ancestor named Ellei, is the annual summer YHYAK festival, a celebration of seasonal change, of KUMYS (fermented mare's milk), and of kin solidarity. Once a religious celebration led by a shaman, the ceremony has been adapted since World War I into a secular commemoration of Yakut traditions. Practiced in villages and towns, it features opening prayers (ALGYS) and libations of KUMYS to the earth. Although some Yakut debate its "authenticity," the festival still includes feasting, horse racing, wrestling, and all-night line dancing to improvised chants. It lasts three joyous days in Suntar, where it is especially famed. Wedding rituals, pared down from previous eras, center around memorial hitching posts (SERQE), carved for the occasion, with couples honored by prayers, special food, and dancing. New rituals marking wedding anniversaries and graduations at all educational levels include the placement of SERQE, on which names of those honored are carved. But traditional rituals of birth, supplicating the goddess of fertility, Aiyycyt, have become less popular, with some Yakut women even mocking the restrictions that were once associated with beliefs about female impurity. Russian Orthodox holidays are rarely celebrated.' [1,049] Shamanism was important: 'Pre-Christian beliefs comprise the dominant component of the traditional worldview of the Yakuts. “Traditional” because the foundation for such a worldview by these people was developed during an era when mythological-epic thinking dominated among a people of a preclass society (L’vova et al., p. 6). “World-view” is interpreted here to mean “the spiritual assimilation of the universe . . . from the pint of view of the interrelation of such fundamental elements of the universe as nature and humanity” (Chanyshev, p. 38).' [1,050] 'Yakut traditional beliefs and shamanism have been studied in considerable detail.’ Despite this, the genesis of black and white shamanism has not received an appropriate explanation, although the history of research into this matter has begun.' [1,051] 'The first information concerning the existence of black and white shamans among Yakuts was reported by participants of the Second Kamchatka Expedition. I. Gmelin and G. Miller described the “summer” shaman, who directed the performance of the ritual holidayyhyakh. Ia. I. Lindenau gave another name for the Yakut white shaman-tnnnrrr oiiiunn, the “heavenly shaman” or the “shaman of the sky” (Lindenau, p. 39). But a more thorough description of the white shaman was given by one of the first Yakut ethnographers, N. S. Gorokhov. “For the dealings of earthly humans with Iuriung Aiyy foion there exist ‘ai oiuna,’ ” he wrote, “-the ai shamans, who can never do any evil to anyone. . . . The ai oiuna do not have any shamanic costume. . . , not even a shamanic drum; they only give benedictions and beg for the mercy of Iuriung Aiyy toion. The ai oiuna always pray only to Iuriung Aiyy toion, and only in one case, when attempting to cure infertility, do they pray to Magan Sylgylakh or to some other dweller of the heavens, in order to petition for a son. The ai oiuna do not perform sacrifices-that is, they do not slaughter livestock as sacrifices, and may only consecrate one animal or another to a heavenly dweller, and then they do not do any work with this animal and, if possible, safeguard it and care for it” (Gorokhov, p. 56).' [1,052] 'N. S. Gorokhov was born and lived in the north of Yakutia, in Verkhoiansk, where white shamans, the “aiyy shamans,” could still be found until the 1870s. “These were,” as he notes, “truly wonderful people, gentle to the point of delicacy, unconditionally honest, and genuinely kind. Looking at them, it would be difficult to doubt the sincerity of their faith in their vocation. . . .” ' [1,053] 'Gorokhov explained the division of shamanism into black and white by the Yakuts’ division of the visible and invisible world into two parts: into aiyy-the divine, light, clean, and good-and abahy-the diabolical, evil, and unclean. Humanity, livestock, and useful animals and plants comprised aijy. Everything harmful and foul-that is, everything that causes harm to humanity-was the invention of abahy.' [1,054] 'Certain prerevolutionary researchers, uncovering features of dualism in Yakut beliefs, explained them by pointing out that numerous ethnic groups had participated in the ethnogenesis of the Yakuts, and that a unification of the various mythological and religious systems had taken place during their merging into one people (Kharuzina, pp. 171-72).' [1,055] 'In the opinion of V. F. Troshchanskii, the division of shamanism is the result of the evolutionary development of primal [pervobytnaia] religion. One evolutionary direction is associated with the continued development of black shamanism. This finds its highest expression in the formalization of the “religion of the devotees of Shiva.” Yakut beliefs were correlated to a “black faith” derived from the beliefs of the “Turkic and Mongol peoples” (Troshchanskii, pp. 156-58). In contrast, W. I. Jochelson (pp. 197-205) found themes of dualism in the custom of celebrating two holidays during the year-in early summer, an yhyakh was organized as a holiday of fertility, while in the autumn, an yhyakh took place in honor of destructive forces and evil spirits and deities-“the dwellers of the west.” Therefore, “the dualistic ideas and poetic folklore of Western Asia are characteristic. . . ” of Yakut spiritual culture.' [1,056] 'In Soviet times, a number of researchers have regarded the pre-Christian religion of the Yakuts as consisting of two components. P. A. Oiunskii separated shamanism from the ancient religious cults of Yakut ancestors. A similar opinion was expressed by the well-known expert on Yakut ethnography, M. M. No~ov.~ G. V. Ksenofontov associated the airy cult with a “higher,” predominant component of the religion, which was publicly recognized and openly practiced. Demonology, alternatively, comprised the “lower” tier-the unofficial popular religion of the masses. He explained the disappearance of white shamans, who served the higher tier of Yakut religion: “with the acceptance of Christianity, Yakut leaders [toions] were obliged to liquidate their ancient official cult.” Yet black shamans, as the practitioners of the popular demonology, did not yield easily to public control, and therefore were able to remain alongside Christianity.' [1,057] 'S. A. Tokarev described white shamanism in different waysfor instance, as involving the priests of particular deities of light. “The very concept of benevolent, luminous deities,” he wrote, “as distinct from evil spirits, arises relatively late, as the result of more complex conditions of social life” (Tokarev, pp. 171-72).' [1,058] 'In the opinion of N. A. Alekseev, white shamans were the priests of tribal uiyy deities. In his work, he gave a fuller description of this cult in its entirety. In contrast to black shamans, white shamans prayed to their deities during their rituals, similarly to the priests of any polytheistic religions; they did not “voyage” or “fly” to them, they did not fall into ecstasy, nor did they have helper-spirits. They had to observe ritual purity (including avoiding the dead, not associating with black shamans, and so on) (Alekseev, 1975, pp. 77-102).' [1,059] 'Research in the area of the historical lexicon of the Yakut language has led to the conclusion that the terminology of black shamanism is of Mongol-Buryat origin (including the names of the parts of the shamanic drum, the cloak, and shamanic rituals), while terminology associated with the uiyy cult and its priests has a Turkic origin as its basis (Antonov, p. 145). According to Ksenofontov, the attitude of the livestock-herding peoples of the Lena toward shamans was hostile; shamans were considered to be servants of a foul profession alien to their own age-old traditions.' [1,060] 'According to modern evolutionary thought on the subject, shamanism is understood to be a particular form of religion widespread among peoples of classless societies-particularly at the stage of their decline-and is then retained as a vestige at higher stages of social development. In a narrower sense, shamanism usually refers to the religion of the peoples of Northern Asia. The typical course of action in shamanism is the seance [kumlunie], the purpose of which, more often than not, is to heal the sick. As perceived in folk conceptions, shamans make inquiries of spirits with the assistance of their personal helper-spirits. A good shaman would need to possess many extraordinary qualities. “He is not conceited,” notes V. L. Seroshevskii, “ . . . not greedy, not overly demanding. Neither excessive arrogance nor pride are discernible in his dealings with people; more likely, a tangible feeling of internal strength is revealed, before which those surrounding him involuntarily bow, and which generates trust in and obedience to him” (Seroshevskii, p. 631).' [1,061] 'The ethnographic record of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries has provided a wealth of material on shamanism among the peoples of Siberia, Kazakhstan, and Central Asia, the American Indians and Eskimos, and many of the peoples of Southeast Asia. The majority of these peoples lived under the conditions of an appropriative [pr-isvnivni~tshchee] economy, nomadic livestock-breeding, and slash-and-burn agriculture. All of this seems to demonstrate that shamanism indeed represents a specific early stage in the development of religion. Figuratively speaking, shamanism is the focused nucleus of the religious beliefs of an early society during the era of its decline, being fundamentally the ideology of an appropriative economy. In those regions of the world where a transition took place from Stone-Age society directly to a producer economy, religious conceptions changed accordingly, and the foundations of the agricultural polytheistic religions were laid. But in societies that never made a transition to developed agriculture (among advanced fishing, hunting, gathering, and, to some extent, livestock-breeding societies), shamanism remains the principal form of religious belief, attaining more refined forms of development. Therefore, in the forest-and-steppe regions, the dense taiga of the north, and the tropical jungles-that is, in those places where gathering and fishing, hunting, and undevcloped forms of producer economy dominate-there have remained the conditions for the existence of shamanism.' [1,062] 'The Eurasian steppes, due to their geographic situation, have occupied a “buffer zone” position. In the east, the steppes divided the relevant portion of the continent into a northern part, where primarily the appropriative economy developed, and a southern one, which had producer forms of economy. The steppes themselves occupied the central area. It is possible that on the strength of the mediating position of the steppe nomads, their religious formulations were characterized by syncretic features-the intertwining of shamanic and priesthood concepts, with a clear dominance of the former. Not only that, but in the early state formations that were situated in the semisteppe regions of the Far East and Central Asia during the tenth through thirteenth centuries-those of the Jurchens, Kidans, and Tanguts-shamanism was elevated to the status of a state religion (Vorob’ev, pp. 48-49). Shamanism existed right up until the twentieth century in such an expressly agricultural East Asian country as Korea (Ionova). This is connected with the idea that Altaic-speaking elements, such as the ManchuroTungus, played an active part in the origin of the Koreans.' [1,063] 'The perpetuation of shamanism among the peoples of Kazakhstan and Central Asia was closely connected with the ancient beliefs and rituals of local Iranian-speaking peoples. This view held by researchers is confirmed in part by the phenomenon that vestiges of the ancient Prashaman complex of Iranian-speaking ethnoses are distinctly manifested in the fervor of the Central Asian and Iranian dervishes, which consists of the recitation of verses, the attainment of a trance state, the utilization of zoomorphic helper-spirits, and the use of a shamanic drum and beater (Kuz’mina, p. 171).' [1,064] 'The origin of the shamanism of the Turkic-speaking Yakuts from outside of the ethnic group seems to be confirmed not only linguistically, but also by folkloric data. According to legends, the Yakuts are descended from two progenitorsOmogoi and Ellei. From Omogoi came the residents of the Namsk and Baiagantai regions [ulus], who in ancient times did not have the right to organize an yhyakh festival. The origins of the principal central-Yakut ulus are associated with Ellei, the cultural hero, the first organizer and priest of the yhyclkh, and the founder of the niyy cult. These people, the “Tribe of Ellei,” most likely belonged to the Turkic-speaking ancestors of the Yakuts. The etymology of the word “Ellei”-which in the opinion of 0. Botling, is derived from the Uighur 3115 meaning “to give birth to a clan”-likewise supports this. Horse-breeding dominanted their economy, which is also corroborated by linguistic materials: all Yakut words for equine livestock, for their stages of growth, and for meat and milk products obtained from equine livestock, as well as all terms associated with the exploitation of the horse, are Turkic (Antonov, pp. 25-34). In their beliefs, a prominent place was occupied by theyhyakh, the cult holiday of equine livestock fertility. The principal themes of Yakut mythology, in which worldviews derived from the ancient nomadic Iranian-speaking tribes of Middle and Central Asia are evident alongside those of Turkic peoples, are associated with this complex.' [1,065] 'The bulk of Yakut livestock-breeding terms are of Mongol derivation, associated with the “People of Omogoi” in their origin. The terminology of a “hunter-artisan cult” likewise belongs among the words of Mongol derivation (Antonov, pp. 36-37, 145). This complex consists of shamanism and the entire demonological aspect of the Yakut religious system. The “livestock-breeding accoutrements” of these two outlooks have found reflection in proverbs and sayings.' [1,066] 'On the cliff drawings on the Middle Lena, dated as being prior to the arrival of Yakut ancestors, figures of shamans with drums and rattles have been uncovered, as well as a depiction of a person with arms raised upward as if in prayer, above whom were carved three circles-symbols of three suns or of a three-dimensional conception of the Universe. A. P. Okladnikov considered this priest figure to be a depiction of a Yakut white shaman (Okladnikov, pp. 375-76).' [1,067] 'It is not enough to explain the nature of the dualism in Yakut traditional beliefs merely through ethnic considerations, given the fact that dualism to one extent or another actually appears in many religions. The division of shamanism was likewise inherent in the beliefs of the Mongol-speaking peoples, with which we have attempted to associate the origin of Yakut black shamanism. The Mongol white shamans dressed all in white, rode on white horses, and participated in running the country. But starting at the end of the thirteenth century, they began to be supplanted by the clergy of the “yellow religion.”e The black shamans, on the other hand, continued to exist alongside the yellow-robed lamas, M. N. Khangalov (p. 89) associates the appearance of white shamanism among the Buryats with the time their ancestors underwent a transition from hunting to mass livestock-breeding and the noyon class first appeared.' [1,068] 'Until the middle of the nineteenth century, the Yakuts continued to conduct two large yhyakhs during the year-in spring and in autumn. The first, directed by white shamans, was dedicated to the aiyy deities, which represented the eastern, “benevolent” direction of light, whence the sun rises. Originally, Tangara-the sky god, the father of the gods, typologically comparable to the Rigvedic D’iaus, and to the Latin concept of “god” (D’iaus-Deos-Theo)-was supposed to occupy the dominant position among the aiyy deities. Later, this image was embodied in the central figure of the Yakut pantheon, Iuriung Aiyy toion, the “White Creator God,” the god of light, the personified image of the Sun, with the functions of sovereign of the Universe. Then came the other aiyy deities. A particularly important place was occupied by Aal Uot ichchite, the spirit of sacred fire-both of the sacrificial flame and of the domestic hearth. Like the Arian Agni, Aal Uot ichchite was considered to be the protector of the family and the giver of good fortune and healthy offspring. If the goddess Ieiiekhsit was regarded as the messenger of Iuriung Aiyy toion, then the spirit of fire fulfilled the function of intermediary between earth and heaven, between humanity and the gods.' [1,069] 'The second, autumnal yhyakh was dedicated to the terrible, destructive forces of nature, the deities and demonic spirits of the cult of abahy-“the dwellers of the west.” It took place at night and was led by nine black male and female shamans. Blood sacrifices of livestock and horses took place in honor of the chief deities of Yakut demonology Uluu toion and Arsan Duolai. This entire complex with its multitude of shamanic rituals, in the center of which stood a shamanic seance, may be called the cult of abahy. At the same time, it should be explained that the word abahy refers to all manner of evil origins, everything malevolent, hostile, and contrary to the interests of humanity or customs. In the epics [olonkho], abnhy was a nonspecific word for evil beings and monsters, including members of alien tribes, speakers of foreign tongues, and persons with different moral values and customs or completely foreign religions (Ksenofontov, 1977, p. 236). The etymology of abahy is not completely clear. E. K. Pekarskii derived it from aba, ap, meaning “sorcery.” In the dictionary of M. Kashgarskii, which was compiled at the beginning of the twentieth century, this word is found in the form abachi, meaning “scarecrow” (Kashgarskii, p. 10). It can speculatively be connected with the term albasti, which refers to an evil demon associated with waterrelated disasters among Turkic peoples. According to the most widespread version, the image of albasty is associated with Iranian mythology.' [1,070] 'In this manner, the juxtaposition of two groups of mythological symbols-those of good and of evil, typologically common to many religions-became the foundation of the dualism in Yakut religious beliefs. An analogy is found in the Altaic dualistic myth, according to which Ul’gen proclaims that the people created by his brother Erlik are black and go to the west, while the white people created by him personally must go to the east.' [1,071] 'It is possible that at one time the Yakut white shaman, the a&y oiuuna, had a special name, which the word toion-used in historical times with the meaning “master, sovereign, ruler, prince, military leader, tsar, lord, owner”-migh t have turned into. Pekarskii derived it from the ancient Turkic toiyn- “a monk, a Buddhist priest” (Pekarskii, col. 2706). Indeed, in the Kashgarskii dictionary, this word is given with the meaning “an ecclesiastical order of a non-muslim religion.” Khan Dzhubeini, who lived in the thirteenth century, uses the term tuin in the meaning “Manichaean priest.” The editors of an ancient Turkic dictionary derive tojun = tojoin from the ancient Chinese daozhen, literally “a person on the path” (Drevnetiitrkskii sfovar’, 1977, p. 572).' [1,072] 'Evidently Prof. N. K. Antonov is correct in regarding this term as an ancient Turkic word, comparable to the Mongol toin-“a monk of noble [origin]” (Antonov, p. 110). As a hypothetical exercise, it can be supposed that the word toion, etymologically speaking, once represented a compound word, consisting of two words-foiuk and oiiun, where toiuk is “a shamanic hymn, song, or incantation” (Pekarskii, col. 2710), and tuoi is “to sing, to praise.” The ancient Turkic (Uighur) oiiun-“a game” and Uighur oina-“to play, to engage in a seance”-are like the Yakut onn’oo-“play” [imperative]. Thus, toi + oiiun is “one who sings = one who plays” in the sense of “entering into play with god.” Toion may have originally referred to a tribal priest or to a nobleman leader who had been charged with priestly functions. It should also be noted that the names of all of the Yakut gods contain the obligatory appendage “toion.” And it is not for nothing that L. G. Levental’, one of the leading researchers of the Yakut foionate, gave it the following definition: “A military aristocracy, cruel and proud, which traces its origins to the members of the Yakut Olympus, and to illustrious shamans and shamanesses” (Levental’ et al., p. 241).' [1,073] We have found no evidence that shamans acted as moralistic enforcers: 'A man-shaman is called oy[unknown]un and a woman-shaman, udahan . Both play an important rôle in Yakut beliefs. While oy[unknown]un is a Turkic word, udahan is adopted from the Mongolian language. Why? Why also is a woman-shaman regarded as more powerful than a man shaman? Why may oy[unknown]un enter into the formation of compound words (for instance, mas oy[unknown]un, a wooden shaman, is called the humming top) while udahan may not be so used? Why may oy[unknown]un and not udahan be part of words designating inanimate objects?' [1,074] 'We have previously seen that udahan is a Mongol word and that us (smith) is Turkic. The Yakut, when comparing the power of black shamans and smiths, regard the latter as more powerful. They make no comparisons with reference to the udahan’s power, but say that udahans are more powerful than men-shamans. The Yakut preserved the names of their former white shamans, but not those of white women-shamans. From this we might infer that white shamanism was not an aboriginal institution, and that black shamanism is a transformation of female shamans after their functions were transferred to men. No tales of white smiths (smiths working with copper and silver) are extant, but accounts of black smiths (iron smiths) relate that they are more powerful than black shamans. This leads us to the belief that the concept of black smiths and women-shamans appeared as ready-made institutions among the Yakut.' [1,075] 'Shamans ( saxa ababyta, Yakut priest, and säbäki in the Viliuisk District) are divided into two classes, white or creative shamans ( Aj[unknown]y a[unknown]yuna ) and black or malevolent beings’ shamans ( Abasy oyuna ). The white shaman serves as an intermediary between benevolent creative beings and mankind, whom he does not and cannot harm. He has no special shamanistic dress and does not even possess a drum. He bestows only blessings and asks the White-Lord-Creator to make beneficent gifts. He seldom addresses any other sky-dweller but the White-Lord-Creator: for instance, to cure barrenness he appeals to Mohan Sylgylax or some other deity. He does not kill cattle as a sacrifice; he only dedicates them to some sky dweller, after which the animal is not required to perform any work and is cared for and well fed.' [1,076] 'The black shaman serves as an intermediary between evil spirits and men. He cures sick people by extracting from them the evil spirits causing the illness.
