The power and ability of the black shaman varies. His spirit protectors may dwell in the upper, middle, or lower worlds. The most powerful shaman is one who has wolf and bear spirits as his protectors. The black shaman may also harm men against whom he is ill-disposed, casting diseases and miseries on them.' [1,077] Sesens or elders exercised social control, but they were not ritual specialists per se: 'According to tradition, the seseny played no minor role in assemblies in the past. The word sesen comes from the same root as the verb sesenibin - I advise, I think, I predict. Legend portrayes the seseny as white-haired, honored, experienced elders.' [1,078] 'This dignity was neither elective nor hereditary, but not every old man was considered to be a sesen. For this he had to have a special gift of prophecy - in other words: an acknowledged intellect, experience, and knowledge. In difficult moments the heroes of olongo frequently turn to such advice-giving, honored, light-eyed Old Men-Talkers. ' [1,079] 'In the past we did not decide anything without sesen. (Namsk Ulus, 1888). I will note that in this testimony sesen is used in the sense of sorcerer. The sesen decided disputed questions on the basis of custom, and gave advice when the clan was undergoing hard times. At ysyakh, before the games and contests began, the sesen of each clan or clan union would look over their own wrestlers; and they would remove those who were not good enough, who had recently sinned with a woman, who did not restrain themselves sufficiently in eating and drinking, so that they would not bring shame to their own people. They found all this out by feeling the body of the wrestlers, and by looking into their eyes and face. (Namsk Ulus, 1891). In the Bayagantaysk Ulus, when I asked who had named the rivers, hills, and other natural features, they answered: It must be the sesen - the old, ancient men, who knew everything! (Bayagantaysk Ulus, 1885).' [1,080] 'Since within the clan many sesen were at the same time toen, i.e., the representatives of separate groups, they wielded enormous influence 466 in clan councils. Usually in legends they are simply called old men - ogonior.' [1,081] 'They wielded less importance in councils of clan unions: there the first place was held by the heads of the clans, bis' usa toeno.' [1,082]

Type of punishment this typically entailed (can be more than one):

♠ physical punishment ♣ present ♥ Prisoners were kept in council buildings: 'In the Yakut settlements there are no special places set up for the maintenance of prisoners; consequently, they are kept until the final decision of their case in the houses where the trial is taking place. For thievery of any kind and similar big [Page 6] crimes, they are kept with wooden blocks on their legs, or with handcuffs on their arms, or, for petty misdemeanors, without anything special. if the trial takes place in town, the accused is kept in the town council building. The reasons for which the Yakut are arrested and imprisoned are as follows: 1) a discovered crime; 2) suspicion of any crime prior to the final investigation and decision of the case; 3) disobedience and insubordination to the clan-chiefs; 4) nonpayment of taxes and duties in the allotted time, and also just and proved debts to private individuals; 5) drunkenness, uproarious behavior, and playing with dice; and , finally, 6) according to the decision of the clan-chiefs or the authorities, as a punishment for any crime.' [1,083] Offenders were excluded from community affairs, had to pay a fine or were beaten: 'The following are considered wicked: those who have suffered corporal punishment for theft and other crimes by sentence of the authorities, their own communities, or the clans-chiefs; those who have been suspended from their office; those who have gone to settle far from their former place of residence; those who have been proclaimed slanderers or other dishonorable people; those who have been convicted of false and unjust denunciations or of lechery; those who have been judged intolerable by the community because of their bad behaviour and dissolute life. No such people are invited to community meetings, nor are they allowed to fill any office or have any voice in community affairs.' [1,084] '3. A person who commits a theft for the first time and confesses or is convicted by some other proofs which make his crime certain although he does not confess, pays four times what he has taken, in age, quality, and value; and, if a stolen head of cattle is found alive, then he pays three in addition to it, and, moreover, reimburses the plaintiff for his losses, for in prolonged investigations, what with the distance and dispersion of the Yakut dwellings, a considerable number of people are employed and given whole heads of cattle for subsistence, and some of them, who are killed in tracking down and finding thieves by various signs which are known to them, receive pay as well. In addition, thieves who have previously been found misbehaving suffer corporal punishment, whereas others are not subjected to beating their first theft.' [1,085] '1. Every Yakut who is not especially needed by the nasleg is free to leave for his own needs without the permission of the clan-chiefs for not more than one month. If anyone stays away for more than two months in this way, and his whereabouts are not made known during this time, he is considered a fugitive, and, when he is caught, he is imprisoned or beaten, depending on the length of time he has been away; on the other hand, if anyone stays away even longer, but sends word of his whereabouts and his reason for delaying, he is not subject to any penalty.' [1,086] '2. If anyone has committed a theft or any other crime of which he has been finally convicted runs away, then, when he is caught, he is given double the punishment appropriate to the crime itself; and if anyone runs away who is suspected of some crime, the crime becomes evident and he is charged with the crime which was imputed to him.' [1,087] '3. If a worker who has been hired by a proprietor runs away, taking all or part of his pay, he is beaten; in addition, he pays the proprietor for the latter's losses.' [1,088] '4. Fugitives and vagrants who do not belong to the class of the completely poor have their taxes and duties paid 233 for them by the communities; when they are caught, if they cannot pay, they give their labor to private persons for several years.' [1,089] '4. A person who is convicted a second and third time, in addition to the above payment, is beaten with rods according to the sentence of the chiefs: 228 the first time, lightly, the second time, harder,; and after that if he steals a third time and is considered beyond reform, he is expelled form the naslegs to settle in Okhotsk and Kamchatcka, by the sentence of the community and by decree of the local authorities. But those whom reform and usefulness to the community are expected are left in the nasleg, under the guarantee of their close relatives. However, if they are convicted again of stealing or of other misdeeds, they too are expelled in the manner described above.' [1,090] Imprisonment and physical punishment were also imposed for gambling and drunkenness: 'Card games for money and objects, and other games of chance are considered a vice worthy of punishment, whence they are strictly forbidden to all Yakut. If anyone is convicted on such a complaint, he is imprisoned, and, if violence and fighting occurred during the game, he is beaten with rods; losses are taken away from the winners and returned to their owners.' [1,091] 'Those who are always drunk are restrained from this by a reprimand and by imprisonment; anyone who causes violence or a fight when drunk is imprisoned or beaten with rods, depending on the degree of the damage caused by him; in addition, he is ordered to satisfy his victims with an additional indemnity.' [1,092] Some convicts were exiled during the Russian period: 'Yakut are considered disorderly and intolerable in the clans [Page 7] if: a) they are convicted three times of stealing, with a fine and punishment, and do not refrain from continuing to steal and are convicted for a fourth time; b) they use deceit and other dishonest tricks when they 209 incur unpaid debts and other unpleasantness and cause plaintiffs to come to the nasleg, and also if they are dissolute drunkards or if they do not pay their state taxes and community duties so that instead of helping the community they cause it losses and disorder; c) they are prankish, impudent, impertinent, do not show due subordination to the clan-chiefs, or make jesting and unjustly slanderous complaints against their fellow clansmen and strangers, and likewise if they themselves justly incur many complaints or avoid a proper penalty through trickery and thereby cause disorder for the community. With a clear and precise statement of their guilt contained in the sentence of the nasleg communities, all such people are presented to the authorities to be sent to Okhotsk and to be settled in Kamchatka. this law must be preserved in the future as well, in order to restrain the impudent.' [1,093]
♠ exile ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ loss/seizure of property or wealth ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ loss of status ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of toyons being deposed as the result of a crime committed by them. More material may be needed.

Extent of punishment (can be more than one):

♠ punishment of rulers ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Given the highly stratified nature of Sakha society at the time, toyons may not have been liable to punishment in the same way as 'commoners', at least in practice. More material is needed in order to confirm this.
♠ punishment of elites ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Given the highly stratified nature of Sakha society at the time, toyons may not have been liable to punishment in the same way as 'commoners', at least in practice. More material is needed in order to confirm this.
♠ punishment of commoners ♣ present ♥ See above.

Well-Being[edit]

Economic Well-Being[edit]

State Intervention in Economy

♠ The state regulates banking ♣ ♥ Note: Pastoralism has a long history in the region: 'In prehistoric times, beginning with the northern retreat of the glaciers, many southern peoples who had to adjust themselves to the severe conditions of life in the northern forests or the polar tundra, occupied Siberia. Some of the newcomers, like the Tungus, lost many of their former culture traits, and became reindeer breeders or hunters, while others, like the Yakut, were able in the far north to retain their cattle-breeding culture of the Central Asiatic steppes. But this northward [Page 61] migration was involuntary; the southerners were forced out from their former habitat by the competition of alien tribes. Naturally, in the course of their wandering, they left some traces which have been disclosed by the work of archaeologists. Skeletal finds also have shown that northern Siberia was primarily inhabited by a long-headed people of the Nordic type who had come from the west, and who were assimilated or else annihilated by Mongoloid newcomers from the south. Many of these questions still await solution through the work of archaeologists.' [1,094] 'We have some knowledge of prehistoric Yakut monuments through the recent work of Russian archaeologists, chiefly Petri, whose excavations in the region of Lake Baikal revealed many remains of a horse and cattle breeding tribe, in all probability, the prehistoric Yakut.' [1,095] 'The identifications by the chief zoologist of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Bialanitski-Birula, of animal bones found at the Murino sites and the caves of Orkhon show that these are chiefly the remains of domesticated animals-of oxen, rams, goats, and horses. Remains of wild animals, the products of hunting, are very scarce, proving that the people were cattle breeders. Besides, no traces of agriculture were found to the north of Lake Baikal, presenting negative evidence that the prehistoric inhabitants were herders. Further, Bialanitski-Birula pointed out that the ox of these people, like that of the Yakut, was a cross-breed of the yak. Among the iron arrows were found many with bifurcated heads, a characteristic of Yakut arrows. The iron knives and scissors found have the same distinguishing marks as Yakut knives, as will be shown in the discussion of their iron industry. The horseshoe found in the excavations is exactly like the Yakut horseshoe; it is narrow, with holes for nails and one calk in the middle. The Siberian natives, even in stony mountainous places, seldom shoe their horses. The iron bits of an ancient bridle consisted of two unequal parts, without appendages in the corners. This may be explained by the manner in which the rider held the reins on the left side of the horse as do the present Yakut. Modern Yakut bits consist of two equal parts, a form which may be regarded as having been adopted from the Russians, from whom the Yakut learned to harness horses to sledges and carts, for which long reins are necessary. Formerly, the Yakut used the horse only as a riding and pack animal. Appurtenances of horse harness show that the people bred horses. An iron sickle for hay making was found by Petri. It is quite different from the Russian form and resembles the present Yakut sickle. [Page 62] An iron hook for digging edible roots and plants and iron fish hooks were also found.' [1,096] 'It is indubitable that the training of the deer was at one time the occupation of the natives throughout the country. Even in those areas of the Yakut region where there are no deer at present, deer bones are found in the ground intermingled with human ones and with metallic items of deer harness. Many localities have preserved legends about the one-time existence of the domestic deer among the inhabitants. I can point, as an example, to the valley of the Borgonski settlement, which until the coming of the Yakuts was the scene of nomadic travels of the Tungus Miore with his numerous herds; also--to the valley of the Suntarski lake, which supposedly derived its name from the Tungus Suntar. The Tungus did not know any other cattle, except the deer...The deer are the Tungus cattle! unanimously assert the legends. They also assert, that the Yakuts imitated the Tungus in their use of the deer.' [1,097] 'The capacity to bear bad weather, cold, and hunger, to eat little and literally everything and anything that grows, to be satisfied with little in time of need, and afterwards to fatten up on the good feed and to live on the reserves of the fat and the meat stored up--this capacity is remarkably developed in the [Page 313] Yakut cattle. A great deal of energy is thus spent to survive. From the point of view of productivity this capacity for survival has no significance except, perhaps, a negative one. On the other hand this quality of survival makes the Yakut cattle invaluable in pioneering. Only because of it were the Yakuts able to penetrate with their cattle so far to the north. At present the Yakuts are the northernmost cattle breeders not only in Asia, but on the whole globe. Their northernmost cattle breeding sett lements known to me are on the Amoloi river at 70° N.L. and the northernmost one visited by me (in 1882) was on The Yana River at 69° where the Kungyas River enters it. On the Kolyma, the Alazei, and the Indigirka, the breeding of horned cattle does not, at present, reach such proportions, and stops about two degrees 152 south of the above mentioned point. In ancient times, cattle breeding reached the Arctic but was practised--of course--only in the river valleys. Fossils of horned cattle are found in Ustyansk, and legends about it are preserved in Nizhne-Kolymsk and on the Allaikha (the lower course of the Indigir-' [1,098] 'All those who have tried to connect the horses of the Yakut with those of southern or western Siberia in external appearance have most often pointed to the breed of horses of the Kirghiz. So far there have been no scientific investigations based on any numerous and exact measurements. The only data worthy of attention on this subject are those found in Cherskii. On the basis of a study of the skull of a contemporary Yakut horse, brought by Doctor Bunge from the Adycha River (Berkhoyansk Okrug), Cherskii was able to establish a distinct type of Yakut horse, differing from other Siberian horses and coming closest to the tarpans of southern Russia and the western Siberian subfossilis horse. I. Cherskii classifies the Yakut horse in the eastern group, with the breed of dwarfs (the length of the skull at the base is 472 millimeters) and with medium browed horses (the width of the forehead is 235.2 millimeters). The post-tertiary fossil horse whose remains are found in great number at the Yakutsk Oblast, bears a certain relation, in the shape of the skull and of the bones, to present Siberian breeds and, by the way, to the Yakut horse. This is the opinion of the same Doctor Cherskii. This relationship expresses itself in the moderate width of the forehead, the inclined position of the bones above the eyebrows, the narrow width of the offshoots of the bones in the forehead to the skull, the concavity of the profile, and the singular dental systemThe size of the fossil [Page 343] Yakut horses makes one class them with the tall breeds (around Lake Lyakhov) and the very tall breeks (Yana River).' [1,099] 'The finding of the fully preserved corpse of a white horse in the frozen soil of the lower Yana, as reported by Bunge , strengthens this interest, as it seems to indicate the possibility of coming to a definitive solution of this problem. The answer to both these questions is directly bound with the time of the northern migration of the Yakut and with the location of their original homeland. Here I will only note that white is still the predominant color among Yakut horses, and that [Page 344] the interbreeding of domestic with wild animals is considered by them to be advantageous for the improvement of the breed. Such interbreeding in the case of domesticated deer, as I mentioned above, is practiced even now by the Yakut and Tungus of the far north.' [1,100] 'We must analyze some discrepancies in the account of the finds representing supposedly old Yakut culture. The excavations were made in old earth huts and caves. Thus this horse and cattle-breeding tribe must have been nomadic, yet, at the same time, must have had permanent dwellings. This may be explained by their double occupation. Iron [Page 63] mining, smelting, forging, and smithing required a sedentary life. While some families of a clan, or even some members of a family, were engaged in the iron industry, their relatives nomadized with their herds. Caves may have served as temporary shelters during the winter when the wet walls became frozen and a fire was used as protection from the cold.' [1,101] The Sakha were initially nomadic pastoralists: 'Traditional pastoralism in central Yakutia required homestead self-reliance, with intense dependence on calves and foals in a harsh climate. Stables, corrals, and haying developed in conjunction with hardy breeds of cattle and short, fat, furry horses. Richer families owned hundreds of horses and cattle; poorer ones raised a few cattle or herded for others. A huge variety of dairy products, including fermented mare's milk, (Russian: KUMYS), was the staple food, with meat for special occasions. The diet was augmented by hunting (bears, elk, squirrels, hare, ferrets, fowl), fishing (salmon, carp, MUSKSUN, MUNDU), and, under Russian influence, agriculture (cereals). Wealthy Yakut hunted on horseback using dogs. The poorest Yakut, those without cattle, relied on fishing with horsehair nets and, in the north, herded reindeer like their Evenk and Yukagir neighbors.' [1,102] Most implements were made in the home: 'Before iron was imported, ironworkers used ore from local marshes. Similarly, ceramics from local clay preceded Russian pottery. Most homemade crafts were for household use: decorated birch-bark containers, leather bags, dairy-processing equipment, horsehair blankets, fur clothing, benches, hitching posts, and elaborately carved wooden containers (including CHORONS for KUMYS).' [1,103] 'Although occupations within a household were divided by gender and status, the atmosphere was usually one of productive group activity. All participated in hay making, cattle herding, and milking, but, in general, horses were more a male preserve and cattle a female responsibility. Women tended children and fires, prepared food, carried water, and made clothing and pottery. Men handled more strenuous firewood preparation, house building, sled making, hunting, fishing, and mowing. Ivory carving and wood- and metalworking were male tasks.' [1,104] Sieroszewski reports some trades, such as carpentry and blacksmithing, for the south: 'In the north, where most of the household utensils are mad at home, all are prepared with the aid of only these clumsy implements. In the south, where trades are kept separate to a greater degree, a carpenter owns, besides these, a wide and a narrow saw, planes, a brace and bit, chisels, and sometimes even a rasp. But everywhere the axe is most important. The Yakut handle the axe in a masterly fashion and are excellent carpenters. The majority of the churches in the Yakutsk Okrug and almost all the house s in the town of Yakutsk have been built by Yakut carpenters. In their carpentry work they use the same methods, the same compass for cutting, the same pitch rope, plumb, triangle, and ruler as do the Russians. The head of the carpenters artel, the elder carpenter, is called the regulator, after the Russian fashion. But their chief instruments, the axes and knives, have retained their ancient shape.They weigh from two to no more than four pounds, and cost from fifty kopecks to one ruble. The Yakut cut with them smoothly, cleanly, and quickly; they are ready to fashion even small pieces with an axe.' [1,105] 'As with other Siberian peoples, Yakut shamans (OIUN if male, UDAGAN if female) combine medical and spiritual practice. [...] In the nineteenth century a few Yakut leaders financed the building of Russian Orthodox churches, and many Yakut declared themselves Christian, but this did not mean that they saw Christianity and shamanism as mutually exclusive. The Yakut also believed in the spiritual power of blacksmiths.' [1,106] But most Sakha continued to rely on household-level subsistence production after the introduction of cereal agriculture: 'In pre-Revolutionary Yakutiya the poor and middle peasant families totaled more than 80 percent of all households. One-seventh of all the households were entirely without sowings, and many were only able to sow a few hundredths of a hectare each. Most of the households (97 percent) had to do without factory-made agricultural implements. Stockbreeding produced extremely poor results. The owners of large areas of land and abundant livestock i.e.,-the kulaks and toyons, grew rich, but not so much by raising the level of land cultivation and animal husbandry as by exploiting the poor and middle peasants.' [1,107] Temporary wage labour was slightly more common in areas close to Russian settlements: 'The Yakut are unwilling to hire themselves out on a daily basis, although the daily rate of pay is always higher than the monthly or yearly rates. Among themselves they hardly ever do this. This has begun to come into custom only in the vicinity of cities, and only very lately. The Skoptsy were particularly responsible for spreading this custom. The Skopsty usually pay their workers in flours, baked bread, potatoes, brick tea, and sugar; only rarely in money and in cotton goods.' [1,108] Some of the below variables may not be applicable to the Sakha.****Russian settlers, such as members of the skoptzy religious sect, held deposits in Siberian banks: 'The enterprising spirit of the skoptzy was not limited by their agricultural pursuits, for they successfully occupied themselves with commerce and trades. They built mills, tanneries, smithies, harness shops, and kept provision shops. Some of their leaders were prosperous and were able to assist the community in building new houses and roads. The skoptzy had no children to provide for and were able to accumulate money and many had large deposits in Siberian banks.' [1,109] We have assumed this not be true for the Sakha. Sakha families transmitted wealth in the form of family heirlooms, such as ceremonial dress: 'Such festive sangyyakh sometimes cost up to two hundred, or even to one thousand rubles, are handed down from generation to generation, and are worn exclusively on ceremonial occasions. For everyday use the son is more widely used than the sangyyakh everywhere. I only came across sangyyakh used for everyday wear once or twice, in very remote regions. These were good-looking, light caftans, reaching a little below the knees and sewn out of striped calfskin. They were cut to the shape of the body, were worn without any undergarments, and outlined the figure perfectly; the absence of a collar and the small opening in front which bared the neck made them looklike the coquettish costumes of the south. There are indications that the sangyyakh, which is also called sanynyakh was much mo ed to be buried in sangyyakh, and a couple would be dressed in sangyyakh for their wedding; this practice is still followed in the north. A sangyyakh is given as the wedding present of the mother-in-law. Finally, in the north shamans perform their mysteries dressed in a woman's sangyyakh, in the absence of their regular costume (Kolymsk Ulus, 1883). But in the south the sangynyakh is becoming rarer and rarer; there the son has become the national costume of the Yakut. It has followed them into their new colonies everywhere. Its use, together with the Yakut language, has spread to the local Russians and to the Yakutized Tungus and Yukaghir. It is worn, with only small changes, by Yakut of both sexes, and of the most widely varied circumstances and ages. Even if the assumption that it was brought here by the Cossaks no earlier than in the seventeenth century is true, such a firmly established and universal use of this garment shows that there were corresponding beginnings in the national taste and that in practice its forms turned out to be utilitarian as well. And thus: the puffs on the shoulders offer splendid protection from cold and keep the shoulder muscles protected from dampness;it is, after all, these muscles which when riding are most susceptible to the effects of bad weather. Again, the wing-like inserts protect the thighs, stomach, and seat of the rider, and do not allow the flaps of the coat to come apart very much.' [1,110] We are unsure whether these banks were state-controlled. More material is needed.
♠ Price controls ♣ ♥ We have found no material on this.
♠ Regulations against hoarding/stockpiling goods ♣ ♥ We have found no material on this.
♠ Regulations regarding usury ♣ ♥ We have found no material on this.
♠ Debt-relief measures ♣ ♥ We have found no material on this.
♠ Pensions ♣ absent ♥ See below.
♠ Standardization of weights/measures ♣ absent ♥ Length was measured by time: '“They reckon distance by time; and 30 or 40 versts, according to the goodness of the roads, make a day’s journey.”' [1,111] 'Additional evidence of the antiquity of the industry among the Yakut appears in the Turkic names for pottery-making implements and vessels. A clay pot is called küös; a metal kettle is called salyr . Even in places where, as in the northern districts of Yakut Province, no pottery is made at present, the word küös is well known and used as a linear measure. In terms of linear measure one may say, “one pot,” “two pots,” “pot of a walker, horse, or ox rider.” For küös (pot) the Yakut understand a distance of from seven to twelve versts (from 6.6 to 8 miles). Translating küös in terms of time, it means a period during which a pot with meat for an average family is cooked. In Afghanistan küös is used as a linear measure of about eighteen miles. Böhtlingk distinguishes the word küös as a unit of time from kös as a linear measure as does Pekarsky in his Yakut-Russian dictionary, where he interprets kös as a term for a day’s journey from one camping place to another.' [1,112] Area was measured by the amount of produce associated with a given plot of land: 'The unit of measurement of land among the Yakuts was the “rick” ([unknown]γ[unknown]γ[unknown]), a plot of land from which one hayrick could be mown (the size of the rick ranged from 10 to 30 cartloads, sometimes as many as 40 or 60). These allotments made up plots [...] which were extremely varied in size, depending on the “class,” and there were three or four “classes.” One first-class plot [...] was equal to two secondclass plots [...] and three or four third-class plots (kenniki or [...]). The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called [...] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [1,113] Haystacks were measures in multiple ways: 'When the haystacks are sold or evaluated their size is determined in different ways, depending on the locality: by ricks, loads, and bulas. A load of one true sagene of hay is considered equal to a cubic sagene of unpressed hay; it weighs approximately twenty poods and, converting this figure to ricks, counts as twenty ricks. The bulas is a different measure and is used primarily in the north. A pulas or bulas is strictly speaking the distance between the ends of the fingers of one's outstretched hands. A haystack that is the height of a man is measured by these spans, and it takes its name according to the size of the circumference: six, seven, or nine bulas. The height is assumed to be a minimum of one and one-quarter sagenes not counting the top. The method of counting by bulas is rather confused. In the south it is customary to assume that a haystack of ten bulas is equal to twenty loads, i.e. four hundred Yakut ricks of one pood each. This reckoning and the names of the measures shows once again, I think, the influence of the Russians in the teaching of methods of haying to the Yakut.' [1,114] However, it appears that none of these measures were imposed and regulated by the Russian authorities.
♠ Guarantee stability of coin value ♣ ♥ The Sakha actively participated in barter trade with Russians: 'Yakut also engaged in the fur trade; by the twentieth century hunters for luxury furs had depleted the ermines, sables, and foxes, and they were relying on squirrels. Yakut merchants and transporters spread throughout the entire northeast, easing communications and trade for natives and Russians. They sold luxuries like silver and gold jewelry and carved bone, ivory, and wood crafts in addition to staples such as butter, meat, and hay. Barter, Russian money, and furs formed the media of exchange. Guns were imported, as was iron for local blacksmiths.' [1,115] Fox and ermine skins doubled as units of exchange: 'The Yakuts hunt foxes only in autumn and winter by setting up traps and self-released bows. Sometimes foxes get caught in the nooses set up to hares, but rarely perish in the noose trap, since the beam is not sufficiently quick to lift their weight. The fox eats everything: fish, meat, berries, roots, even the carrions of other foxes that got caught in the trap. The fox is far from being a rare animal in the north of the region: I saw one on several occasions near people's houses and once witnessed a fox running across the yard of the yurta. A fox, especially the darker varieties which are larger, can be easily mistaken for a Yakut dog. The skin of the red fox serves in the north as a unit of exchange. It is priced between 2 and 5 rubles; sivodushka-between 6 & 15 rubles; and the black-brown variety between 25 and 50 rubles. I was shown very beautiful, perfectly black skins with a slight grizzle, for which 120 rubles was paid on the spot.' [1,116] 'ERMINE (mustela erminea), kyrnas, belelyakh, is the animal most hunted for the purposes of trade. It is found in all parts of the country, on the tableland and in the tundra. Increase and decrease in the numbers of this animal depend probably on the amount of available food. In winter it comes near human dwellings, gets into the granaries, and eats and carriesaway meat and fish. It is caught by special traps called hlopushi (chirkan - a mouse trap). The ermine is a predatory, bold, and curious animal. When irritated it will attack even human beings. Cases are known of the ermine inflicting serious wounds on people, for it attempts to cut through the blood vessels on the neck, where it ascends with exceptional speed and agility. The ermine skin is priced between 2 and 5 cents and is used as the smallest exchange unit.' [1,117] The same was true for butter: 'Butter naturally acquired particular value with the coming of the Russians. Butter began to go into circulation only when the Russians came and built a city, and particularly when they began to buy it for the mines, maintained the Namsk Yakut (1891). The Yakut monetary unitary, which means one bezem of heated butter of two and one-half funts testifies to the trading significance of butter. In remote corners the Yakut often convert the price of goods from a monetary basis to a butter basis, and express hiring prices and selling prices of objects offered in terms of butter. The majority of women are only familiar with this system, and get confused in trying to count with money. Butter comprises one of the most important food products of the Yakut. The poorest Yakut tries to have it on his table on feast days, and even the stingiest master must feed his workers butter at least once a week. The Yakut consume butter in various ways: they eat it in hard pieces, they drink it crumbled with kumiss, they drink it in tea, and they drink warm heated butter in its pure form. In their climate this beverage is far from distasteful, and when coming back chilled from hunting, or frozen through during a long winter journey I would willingly drink a full dish of it myself. It warms one quickly, and restore's one's strength and vigor, just like grape wine. A Yakut is able to drink not more than one-half a funt at a gulp, but can drink up to two and one-half funts over a ceratin period of time, stopping to rest. Sturdy fellows who are able to drink five to ten funts at one time are known in every section , but I do not think that there are more than two or three in the oblast capable of drink one-half a pood; I do not know a their ability to drink a large quantity of melted butter just as Russians boast of their ability to drink large quantities of vodka.' [1,118] Russian money also became an important medium of exchange: 'Yakut also engaged in the fur trade; by the twentieth century hunters for luxury furs had depleted the ermines, sables, and foxes, and they were relying on squirrels. Yakut merchants and transporters spread throughout the entire northeast, easing communications and trade for natives and Russians. They sold luxuries like silver and gold jewelry and carved bone, ivory, and wood crafts in addition to staples such as butter, meat, and hay. Barter, Russian money, and furs formed the media of exchange. Guns were imported, as was iron for local blacksmiths.' [1,119] Furs and meat were sold for money: 'Deer meat is most delicious in September and October, and during this period the deer's fur is regarded as at its best. The northern deer's fur is considered warmer than that of the domesticated deer. On the spot the skin of the wild deer brings between 1 ruble and 2 rubles and 50 cents. The Yakuts hunt the deer with guns, or by setting up self-releasing bows. Pit-traps are not used by the Yakuts in hunting this or any other animal.' [1,120] Russian money was also at least occasionally used in dealings among the Yakut themselves: 'I at least never heard anything about a wealthy shaman; on the contrary, the shaman often gets no more than 5 kopeks for healing a sick eye. And how little is this sum worth north of Yakutsk! Some Yakuts refused to accept a twenty kopeks coin for a hazel-hen I wanted to buy, saying that they could not manage to use the money; if it had an eye, they would have used it as a button; but as there was no such, I was to take it back. The smallest unit for them is the ruble.' [1,121] We are unsure whether there was 'guaranteed stability of coin value'.
♠ Public markets ♣ absent ♥ The Sakha actively participated in trade relations with Russians: 'Yakut also engaged in the fur trade; by the twentieth century hunters for luxury furs had depleted the ermines, sables, and foxes, and they were relying on squirrels. Yakut merchants and transporters spread throughout the entire northeast, easing communications and trade for natives and Russians. They sold luxuries like silver and gold jewelry and carved bone, ivory, and wood crafts in addition to staples such as butter, meat, and hay. Barter, Russian money, and furs formed the media of exchange. Guns were imported, as was iron for local blacksmiths.' [1,122] Outside of Russian settlements, the Sakha relied on travelling merchants rather than markets: 'The system of tsarist administration was no different here from what existed in any other part of Northern Siberia. The Dolgans, Yakuts and Evenks had to pay the fur-tax as “natives” and formed “clans” headed by princelings, while the tundra peasants were forced to pay a poll tax, were formed into a “community” and headed by an elder. People living many hundreds of kilometers away from the nearest centers were economically dependent on the merchants who monopolized supplies to the region, bought up all the furs, and cruelly exploited the population.' [1,123] Accordingly, we have assumed that the Sakha did not usually have access to markets.

Contracts

♠ State enforcement ♣ ♥ We have found no evidence of written contracts. There were lease arrangements of sorts between wealthy and poor households, but we are unsure how formal they were.
♠ Non-state enforcement ♣ ♥
♠ Corporate Agency ♣ ♥
♠ State contracting ♣ ♥
♠ Limited Liability ♣ ♥

Patronage

♠ within-class formal patronage ♣ ♥ We have found no evidence of patronage relations. Labour hire and lease arrangements between wealthy and poor households might qualify, but this is debatable.
♠ between-class formal patronage ♣ ♥
♠ within-class informal patronage ♣ ♥
♠ between-class informal patronage ♣ ♥

Public Goods[edit]

♠ Famine relief ♣ absent ♥ See below.

♠ provision of famine relief ♣ ♥

♠ Food storage ♣ absent ♥ Family yurts where surrounded by storehouses: 'As horse and cattle breeders, the Yakut had a transhumant pattern of summer and winter settlements. Winter settlements comprised as few as twenty people, involving several closely related families who shared pasture land and lived in nearby yurts (BALAGAN) with surrounding storehouses and corrals. The yurts were oblong huts with slanted earth walls, low ceilings, sod roofs and dirt floors. Most had an adjoining room for cattle. They had substantial hearths, and fur-covered benches lining the walls demarcated sleeping arrangements according to social protocol. Yurts faced east, toward benevolent deities. In summer families moved to larger encampments with their animals. The most ancient summer homes, URASY, were elegant birch-bark conical tents. Some could hold one hundred people. Their ceilings soared at the center point, above a circular hearth. Around the sides were wide benches placed in compartments that served as ranked seating and sleeping areas. Every pole or eave was carved with symbolic designs of animals, fertility, and lineage identities.' [1,124] Russian and Sakha farmers constructed grain warehouses, but the Sakha were generally unfamiliar with effective methods of grain preservation: 'The seeds always cost more than three rubles. Even in harvest years, when in winter one can buy four for one ruble eighty kopecks a pood, a pood of seeds costs two rubles. This i s due to the fact that in the first place, they use selected grain for seeds, so that not every homeowner is willing to sow with his own seeds, and secondly, because most Yakut sow less grain than they use. Rich Yakut naturally take advantage of this, and encouraged by the spring season of bad roads and the constant pecuniary embarrassment of the Yakut they loan seeds and make profits of one hundred percent on them. I must remark that in general the Yakut still have not learned how to store grain. Their grain warehouses and , even the public warehouses, are in almost all cases so poorly constructed that grain which has lain there for two or three years is no longer good f or seeds. Sometimes it becomes so moldy that it is hard to eat flour prepared from it. This inability to keep grain in storage supports the custom of handing out public seeds as a loan, pood for pood, to well-to-do clan heads, even in harvest years. Because of this many warehouses are found to be empty in poor crop years, and this factor is just about the strongest hindrance to the success of agriculture. At such times there are exceedingly few seeds in the okrug. A poor crop of grain usually concides with a small harvest of grass, and therefore a lack of milk. The grain is consumed. It is remarkable that the raising of grain has been strengthened even in the more northern regions, but only where there are large permanent stores of seeds, either in the form of Russian agricultural settlements or Yakut homesteads operating on a large scale. There are very few Yakut carrying on the raising of grain on a large scale for commercial purposes. Even such rich Yakut as, for example, Syrom yatnikov, of the Bayagantaysk Ulus sowed only for themselves, something like one desiatin per household; there were four household in all. [...] In the Olekminsk Okrug I saw splendid farmsteads, well cultivated, with large areas sowed with the same kind of grain, with judicious household arrangeme nts, warehouses, threshing barns, and flour mills. I was told that these farmsteads belong to rich Yakut.' [1,125] Sieroszewski's material suggests that Sakha food storage was household-level only in most cases. Accordingly, we have assumed that most Sakha had little to no access to 'public goods' type storehouses.

♠ provision of food storage ♣ ♥

♠ Alimentary supplementation ♣ absent ♥ See above.

♠ provision of alimentary supplementation ♣ ♥

♠ Drinking water ♣ absent ♥ Settlements were built in close proximity to freshwater streams and lakes: 'It is watered [Page 327] from an ice-hole at the nearest river or lake. In spring it is often necessary to cut deep pathways in the ice, towards the old, exhausted ice-holes in order to secure the cattle access to the water. The cattle frequently kneel as they drink, while calves and horses drink out of buckets filled with water. The water in such old ice holes is nauseatingk putrid, and smells of hydrogen sulfide and of swamp. In order to diminish the freezing of the ice-holes during the night, the Yakut frequently cover them with straw covers and with snow. In this connection I may note that the ice on the lakes with ice-holes freezes apparently in a thicker layer than on the lakes on which no ice-holes are cut. In spring, [Page 328] when the nearest watering places are exhausted or have been frozen up, it becomes necessary on occasions to drive the cattle to a watering place about two viersts away, which is very inconvenient. That is why the selection of a place of settlement is strongly influenced by the nearness of the winter watering place. In hard frost, the watered cattle, shaking from cold, is driven into [Page 329] the warm cattle sheds where some feed is prepared for them in the mangers. In spring they have a little hay of a worse sort right in the enclosures. The calves, which all through the winter are kept in human dwellings, are fed and watered there, with the water on many occasions warmed up before the calves receive it. The cows that have just given birth to calves are also fed in the cattle sheds. Such cows are not taken 158 to water for 3-4 days and are instead given warm water to drink.' [1,126] Tokarev's material suggests that irrigation and drinking water supply systems did not become common prior to the Soviet period: 'Many farms use water wheels and pumps to water their gardens. In 1952, more than 300,000 hectares of land, chiefly green meadows and pastureland, were irrigated by means of both permanent and temporary installations. The first specialized meadow-reclamation station had been set up in the Gorniy Rayon.' [1,127]

♠ provision of drinking water ♣ ♥

♠ Irrigation works ♣ absent ♥ Settlements were built in close proximity to freshwater streams and lakes: 'It is watered [Page 327] from an ice-hole at the nearest river or lake. In spring it is often necessary to cut deep pathways in the ice, towards the old, exhausted ice-holes in order to secure the cattle access to the water. The cattle frequently kneel as they drink, while calves and horses drink out of buckets filled with water. The water in such old ice holes is nauseatingk putrid, and smells of hydrogen sulfide and of swamp. In order to diminish the freezing of the ice-holes during the night, the Yakut frequently cover them with straw covers and with snow. In this connection I may note that the ice on the lakes with ice-holes freezes apparently in a thicker layer than on the lakes on which no ice-holes are cut. In spring, [Page 328] when the nearest watering places are exhausted or have been frozen up, it becomes necessary on occasions to drive the cattle to a watering place about two viersts away, which is very inconvenient. That is why the selection of a place of settlement is strongly influenced by the nearness of the winter watering place. In hard frost, the watered cattle, shaking from cold, is driven into [Page 329] the warm cattle sheds where some feed is prepared for them in the mangers. In spring they have a little hay of a worse sort right in the enclosures. The calves, which all through the winter are kept in human dwellings, are fed and watered there, with the water on many occasions warmed up before the calves receive it. The cows that have just given birth to calves are also fed in the cattle sheds. Such cows are not taken 158 to water for 3-4 days and are instead given warm water to drink.' [1,128] Tokarev's material suggests that irrigation systems did not become common prior to the Soviet period: 'Many farms use water wheels and pumps to water their gardens. In 1952, more than 300,000 hectares of land, chiefly green meadows and pastureland, were irrigated by means of both permanent and temporary installations. The first specialized meadow-reclamation station had been set up in the Gorniy Rayon.' [1,129]

♠ provision of irrigation works ♣ ♥

♠ Health infrastructure ♣ absent ♥ Shamans cured sickness and cast out malevolent spirits: 'As with other Siberian peoples, Yakut shamans (OIUN if male, UDAGAN if female) combine medical and spiritual practice.' [1,130] 'Vitashevsky gives a vivid description of a performance at which he was present. 1 He came too late to see its initiation, called oloxxo oloror (on the seat he is seated) and, he understood, at this point the shaman’s voice and the drum beats should be weak and almost listless. When he entered the earth hut the shaman was sitting on a small bank in its eastern corner, so that he had to pass between him and the fireplace. The shaman wore his shamanistic coat and his assistant dried the hut master’s drum by the fire. The shaman asked for a tobacco pipe. He inhaled the smoke several times and asked for the drum and stick which were given to him. He rose, walked a few steps, and jerking his shoulders and head up and down, he tried to beat the drum, but rejected it because it was wet. He asked that his own drum be dried. This was done very quickly. Evidently his drum was already dry. Now began the second or preliminary stage, called mäñniyär and sürgüyar 2 when the shaman searched for the direction in which to locate [Page 121] the evil spirit that captured the sick man’s soul. And, indeed, at times he stopped beating and gazed into the distance. In the beginning of the act the shaman beat the drum slightly and sang in a low voice, but gradually his voice and the drum beatings rose to a climax and the shaman turned his face to the southern window of the hut. The act lasted from fifteen to twenty minutes. During the performance the shaman imitated the neighing of a horse and the cry of some bird.//'The third act consisted in inhaling from the sick man the evil spirits causing the illness, and in dispatching them to the south. The shaman had to dispatch four evil spirits. First the shaman sat on the floor behind the fireplace, not far from the entrance, holding in his left hand a jalbyr (see above) which he stretched out in the direction of the patient. Gradually, still in a sitting position, he moved toward the sick man, singing louder and shaking his head more and more. At a distance of about a meter from the sick man he rose from the floor and sat on a bank prepared for him. He continued to cry out his incantations, touching the sick man with his jalbyr . This movement is called jalbiyal . Slowly the shaman rose from the bank and, dropping the jalbyr, bent over the sick man. In a powerful voice he commanded his spirits to fulfil his order and to pass from the patient. He pretended to swallow them in order to dispatch them to their dwelling places. To this end, he ran out to the yard and after dispatching the spirits to the “south” he fainted. He was taken up and carried into the hut, quite exhausted. Then the shaman started for the “upper” world and brought back one of the souls, the kut, of the sick man which had deserted him, having been frightened off by the evil spirits. The shaman looked around to see whether any evil spirit was left near the patient. Once more he pretended to start for the “upper” world and he fainted when he returned to this world. He was revived by his assistant and the shaman sang his last incantation. This was the final act of the performance. Vitashevsky was unable to record the text of the performance for the following reasons: it was almost dark in the hut; in spite of his perfect knowledge of the Yakut language many expressions in the performance were incomprehensible to him; the use of a phonograph to record the text would be prohibited by the shaman or otherwise influence the performance. When Vitashevsky invited the shaman to his hut for an interview the latter declined the invitation, saying that a shamanistic performance was too serious a subject for futile curiosity. The shaman, learning of Vitashevsky’s presence during his performance, said that it would fail to benefit the sick man. Sieroszevski refers in his [Page 122] book on the Yakut 1 to a shamanistic incantation, but other students of the Yakut criticized the authenticity of his text. I was more successful with Yukaghir and Tungus shamans. For a remuneration they recited their incantations in my phonograph and also dictated to me in order that I might be able to compare the two versions. In my work on the Yukaghir 2 I gave the Yukaghir text of a shamanistic performance on the Yassachnaya River. But the shaman himself, whose mother was a Yakut woman, originally recited the text in Yakut, which appeared in the Russian edition of my Yukaghir texts published by the Russian Academy of Sciences in 1900 (p. 118).' [1,131]//Sauer also provides a description of a shamanistic healing performance: '“When a sick Socha sends for a shaman to appease the wrath of the evil spirits that torment him, the sorcerer takes a switch, ties a few hairs from the mane of a horse to the end of it, walks and jumps about the sick person, waves his switch, and conjures the demons to appear and relate the cause of their tormenting him, and how they are to be appeased. After some time has passed in this invocation, he starts, pretends to see the spirits, and, listening to their admonition for some time, turns to the patient, and tells him whence the spirits came; that it was with a view of destroying him, but that they might be induced to accept as a sacrifice, instead of him, a fat mare or a cow, mentioning the particular colour. This is immediately procured; for whoever has one answering the description readily gives it. The offering being procured, the shaman dresses himself in full form, walks with his switch to the possessed, embrances him, and commands the demons to leave him; then, rising in great agitation, he suddenly springs upon the offering, raving and shouting as much as he possibly can: the beast now starting, and being restless, is a proof of the pain that it endures from the demon. The following morning the sacrifice is led to the place appointed, which is always on a rising ground at the entrance into a wood. Four poles are driven into the ground, on which they erect a stage covered with twigs, wheron the offering is slain and skinned. The flesh is dressed and eaten on the spot; the bones collected, wrapped up in the twigs that were on the scaffold, put inside the skin of the animal, and stuck at the top of some tree on the spot: if the sacrifice was to the aërial spirits, the head is directed upwards; if to the spirits of the pit, the head is looking downwards. The sorcerer then, arrayed in his magic robes, takes his tambour, and begins his formal spells; beating his tambour, raving, jumping, and using an unintelligible jargon in the most extravagant manner; his long hair hanging over his face, he conjures the spirit of the sacrifice to its demons, and the demons to their proper place of retirement; seems, several times during his incantations, to faint, during which paroxysms he receives the inspired power of prognosticating the fate of the diseased, and the day either of his restoration to health, or of his death. If 121 he prove mistaken, it is not regarded as arising from want of skill, but the unacceptableness of the sacrifice, which is occasionally renewed till he dies or recovers. If a shaman acquaints any family that some demon is intent on inflicting a punishment, offerings are made to avert the evil; not of live beasts, but the rich skins of animals, which are hung up in a conspicuous part of the hut, and buried with the owner when he dies.”' [1,132] Hospitals and clinics became common in the Soviet period and after: 'With the decline of shamanism, most Yakut rely on Western medicine administered in hospitals and clinics. Yet rumors persist of faith healing, described as spiritual or hypnotic. A few Yakut with shamanic family backgrounds attend medical school, supporting beliefs that healing talent can be inherited. Traditional healers (who had long periods of apprenticeship) were specialized, with herbal experts, bonesetters, shaman's assistants, and various grades of shamanic power. Sources vary as to whether male or female shamans were more powerful. Drumming and the music of the of the KHOMUS enhanced a shaman's trance during séances to ascertain the cause of illness. Each person was believed to have three souls, which were necessary to maintain health.' [1,133] We have assumed that most Sakha had no access to Western medicine in the early Russian period.

♠ Control of infectious disease ♣ absent ♥
♠ Care of war invalids/veterans ♣ absent ♥
♠ Care of orphans ♣ absent ♥ We have assumed that orphans and the elderly were cared for by extended kin.
♠ Care of elderly ♣ absent ♥ We have assumed that orphans and the elderly were cared for by extended kin.

♠ State pensions for elites ♣ absent ♥ The early invaders imposed tribute in furs on the Sakha population after successful military expeditions: 'By 1620 a report had reached Tobolsk from the Mangaseya Cossacks of the Great (Lena) River and the Lena Yakut. In 1631 they descended by the Viliui River, a tributary of the Lena, to the Lena River and imposed tribute on the adjacent Yakut. In 1632 a party of Cossacks under the command of the Boyar’s son, Shakov, took tribute in sables from a clan of Viliui horse-breeding Yakut. The Viliui River farther up from its mouth was occupied by Tungus only. The northern boundary of the distribution of the Yakut at that time was the mouth of the Viliui. The whole Lena Valley from the mouth of the Viliui River to the south, at a distance of about 500 kilometers (or 710 miles) was occupied by Yakut. In their possession were also all the Lena islands of that region, rich in pasture lands. There is no definite information as to how far inland they penetrated at that period. We may admit, however, that the Yakut, being horse and cattle breeders, were hardly inclined to move into the dense forests far from the majority of their tribesmen, i.e., far from the Lena Valley. In the beginning of the seventeenth century the Yakut abode on the western banks of the Lena must have been the territory of the two present uluses of Yakutsk District, Namskij and Western Kangalassky. There, according to Yakut traditions, was the first place of refuge of their mythical forefather, the “Tatar” Elliei. From there a part of his nearest descendants could also have emigrated over the Lena islands to the eastern banks of the Lena River, where excellent pastures are as abundant as on the western banks.' [1,134] 'We have previously noted (see p. 64) that the Yakut were subjugated by two different Cossack parties from Mangasey aand Yeniseisk. The Olekminsk fortress on the Lena River was erected in 1630 when only Tungus lived in the region. In 1637 a Cossack party, under the command of Busa, collected tribute in furs from the Yakut of the Yana River.' [1,135] The czarist administration imposed taxes and established an administrative infrastructure: 'The system of tsarist administration was no different here from what existed in any other part of Northern Siberia. The Dolgans, Yakuts and Evenks had to pay the fur-tax as “natives” and formed “clans” headed by princelings, while the tundra peasants were forced to pay a poll tax, were formed into a “community” and headed by an elder. People living many hundreds of kilometers away from the nearest centers were economically dependent on the merchants who monopolized supplies to the region, bought up all the furs, and cruelly exploited the population.' [1,136] 'The committee of Cherkashennikov which worked in the Yakutsk Oblast was only a branch of this All-Siberian commission. On December 14, 1766, an ukaz was issued which called for deputies from all of Russia to form a committee for establishing a better administration, discussing various problems of internal policy, and, incidentally, to establish a new code for the natives of Siberia. The Yakut, who were listed as nomads, were excluded from the list of electors, but they sent their deputy anyway and he was allowed to join the committee by a special order of the Empress.' [1,137] 'The overall development of commodity relationships helped to speed up the development of agriculture and here and there ploughing was enforced by the administration.' [1,138] 'No less significant changes occurred in the administrative organization of the Yakut country. In the seventeenth century Yakutsk was the center of a great independent country directly subordinate to Moscow, although for some specific questions it was dependent on the governors of Tobolsk. In the time of Peter the Great, Yakutsk entered into the newly organized Siberian Goubernyia (government) and with the division of the Siberian government into provinces was included in Irkutsk Province. In 1775 Irkutsk Province was organized into a government and the Yakut country formed one of the provinces of the new government. In 1783 the government was again reorganized into a vice-royalty composed of four provinces, one of which was Yakutsk Province. In 1797 the vice-royalty was abolished and the government restored. In [Page 225] 1805 under the Emperor Alexander I, the Yakut country was made a separate province dependent upon Irkutsk. In 1852 the Yakut country was given a separate governor. After the revolution in February, 1917, a commissar was appointed by the Provisional Government.' [1,139] Sieroszewski reports corruption and exploitation of the Sakha population by administrators: 'The government undertook to regulate the distribution of Yakut land, [Page 764] partly to cease the disorders which arose as a result of this a nd partly to as sure and regulate the taking of yassak, which was being gathered with unbelievable arbitrariness and accompanied by terrible ill use, was stolen, substituted for, and hidden, and they stole from the Great Tsars by putting far too little in the treasury and by undervaluing the yassak greatly, and they impoverished the yassak-paying people and robbed the taxes and injured them.' [1,140] In addition to Russian officials, land-holding toyons also doubled as officials in their districts: 'The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called [...] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [1,141] However, we have found no evidence of pensions being paid to 'natives', including toyons.

♠ State pensions for non-elites ♣ absent ♥ See above.

Entertainment and Knowledge Well-Being[edit]

♠ Funding for festivals ♣ absent ♥ Jochelson describes Kumiss festivals: "Spring festival is called Ayy ysyaxa (“kumiss festival in honor of the ‘creators’ ”). During the summer, in olden times, every rich man arranged a kumiss festival, at which all members of the clan assembled and were entertained. Other people, and frequently whole clans, were invited; and during the festival, defensive and offensive leagues were concluded. Every such festival commenced with sacrifices, and was accompanied with songs, dances, games, horse and foot races, and other contests. The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them. The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn. The steward addresses a prayer to the “creators,” begging for blessings,-increase of horses and cattle, a good harvest of hay, good health for the people and animals, and an abundance of food. Then he takes the kumiss-festival ladle , and makes a libation, in the direction of the dawn, to the benevolent deities . Then, while making a libation to the ground, he addresses the local deity, “the owner of the place” (än doidu iccitä), asking him not to harm the inhabitants of the spot and the members of the clan. After that, the steward, with the help of the sacrificial ladle, proceeds to divine. He throws the ladle towards the sky: and if it falls with the front part upwards, it portends the granting by the deities of future abundance; and all the people utter the joyful cry Uru! Then the boys and girls give the goblets with the sacrificial kumiss, according to the directions of the steward, to the elder and honored members of the clan, both male and female. These, after placing themselves,-the men on the right and the women on the left of the altar,-drink off the kumiss from the goblets, and pass them on to the less important and the younger people." [1,142][1,143] Weddings were subject to a high degree of ritualization, resembling peacemaking procedures between two families: 'Traditionally, for wealthy Yakut, marriage could be polygamous. More common, however, was monogamy, with occasional remarriage after the death of a spouse. Arranged marriages were sometimes politically motivated. Patrilineage exogamy was reckoned strictly; those one could marry were called SYGAN. Until the 1920s many marriage arrangements were complicated and protracted, involving financial, emotional, and symbolic resources of the bride's and groom's extended families. This included the matchmaking ritual; several formal payments of animals, furs, and meat to the bride's family; informal gifts; and extensive dowries. Some families permitted poor grooms to work in their households as a replacement for the bride-price. Occasionally bride-capture occurred (it may have been more common in pre-Russian times). Wedding ceremonies and their attendant feasts, prayers, and dancing, were held first at the household of the bride's parents, then at that of the groom's. The couple usually lived or settled in a nearby yurt.' [1,144]//Kharuzin also describes the wedding proceedings: 'On the day of the wedding the choom of the father of the bride and that of the father of the bridegroom were set up side by side. Depending on the degree of their prosperity the owner of each of the chooms slaughtered between one and five deer and treated the assembled guests. In addition, the bridegroom slaughtered one more deer and sent its meat to the father of the bride. Aided by his friends the bridegroom would next catch the deer for the black kalym. At the same time, near the choom of the bride, other young men caught deer that were to be handed over as dowry. Out on the street, in the meanwhile, the bride would dance in the company of her girl friends and of other young men. Having caught the deer for the black kalym, the young men tied them up to the back of the narta of the match-maker who, with the deer behind him, rode in front of the bridegroom.//'Upon approaching the choom of the bride the matchmaker and the bridegroom rode around her choom in the direction of the movement of the sun. The matchmaker would then enter the choom alone and announce: The son-in-law has arrived. At the same time the people present would let the deer in a special enclosure built by stretching lassoes between trees and by setting up of overturned nartas . A great number of guests would arrive together with the bridegroom. Out on the street the matchmaker would lead the bridegroom to the father of the bride. The bridegroom would pull behind him a vazhenka ( nyal'dzhin ) tied to a leather strap. Upon approaching his future father-in-law he would hand the animal over to him. The bridegroom together with the guests would then remain outside while in the choom preparations were made for a feast and a wedding bed was set up for the newlyweds. The making of the bed was entrusted to one of the relatives of the bride.//'While the guests stood outside and waited for the beginning of the feast, the matchmaker would make numerous sorties from the choom of the bride and in a light-hearted way inform them of what was going on inside the choom. At the same time the father of the bride would received the deer of the black kalym. In the east tundra all the brought deer were accepted without any argument; in the Noril'-skiy rayon, however, the father of the bride would frequently pronounce some animals unacceptable and would send them back expecting other animals in their stead. In the case of a demanding father the business of receiving the deer would occasionally extend into the late evening.//'If the father of the bride was a snob he wold make the guests freeze outside for a long time. When, at long last, the feast and the bed were ready and the deer of the black kalym all checked, the match-maker would lead the bridegroom into the choom and would make him pray in front of the ikons. The bride stationed herself by the side of the bridegroom and prayed together with him. After the prayers were ended the matchmaker would say to the bridegroom: Bow to the big father-in-law and ask for his blessing. The bride and the bridegroom would then make a low bow before the parents and came up to receive their blessing as well as the blessing of the relatives older than the bride. All of them blessed the young people, gave them their hands to kiss, and proffered their best wishes. The matchmaker would at this point, give ten rubles to the father of the bride, and to all her relatives pieces of cloth and kerchiefs. In Noril'sk in the place of money the matchmaker gave the bride's father a fox skin, and to her mother a polar fox skin or a fur coat. These presents were called yungyu --prayer or request. After these presents had been made all the relatives of the bride got up and shook the bridegroom's hand. There were no handshakes between these relatives and the members of the bridegroom's entourage.//'After the blessing ceremony was over the bride and the bridegroom were placed behind the bed curtain. Only then would the guests be let in in a strictly observed order. The guests would be brought in from outside by the relatives, who would lead them by the hand--the adult relatives accompanying the adult guests, and children-relatives--other children. The guests would be taken to places that were asssigned to them. The closest relatives and the most honored guests as well as foreigners (Yakut, Russians, Tungus) would be let in first. To avoid mistakes the relatives of the bride asked their friends as to who should come in and in what order. Before the guests were let in two people would be selected from among those who were known for their talents as improvisers. The two chosen men were to play the role of people who predict the future ( yr kerderer dzhon ). One of these men was selected by the relatives of the bridegroom, the other----by the relatives of the bride. The presence of these men was not an essential part of the wedding ceremony.//'When all the honored guests were seated the bride's father would ask them: Guests! What do you have to say? The matchmaker would answer: We have a word to say. Then a representative of the bridegroom would get us and colorfully and ornately would describe the future life of the young people and the peace and harmony of their household. He would also describe the number of the children they were going to have, how rich they were going to be, etc. He would end his speech by saying: My words ended, now is your turn. Thereupon a similar speech would be make by a representative of the bride. The guests predicted a happier life for the bridegroom or the bride, depending on which side gave the better speech. After this a woman relative of the bride poured out tea and took charge of the serving of the food. After the first meal, i.e. after drinking the tea, and before the opening of the table ( ostuolu asyar inniger ), i.e. the serving of the meal, all the guests would go out on the street and dance until the second meal was served. The ceremony of distributing the kalym ( sulu tuttarar ) would be taking place at the same time.//'The wedding bed was transported to the choom of the bridegroom before the arrival of the bride herself. In front of the procession rode the matchmaker; he was followed by the bridegroom, behind whom was the bride, and behind the latter the deer loaded with the bride's dowry. The bride put on two coats made out of cloth ( sontap ) and a Siberian fur-coat ( dokha ), embroidered with patterns ( ardaydakh sangyyakh ). In the Noril'skiy rayon the size of the dowry was decided upon in the course of the negotiations conducted by the matchmaker; in other places the custom was different and the size of the dowry depended on that of the kalym. If the kalym consisted of sixty deer, the number of deer given with the dowry would be forty-five. A rich dowry consisted of sixty or seventy selected deer of various ages, among them no harness or old deer. Nor more than two or three deer could be included in a rich dowry. In addition to the deer a rich dowry would consist of seven and the poor one of five nartas, harnessed to the best deer (a pair of deer harnessed to each narta of the rich dowry, and a single deer harnessed to each narta of the poor one). In addition to the nartas a dowry included a narta choom, to which were harnessed four deer.//'When the bride's train approached the choom of the bridegroom, the matchmaker would go to the parents of the bridegroom and announced to them the arrival of the bride. The newlyweds would then travel three times around the choom in the direction of the movement of the sun. In the Noril'skiy rayon the bride rode around the choom by herself; after she had entered the choom the deer were led around the choom by some one else. This ceremony was called the entrance of the hearth ( sarany bullarar ). The bride was led into the choom of the bridegroom by a respected old woman who could not be her relative. The bride and the bridegroom prayed together before the ikon, and then, with a deep bow to the bridegroom's father and mother, asked for their blessing and came up to kiss their hands. The parents of the bridegroom then blessed the newlyweds and wished them a happy life. At this point the bride would give the bridegroom's parents presents of money or of valuable skins; these presents had to be much more valuable that those given by the bridegroom to the parents of the bride, for the father of the bride would want to put up a front before the bridegroom's father. In the bridegroom's choom the guests were again treated to a feast, which was served to them in two shifts. In the ancient times a shaman would always be invited to a wedding. Before the beginning of the feast he would stand dressed not in his ceremonial but in his ordinary garments, and leaning upon a deer staff of the bride called upon beneficent gods and spirits to be kind to the newlywed, and for himself wished them a happy and prosperous life. After this address by the shaman the first group of honored guests sat down to the feast.'//'The bridegroom's father would next come out to glance at the deer that were brought as a dowry, and offered the people who helped him in the equipping of the kalym to chose the animals they wanted.//'After the end of the festivities the father would inspect the dowry in the light of the day (this custom was not practised by the Noril'skiye Dolgani): he would go out of the choom, open up the trunks and examine their contents. If it turned out that the amount of the dowry was not equivalent to the amount of the kalym, the stinginess of the bride's parents would be disapprovingly commented on by all those present. As a rule, the father of the bride tried to include in the dowry as many valuable things as he could, for fear that otherwise he might disgrace himself. The inspection described above ended the ceremonies of the Dolgani wedding. The assembled guests would spend the day in eating, in games and in dancing, and would depart in the late evening. The father and the mother of the bride stayed with the bridegroom for a period of three days. Before their departure the father of the bridegroom would present the parents of the bride with one deer (ogo kereryu) which was to be looked upon by them as their daughter. The animal thus given as a present was highly valued. On the morning of the third day the young wife poured out tea. During the tea drinking her father would publicly instruct her as follows: From this time on you must obey your husband. Your mother-in-law now stands in the place of your own mother. Your father-in-law in the place of your father. Respect and obey them and do not quarrel with them.' [1,145]//Elders played a prominent role alongside parents and shamans: 'The oldest kinsman in the clan, or the [unknown]iye-[unknown]usa , is always heaped with honors, if he is both rich and has never been put on trial. To him pertains the jurisdiction in trifling quarrels between kinsfolk. The following ceremonies serve to recall the religious functions that he (Ysekh) formerly exercised a. At the time of the spring festival, which bears a strictly clan character, they bring to him, first of all, a large wooden vessel ( Choron ) containing kumiss; he pronounces a prayer of thanks to the gods and then pours the kumiss upon the fire. b. At the time of the arrival of the betrothed at the bridegroom’s yurt, they take from the sleigh of the betrothed, and place upon a table in front of the fire place the boiled head of a horse, whose eyes are covered with butter, to whose ears are attached intestines filled with horse’s blood, and a wooden cup filled with butter. After this the betrothed enters the yurt, and stands, having first untied her girdle, on the right side of the komelok [RCH: i. e., the fireplace] where she is met by the oldest kinsman, whose place is sometimes taken nowadays by the most honored guest, who, kneeling, throws into the fire 41 pieces of meat, blood and butter, and blesses the bride. For the completion of this ceremony, whose obvious object is to unite the bride with the bridegroom’s home, the oldest kinsman secures for his use the head, blood and butter brought into the yurt, and in addition the sum of one ruble.'
