[1,146]// It appears that festivals were a clan or community effort rather than being 'publicly funded' by a third-party authority.

♠ Entertainment buildings ♣ absent ♥

♠ Theatres ♣ absent ♥
♠ Arenas ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ritual buildings/spaces ♣ absent ♥ Stone monuments were placed over graves: 'The position of sons in the parental home is considerably more independent than that of the daughters. Nevertheless, in personal relations the patriarchal parental authority finds a many-sided application. In addition to the right of giving sons out for adoption, a right which is limited with respect to the sons by the condition that the adoption take place within the confines of the clan, the parents can put their sons out to hire or to apprenticeship. Parents further have the right to use the earnings of their children; their labor goes to the profit of the family; they are obliged to support their parents, and in the event of non-fulfillment of this obligation, the parents can make complaint before the elders of the clan, who, in accordance with the earnings of the son, or his competence order him to support his father. But all these rules have significance only as long as the son has not left the household or married. In general, if the parents feed, clothe their children, “seek their good,” and the children feed and support their parents in their old age, bury them decently after death, hold a wake on the 40th day [RCH: on the 40th day the soul of the deceased departs from the earth] and finally place a stone monument over the grave, they are considered to have mutually fulfilled their obligations.' [1,147] But we have found no evidence of post-mortuary ritual being conducted at these sites. For the celebration of seasonal festivals, the Sakha built non-permanent altars rather than temples or the like: 'The spring kumiss festival takes place in the open air. In the midst of a large smooth grass meadow a kind of altar is erected. This consists of two posts with a crossbeam, and three young birch-trees with young shoots on them (see Plate XVII). The altar is hung round with sacrificial horsehair, and on the ground in front of it are placed ornamented birch-bark and ox-hide barrels filled with kumiss. The skin barrels are tied to the altar-frame by long ornamented straps of soft elk-leather. This is done so that the vessels, when softened by the liquid in them, shall not collapse. The ceremony commences by sacrifices to Lord Bright-Creator and to other “creators.” Their names are uttered by the steward of the festival, who may be a shaman or an elder member of the clan. The sacrifices consist of libations of kumiss, in the direction of the dawn, to every deity; and formerly horses were often consecrated by being driven to the east.' [1,148] Russian Orthodox settlers and missionaries introduced churches: 'In the north, where most of the household utensils are mad at home, all are prepared with the aid of only these clumsy implements. In the south, where trades are kept separate to a greater degree, a carpenter owns, besides these, a wide and a narrow saw, planes, a brace and bit, chisels, and sometimes even a rasp. But everywhere the axe is most important. The Yakut handle the axe in a masterly fashion and are excellent carpenters. The majority of the churches in the Yakutsk Okrug and almost all the house s in the town of Yakutsk have been built by Yakut carpenters. In their carpentry work they use the same methods, the same compass for cutting, the same pitch rope, plumb, triangle, and ruler as do the Russians. The head of the carpenters artel, the elder carpenter, is called the regulator, after the Russian fashion. But their chief instruments, the axes and knives, have retained their ancient shape.They weigh from two to no more than four pounds, and cost from fifty kopecks to one ruble. The Yakut cut with them smoothly, cleanly, and quickly; they are ready to fashion even small pieces with an axe.' [1,149] We have assumed that churches were attended by Russians rather than Yakuts at the time, as the spread of Christianzation could be slow and patchy.
♠ Other ♣ absent ♥ Tokarev's material suggests that even in newly established settlements symbolic and other non-residential and non-governmental buildings were largely absent until the Soviet period: 'In 1917 there were only two clubs, three small libraries and one museum in Yakutiya. In 1951 the Republic had more than 1000 educational-cultural establishments, among which there were about 500 reading rooms, several hundred libraries and 5 museums. At the present time there are Party schools in all rayons. In 1948, 986 amateur music and entertainment groups were functioning in the various clubs. There are regular amateur art exhibitions in the clubs and houses of culture. In the north, e.g., the Anabarskiy, Olenekskiy and other rayons,-Red tents with mobile film units have been set up for the population of the tundra.' [1,150]
♠ accessibility of entertainment buildings ♣ ♥

♠ Full-time entertainment specialists ♣ absent ♥ Music, dance and art were produced by community members rather than professionals: 'Yakut art takes many forms, sometimes rooted in ritual life but, in the Soviet period, often secular and commercial. Silver and gold jewelry once considered talismanic is enjoyed for its aesthetic value. Famed for ivory- and woodcarving, Yakut artists have branched into graphic art, painting, and sculpture. [...] Continuity of folk art is strongest in exuberant improvisational poetry that accompanies line dancing (OHUOKHAI) and in a revival of mouth-harp (KHOMUS) playing. But few young people memorize the OLONKHO that once took days to tell. Instead, OLONKHO heroes are memorialized in other art forms.' [1,151] Full-time entertainment professionals only emerged in the Soviet period.

♠ status of full-time entertainment specialists ♣ ♥

♠ Access to education ♣ absent ♥

♠ Publicly funded or subsidized education ♣ absent ♥ Tokarev's material suggests that even in newly established settlements symbolic and other non-residential and non-governmental buildings were largely absent until the Soviet period: 'In 1917 there were only two clubs, three small libraries and one museum in Yakutiya. In 1951 the Republic had more than 1000 educational-cultural establishments, among which there were about 500 reading rooms, several hundred libraries and 5 museums. At the present time there are Party schools in all rayons. In 1948, 986 amateur music and entertainment groups were functioning in the various clubs. There are regular amateur art exhibitions in the clubs and houses of culture. In the north, e.g., the Anabarskiy, Olenekskiy and other rayons,-Red tents with mobile film units have been set up for the population of the tundra.' [1,152] We have assumed that the Sakha had no access to these facilities until the 20th century.
♠ Schools for children? ♣ absent ♥
♠ Universities, “proto-universities”, or other higher education ♣ absent ♥
♠ Libraries ♣ absent ♥
♠ Museums ♣ absent ♥
♠ Literacy rate ♣ absent: 1642-1800 CE; rare: 1801-1900 CE ♥ Sakha traditions were orally transmitted: 'Yakut oral histories begin well before first contact with Russians in the seventeenth century. For example, OLONKHO (epics) date at least to the tenth century, a period of interethnic mixing, tensions, and upheaval that may have been a formative period in defining Yakut tribal affiliations. Ethnographic and archaeological data suggest that the ancestors of the Yakut, identified in some theories with the Kuriakon people, lived in an area near Lake Baikal and may have been part of the Uighur state bordering China.' [1,153] 'Tradition has preserved the names of some of them. They list the following as living contemporaneously with the coming of the Russians: Tygyn of the Kangalas Ulus, Chorbokha (of the clan of Chaky) of the Namsk Ulus, Bert-Khara of the Borogon Ulus, Bata batyra of the Bayagantaysk Ulus, and many others of secondary importance. The Yakut are glad to relate long sagas of their activities, of their warfare with each other, and of their resistance to the Russians. According to them all these leaders were noted for their unusual strength, cleverness, and military capacity.' [1,154] Distant ancestors of the Yakut may have been familiar with writing, but lost that knowledge during past migrations: 'Spindle whorls were made of a kind of hard stone coal (slate?). Of particular interest was one spindle, found in Kurumchinakh, which was covered with writing (letters). In comparing these characters with those of various alphabets, it may readily be observed that many of them are similar, as far as they can be deciphered, to the characters of the Orkhon alphabet. There were thirty-seven symbols of which twenty-one are letters and sixteen indistinct, effaced signs, including perhaps mere scratches. The twenty-one letters appear to be an exact reproduction of the Yenisei-Orkhon characters. There are eighteen consonants and three vowels. Some of the characters are repeated and in all there are ten different symbols. The discovery of these writings so far to the north is of great interest. The ancestors of the Yakut, who, in remote times, emigrated from northern Mongolia, undoubtedly knew the Orkhon alphabet and this may explain the Yakut traditions as to the loss of their writings on the way to Yakutsk Province.' [1,155] The first recent script for the Yakut language was developed by 19th century Russian missionaries: 'The Yakut speak Yakut, a Northeast Turkic language of the Altaic Language Family. It is one of the most divergent of the Turkic languages, closely related to Dolgan (a mixture of Evenk and Yakut sometimes described as a Yakut dialect). The Yakut, over 90 percent of whom speak Yakut as their mother tongue, call their language "Sakha-tyla." Their current written language, developed in the 1930s, is a modified Cyrillic script. Before this, they had several written forms, including a Latin script developed in the 1920s and a Cyrillic script introduced by missionaries in the nineteenth century. Yakut lore includes legends of a written language lost after they traveled north to the Lena valley.' [1,156] 'Such was the culture of the Yakut people up to the October Revolution. Particularly important was the cultural assistance which the Yakuts obtained from the fraternal Russian people during the prerevolutionary years. In the 19th century it was mainly the political exiles, beginning with the Decembrists, who spread culture through Yakutiya. There were also other progressive Russian people who diffused the beginnings of a cultivated way of life among the Yakuts. In particular, they laid the foundations of the Yakut written language.' [1,157] Russian administrators communicated in writing and composed clerical documents: 'The people became rapidly impoverished, and the order of the voivode to the clerk Evdokim Kurdiukov in 1685 already mentions the arrears in the treasury and orders the yassak gatherers to treat the people in arrears in the following way: from them who have no cattle take, because of their povetry and extreme need one cherno-cherevyya and one sivodushatyya fox from each, and for a sable, two red foxes from each. This same document orders him to make a census of the people, and their goods and cattle: collect the taxes for the current year, 193 (1685) in full, and collect the arrears for the past years, from each as much as possible. Similar censuses were taken earlier also, and their character may be judged by the census of Grishka Krivogornitsyn in 170 (1671) “for the Meginsk volosts” There we find mentioned not only the taxes and the amounts in arrears, but also the houses, wives, number of workers in the family. There is information about those who have died and those who have run away. Moreover the name and clan of every person is given. The personal and clan nicknames, of course are very much corrupted in these notes, and changed to conform with the Russian style, but it is not hard to determine what they actually are. The yassak books and these censuses were the materials out of which was later created the present system of Yakut self-government.' [1,158] But the Sakha probably had little to no access to these. Illiteracy was widespread until the 20th century: 'In 1942 Yakutiya celebrated the end of illiteracy among the adult population. Over the years of the Soviet regime more than 155,000 illiterate people have been taught to read and write. Work continues with those who are only partially literate in the network of adult schools.' [1,159] We have selected 1800 as a provisional date of transition.

Biological Well-Being[edit]

Mortality

♠ Life expectancy ♣ ♥ We have found no reliable data on this.
♠ Infant mortality ♣ ♥ Infant mortality was high, but the sources reviewed do not provide precise figures: 'The position of children, despite the fact that the Yakuts loved their children, as pointed out by many observers, was also rather unfortunate. The birth rate was very high among the Yakuts and most families produced from 5 to 10 children, sometimes as many as 20 or even more. However, the bad living conditions, poor food and inattention resulted in very high child mortality. Apart from their own children, many families, particularly those in which there were few children, often adopted children, whom they often simply bought from the poorer people.' [1,160] 'I know of cases where husbands loved and spoiled children whom they knew to have been begotten by outsiders just as they would their own. It's a child in any case... After all, we do take the children of others!... (Namsk Ulus, 1890). The Yakut are very willing to adopt children or enter into agreements with their parents for ever or for a time. In the first case the adopters usually pay the parents or the clan; in the second case - they demand repayment themselves. To be sure, this repayment is small: several rubles a year or a present. But when rich people give a child to feed to poor people, because of superstition, the latter usually receive a cow to milk and constant hand-outs of food and money as payment. The Yakut are usually very attentive to their children, where they are their own or have been taken for upbringing or adopted. Nevertheless children die in their early years at a fearful rate. Our children are dying without number. A Yakut woman is only torturing herself in vain when she gives birth to a child. (Namsk Ulus, 1890).' [1,161] 'This is a result of poverty and the general low level of culture among the Yakut, 528 which does not allow even rich people to give their children any better care than that which they now receive. This care is very simple.' [1,162]

Disease

♠ Endemic disease ♣ present ♥ Sauer mentions rheumatism, skin diseases, small-pox and measles: “The Yakuti are a healthy and hardy race, bear the extremes of heat and cold to an astonishing degree, and travel in the severest frosts on horseback, frequently suffering much from hunger; they are, however, subject to rheumatic pains, boils, the itch, and sore eyes; and great numbers were carried off in 1758 and 1774 by the small-pox and measles: the shamans are their doctors.” [1,163] Leprosy was common: 'Because of their slovenliness , skin disea ses, such as rashes, various herpes, scabs, fistula, ulcers, and abscesses are extremely widespread among the Yakut. Cachexia and scrofula are common also, particularly in poor localities which are subject to frequent famines. In damp and marshy places, among lakes, where the population feeds primarily on the poorest kinds of fish, leprosy is found, although by no means to such an extent as has been proclaimed. The point is that the inhabitants confuse this disea se with some forms of chronic syphilis, which manifests itself in this severe climate with fearsome severity: the body and the bones rot away, and the sick man decomposes while he is still alive, just as he does from leprosy. The inhabitants have a great fear of both these disease and, as soon as they develop, banish the sick one mercilessly: they put the syphilitics into the okrug hospitals, and drive those suspected of leprosy into the woods, where they have houses built for them and where they bring the m food at definite intervals. When such a colony dies off, the Yakut burn down the buildings with everything that is inside them. They call leprosy the big sickness (ulakhan olyu, and also syster), and call syphilis the Russian or French disease. The worst of the epidemic diseases for [Page 472] the Yakut is smallpox. Ninety percent of those that fall sick from this disease die; in the south it does not have as deadly an effect as in the north.' [1,164] 'Leprosy is very prevalent in Yakut Province, particularly in the Viliuisk and Kolymsk districts. Of all Russia, Yakut Province leads in the distribution of this disease, there being one case of leprosy in every 2,800—a very high percentage. In Europe it has been estimated that there are one or two cases in every 10,000.' [1,165] 'Fig. 103 shows two lepers, with the disease in an advanced stage, photographed by me in the leper-house of Sredne Kolymsk. Their finger joints and toes have dropped off, leaving well healed stumps. Their faces (called lions’ faces), their eye-lids, the lining of their mouths, noses, throats, and larynx (causing hoarseness) are covered with ulcers, deeply implicating the structure and function of the peripheral nervous system.' [1,166] Tapeworm infections were also widespread: 'On the other hand in spring there is hardly a pike or an aged carp without a tapeworm in its inside. In the north the tapeworm 117 is found rarer inside the fish. The tapeworm makes its abode in the insides of horned cattle and in the horses from which it is transferred to men who use the raw or half-boiled cattle meat. Tapeworm infection is a widespread disease among the Yakut and both varieties of that disease are frequently encountered among them. Often the disease reaches serious proportions, weakens the victim, and causes pain and spasms. I have known several cases of death from tapeworm. The Yakut use no medicine to get rid of the worm and do not believe that it gets into their insides together with raw meat. The swear word -- wormy (cherebnyy) is considered offensive and the sick people are unwilling to confess of having the disease.' [1,167] Goiter was common among Russian settlers: 'I have yet to mention those deformities and diseases which are widespread among the Yakut. I did not notice many among them who were hunchbacked, mis-shapen, or lame; neither were there many who were tongue-tied or who lisped. Cross- eyed Yakut are more frequent; diseases of the eye are in general very widespread, and most of the old men lose their sight toward the end of their life. I did not come across any cases of goiter among non-Russians, although this is a fairly common occurence among the Russians of that region, particularly among those who live in the valley of the Lena.' [1,168] Sieroszewski provides a general summary: 'Almost nothing is known about the prevalence of other diseases; they are all treated with homemade remedies, incantations, and shamanism, and since they are accompanied by delirium and moaning, they ascribe them to the influence of hostile spirits. From the reports of medical acquaintances and my own observations, the following diseases are known to me: catarrhal, gastric, and rheumatic fevers, pneumonia, diseases o the heart, liver, and gall bladder, consumption, cancer of the throat, uterus, and stomach, and diseases of the eye... Slight inflammations of the eye are cured very successfully by licking the pus from under the eyelid with the tip of the tongue. Sometimes this is done by particular specialists who have a particularly soft and thin tongue. People come purposely to the houses of such people and pay as much as thirty kopecks for an operation. Despite the abundance of water, swamp fever is comparatively rare; sufferers are cured by frightening them, or pouring cold water over them; even oftener they are not treated at all. Fever belongs to that class of diseases against which shamanism acknowledges itself to be powerless. Rheumatism is extremely widespread; finally, the terrible disease, contraction of the throat, is not a rarity; its victims die a death from hunger. This malady is apparently found most often in those places where cattle raising is the exclusive occupation, where the supply of wild animals has been exhausted and they do not raise grain; I think it appears as a result of eating liquid foods exclusively. Besides this, it is a rare Yakut who does not suffer from tape-worm or round worm - a result of eating meat that is raw or not sufficiently cooked; the local cattle suffer equally severely from these parasites. From the observations of doctors, diseases and medicines alike act more quickly on the organisms of Yakut, than on Russians. Yakut live to a [Page 473] ripe old age: old men of seventy or eighty are far from rare among them.' [1,169]
♠ Disease outbreaks ♣ present ♥ Sauer mentions rheumatism, skin diseases, small-pox and measles: “The Yakuti are a healthy and hardy race, bear the extremes of heat and cold to an astonishing degree, and travel in the severest frosts on horseback, frequently suffering much from hunger; they are, however, subject to rheumatic pains, boils, the itch, and sore eyes; and great numbers were carried off in 1758 and 1774 by the small-pox and measles: the shamans are their doctors.” [1,170] Leprosy was common: 'Because of their slovenliness , skin disea ses, such as rashes, various herpes, scabs, fistula, ulcers, and abscesses are extremely widespread among the Yakut. Cachexia and scrofula are common also, particularly in poor localities which are subject to frequent famines. In damp and marshy places, among lakes, where the population feeds primarily on the poorest kinds of fish, leprosy is found, although by no means to such an extent as has been proclaimed. The point is that the inhabitants confuse this disea se with some forms of chronic syphilis, which manifests itself in this severe climate with fearsome severity: the body and the bones rot away, and the sick man decomposes while he is still alive, just as he does from leprosy. The inhabitants have a great fear of both these disease and, as soon as they develop, banish the sick one mercilessly: they put the syphilitics into the okrug hospitals, and drive those suspected of leprosy into the woods, where they have houses built for them and where they bring the m food at definite intervals. When such a colony dies off, the Yakut burn down the buildings with everything that is inside them. They call leprosy the big sickness (ulakhan olyu, and also syster), and call syphilis the Russian or French disease. The worst of the epidemic diseases for [Page 472] the Yakut is smallpox. Ninety percent of those that fall sick from this disease die; in the south it does not have as deadly an effect as in the north.' [1,171] 'Leprosy is very prevalent in Yakut Province, particularly in the Viliuisk and Kolymsk districts. Of all Russia, Yakut Province leads in the distribution of this disease, there being one case of leprosy in every 2,800—a very high percentage. In Europe it has been estimated that there are one or two cases in every 10,000.' [1,172] 'Fig. 103 shows two lepers, with the disease in an advanced stage, photographed by me in the leper-house of Sredne Kolymsk. Their finger joints and toes have dropped off, leaving well healed stumps. Their faces (called lions’ faces), their eye-lids, the lining of their mouths, noses, throats, and larynx (causing hoarseness) are covered with ulcers, deeply implicating the structure and function of the peripheral nervous system.' [1,173] Tapeworm infections were also widespread: 'On the other hand in spring there is hardly a pike or an aged carp without a tapeworm in its inside. In the north the tapeworm 117 is found rarer inside the fish. The tapeworm makes its abode in the insides of horned cattle and in the horses from which it is transferred to men who use the raw or half-boiled cattle meat. Tapeworm infection is a widespread disease among the Yakut and both varieties of that disease are frequently encountered among them. Often the diseae reaches serious proportions, weakens the victim, and causes pain and spasms. I have known several cases of death from tapeworm. The Yakut use no medicine to get rid of the worm and do not believe that it gets into their insides together with raw meat. The swear word -- wormy (cherebnyy) is considered offensive and the sick people are unwilling to confess of having the disease.' [1,174] Goiter was common among Russian settlers: 'I have yet to mention those deformities and diseases which are widespread among the Yakut. I did not notice many among them who were hunchbacked, mis-shapen, or lame; neither were there many who were tongue-tied or who lisped. Cross- eyed Yakut are more frequent; diseases of the eye are in general very widespread, and most of the old men lose their sight toward the end of their life. I did not come across any cases of goiter among non-Russians, although this is a fairly common occurence among the Russians of that region, particularly among those who live in the valley of the Lena.' [1,175] Sieroszewski provides a general summary: 'Almost nothing is known about the prevalence of other diseases; they are all treated with homemade remedies, incantations, and shamanism, and since they are accompanied by delirium and moaning, they ascribe them to the influence of hostile spirits. From the reports of medical acquaintances and my own observations, the following diseases are known to me: catarrhal, gastric, and rheumatic fevers, pneumonia, diseases o the heart, liver, and gall bladder, consumption, cancer of the throat, uterus, and stomach, and diseases of the eye... Slight inflammations of the eye are cured very successfully by licking the pus from under the eyelid with the tip of the tongue. Sometimes this is done by particular specialists who have a particularly soft and thin tongue. People come purposely to the houses of such people and pay as much as thirty kopecks for an operation. Despite the abundance of water, swamp fever is comparatively rare; sufferers are cured by frightening them, or pouring cold water over them; even oftener they are not treated at all. Fever belongs to that class of diseases against which shamanism acknowledges itself to be powerless. Rheumatism is extremely widespread; finally, the terrible disease, contraction of the throat, is not a rarity; its victims die a death from hunger. This malady is apparently found most often in those places where cattle raising is the exclusive occupation, where the supply of wild animals has been exhausted and they do not raise grain; I think it appears as a result of eating liquid foods exclusively. Besides this, it is a rare Yakut who does not suffer from tape-worm or round worm - a result of eating meat that is raw or not sufficiently cooked; the local cattle suffer equally severely from these parasites. From the observations of doctors, diseases and medicines alike act more quickly on the organisms of Yakut, than on Russians. Yakut live to a [Page 473] ripe old age: old men of seventy or eighty are far from rare among them.' [1,176]
♠ Endemic malnutrition ♣ present ♥ Some Sakha, especially poor people, suffered from malnutrition: “The Yakuti are a healthy and hardy race, bear the extremes of heat and cold to an astonishing degree, and travel in the severest frosts on horseback, frequently suffering much from hunger; they are, however, subject to rheumatic pains, boils, the itch, and sore eyes; and great numbers were carried off in 1758 and 1774 by the small-pox and measles: the shamans are their doctors.” [1,177] “There is perhaps no nation in the world that can exhibit a greater variety with regard to size. The affluent, whose dwellings are situated about the meadows on the south side of the Virchoyanski chain, are from five feet ten inches to six feet four inches high, well proportioned, extremely strong, and very active; while the indigent inhabitants of the more northern parts are in general below the middle size, indolent, and of an unhealthy complexion, evidently stunted by the badness of their food, the severity of the climate, and the want of proper cloathing. Their wealth consists in horses and horned cattle. The private property of no individual at this instant exceeds 2000, all species included; formerly, numbers of them possessed 20,000, according to their own testimony . . .” [1,178]

Physiology

♠ Average height (male) ♣ ♥ Gogolev reports considerable 'ethnic' hybridization: 'These surmises are also supported by the observations of prerevolutionary scholars. R. K. Maak identified three types among the Yakuts of Viliui: hybrid, Mongolian, and Turkic. He called the latter type “Yakuts.” This was comprised of predominantly tall people with a long, oval face, aquiline nose, and wide, open eyes, “a type that has survived till the present [it., the middle of the nineteenth century-A.G.] among the elderly and the wealthy.”22 A somewhat different picture was given by A. F. Middendorf: “The earliest form of Tatar face of the Yakuts is apparently closely related to the facial forms of certain North American Indian tribes.”23 He noted that, among the younger generation of Yakuts during the time of his stay (i.e., the 1840s), there were often found “a preponderance of Mongol-ian, especially Tungusic, facial features.”' [1,179] 'V. L. Seroshevskii also confirmed the observations of these scholars. “The Turkic type,” he noted, “embraces primarily the true-born toyons. One gets the impression”-writes Prof. N. K. Antonov, who worked inthe region many years later on a Yakut historical lexicon-“that the ruling class in ancient Yakut society was comprised of Turkic-speaking tribes, while the poor, laboring, subordinate group was primarily Mongolianspeaking.”' [1,180] 'N. L. Gekker, who concerned himself especially with anthropological studies of people of the central Yakutia regions, confirmed the presence of two anthropological types-brachycephalic and dolichocephalic. He noted that such a division is characteristic not only of the Yakuts, but also of all Turkic peoples.26 Furthermore, he discovered a complete coincidence of the brachycephalic type and tall height. “The Yakuts are not a homogeneous and anthropologically pure medium,” he notes, “but are now the product of a long mingling of two or more related tribes.”27 In his abstract understanding, one of these types was tall, long-faced, and long-nosed, the other short in stature, with large spherical head, and a short and very broad, tlat face and nose. Yet af‘terwards, a few transitional stages were formed between them. These data are apparently supported by more recent reports. Ia. I. Lindenau, who spent time among the Yakuts during the first half of the eighteenth century, wrote as follows: “The Yakuts are for the most part large and well-made, and their faces resemble the Buryats and the Barabinsk Tatars,”28 i.e., a Central Asiatic type, represented by the Mongols and Buryats, and a mixed, southern Siberian type, which comprises the Barabinsk Tatars, southern Altaians, Kazakh, and Kyrgyz.' [1,181] There was considerable variation in height: “There is perhaps no nation in the world that can exhibit a greater variety with regard to size. The affluent, whose dwellings are situated about the meadows on the south side of the Virchoyanski chain, are from five feet ten inches to six feet four inches high, well proportioned, extremely strong, and very active; while the indigent inhabitants of the more northern parts are in general below the middle size, indolent, and of an unhealthy complexion, evidently stunted by the badness of their food, the severity of the climate, and the want of proper cloathing. Their wealth consists in horses and horned cattle. The private property of no individual at this instant exceeds 2000, all species included; formerly, numbers of them possessed 20,000, according to their own testimony . . .” [1,182] This makes the identification of a meaningful 'average' height more difficult.
♠ Average height (female) ♣ ♥ Gogolev reports considerable 'ethnic' hybridization: 'These surmises are also supported by the observations of prerevolutionary scholars. R. K. Maak identified three types among the Yakuts of Viliui: hybrid, Mongolian, and Turkic. He called the latter type “Yakuts.” This was comprised of predominantly tall people with a long, oval face, aquiline nose, and wide, open eyes, “a type that has survived till the present [it., the middle of the nineteenth century-A.G.] among the elderly and the wealthy.”22 A somewhat different picture was given by A. F. Middendorf: “The earliest form of Tatar face of the Yakuts is apparently closely related to the facial forms of certain North American Indian tribes.”23 He noted that, among the younger generation of Yakuts during the time of his stay (i.e., the 1840s), there were often found “a preponderance of Mongol-ian, especially Tungusic, facial features.”' [1,183] 'V. L. Seroshevskii also confirmed the observations of these scholars. “The Turkic type,” he noted, “embraces primarily the true-born toyons. One gets the impression”-writes Prof. N. K. Antonov, who worked inthe region many years later on a Yakut historical lexicon-“that the ruling class in ancient Yakut society was comprised of Turkic-speaking tribes, while the poor, laboring, subordinate group was primarily Mongolianspeaking.”' [1,184] 'N. L. Gekker, who concerned himself especially with anthropological studies of people of the central Yakutia regions, confirmed the presence of two anthropological types-brachycephalic and dolichocephalic. He noted that such a division is characteristic not only of the Yakuts, but also of all Turkic peoples.26 Furthermore, he discovered a complete coincidence of the brachycephalic type and tall height. “The Yakuts are not a homogeneous and anthropologically pure medium,” he notes, “but are now the product of a long mingling of two or more related tribes.”27 In his abstract understanding, one of these types was tall, long-faced, and long-nosed, the other short in stature, with large spherical head, and a short and very broad, tlat face and nose. Yet af‘terwards, a few transitional stages were formed between them. These data are apparently supported by more recent reports. Ia. I. Lindenau, who spent time among the Yakuts during the first half of the eighteenth century, wrote as follows: “The Yakuts are for the most part large and well-made, and their faces resemble the Buryats and the Barabinsk Tatars,”28 i.e., a Central Asiatic type, represented by the Mongols and Buryats, and a mixed, southern Siberian type, which comprises the Barabinsk Tatars, southern Altaians, Kazakh, and Kyrgyz.' [1,185] There was considerable variation in height: “There is perhaps no nation in the world that can exhibit a greater variety with regard to size. The affluent, whose dwellings are situated about the meadows on the south side of the Virchoyanski chain, are from five feet ten inches to six feet four inches high, well proportioned, extremely strong, and very active; while the indigent inhabitants of the more northern parts are in general below the middle size, indolent, and of an unhealthy complexion, evidently stunted by the badness of their food, the severity of the climate, and the want of proper cloathing. Their wealth consists in horses and horned cattle. The private property of no individual at this instant exceeds 2000, all species included; formerly, numbers of them possessed 20,000, according to their own testimony . . .” [1,186] This makes the identification of a meaningful 'average' height more difficult.

Prosocial Behavior[edit]

♠ Volunteering ♣ absent ♥

♠ Charity ♣ absent ♥ Cooperative herding was practiced in the summer: 'In summer the herds of several owners unite to form one big herd which is often quite large in size. In the first place, such large herds formed from smaller ones result in economizing of the working forces, since a considerably smaller number of people is required to look after these large herds 185 [Figure 1] than is needed for the separate smaller herds which united to form the larger one; in the second place, when dark clouds, gnats, and gadflies pass over the tundra, the large herd does not disperse like the small herds do; the reindeer bunch up and keep revolving constantly, since each one of the circling group tries to squeeze into the center in order to protect his sides from the bites of the gnats. When they drive the reindeer to the camp, the latter do this “circle dance” of theirs around the chooms, which threatens to knock them down. In the case of animals with such habits very few persons are required to pasture a large herd, since the only work they have to do amounts to driving the strays back into the herd.' [1,187] 'Another advantage of having the large herds in summer is the fact that there is a sufficiently large number of workers for the times when it is necessary to guard the herd day and night--at the time when the grass grows in spring, and during the mushroom period in the summer; the sufficiently large number of people makes it possible for them to take regular shifts at the pasture, which almost never has the effect of withdrawing the working forces in the economy.' [1,188] Mutual aid between families was practiced in pitching hay: 'Ordinarily they try to place grass which has been mowed early into large ricks, for this reason also, that these ricks will have to stand the whole summer, since the Yakut throw the hay into haystacks only after they have finished all the mowing, in the last days of August or even the early part of September. It sometimes happens that downpours, which come down for whole weeks at a time in the end of July and in August, penetrate right through the small ricks, and the hay in them rots, burns, and blackens. Even in large ricks a thick crust of rotten hay always forms, and the bottom of the rick, if it has been lying on the ground, and not on a peg, rots a great deal. Only the middle of the rick remains green. This admixture of black, rotten hay is quite considerable, in view of the small size of the ricks, and given even the finest Yakut hay, which has been gathered at the proper time and has been carefully dried, a greyish color. [Page 499] Such greyish-green hay is preferred by the Yakut and is called Yakut, to distinguish it from bright green hay gathered by Russian methods, i.e. first dried out in the open air right where it has been mowed for twenty-four hours, then tedded and turned over, and heaped together on the third day, in good weather, then placed in large ricks weighing four or five poods, and finally raked into haystacks as soon as possible, as soon as the weather and the assignment of labor permits. This method of work is recommended by government ukases, whose printed blanks I saw in native upravas; it is well known to the non-Russians, particularly those who live near Russian villages and cities. The introduction of these improvements is hindered by the parallelism of household arrangements throughout the whole region which is to a considerable degree necessary, for example, the custom of opening or closing the meadows to the cattle at certain definite times, the certain sequence in which arable land is mowed, and also the necessity of pitching hay everywhere at the same time. Far from all Yakut families have the strength to pitch all the hay from their spacious farmsteads in one or two days all by themselves and quickly. On the other hand it is dangerous to continue this work very long, in view of the changeability of the weather in the second half of the local summer. They are forced to pitch hay in company with 280 other families. This makes each individual homestead owner dependent on the general progress of the labor. In families which can get along without outside help, they always try to pitch part of the hay as early as possible, in the middle of the summer. The Yakut yearning to mow as much hay as possible forces them just as naturally to treasure every day of good weather in the first half of the summer, when the grasses have not yet hardened and dried up. When the grass is already moved and put into ricks, then it is another matter. It is then that all kinds of mutual help - keme and gulyay Begin, and families join together in small [Page 500] cartels for pitching the hay. They bring the hay to the [unknown] in sleds on wh ich they pla ce not more than four or five ricks which are tightened by belts placed slantwise. At the [unknown]they overturn the sleds. In this way, enormous heaps of hay arise around the from here they systematically pile the hay into haystacks with pitchforks. Among the various kinds of pitchforks, atyrdzhakh, there is one enormous one, reaching a length of two sagenes. The Yakut are not familiar with the application of beams and with lifting up the hay in whole cart-loads. Their haystacks are small; year after year they place them in the same places, on the very highest points of the meadows where they will not be swamped with floods and the water from snows in spring. They always put the worst grasses as a foundation for the [unknown] : they will dampen and blacken in any case. They put the best grass in the middle of the stacks, and the more moist grass at the edges. Workers, usually women or youths, trample hard on the edges and kill the grass. Every man who raises and piles the hay with a pitchfork needs one youth on the haystack and one or two youths with the bulls in the sled, and two rakers. Such a number of Yakut workers are able to pitch from twenty-five to thirty loads of hay (cubic sagenes) in one day, i.e. to transfer from one place to another, carry away, and lift to a certain height from five to six hundred Yakut ricks each weighing one pood. The haystacks are round or rectangular in shape; the latte r shape is preferred, particularly for damp hay which has been wettened by rain.' [1,189] Social life was characterized by a lot of ad hoc mutualism: 'Among the Yakut there are only temporary co-operative unions [Page 680] in use. These are very popular. Two fisherman who come together a t the same fishing place will immediately organize a company. They will fish together and divide the catch equally. Several wood-choppers who chop wood in the same vicinity will also enter into a company, because this is more fun. Mowers often join together into small brigades consisting of five or six men and will mow the meadows of each member in turn (Namsk Ulus, 1889). A peasant woman will help her neighbor rake, in return for the same service, and it has practically become a custom to pitch hay by combining the joint strength of two or three households and doing each household's work in turn. Besides this, neighbors constantly exchange a great number of small services which demand a special skill; the number of these is beyond calculation. Cutting and sewing a dress, gluing together a broken dish, catching and restraining a raging stallion, squaring a door, finding a lost piece of livestock, and so forth -- a whole mass of services, whose total far exceeds those which are paid for by agreement, are exchanged without causing any particular misunderstanding. It is also remarkable that all these unions have clearly expressed within them the foundations of artels: equal distribution of labor and equal partnership is called kompaniya, as in Russian, although the Yakut have their own word: kytyk - kytykas, 428 which expresses this conception quite well. They also use the Russian word gulyay for the support of beggars; in the Yakut language this word is komo. The word is used by prosperous people who can afford to extend certain hospitality, or by the needy paupers themselves. The latter bow from the waist to their neighbors, give them some [Page 681] small present: a brick of tea, one ruble in money, and if the reasons presented by the petitioner were sufficiently valid, then the one supplicated will carry out the work without repayment, at his own expense: he will build a house, mow the meadow, chop and deliver kindling wood. For rich Yakut, princes, and all personages who are influential in their neighborhood, this custom of aid is exceedingly profitable. It is impossible to refuse them, while the hospitality they extent is always calculated so that it costs them less than it would to hire a laborer. The day for gulyay begins at sunrise and ends at sunset. During the working day the laborers are only fed once and given tea once; the main hospitality is extended after the work is done. Sometimes the owner brings his helpers a glass of vodka apiece; this is considered a great honor. The food given consists of kumiss or tea, milk, butter, flour, and meat. Usually they slaughter a piece of livestock and cook part of it, while the rest is given out raw as a present. Besides mowing hay, aid is given in the form of building houses, harrowing, carrying hay, and in general all kinds of work where collected efforts are useful and applicable. Only paupers and homeowners of average means are invited for aid; rich people consider it shameful for them to take part in this.' [1,190] But this does not seem to constitute charity.

Voluntary Associations

♠ voluntary trade associations ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of voluntary trade associations ♣ ♥
♠ voluntary community organizations ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of voluntary community organizations ♣ ♥
♠ voluntary athletic clubs ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of voluntary athletic clubs organizations ♣ ♥
♠ other voluntary organizations ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of other voluntary organizations ♣ ♥
♠ voluntary religious associations ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of voluntary religious associations ♣ ♥

Economy variables (polity-level)[edit]

State Income[edit]

♠ Tribute ♣ present ♥ Tribute was collected in the form of furs, not food items, labour or currency.

♠ Staple ♣ absent ♥
♠ Labor ♣ absent ♥
♠ Currency ♣ absent ♥

Debt and Indemnities

♠ Polity has obligation to other polity or group ♣ present ♥ The early invaders imposed tribute in furs on the Sakha population after successful military expeditions: 'By 1620 a report had reached Tobolsk from the Mangaseya Cossacks of the Great (Lena) River and the Lena Yakut. In 1631 they descended by the Viliui River, a tributary of the Lena, to the Lena River and imposed tribute on the adjacent Yakut. In 1632 a party of Cossacks under the command of the Boyar’s son, Shakov, took tribute in sables from a clan of Viliui horse-breeding Yakut. The Viliui River farther up from its mouth was occupied by Tungus only. The northern boundary of the distribution of the Yakut at that time was the mouth of the Viliui. The whole Lena Valley from the mouth of the Viliui River to the south, at a distance of about 500 kilometers (or 710 miles) was occupied by Yakut. In their possession were also all the Lena islands of that region, rich in pasture lands. There is no definite information as to how far inland they penetrated at that period. We may admit, however, that the Yakut, being horse and cattle breeders, were hardly inclined to move into the dense forests far from the majority of their tribesmen, i.e., far from the Lena Valley. In the beginning of the seventeenth century the Yakut abode on the western banks of the Lena must have been the territory of the two present uluses of Yakutsk District, Namskij and Western Kangalassky. There, according to Yakut traditions, was the first place of refuge of their mythical forefather, the “Tatar” Elliei. From there a part of his nearest descendants could also have emigrated over the Lena islands to the eastern banks of the Lena River, where excellent pastures are as abundant as on the western banks.' [1,191] 'We have previously noted (see p. 64) that the Yakut were subjugated by two different Cossack parties from Mangasey aand Yeniseisk. The Olekminsk fortress on the Lena River was erected in 1630 when only Tungus lived in the region. In 1637 a Cossack party, under the command of Busa, collected tribute in furs from the Yakut of the Yana River.' [1,192] The czarist administration imposed taxes and established an administrative infrastructure: 'The system of tsarist administration was no different here from what existed in any other part of Northern Siberia. The Dolgans, Yakuts and Evenks had to pay the fur-tax as “natives” and formed “clans” headed by princelings, while the tundra peasants were forced to pay a poll tax, were formed into a “community” and headed by an elder. People living many hundreds of kilometers away from the nearest centers were economically dependent on the merchants who monopolized supplies to the region, bought up all the furs, and cruelly exploited the population.' [1,193] 'The committee of Cherkashennikov which worked in the Yakutsk Oblast was only a branch of this All-Siberian commission. On December 14, 1766, an ukaz was issued which called for deputies from all of Russia to form a committee for establishing a better administration, discussing various problems of internal policy, and, incidentally, to establish a new code for the natives of Siberia. The Yakut, who were listed as nomads, were excluded from the list of electors, but they sent their deputy anyway and he was allowed to join the committee by a special order of the Empress.' [1,194] 'The overall development of commodity relationships helped to speed up the development of agriculture and here and there ploughing was enforced by the administration.' [1,195] 'No less significant changes occurred in the administrative organization of the Yakut country. In the seventeenth century Yakutsk was the center of a great independent country directly subordinate to Moscow, although for some specific questions it was dependent on the governors of Tobolsk. In the time of Peter the Great, Yakutsk entered into the newly organized Siberian Goubernyia (government) and with the division of the Siberian government into provinces was included in Irkutsk Province. In 1775 Irkutsk Province was organized into a government and the Yakut country formed one of the provinces of the new government. In 1783 the government was again reorganized into a vice-royalty composed of four provinces, one of which was Yakutsk Province. In 1797 the vice-royalty was abolished and the government restored. In [Page 225] 1805 under the Emperor Alexander I, the Yakut country was made a separate province dependent upon Irkutsk. In 1852 the Yakut country was given a separate governor. After the revolution in February, 1917, a commissar was appointed by the Provisional Government.' [1,196] Sieroszewski reports corruption and exploitation of the Yakut population by administrators: 'The government undertook to regulate the distribution of Yakut land, [Page 764] partly to cease the disorders which arose as a result of this a nd partly to as sure and regulate the taking of yassak, which was being gathered with unbelievable arbitrariness and accompanied by terrible ill use, was stolen, substituted for, and hidden, and they stole from the Great Tsars by putting far too little in the treasury and by undervaluing the yassak greatly, and they impoverished the yassak-paying people and robbed the taxes and injured them.' [1,197] In addition to Russian officials, land-holding toyons also doubled as officials in their districts: 'The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called [...] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [1,198] We have considered furs collected from clan elders as tribute and contributions collected from households as taxation.
♠ Polity receives obligatory payment from other polity or group ♣ absent ♥

Taxation[edit]

♠ Degree of taxation ♣ present ♥ The early invaders imposed tribute in furs on the Sakha population after successful military expeditions: 'By 1620 a report had reached Tobolsk from the Mangaseya Cossacks of the Great (Lena) River and the Lena Yakut. In 1631 they descended by the Viliui River, a tributary of the Lena, to the Lena River and imposed tribute on the adjacent Yakut. In 1632 a party of Cossacks under the command of the Boyar’s son, Shakov, took tribute in sables from a clan of Viliui horse-breeding Yakut. The Viliui River farther up from its mouth was occupied by Tungus only. The northern boundary of the distribution of the Yakut at that time was the mouth of the Viliui. The whole Lena Valley from the mouth of the Viliui River to the south, at a distance of about 500 kilometers (or 710 miles) was occupied by Yakut. In their possession were also all the Lena islands of that region, rich in pasture lands. There is no definite information as to how far inland they penetrated at that period. We may admit, however, that the Yakut, being horse and cattle breeders, were hardly inclined to move into the dense forests far from the majority of their tribesmen, i.e., far from the Lena Valley. In the beginning of the seventeenth century the Yakut abode on the western banks of the Lena must have been the territory of the two present uluses of Yakutsk District, Namskij and Western Kangalassky. There, according to Yakut traditions, was the first place of refuge of their mythical forefather, the “Tatar” Elliei. From there a part of his nearest descendants could also have emigrated over the Lena islands to the eastern banks of the Lena River, where excellent pastures are as abundant as on the western banks.' [1,199] 'We have previously noted (see p. 64) that the Yakut were subjugated by two different Cossack parties from Mangasey aand Yeniseisk. The Olekminsk fortress on the Lena River was erected in 1630 when only Tungus lived in the region. In 1637 a Cossack party, under the command of Busa, collected tribute in furs from the Yakut of the Yana River.' [1,200] The czarist administration imposed taxes and established an administrative infrastructure: 'The system of tsarist administration was no different here from what existed in any other part of Northern Siberia. The Dolgans, Yakuts and Evenks had to pay the fur-tax as “natives” and formed “clans” headed by princelings, while the tundra peasants were forced to pay a poll tax, were formed into a “community” and headed by an elder. People living many hundreds of kilometers away from the nearest centers were economically dependent on the merchants who monopolized supplies to the region, bought up all the furs, and cruelly exploited the population.' [1,201] 'The committee of Cherkashennikov which worked in the Yakutsk Oblast was only a branch of this All-Siberian commission. On December 14, 1766, an ukaz was issued which called for deputies from all of Russia to form a committee for establishing a better administration, discussing various problems of internal policy, and, incidentally, to establish a new code for the natives of Siberia. The Yakut, who were listed as nomads, were excluded from the list of electors, but they sent their deputy anyway and he was allowed to join the committee by a special order of the Empress.' [1,202] 'The overall development of commodity relationships helped to speed up the development of agriculture and here and there ploughing was enforced by the administration.' [1,203] 'No less significant changes occurred in the administrative organization of the Yakut country. In the seventeenth century Yakutsk was the center of a great independent country directly subordinate to Moscow, although for some specific questions it was dependent on the governors of Tobolsk. In the time of Peter the Great, Yakutsk entered into the newly organized Siberian Goubernyia (government) and with the division of the Siberian government into provinces was included in Irkutsk Province. In 1775 Irkutsk Province was organized into a government and the Yakut country formed one of the provinces of the new government. In 1783 the government was again reorganized into a vice-royalty composed of four provinces, one of which was Yakutsk Province. In 1797 the vice-royalty was abolished and the government restored. In [Page 225] 1805 under the Emperor Alexander I, the Yakut country was made a separate province dependent upon Irkutsk. In 1852 the Yakut country was given a separate governor. After the revolution in February, 1917, a commissar was appointed by the Provisional Government.' [1,204] Sieroszewski reports corruption and exploitation of the Sakha population by administrators: 'The government undertook to regulate the distribution of Yakut land, [Page 764] partly to cease the disorders which arose as a result of this a nd partly to as sure and regulate the taking of yassak, which was being gathered with unbelievable arbitrariness and accompanied by terrible ill use, was stolen, substituted for, and hidden, and they stole from the Great Tsars by putting far too little in the treasury and by undervaluing the yassak greatly, and they impoverished the yassak-paying people and robbed the taxes and injured them.' [1,205] In addition to Russian officials, land-holding toyons also doubled as officials in their districts: 'The population was also divided into three or four classes: the toyon households belonged to the first class, and received a first-class plot, the middle households were usually assigned to the second class and the poorer people to the third and fourth classes, each receiving the corresponding clan plot. Thus, the system itself gave the toyons plots of land which were three or four times larger than those of the poorer people. It is true that in return for this the toyons had somewhat greater obligations, but the difference in their extent was extremely small. However, this inequality was by no means the only thing. The toyons actually possessed much more land, having seized it in a variety of different ways. For example, they had several plots, rather than just one, by registering them in the names of their children, workers and so on. It was also the custom to give officials (who were more often than not themselves toyons) additional plots of land, so-called [...] (from the Russian word “ukaz” [edict]), for which, incidentally, there was no payment. The influential toyons also obtained extra plots called ugayy (or kharyy). Furthermore, the toyons frequently enjoyed the right of possessing larger plots, sometimes through inheritance, cleared from the forest or formed at the site of a drained lake. The leasing of land was also common.' [1,206] We have considered furs collected from clan elders as tribute and contributions collected from households as taxation.

Taxes are imposed on:

♠ Land ♣ absent ♥
♠ Property ♣ absent ♥
♠ People ♣ present ♥ Taxes were collected in furs (see above).
♠ Trade ♣ absent ♥
♠ Income ♣ absent ♥
♠ Production ♣ absent ♥

Taxes are imposed by:

♠ executive or ruling elite ♣ present ♥ Taxes were imposed and collected by Russian authorities, local administrators and local elites (see above).
♠ local elites ♣ present ♥
♠ state officials ♣ present ♥

Type of taxes paid:

♠ Staple ♣ absent ♥ Taxes were collected in the form of furs, not food, labour or currency.
♠ Labor ♣ absent ♥
♠ Currency ♣ absent ♥

Wages and Costs[edit]

♠ Wages ♣ ♥ Note: Pastoralism has a long history in the region: 'In prehistoric times, beginning with the northern retreat of the glaciers, many southern peoples who had to adjust themselves to the severe conditions of life in the northern forests or the polar tundra, occupied Siberia. Some of the newcomers, like the Tungus, lost many of their former culture traits, and became reindeer breeders or hunters, while others, like the Yakut, were able in the far north to retain their cattle-breeding culture of the Central Asiatic steppes. But this northward [Page 61] migration was involuntary; the southerners were forced out from their former habitat by the competition of alien tribes. Naturally, in the course of their wandering, they left some traces which have been disclosed by the work of archaeologists. Skeletal finds also have shown that northern Siberia was primarily inhabited by a long-headed people of the Nordic type who had come from the west, and who were assimilated or else annihilated by Mongoloid newcomers from the south. Many of these questions still await solution through the work of archaeologists.' [1,207] 'We have some knowledge of prehistoric Yakut monuments through the recent work of Russian archaeologists, chiefly Petri, whose excavations in the region of Lake Baikal revealed many remains of a horse and cattle breeding tribe, in all probability, the prehistoric Yakut.' [1,208] 'The identifications by the chief zoologist of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Bialanitski-Birula, of animal bones found at the Murino sites and the caves of Orkhon show that these are chiefly the remains of domesticated animals-of oxen, rams, goats, and horses. Remains of wild animals, the products of hunting, are very scarce, proving that the people were cattle breeders. Besides, no traces of agriculture were found to the north of Lake Baikal, presenting negative evidence that the prehistoric inhabitants were herders. Further, Bialanitski-Birula pointed out that the ox of these people, like that of the Yakut, was a cross-breed of the yak. Among the iron arrows were found many with bifurcated heads, a characteristic of Yakut arrows. The iron knives and scissors found have the same distinguishing marks as Yakut knives, as will be shown in the discussion of their iron industry. The horseshoe found in the excavations is exactly like the Yakut horseshoe; it is narrow, with holes for nails and one calk in the middle. The Siberian natives, even in stony mountainous places, seldom shoe their horses. The iron bits of an ancient bridle consisted of two unequal parts, without appendages in the corners. This may be explained by the manner in which the rider held the reins on the left side of the horse as do the present Yakut. Modern Yakut bits consist of two equal parts, a form which may be regarded as having been adopted from the Russians, from whom the Yakut learned to harness horses to sledges and carts, for which long reins are necessary. Formerly, the Yakut used the horse only as a riding and pack animal. Appurtenances of horse harness show that the people bred horses. An iron sickle for hay making was found by Petri. It is quite different from the Russian form and resembles the present Yakut sickle. [Page 62] An iron hook for digging edible roots and plants and iron fish hooks were also found.' [1,209] 'It is indubitable that the training of the deer was at one time the occupation of the natives throughout the country. Even in those areas of the Yakut region where there are no deer at present, deer bones are found in the ground intermingled with human ones and with metallic items of deer harness. Many localities have preserved legends about the one-time existence of the domestic deer among the inhabitants. I can point, as an example, to the valley of the Borgonski settlement, which until the coming of the Yakuts was the scene of nomadic travels of the Tungus Miore with his numerous herds; also--to the valley of the Suntarski lake, which supposedly derived its name from the Tungus Suntar. The Tungus did not know any other cattle, except the deer...The deer are the Tungus cattle! unanimously assert the legends. They also assert, that the Yakuts imitated the Tungus in their use of the deer.' [1,210] 'The capacity to bear bad weather, cold, and hunger, to eat little and literally everything and anything that grows, to be satisfied with little in time of need, and afterwards to fatten up on the good feed and to live on the reserves of the fat and the meat stored up--this capacity is remarkably developed in the [Page 313] Yakut cattle. A great deal of energy is thus spent to survive. From the point of view of productivity this capacity for survival has no significance except, perhaps, a negative one. On the other hand this quality of survival makes the Yakut cattle invaluable in pioneering. Only because of it were the Yakuts able to penetrate with their cattle so far to the north. At present the Yakuts are the northernmost cattle breeders not only in Asia, but on the whole globe. Their northernmost cattle breeding sett lements known to me are on the Amoloi river at 70° N.L. and the northernmost one visited by me (in 1882) was on The Yana River at 69° where the Kungyas River enters it. On the Kolyma, the Alazei, and the Indigirka, the breeding of horned cattle does not, at present, reach such proportions, and stops about two degrees 152 south of the above mentioned point. In ancient times, cattle breeding reached the Arctic but was practised--of course--only in the river valleys. Fossils of horned cattle are found in Ustyansk, and legends about it are preserved in Nizhne-Kolymsk and on the Allaikha (the lower course of the Indigir-' [1,211] 'All those who have tried to connect the horses of the Yakut with those of southern or western Siberia in external appearance have most often pointed to the breed of horses of the Kirghiz. So far there have been no scientific investigations based on any numerous and exact measurements. The only data worthy of attention on this subject are those found in Cherskii. On the basis of a study of the skull of a contemporary Yakut horse, brought by Doctor Bunge from the Adycha River (Berkhoyansk Okrug), Cherskii was able to establish a distinct type of Yakut horse, differing from other Siberian horses and coming closest to the tarpans of southern Russia and the western Siberian subfossilis horse. I. Cherskii classifies the Yakut horse in the eastern group, with the breed of dwarfs (the length of the skull at the base is 472 millimeters) and with medium browed horses (the width of the forehead is 235.2 millimeters). The post-tertiary fossil horse whose remains are found in great number at the Yakutsk Oblast, bears a certain relation, in the shape of the skull and of the bones, to present Siberian breeds and, by the way, to the Yakut horse. This is the opinion of the same Doctor Cherskii. This relationship expresses itself in the moderate width of the forehead, the inclined position of the bones above the eyebrows, the narrow width of the offshoots of the bones in the forehead to the skull, the concavity of the profile, and the singular dental systemThe size of the fossil [Page 343] Yakut horses makes one class them with the tall breeds (around Lake Lyakhov) and the very tall breeks (Yana River).' [1,212] 'The finding of the fully preserved corpse of a white horse in the frozen soil of the lower Yana, as reported by Bunge , strengthens this interest, as it seems to indicate the possibility of coming to a definitive solution of this problem. The answer to both these questions is directly bound with the time of the northern migration of the Yakut and with the location of their original homeland. Here I will only note that white is still the predominant color among Yakut horses, and that [Page 344] the interbreeding of domestic with wild animals is considered by them to be advantageous for the improvement of the breed. Such interbreeding in the case of domesticated deer, as I mentioned above, is practiced even now by the Yakut and Tungus of the far north.' [1,213] 'We must analyze some discrepancies in the account of the finds representing supposedly old Yakut culture. The excavations were made in old earth huts and caves. Thus this horse and cattle-breeding tribe must have been nomadic, yet, at the same time, must have had permanent dwellings. This may be explained by their double occupation. Iron [Page 63] mining, smelting, forging, and smithing required a sedentary life. While some families of a clan, or even some members of a family, were engaged in the iron industry, their relatives nomadized with their herds. Caves may have served as temporary shelters during the winter when the wet walls became frozen and a fire was used as protection from the cold.' [1,214] The Sakha were initially nomadic pastoralists: 'Traditional pastoralism in central Yakutia required homestead self-reliance, with intense dependence on calves and foals in a harsh climate. Stables, corrals, and haying developed in conjunction with hardy breeds of cattle and short, fat, furry horses. Richer families owned hundreds of horses and cattle; poorer ones raised a few cattle or herded for others. A huge variety of dairy products, including fermented mare's milk, (Russian: KUMYS), was the staple food, with meat for special occasions. The diet was augmented by hunting (bears, elk, squirrels, hare, ferrets, fowl), fishing (salmon, carp, MUSKSUN, MUNDU), and, under Russian influence, agriculture (cereals). Wealthy Yakut hunted on horseback using dogs. The poorest Yakut, those without cattle, relied on fishing with horsehair nets and, in the north, herded reindeer like their Evenk and Yukagir neighbors.' [1,215] Most implements were made in the home: 'Before iron was imported, ironworkers used ore from local marshes. Similarly, ceramics from local clay preceded Russian pottery. Most homemade crafts were for household use: decorated birch-bark containers, leather bags, dairy-processing equipment, horsehair blankets, fur clothing, benches, hitching posts, and elaborately carved wooden containers (including CHORONS for KUMYS).' [1,216] 'Although occupations within a household were divided by gender and status, the atmosphere was usually one of productive group activity. All participated in hay making, cattle herding, and milking, but, in general, horses were more a male preserve and cattle a female responsibility. Women tended children and fires, prepared food, carried water, and made clothing and pottery. Men handled more strenuous firewood preparation, house building, sled making, hunting, fishing, and mowing. Ivory carving and wood- and metalworking were male tasks.' [1,217] Sieroszewski reports some trades, such as carpentry and blacksmithing, for the south: 'In the north, where most of the household utensils are mad at home, all are prepared with the aid of only these clumsy implements. In the south, where trades are kept separate to a greater degree, a carpenter owns, besides these, a wide and a narrow saw, planes, a brace and bit, chisels, and sometimes even a rasp. But everywhere the axe is most important. The Yakut handle the axe in a masterly fashion and are excellent carpenters. The majority of the churches in the Yakutsk Okrug and almost all the house s in the town of Yakutsk have been built by Yakut carpenters. In their carpentry work they use the same methods, the same compass for cutting, the same pitch rope, plumb, triangle, and ruler as do the Russians. The head of the carpenters artel, the elder carpenter, is called the regulator, after the Russian fashion. But their chief instruments, the axes and knives, have retained their ancient shape.They weigh from two to no more than four pounds, and cost from fifty kopecks to one ruble. The Yakut cut with them smoothly, cleanly, and quickly; they are ready to fashion even small pieces with an axe.' [1,218] 'As with other Siberian peoples, Yakut shamans (OIUN if male, UDAGAN if female) combine medical and spiritual practice. [...] In the nineteenth century a few Yakut leaders financed the building of Russian Orthodox churches, and many Yakut declared themselves Christian, but this did not mean that they saw Christianity and shamanism as mutually exclusive. The Yakut also believed in the spiritual power of blacksmiths.' [1,219] But most Sakha continued to rely on household-level subsistence production after the introduction of cereal agriculture: 'In pre-Revolutionary Yakutiya the poor and middle peasant families totaled more than 80 percent of all households. One-seventh of all the households were entirely without sowings, and many were only able to sow a few hundredths of a hectare each. Most of the households (97 percent) had to do without factory-made agricultural implements. Stockbreeding produced extremely poor results. The owners of large areas of land and abundant livestock i.e.,-the kulaks and toyons, grew rich, but not so much by raising the level of land cultivation and animal husbandry as by exploiting the poor and middle peasants.' [1,220] Temporary wage labour was slightly more common in areas close to Russian settlements: 'The Yakut are unwilling to hire themselves out on a daily basis, although the daily rate of pay is always higher than the monthly or yearly rates. Among themselves they hardly ever do this. This has begun to come into custom only in the vicinity of cities, and only very lately. The Skoptsy were particularly responsible for spreading this custom. The Skopsty usually pay their workers in flours, baked bread, potatoes, brick tea, and sugar; only rarely in money and in cotton goods.' [1,221] Some of the below variables may not be applicable to the Sakha.

♠ staple cost of principal source of carbohydrates ♣ ♥

♠ Top fortune ♣ ♥ Wealth was unevenly distributed among the Sakha (see property and social class variables). However, we are unsure about precise measures of wealth stratification (as in how many more livestock were owned by wealthy households than poor households etc).

♠ Other wealth distribution ♣ ♥ Wealth was unevenly distributed among the Sakha (see property and social class variables). However, we are unsure about precise measures of wealth stratification (as in how many more livestock were owned by wealthy households than poor households etc).
